title: A Photovoltaic Power Prediction Method Based on Improved Transformer and Continual Learning
authors: Kecheng Geng, Bihui Lv, Fang Liu, Wei Chen, Chaoran Zheng
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Due to the high randomness, volatility, and intermittency of photovoltaic power generation, accurate prediction of photovoltaic power output is quite challenging, which severely affects energy utilization efficiency and the economic benefits of power plants. Existing photovoltaic power prediction methods have problems such as insufficient capture of time-series dependencies, poor model generalization ability, and vulnerability to seasonal changes. To address these issues, this paper proposes a photovoltaic power prediction method based on an improved Transformer and continual learning. This method innovatively addresses the catastrophic forgetting problem caused by seasonal changes in meteorological features. It establishes multi-scale correlations between meteorological factors and power generation via a hybrid convolutionTransformer architecture. Additionally, it constructs a dynamic knowledge distillation framework and incorporates a memory replay mechanism to effectively mitigate the interference from seasonal meteorological trend changes. Comparative experimental results show that this method performs prominently in error control and data fitting, with overall prediction performance superior to compared algorithms, enabling more accurate prediction of photovoltaic power generation.

title: Interprocedural Call Graph Embedding with GAT for Memory safety Vulnerability Detection
authors: Rong Ren, JingYi Wu, HongBo Jin, QingYu Song, Bing Zhang, Qian Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Memory safety vulnerabilities remain a critical threat to software security, often leading to system crashes, data leakage, and service disruptions. Existing deep learning-based detection methods mainly rely on intra-procedural analysis, which limits their ability to capture complex memory behaviors involving pointer variable flows across function boundaries. This study proposes IpGAT, an InterProcedural memory vulnerability detection framework based on Graph Attention Network (GAT) that aims to overcome the limitations of intra-procedural approaches by modeling cross-function data flows of pointer variables. IpGAT constructs an Interprocedural Program Call Graph (IpCG) that integrates Abstract Syntax Trees (AST), Control Flow Graphs (CFG), and Data Flow Graphs (DFG) to represent memory-sensitive function interactions. The IpCG is embedded using Word2Vec and then fed into a GAT for vulnerability classification. Experimental results show that IpGAT achieves an accuracy of 88.9%, a precision of 86.5%, and an F1-score of 89.1%, significantly outperforming six state-of-the-art tools and intra-procedural baselines. Furthermore, IpGAT successfully identified eight real-world memory safety vulnerabilities in open-source projects such as ffdshow, Libav, Seamonkey, and VLC, all of which have been confirmed in the CVE database. By incorporating interprocedural analysis and graph-based learning, IpGAT effectively captures the semantics of memory-sensitive operations and demonstrates strong generalizability across both benchmark datasets and real-world software.

title: Perceived Risks and Algorithmic Control: A Study of Ride-Hailing Platform Workers in Indonesia
authors: E. H. Prasetyo, P. F. Belgiawan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: This research investigates the ethical implications of algorithmic management (AM) on workers of ride-hailing platforms, with a focus on two-wheeled taxi riders (ojek) in Indonesia. The algorithmic control built into mobile applications automatically evaluates workers' performance under precarious working conditions. This study examines the intersection between technology adoption and social issues by asking: How do platform workers perceive algorithmic control, considering the risks they may encounter? Built on the literature on perceived risks, this study employed a qualitative approach, conducting focus group discussions and interviews. The results of this study identified the risks encountered by riders and elucidated the mechanisms by which algorithms control workers. Overall, this study contributes to the literature on algorithmic management by focusing on its dual function: as a tool for risk reduction and surveillance among its riders.

title: Computer Vision-based Handwritten Text-area Detection for Industrial Document Digitization
authors: J. Hong, S. Yu, J. Kim, J. Park, S. Moon
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: This study addresses the need for technologies that digitize handwritten documents commonly produced in industrial sites. As a core component of this process, we propose a method to detect text-areas in table-based handwritten documents. Traditional OCR techniques have difficulty recognizing text that crosses table boundaries or is irregularly arranged. To overcome this limitation, we present a computer vision-based approach that accurately detects text-areas within structured tables. Our framework integrates a Faster R-CNN-based object detector with the RLSA algorithm to perform table detection and text-area recognition in sequence. In our experiments using 124 annotated text-areas, the proposed method achieved an F1 Score of 0.93 for online text and 0.67 for offline text. This technique not only improves OCR performance but also lays the groundwork for ontology-based document analysis, contributing to the broader goal of document digitization.

title: Evaluating Machine Learning Approaches for Predicting Impact Strength of Areca Fibre–Epoxy/SiC Polymer Composites
authors: R Vasanth, R. Aravind Kumar, Dhivakaran S, S. Binson, B. Karthik, Lavanya M
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: This study employs machine learning techniques to predict the impact strength of areca fiber epoxy composites supplemented with SiC filler. Experimental assessments were conducted to determine the actual impact strength values, which were then compared to predictions from the Decision Tree, Random Forest, and XGBoost models. The methodology used feature extraction and regression analysis to improve prediction accuracy. We evaluated performance using metrics such as MAE, MSE, R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, precision, recall, F1-score, and accuracy. The results showed that ensemble models, particularly Random Forest and XGBoost, outperformed the Decision Tree model in terms of predicted accuracy (0.83) and alignment with experimental data. The results demonstrate that advanced machine learning techniques provide dependable and widely applicable approaches for predicting the mechanical properties of fibre-reinforced polymer composites, reducing the need for extensive experimentation while ensuring accurate assessment of material behavior. This contributes to Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure by fostering technologically advanced evaluation methods and supports Responsible Consumption and Production through optimized resource usage and more efficient research practices.

title: Toward Sustainable AI: A Scoping Review of Carbon Footprint and Environmental Impacts Across Training and Inference Stages
authors: Min-Kyu Kim, Tae-An Yoo, Ji-Bum Chung
abstract: AI is spreading rapidly, creating significant social and economic value while also raising concerns about its high energy use and environmental sustainability. While prior studies have predominantly focused on the energy-intensive nature of the training phase, the cumulative environmental footprint generated during large-scale service operations, particularly in the inference phase, has received comparatively less attention and remains difficult to compare across studies due to inconsistent boundaries and disclosure practices. To bridge this gap, this study conducts a scoping review of methodologies and evidence on AI carbon footprint assessment. We analyze the classification and standardization status of existing AI carbon measurement tools and methodologies, and comparatively examine the environmental impacts arising from both training and inference stages, and synthesize inference evaluation into a benchmark-oriented framework. In addition, we identify how multidimensional factors such as model size, prompt complexity, serving environments, and system boundary definitions shape the resulting carbon footprint. Our review reveals critical limitations in current AI carbon accounting practices, including methodological inconsistencies, technology-specific biases, and insufficient attention to end-to-end system perspectives. Building on these insights, we propose future research and governance directions: (1) establishing standardized and transparent universal measurement protocols with clear boundary, functional-unit, and disclosure requirements, (2) designing dynamic evaluation frameworks that incorporate user behavior and service-level operating conditions, (3) developing life-cycle monitoring systems that encompass embodied emissions, and (4) advancing multidimensional sustainability assessment framework that balance model performance with environmental efficiency. This paper provides a foundation for interdisciplinary dialogue aimed at building a sustainable AI ecosystem and offers a baseline guideline for researchers and policymakers seeking to evaluate AI environmental impacts across technical, social, and operational dimensions.

title: TLSA: Transfer Learning Enhanced Link Stealing Attacks on Graph Neural Networks
authors: Zhenkun Jin, Jiaqi Ma, Yuanyuan He, Wei Xiang, Qiankun Zhang, Tao Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) are inherently vulnerable to link stealing attacks, as their structural aggregation mechanisms may inadvertently leak training graph data. Existing link stealing methods primarily rely on posterior similarity for inference but suffer from critical limitations: inherent semantic bias (e.g., misclassifying semantically similar but unconnected nodes) and insufficient structural information, which constrain attack performance. To address these issues, we propose TLSA (Transfer Learning-based Link Stealing Attack), a novel framework that captures generalized structural knowledge from multi-domain heterogeneous graphs based on cross-domain knowledge transfer, and merges it with posterior similarity to enhance attack performance. The cross-domain knowledge transfer is enabled by integrating partially leaked target subgraphs with shadow graphs. Specifically, TLSA designs a triple-level alignment mechanism, including node feature reconstruction, which unifies heterogeneous posterior dimensions across domains; trainable hub nodes with gradient-driven topological optimization, forming bidirectional learning loops that bridge target and shadow domains; and domain adversarial training, which minimizes graph distribution distance and ensures deep semantic consistency across domains. Since its extracted structure-aware features are fused with node-pair semantic similarity, TLSA generates enhanced attack features for accurate edge existence prediction, significantly improving link stealing performance. Extensive experiments on diverse graph datasets validate the effectiveness of TLSA.

title: CatPoison: Category-Oriented Knowledge Poisoning Attacks in Retrieval-Augmented Generation Systems
authors: Haitao Mei, Zhangzhuo Du, Chao Cai, Chi Cheng, Jian Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Data poisoning attacks, which maliciously manipulate the knowledge corpus to influence model behavior, have emerged as a significant threat to the security of Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) systems. Existing data poisoning attacks in RAG predominantly operate at the instance level, targeting individual queries, which fall short in real-world scenarios where attackers often seek broader influence. In this paper, we introduce a more general and impactful attack paradigm, in which all queries belonging to a target category are forced into generating attacker-desired outputs, while maintaining accurate responses for unrelated queries. To this end, we propose CatPoison, the first category-oriented knowledge poisoning attack against RAG. We formulate CatPoison as an optimization problem aimed at generating a set of generalized poisoned texts crafted by a black-box attacker. Extensive experiments across standard RAG benchmarks demonstrate that CatPoison achieves substantially higher attack success rates compared to prior poisoning baselines. Our findings expose a previously overlooked vulnerability in semantic-level retrieval and highlight the urgent need for defenses tailored to category-oriented knowledge corruption.

title: Research on Sensitivity Analysis Methods for DC Bias Risk in Large-Scale Power Grids
authors: Yingying Zhang, Xiaotong Gou, Zhuohong Pan, Lin Geng, Bichuan Xu, Xin Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: The sensitivity of DC bias risk is closely related to the parameters of large power grids. To improve the accuracy of the simulation model for bias risk assessment, this paper proposes a sensitivity analysis method for DC bias risk in large power grids. By solving the sensitivities of two key bias risk indicators, the degree of bias risk and its influencing factors have been analyzed from a theoretical perspective. Finally, a case study has been conducted to apply the proposed method. Taking the sensitivity of total DC intrusion amount as the indicator, the degree of DC bias risk has been analyzed, and specific risk management schemes has been discussed.

title: Simulation and Analysis of a Boiler Main Steam Temperature Control System Based on Improved Smith- Fractional-Order PID
authors: Jiaxin Yang, Zhengang Wan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Conventional PID and fuzzy PID controllers, the predominant methods for main steam temperature control in thermal power plant boilers, often exhibit unsatisfactory performance in practical applications, characterized by poor step response and inadequate disturbance rejection. This paper proposes a novel control strategy utilizing a Fractional-Order PID (FOPID) controller combined with a Smith predictor. The system was modeled and subjected to one-dimensional simulation in Simulink. The core innovation lies in the synergistic integration of the FOPID controller, which enhances adaptability to complex dynamics through non-integer-order calculus for refined regulation, and the Smith predictor, which effectively compensates for inherent time-delay effects, thereby improving stability, response speed, and disturbance rejection. Simulation results confirm the superior control characteristics of the proposed system. Experimental validation demonstrates a marked reduction in overshoot and significant improvements in both response speed and control accuracy compared to conventional methods.

title: SafeMLLM: Extending Safety Alignment from Single-Modal LLMs to Multimodal LLMs
authors: Di Jiang, Xiaojie Zhu, Chi Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Multimodal large language models (MLLMs) are capable of processing diverse multimodal inputs to generate informative and contextually relevant responses. In this paper, alignment involves safeguarding the model against producing harmful or inappropriate content and ensuring its outputs are aligned with ethical guidelines. Existing alignment works have primarily focused on making the outputs of large language models(LLMs) harmless. However, the integration of multimodal information into MLLM inputs can lead to unintended or undesirable responses, thereby undermining the original alignment mechanisms of LLMs. When image, audio, or video information is contained in queries, MLLMs cannot guarantee the safe alignment of responses. In this study, we first collect VAdvBench to demonstrate that the additional multimodal inputs can easily break the safeguards of LLMs in MLLMs, highlighting the security vulnerabilities in these MLLMs. To address this issue, we propose SafeMLLM, a safety alignment framework designed for MLLMs. SafeMLLM aligns multimodal content by transforming multimodal inputs into a unified space, enabling MLLM to effectively block multimodal harmful information. In addition, since the current multimodal safety alignment works only consider images as additional modality inputs and lack benchmarks for other modalities like audio and video, we propose a pipeline to collect and synthesize a multimodal safety alignment benchmark, MLGuard, to evaluate the safety alignment performance on multimodal queries. The experiment results on MLGuard demonstrate that our SafeMLLM effectively rejects harmful instructions containing multimodal queries of image, audio, and video, ensuring robust safety alignment across diverse multimodal inputs. The code is available at https://github.com/jiangdi841/SafeMLLM/tree/main.

title: Log2Sig: Frequency-Aware Insider Threat Detection via Multivariate Behavioral Signal Decomposition
authors: Kaichuan Kong, Dongjie Liu, Xiaobo Jin, Zhiying Li, Guanggang Geng
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Insider threat detection presents a significant challenge due to the deceptive nature of malicious behaviors, which often resemble legitimate user operations. However, existing approaches typically model system logs as flat event sequences, thereby failing to capture the inherent frequency dynamics and multiscale disturbance patterns embedded in user behavior. To address these limitations, we propose Log2Sig, a robust anomaly detection framework that transforms user logs into multivariate behavioral frequency signals, introducing a novel representation of user behavior. Log2Sig employs Multivariate Variational Mode Decomposition (MVMD) to extract IMFs, which reveal behavioral fluctuations across multiple temporal scales. Based on this, the model further performs joint modeling of behavioral sequences and frequency-decomposed signals: the daily behavior sequences are encoded using a Mamba-Based temporal encoder to capture long-term dependencies, while the corresponding frequency components are linearly projected to match the encoder’s output dimension. These dual-view representations are then fused to construct a comprehensive user behavior profile, which is fed into a multilayer perceptron for precise anomaly detection. Experimental results on the CERT r4.2 and r5.2 datasets demonstrate that Log2Sig significantly outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in both accuracy and F1 score.

title: Scalable Private k-Nearest Neighbors Search Based on Secret Sharing
authors: Peizhao Zhou, Lihai Nie, Zheli Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: k-nearest neighbors search (kNN) is a fundamental algorithm widely used in signal and image processing, recommendation systems, and pattern recognition. Due to the sensitivity of data privacy and laws, directly disclosing raw data for kNN search between entities is often unacceptable in many cases. In this paper, we propose a kNN search scheme based on secret sharing techniques. Our scheme preserves the privacy of both the data owner’s datasets and the user’s queries, except that the user learns the query results. We introduce a communication-efficient secure top-k protocol and construct two secure kNN search protocols: a protocol that searches kNN results exactly, and a more efficient approximate protocol that leverages clustering-based preprocessing. For the clustering-based protocol, we also design an efficient cluster retrieval approach and a compact kNN search phase. Experiments on three large real-world datasets containing 1M/10M samples with 96/128 dimensions demonstrate that the proposed kNN search protocols achieve a speedup of 2.77× to 10.67× compared to the state-of-the-art scheme.

title: FlexiGrain: A Flexible and Fine-Grained Privacy Control Framework for Dynamic Social Networks
authors: Ben Niu, Fanyu Gan, Jinyu Peng, Qian Yang, Jin Cao
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Balancing information sharing with privacy preserving is a fundamental challenge for users in social networks, where the generation of effective privacy control strategies is a critical control mechanism. Existing efforts are typically coarse-grained (e.g., globally uniform) and static to adapt to dynamic scenarios, thus failing to achieve a precise privacy-utility trade-off. In this paper, we propose a FlexiGrain framework, jointly utilizing information diffusion prediction and multi-objective optimization to generate fine-grained privacy control strategies. In this framework, we design a DHGCNUI model, which integrates intimacy and propagation behavior features to produce a highly accurate user activation probability matrix; then we propose a privacy control strategy generation algorithm, named PDO-NSGA-II, which performs multi-objective optimization to simultaneously maximize information utility and minimize privacy risk. Extensive experiments are conducted on two public datasets, and the results demonstrate the FlexiGrain framework outperforms the state-of-the-art methods in terms of effectiveness and flexibility.

title: Challenges to GenAI Adoption in E-Waste Management
authors: Towfique Rahman, Md. Abdul Moktadir, Sanjoy Kumar Paul, Syed Mithun Ali
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: The transition in electronic supply chains is critical to mitigating the environmental impacts of rapidly growing e-waste. Generative artificial intelligence (GenAI) technologies offer promising capabilities to enable e-waste management practices through intelligent data integration, stakeholder coordination, and real-time decision-making. However, the adoption of these technologies faces several challenges. This study identifies and examines ten key challenges to GenAI adoption in e-waste management using expert inputs and a literature review. To analyze the complex interdependencies among these challenges, we employ an advanced Interval-Valued Fermatean Fuzzy Set (IVFFS) Decision Making Trial and Evaluation Laboratory (DEMATEL) model, enhanced by Dombi t-norm and t-conorm operations. The results reveal five causal challenges-led by fragmented product lifecycle data and poor data quality-that significantly influence the remaining effect group challenges, such as limited reverse logistics and regulatory misalignment. Addressing these foundational issues can facilitate the scalable and effective adoption of GenAI. The findings offer strategic insights for policymakers, industry leaders, and researchers aiming to build sustainable, intelligent, and adaptive e-waste supply chains through AI innovation.

title: Power Quality Enhancement Strategy Using Dynamic Adaptive SVPWM Control and SVG Reactive Power Compensation
authors: Xiwei Fu, Yubin Fu, Jun Li, Zewei Zhan, Sijia Hu, Xiaoqiang Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: With the continuous development of power systems, non-pure resistive loads are increasingly being integrated into power systems, impacting power quality and transmission efficiency. Therefore, this paper proposes a power quality improvement strategy based on dynamic adaptive SVPWM control and SVG reactive power compensation. A reactive current detection method is established based on instantaneous reactive power theory, and a dual closed-loop current and voltage reactive power compensation model for SVG is developed, with its working principle analyzed. Furthermore, a dynamic adaptive SVPWM control method is proposed, which adjusts switching frequency and pulse position dynamically to optimize the current waveform. Finally, simulations are conducted to compare scenarios with and without the compensation device under different loads. The results demonstrate that the proposed strategy can enhance the power factor and effectively improve power quality.

title: A Resonant-Switching Capacitor for Impedance Matching in RF Plasma Systems
authors: Jiahao Qi, Haiping Ren
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: A resonant variable capacitance matching mechanism for $\mathbf{1 3. 5 6 ~ M H z ~ R F}$ plasma power systems is proposed in this paper. A novel resonant switching topology is formed by employing semiconductor switching devices and a control capacitor array in the proposed solution. This circuit topology enables the rapid switching of the target capacitance via digital signals, which serves as a replacement for mechanical adjustment methods. Simulation results are demonstrated that this topology achieves impedance matching within extremely short timeframes, offering a novel reference for implementing impedance matching networks in high-power RF plasma systems.

title: On the Use of Indigenous Games in Teaching Software Engineering and Artificial Intelligence
authors: Aaron Hunter
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Concepts in Software Engineering and Artificial Intelligence are often taught by using games as motivation. The structured nature of a game makes it easier to understand the decisions that an agent must make, and it gives us a platform for defining suitable algorithms. In this paper, we point out that this well-known approach can be effectively used in the classroom to support diversity and inclusion. We present two lesson plans for teaching programming concepts using traditional Indigenous games for motivation. These lessons are just as effective as they would be using games from some other cultural context. However, using Indigenous games has several advantages. First, the use of these games can create a more inclusive classroom environment, where we are pushing away from a model where cultural artefacts from the colonial culture implicitly have primacy. Moreover, drawing games from a variety of cultural contexts helps to reduce any bias towards students from any particular cultural tradition. Finally, using these games provides an opportunity to add a little bit of indigenous history and culture into the classroom in a natural way.

title: MBCGAN-SGFM: Detecting Rare and Unknown Attacks via Generative Augmentation and Semantic Memory
authors: Yunhao Wang, Yong Wang, Lin Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: As industrial control systems converge with networked infrastructures, both enterprise and IIoT environments are increasingly exposed to evolving cyber threats. However, existing IDS models struggle with imbalanced data distributions, weak generalization to unknown attacks, and limited ability to capture discriminative temporal-semantic patterns from scarce labeled data. To address these challenges holistically, we propose the Multi-Branch Convolutional Generative Aggregation Network with Semantic-Guided Fusion Memory (MBCGAN-SGFM), a unified two-stage framework that integrates generative minority-class augmentation and semantically guided detection. In the first stage, the Multi-Branch Convolutional Generative Aggregation Network (MBCGAN) employs parallel convolutional branches and residual feature aggregation to synthesize class-consistent minority samples, thereby enriching the training distribution while preserving intrinsic semantic structure. In the second stage, we propose a Semantic-Guided Fusion Memory (SGFM) module that integrates temporal and contextual features through semantic-aware fusion, with a memory refinement mechanism that adaptively updates latent representations to capture evolving traffic patterns. Class-Level semantic prototypes, learned via contrastive objectives, are embedded as structural guidance signals within both the fusion and memory update processes, enabling semantic feedback to modulate feature integration over time. Extensive evaluations on the CICIDS2017 and ML-EdgeIIoT datasets show that MBCGAN-SGFM achieves superior performance compared to state-of-the-art baselines, especially in detecting minority and previously unseen threats under few-shot and zero-shot conditions.

title: PrivANN: Practical and Efficient Private Approximate Nearest Neighbor Search
authors: Xuan Chen, Shujie Cui, Joseph K. Liu, Shi-Feng Sun, Shangqi Lai
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: As applications increasingly rely on vector search to find semantically similar content in large-scale databases, preserving user query privacy is of paramount importance. Existing solutions based on advanced cryptography, such as Fully Homomorphic Encryption (FHE) or Private Information Retrieval (PIR), often incur prohibitive computational or communication overheads, limiting their practical deployment. This paper introduces PrivANN, a fully oblivious system for private approximate nearest neighbor (ANN) search that leverages Trusted Execution Environments (TEEs). PrivANN employs a read-optimized Oblivious RAM (ORAM) protocol to defend against side-channel leakage, introduces a novel shuffling mechanism that decouples costly offline preparation from fast online operations and incorporates a novel oblivious Top-k selection algorithm. We formally prove PrivANN’s security guarantees and demonstrate its real-world performance. Our evaluation shows that PrivANN improves throughput by 2.4x over state-of-the-art FHE-based systems while achieving superior search quality, and reduces client-side communication overhead from gigabytes to kilobytes compared to PIR-based approach.

title: LLM-Generated Description and Reasoning: Use-case for Library Recommendations
authors: Arash Sal Moslehian, Eya Briki, Michalis Vlachos
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries (JCDL)
abstract: Recent advances in recommender systems have begun to explore how large language models can enhance user and item representations through natural language. However, the effectiveness of using LLM-generated descriptions and internal reasoning directly within collaborative filtering models remains underexplored. In this work, we evaluate various content-based embeddings, either by directly encoding metadata or by constructing richer user and item profiles using LLMs with internal reasoning. These embeddings are integrated into standard collaborative filtering models without modifying their architectures. Using a real-world library dataset enriched through external book databases, we show that on average, content-based embeddings improve recommendation performance by $40 \%$ in recall and NDCG over baseline models, and LLM-generated profiles further improve performance and provide compact, interpretable representations. Our findings suggest that LLMgenerated profiles and reasoning not only enhance explainability, but also improve recommendation quality in sparse, real-world environments.

title: Modelling Air Quality Category in Regional Victoria as a Discrete-Time Markov Chain
authors: Simon Anthony Lorenzo, Lizabeth Ann Franco
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Air quality affects our health and quality of life. While emphasis has been given to monitoring and communicating air quality to communities, few studies have been conducted to characterize its behavior. This study looks into the air quality of Ballarat in the Australian state of Victoria and characterizes its temporal evolution. Statistical tests show that the air quality can be characterized as a Discrete-Time Markov Chain, and metrics such as the likelihood of state transitions, its steady state probabilities, and mean time before transition were computed. Prediction accuracy was 77.1%, 72.20%, 69.39% for 3 hours, 1 day, and 1 week, respectively. The study extends the current descriptive functionalities of recording and monitoring to prescriptive functionalities that would provide more benefits to the community of Ballarat.

title: A Method for Enhancing Knowledge Retrieval in Typical Power Scenarios Based on BFS Algorithm
authors: Bowen Shao, Yanli Yao, Zhiyuan Zhang, Sen Wang, Zixin Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: In the field of knowledge retrieval in typical power scenario scheduling, keyword matching based methods are commonly used. However, keyword matching methods only perform simple string matching, resulting in low retrieval efficiency. Therefore, this paper studies an enhanced method for knowledge retrieval in typical power scenario scheduling based on BFS algorithm. Systematically integrate knowledge of power dispatching, form a network architecture consisting of entity relationship entity triplets, and determine the graph structure through complex entity recognition and relationship extraction techniques. Using BFS algorithm to detect effective scheduling solutions, traversing scheduling paths and analyzing them with structured knowledge graph, and identifying all possible solutions. Based on the results of the first two stages, the optimal power scheduling scheme is generated by using retrieval enhancement technology and a reordering machine to recall scheduling schemes with high similarity using cosine similarity. The experimental results show that in terms of retrieval enhancement effect, the scheduling strategy generated by this method reduces the monthly average line loss rate from 4.8% of the original strategy to 3.3%; In the comprehensive score, the BERTScore and Agent Score of this method significantly outperformed the comparison methods in the three rounds of dialogue; In terms of retrieval efficiency, the retrieval time range of this method is $0.5-1.2$ seconds. The experiment shows that this method can effectively reduce line loss, provide high-quality knowledge support, have high retrieval efficiency, and improve the reliability and real-time scheduling of power systems.

title: The Electric Vehicle Routing Problem with Wireless Charging Lanes
authors: J. Bosch, H. Raza, M. Y. Qi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: The Electric Vehicle Routing Problem with Wireless Charging Lanes (EVRP-WCL) introduces dynamic, in-motion charging into routing decisions, demanding algorithms that capture speed choices, detours, and repeated arc traversals in realistic road graphs. We formulate the EVRP-WCL as a mixed-integer linear program on an incomplete network and benchmark three solution strategies: (i) the exact model solved directly in Gurobi, (ii) the same model solved after a Network-Reduction Heuristic (NRH) converts the graph into a complete multigraph, and (iii) an Adaptive Large Neighborhood Search (ALNS) applied to the reduced network. Results on grids up to 12 × 12 verify that NRH preserves optimality while shrinking solve times, and grids up to 25 x 25 showcase that ALNS consistently reaches high-quality solutions for large instances that are superior to the exact solver. A cost-equivalent comparison with stationary-charging EVRP shows wireless charging lanes (WCL) eliminate time-penalty stops, offsetting their higher energy prices and frequently producing lower total cost. These findings establish WCLs as a viable charging alternative for logistics fleets.

title: Fitness-Directed Strategy Switching Particle Swarm Optimization for Global Optimization and UAV Trajectory Tracking
authors: Nacer Hacene, Manal Amieur, Boubekeur Mendil
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: Despite its effectiveness, Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) suffers from premature convergence and a poor balance between exploration and exploitation. To address these limitations, this paper proposes a novel variant, FDSS-PSO, which introduces a Fitness-Directed Strategy Switching mechanism. Particles in FDSS-PSO dynamically alternate between two velocity update rules based on their real-time performance. This strategy is governed by an adaptive inertia weight that ensures a smooth, non-linear transition from exploration to exploitation without requiring manual parameter tuning. The performance of FDSS-PSO is rigorously evaluated against 13 state-of-the-art algorithms, including six PSO variants and six recent metaheuristics, on the CEC 2022 benchmark suite and a complex UAV spiral trajectory tracking problem. Experimental results demonstrate that FDSS-PSO achieves statistically superior accuracy and convergence speed, confirming its robustness and effectiveness as a highly competitive optimizer for complex real-world engineering challenges. Source code for FDSS-PSO is publicly available at: https://www.mathworks.com/matlabcentral/fileexchange/182396-fitness-directed-strategy-switching-pso-fdsspso

title: Demand Prediction for Internet-Based Outpatient Services Incorporating Temporal and Environmental Features
authors: Guowei Hu, Yihui Wang, Liping Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: The fluctuation of patient demand is a critical factor influencing consultation waiting times and operational efficiency in healthcare systems. Accurate demand prediction plays a pivotal role in optimizing hospital resource allocation and enhancing service delivery. This study investigates the prediction of Internet-based outpatient service demands at both daily and half-day temporal granularities. Based on the multi-source data, including patient visit records and environment factors, we first conduct a feature selection engineering through statistical test methods (i.e., the chi-square independence test and grey relational analysis). Building on these selected features, we propose a novel hybrid model that integrates a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), and an Attention Mechanism (AM). Based on the real data from a large public hospital in a central city in China, we compare the performance of our proposed hybrid model with some benchmark methods such as spanning statistical, machine learning, and deep learning models. Numerical results demonstrate that the proposed CNN-LSTM-AM model outperforms the benchmarks in both daily and half-day dimensions.

title: Attention-Inverse Perturbation: A Novel Adversarial Attack Strategy by Targeting Non-Attentive Regions
authors: Ming Zhang, Zhendong Wu, Hu Li, Jin Li, Ling Pang, Cheng Qian
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Adversarial attacks have gained significant research interest for their ability to expose vulnerabilities in deep neural networks. However, current studies on visual adversarial attacks predominantly focus on improving attack efficiency or success rates, typically constraining perturbation magnitudes using l<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">p-</inf>norm while overlooking the critical requirement for human imperceptibility of adversarial examples. Although globally minor perturbations are generated, they may introduce localized artifacts (e.g., abnormal brightness or perceptible texture anomalies) that compromise visual stealthiness. To address this issue, we propose an attention-inverse perturbation (AIP) strategy, which restricts perturbations to visually non-attentive regions (e.g., backgrounds) identified through class activation mapping techniques, thereby minimizing visual discrepancies between adversarial and clean examples. Our strategy can be seamlessly integrated into existing attack methods. Extensive experiments demonstrate that the proposed AIP strategy achieves superior performance across perceptual similarity metrics (e.g., MS-SSIM, VIF, and LPIPS) with only marginal trade-offs in attack success rate, offering a practical solution for balancing imperceptibility and attack efficacy.

title: A Nonuniform Beam Filling (NUBF) Doppler Velocity Bias Estimate for Airborne Radars with Arbitrary Pointing Angles
authors: Charles N. Helms, Matthew L. Walker McLinden, Gerald M. Heymsfield
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Doppler velocity biases introduced by nonuniform beam filling (NUBF) can often resemble legitimate meteorological features, potentially resulting in misinterpretation of radar data. Existing NUBF Doppler velocity bias corrections for airborne radars generally assume the antenna is pointing in the nadir direction. This work generalizes the NUBF bias correction equations to work for any antenna pointing angle, regardless of whether the angle is fixed or changing with time.

title: CrossMiner: Smart Contract Vulnerability Detection in Interactive Scenarios
authors: Xiangfu Liu, Teng Huang, Caiyan Tan, Jiahui Huang, Qiong Wang, Yan Pang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Vulnerability attacks targeting smart contracts have caused significant losses of digital assets. Many approaches based on static analysis, fuzzing, and deep learning have been proposed for detecting contract vulnerabilities. However, most existing methods only support vulnerability detection within individual contracts. When contracts interact with each other through external calls, these methods fail to perform effective cross-contract security analysis, leading to false negatives and false positives. To address these limitations, we propose CrossMiner, a deep learning-based approach for vulnerability detection in contract interaction scenarios. CrossMiner enables comprehensive risk assessment for cross-contract security through trace analysis of function call chains. Specifically, CrossMiner first constructs a cross-contract dependency graph based on function call chains to effectively model inter-contract dependencies and network dynamics, and collect semantic information about contract interactions. Then, it employs a heterogeneous graph neural network with a two-level attention mechanism to finely extract and integrate complex features from the dependency graph, ultimately achieving precise risk assessment and vulnerability detection. We evaluate the effectiveness of CrossMiner on three types of smart contract vulnerabilities: reentrancy, timestamp dependency, and transaction state dependency. Experimental results demonstrate that CrossMiner achieves the best performance among all baseline methods, improving detection accuracy by 5.52%, 4.94%, and 5.60% for these vulnerabilities, and the F1 scores are improved by 5.44%, 5.02%, and 5.40%, respectively.

title: Development and Usability Evaluation of an AR-Based Assembly Support System
authors: Yuto Kiuchi, Harumi Haraguchi, Takeshi Shibata
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: In assembly work on real manufacturing sites, several factors can cause a decline in assembly time and accuracy.. In practice, factors such as worker proficiency, the working environment, and fatigue have been shown to increase assembly time and reduce accuracy. This study focuses on the role of assembly manuals. Traditional 2D-based assembly manuals have been found to negatively impact workers, as they are limited in the amount of information they can convey. In response, this study aims to develop and evaluate a system that leverages augmented reality (AR) technology to facilitate a more intuitive understanding of assembly procedures. The functionality evaluation was conducted on three aspects: startup time, scene transition time, and the accuracy of the AR marker. The startup time was slightly longer than the standard, while the scene transition time was within the standard. The AR marker was able to be recognized to a certain extent. An experiment was conducted to compare AR with 3D, 2D, and paper-based manuals. After the experiment, a questionnaire and interviews were conducted regarding the usability of the application. While several challenges were observed in the use of the AR manual, the results suggest that it holds significant potential for future applications.

title: Development of a Plastic Oil Pyrolysis Plant for the Kenyan Market
authors: Moses Jeremiah Barasa Kabeyi, Stephen Juma Wanjala, Oludolapo Akanni Olanrewaju
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Modernization has led to high levels of plastic production and consumption globally with significant environmental impacts. Major industries heavily rely on plastics like the health, transport, electronics, food and beverage are some of the industries that widely utilize plastic material, which has kept their demand and usage rising. Poor methods of plastic waste disposal and low rates of recycling in countries like Kenya has led to massive environmental pollution by plastics mainly as plastic bags and bottles lying everywhere in the environment, across the country on land and water bodies. Close to, 260,000 tons of plastic material are produced in Kenya on annual basis with only 15% being recycled with the rest being disposed to the environment. This has created an urgent need to increase recycling of waste plastic and mitigate the environmental crisis caused. The main objective of the study is to develop a plastic pyrolysis plant to reduce the high levels of plastic pollution. Since plastic are made from crude fossil oil, pyrolysis can be used to turn the plastics back to oil. Plastic waste pyrolysis can be used to process large quantities mixed plastic waste in mixed form and help overcome the challenge of sorting required by other recycling methods with less pre-treatment, which reduces labor requirement, time and related costs. The design process involved investigation of the design parameters for the pyrolysis process, selection of appropriate machines that are efficient, cost competitive, and environmentally friendly.

title:
Arc Erosion Mechanism and Lifetime Prediction of Graphene-Silver-Spot Reinforced AgSnO
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    Contact Materials
authors: Qiming Gao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: AgSnO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>-based electrical contact materials are widely used in switching devices due to their excellent arc-extinguishing performance. However, existing high arc erosion intensity and difficulty in predicting lifespan remain key issues limiting their engineering reliability. To address this, this paper proposes a complex lifespan prediction model integrating thermo-electrical-mechanical multi physics coupling mechanisms (GSSR). First, a finite element arc erosion module is developed, taking into account the effects of Joule heating, Lorentz force, and transient thermal stress, while incorporating the influence of graphene thermal diffusion networks and silver particle reinforcement on the material’s local heat-mass transfer behavior. Subsequently, an erosion mass loss function is established based on a nonlinear Arrhenius-Maxwell stress coupling law, characterizing the evolution of molten pits and material vaporization under multiple arc impacts. On this basis, a Bayesian fatigue damage accumulation layer is introduced, and experimental discharge sequences and performance degradation data are used for dynamic parameter calibration, enabling periodic prediction of contact lifespan evolution. Experimental results show that the model predicts erosion mass with an error of less than 6.3%.

title: Generative AI-Enhanced Robust Semantic Communication Architecture for UAV Image Transmission
authors: Canpu Liu, Li Zhou, Xinfeng Deng, Yichi Zhang, Nan Li, Jun Xiong, Boon-Chong Seet
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) wireless image transmission has gained widespread application across various fields due to its flexibility, yet it faces critical challenges such as resource constraints and degradation of reconstruction quality caused by harsh channel conditions. To address these issues, we designed a lightweight semantic communication backbone network that substantially reduces the computational and storage overhead of UAVs through codebook assistance and efficient encoder-decoder design. On this basis, to tackle severe image degradation under adverse channel conditions, we introduced a generative artificial intelligence-based (GAI) enhancement module. Specifically, we developed a semantic refinement network (SRN) that employs an innovative signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) adaptive feature-wise linear modulation (FiLM) layer to dynamically adjust its refinement strategy based on real-time channel quality, fundamentally transforming the image reconstruction paradigm from traditional signal recovery to conditional content generation. Extensive experimental results demonstrate that our proposed framework significantly outperforms the current state-of-the-art method under extreme channel conditions, highlighting its great potential for achieving robust UAV image transmission in challenging operational environments.

title: Modern Middlewares for Automated Vehicles: A Tutorial
authors: David Philipp Klüner, Marius Molz, Alexandru Kampmann, Stefan Kowalewski, Bassam Alrifaee
abstract: This article offers a tutorial on current middlewares in automated vehicles (AVs). Our aim is to provide the reader with an overview of current middlewares and to identify open challenges in this field. We start by explaining the fundamentals of software architectures in distributed systems and the distinguishing requirements of AVs. We then distinguish between communication middlewares and architecture platforms and highlight their key principles and differences. Next, we present five state-of-the-art middlewares as well as their capabilities and functions. We explore how these middlewares could be applied in the design of future vehicle software and their role in the automotive domain. Finally, we compare the five middlewares presented and discuss open research challenges.

title: Design and Analysis of an Integrated NOMA-VLPC System: Achieving Positioning via DC and Communication via AC
authors: Ting Yang, Ping Wang, Yanzhe Sun, Qi Liu, Bo Bai
abstract: An integrated visible light positioning and communication (VLPC) system has been proposed on the basis of non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA), in which the direct current (DC) and alternating current (AC) components of the signal are adopted for positioning and communication, respectively. Specifically, biphase coding, majority vote, and two-stage positioning strategies are introduced to mitigate message randomness, receiver noise, and fingerprinting errors. Besides, the achievable sum rate and energy efficiency (EE) are obtained, and the optimal DC power setting is derived to achieve the best communication performance. Results show that the positioning accuracy improves with the number of light-emitting diodes (LEDs) and as user moves closer to the room center, follows an inverted U-shaped trend with user height, and could achieve the same accuracy as the AC-based positioning method using metaheuristic algorithms but in less time. Moreover, under perfect and imperfect successive interference cancellation (pSIC/ipSIC), both the system sum rate and EE initially increase with DC power and then decrease. A small-scale experiment is also carried out to verify the proposed DC-based positioning method. This work offers a good reference for VLPC system research.
