title: LSCNet: An Adaptive Cloud Detection Network Via Local-Global Spatial Context
authors: Xinyu Cui, Bing Tu, Bo Liu, Yan He, Antonio Plaza
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: The ubiquitous presence of clouds in optical remote sensing images (RSIs) degrades image quality. Thin and fragmented clouds often exhibit low contrast and diverse morphology in complex scenes, which poses a significant challenge for accurate detection. To address the current challenges in thin cloud detection, this study proposes an Adaptive Cloud Detection Network in Remote Sensing Images via Local-Global Spatial Context (LSCNet). It aims to process thin cloud features within global and local spatial contexts, thereby improving the accuracy and robustness of thin cloud detection in complex environments. Specifically, the network simulates a dual perspective by constructing a Mamba-based Multiscale Fusion (MDF) block. This block utilizes learnable fusion weights to adaptively integrate differential and complementary information, thereby capturing thin cloud variations across both spatial and spectral dimensions in RSIs. Additionally, we propose a Local Gated Mamba (LGM) block for detailed feature enhancement. This module utilizes a spatial gating mechanism inspired by Long Short-Term Memory to capture key thin-cloud features and suppress residual background noise. By fully leveraging the spatial structure and morphology of thin clouds and building connections between thin cloud features across different spatial scales, the module achieves precise segmentation of cloud and ground features, thereby boosting the classification performance for thin and thick clouds in identical observational contexts. Extensive experiments conducted on the L8-Biome dataset and the WHUS2-CD+ dataset demonstrate that our method outperforms other existing cloud detection methods.

title: PLAA: Packet-level Adversarial Attacks in Network Traffic Detection
authors: Jinhao You, Zan Zhou, Shujie Yang, Yi Sun, Lei Zhang, Changqiao Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) are widely applied in Network-based Intrusion Detection System (NIDS) due to their high accuracy. However, DNNs are highly susceptible to adversarial attacks, which generate malicious traffic to evade NIDS detection. Existing approaches often adapt adversarial attacks from computer vision (CV) tasks to the NIDS domain, overlooking the fundamental differences between CV and NIDS. This results in two major issues: 1) The generated network traffic may become invalid, 2) The generated traffic may lose its original attack semantics. To address these issues, this paper proposes an adversarial attack specifically designed for NIDS. Instead of directly generating flow-level features, our approach incrementally generates packet-level features to construct adversarial traffic. During the generation process, the semantic integrity of the traffic is monitored at each stage, effectively avoiding the issues of invalid traffic and semantic loss observed in existing methods. We evaluate our attack algorithm against current NIDS models using the CIC-UNSW-NB15, CIC-DDoS2019, and CIC-IDS-2017 datasets. The proposed method achieves an average evasion success rate of 92.78%, while ensuring that the generated adversarial traffic remains semantically consistent with the original malicious traffic.

title: Exploration of the Cultivation Path of Digital Intelligence Engineers with Chinese Characteristics : Based on the Research on Engineering Ethics in the Context of the Digital Intelligence Era
authors: Yu Junyi, Gong Shuyan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: With the rapid advancement of digital technologies, digital intelligence engineers have emerged as a new force in the engineering field and a focal point for talent demand. Against the backdrop of the digital intelligence era, cultivating digital intelligence engineers who meet national strategic needs has become one of the key tasks of higher education. This paper focuses on the exploration of the cultivation pathway for digital intelligence engineers with Chinese characteristics, proposing a series of optimization strategies by analyzing the role positioning and ethical challenges faced by digital intelligence engineers.

title: Mathematical Modeling for the Consolidation of Elementary Schools in Depopulated Areas
authors: T. Kanawa, W. Wu, Y. Hu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: This study proposes a mathematical model to optimize the consolidation of elementary schools in depopulated areas by simultaneously determining student assignment and school closures over multiple years. The problem is formulated as a multi-period facility location problem that incorporates annual fluctuations in enrolled students, the irreversibility of closures, and realistic institutional and geographical constraints. The objective function includes student assignment costs based on distance, penalties for splitting student groups, school closure costs, penalties for underutilized capacity, and penalties for imbalance across grades. In preprocessing, we construct forecast data based on historical birth and enrollment records and propose a customized definition of school closure costs to reflect practical considerations and enhance the realism of the model. Numerical experiments using real-world data from Hamamatsu City in Shizuoka Prefecture, which is known as a typical depopulated area in Japan. The experimental results showed a tendency for schools in depopulated areas to be prioritized for closure and identified cases consistent with actual closure plans, which suggests potential applicability of the proposed model to real-world decision-making.

title: Autonomous Landing of a Quadrotor on a Moving Target Using a Vision-Based Approach
authors: Oumaima Gharsa, Mostefa Mohamed Touba, Mohamed Boumehraz, Nesrine Abderrahmani, Imam Barket Ghiloubi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: Autonomous localization and landing are fundamental capabilities for enabling independent flight missions across a wide range of unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) applications. This paper introduces a vision based framework for fully automated landing system that allows a drone to accurately estimate moving platform motion and achieve landing on it. using only its onboard camera sensor. To regulate the UAV’s motion, a PID controller is developed based on the target’s position in the image plane. Unlike approaches that rely on external localization specialized infrastructure, including motion-capture setups or Global Positioning System (GPS), the proposed method operates efficiently without any external support, It necessitates no prior awareness of the moving landing target’s position. The framework’s efficacy is confirmed using high-fidelity simulations within the Gazebo environment and ROS, with results demonstrating that the proposed strategy consistently achieves precise and reliable landings on moving platforms.

title: Decentralized ISAC Service Modeling and Intelligent Scheduling Paradigm for 6G Low-altitude Aerial-V2X
authors: Qirui Liu, Bile Peng, Xiangnan Liu, Chenren Xu, Eduard A. Jorswieck, Haijun Zhang
abstract: The emerging low-altitude economy leverages airspace below 1000 meters for intensive commercial and social aerial activities, where integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) service in 6G network for aircraft is critical to ensuring safe and efficient operations. However, aircraft often operate under constrained wireless resources, particularly in areas with limited or no network coverage. In such settings, exhaustive sensing and data communication among neighboring nodes lead to uncoordinated competition and prohibitive overhead. This paper investigates the ISAC service modeling and scheduling in aerial-vehicle-to-everything (Aerial-V2X) networks, which provides continuous high-accuracy sensing without compromising communication throughput under constrained resource budgets. First, we design a reconfigurable ISAC waveform tailored for aircraft, enabling flexible resource partitioning for both cellular communication (aerial vehicle-to-infrastructure, A-V2I) and cooperative sensing (aerial vehicle-to-vehicle, A-V2V). Second, we formulate a joint sensing-communication service model under this waveform and cast the optimization problem in a partially observable Markov decision process (POMDP). Third, a multi-agent deep reinforcement learning (MADRL) approach is developed to perform decentralized scheduling of sensing actions for each aircraft, minimizing time-frequency resource consumption. Experiments and trace-driven evaluations demonstrate that the proposed method can reduce sensing overhead by up to 70% compared to benchmark policies, while maintaining satisfactory communication and sensing performance.

title: Fine-Grained Revocable Lattice-Based ABE: Dual User and Attribute Revocation with Low Overhead for Cloud Environments
authors: Yuliang Liu, Yuan Liu, Yiwen Gao, Yongbin Zhou, Licheng Wang, Peng Gao
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Attribute-based encryption (ABE) provides fine-grained access control over encrypted data without restricting itself to a single access policy, making it applicable to diverse scenarios such as cloud environments. However, existing bilinear pairing-based ABE schemes are vulnerable to quantum attacks, while lattice-based ABE schemes typically lack flexible and efficient user or attribute revocation mechanisms. To address these challenges, this paper presents a fine-grained revocable attribute-based encryption (FR-ABE) scheme based on the ring learning with errors (RLWE) assumption. We introduce a two-dimensional attribute structure and an extended Shamir’s secret sharing method, which together support multi-valued attributes and flexible threshold access policies, while reducing storage and computational overhead. Furthermore, We have devised a fine-grained revocation mechanism that functions at both the attribute and user levels, thereby accommodating the frequent role and permission changes. The attribute authority centrally manages attribute revocation through an indirect revocation method, eliminating the need to re-run the sampling algorithm and instead relying solely on polynomial-level operations, which reduces time overhead. User revocation is implemented using a binary tree structure, which updates only the ciphertext and leaves all keys unchanged. Theoretical analysis suggests that our scheme performs well in terms of both computational and storage overhead, and experimental findings further corroborate its superiority. The security analysis establishes the scheme’s selective security under the RLWE assumption.

title: On the Limitations of Fuzzy Hashing for Malware Similarity: An Analysis of Vulnerable Code Detection in Malware
authors: Nathan Ross, Oluwafemi Olukoya, Jesús Martínez Del Rincón
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: As malware variants continue to increase, the risk of evading detection also grows. While fuzzy hashing has traditionally been successful at clustering malware samples based on their structural similarities, its potential as an active defense tool remains largely unexplored. This study investigates the application of fuzzy hashing for the static analysis of malware binaries to identify common vulnerabilities prevalent in malware, serving as a proactive security measure. We utilized a labeled dataset comprising real-world and synthetic Windows binaries to evaluate six fuzzy hashing algorithms for full binary classification and two for function-level matching. Our results indicate that, while fuzzy hashing is effective in simpler tasks such as malware classification and binary-level vulnerability detection, its performance decreases in more complex scenarios, including multi-class vulnerability identification and matching functions from real-world malware. Moreover, we observed a significant drop in performance, by up to 50%, when transitioning from synthetic to actual malware functions. These findings highlight both the potential and limitations of fuzzy hashing in vulnerability analysis, emphasizing the necessity for more robust techniques to detect vulnerable patterns in real-world malware.

title: Design and In-Orbit Performance of a 1U 1 Gbit/s Optical Communication Terminal
authors: Niek Doelman, Gert Witvoet, Dick de Bruijn, Arjo Bos, Arnoud Delissen, Dong-Nhat Nguyen, Loes Scheers, Hedser van Brug, Robbert Voorhoeve, Kristiaan Broekens, Cornelis Willem Korevaar, Floris van Kempen
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Quantum Electronics
abstract: A CubeSat-compatible optical communication terminal (CubeCAT) has been designed, manufactured, and tested in orbit. It achieves 1 Gbit/s data rate in downlink at low biterror- rate (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\leq 10^{-6}$</tex-math></inline-formula>), has a 1U volume, 1.0 kg mass and 10.8 W power consumption. It is based on a compact and efficient optical architecture, a low mass and stable mechanical structure, a high performing and robust pointing control strategy and designed to be compliant with the CCSDS O3K standard, with Reed-Solomon 223/255 coding. For launch survival a dedicated enveloping suspension module has been realized. Being launched and onboard the NorSat-TD satellite, the Cube- CAT terminal has established various successful in-orbit communication downlinks. Data from the optical ground stations TNO (The Hague, Netherlands), MeO (Grasse, France) and Izaña (Tenerife, Spain) have been analyzed and verify the CubeCAT design.

title: A Region Dual-Factor Aware Federated Learning Framework for NWDAF in B5G/6G Core Network
authors: Mingchuang Zhang, Hongbo Tang, Wei You, Xingxing Liao, Jie Yang, Hang Qiu
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: As a key intelligent component of core networks, NWDAF (Network Data Analytics Function) provides network intelligence capabilities while facing increasingly data security challenges. Current research on NWDAF data security primarily adopts federated learning framework, which trains models locally to avoid privacy leakage risks. However, existing NWDAF federated learning studies mostly rely on idealized assumptions, failing to adequately address two critical issues in real-world network deployments: 1) uneven data distribution across different regions, and 2) differentiated optimization requirements for high priority security regions. To solve these problems, we propose a region dual-factor aware federated learning framework for NWDAF (NWDAF-FedRDA), specifically designed to handle regional data imbalance and security priority differences in core networks. The framework comprises three core components: 1) Model parameter distribution: enabling allocation of global model parameters to regional nodes; 2) Local training: performing regional data preprocessing and model training; 3) Region dual-factor aware aggregation: computing regional weights through awareness factors and executing global model aggregation. Experimental evaluations across four network scenarios demonstrate the framework’s performance in anomaly detection tasks. Results show that compared to baseline methods, our framework exhibits significant advantages in uneven data distribution environments while effectively enhancing model performance for high-priority security regions.

title: Enhancing Cross-domain Correspondence for Unsupervised Image-to-Image Translation
authors: Binxin Lai, Wenkang Su, Yuying Liang, Yuan-Gen Wang, Mingjie Li, Jiantao Zhou
abstract: UNsupervised Image-to-image Translation (UNIT) aims to translate images across visual domains without paired training data, which has been widely used in style transfer, image processing, game design, etc. However, ensuring the correspondence (e.g., target category, pose, or head orientation) between generated images and inputs remains a formidable challenge. To this end, we present a new scheme, named EC-UNIT, which comprises three innovative designs aiming to Enhance cross domain Correspondence for UNIT. Specifically, 1) we propose Multi-level Style Embedding to extract multi-level style features for fusion while imposing our newly designed Hierarchical Consistency Constraints on both the content and style features (MSE&HCC), aiming to retain more style representations and facilitate feature disentanglement; 2) we develop Semantic Perceptual Matching (SPM) to minimize the semantic distribution discrepancy between the generated image and the input image by leveraging the multimodal model CLIP, dedicated to enhancing semantic consistency; 3) considering that previous works have struggled to control the image translation using pixel-level visual consistency constraints, we design Visual Perceptual Guidance (VPG) to reduce the perceptual distance between the generated image and the style input in VGG feature space, devoted to enhancing visual perceptual correspondence, thereby preventing the generation of unrealistic image details. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our EC-UNIT is more stable and outperforms current SOTA competitors in terms of image quality and diversity as well as both content and style consistency.

title: Data-driven Framework for Aligning R&D Strategy with Corporate Goals Using a Network-based Roadmapping Approach
authors: G. Schuh, A. Keuper, N. Kelbel, M. Hamker, E. Rebentisch, M. Mertens
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Rising customer expectations, intensifying competition and shortening technology and product life cycles impact technology-driven companies, making technological change a key driver of competitive advantage. While the need for strategic planning has increased, selecting the optimal technology portfolio from an abundance of technological options and allocating sufficient resources to R&D projects have become critical determinants of success. Traditional roadmapping and decision-making approaches struggle to remain effective in rapidly evolving markets, leading to sub-optimal technology portfolios and reduced long-term competitiveness. This paper aims to develop a holistic framework that integrates data-driven analyses and includes capabilities to align with strategic goals using network theory methods.

title: Hybrid Neuro-Fuzzy and NARX Modeling for Optimization and Prediction of Two-Shaft Gas Turbine Performance
authors: Abdelouahab Chebbah, Ahmed Hafaifa, Mourad Bachene, Abdellah Kouzou, Nadji Hadroug
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: This paper presents a hybrid modeling approach that combines Nonlinear Auto-Regressive models with exogenous inputs (NARX) and Adaptive Neuro-Fuzzy Inference Systems of Takagi-Sugeno type (ANFIS-TS) for the prediction and optimization of a two- shaft gas turbine’s performance. The study focuses on three key output parameters: high-pressure shaft speed, low-pressure shaft speed, and exhaust temperature. Real operational data from an MS5002 turbine are used to train and validate both models. The NARX architecture is optimized to capture dynamic behavior, while the ANFIS-TS models are tuned using various clustering and partitioning techniques to enhance interpretability and robustness. Comparative analysis based on performance metrics such as MSE and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> demonstrates the complementarity of both approaches. The results highlight the potential of hybrid AI-based modeling for advanced monitoring, fault diagnosis, and control of industrial gas turbines.

title: Real-Time monitoring of Solar Titan 130 Gas turbine based on vibration modeling
authors: Tarek Idris Bisker, Sidali Aissat, Nadji Hadroug, Ahmed Saïd Nouri, Abdelhamid Iratni, Ahmed Hafaifa
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: This paper presents the implementation of a real-time monitoring system using on the control of input and output variables of an example of a gas turbine, in exploitation at the compression station of Sonatrach SC3. The primary objective of this study is to implement a strategy for modeling the vibrational phenomena affecting this rotating machine, particularly the rotation shaft of the low-pressure turbine and the high-pressure turbine. This approach aims to design a vibration-related fault-tolerant control strategy, capable of detecting and locating vibrational anomalies, thereby preserving system stability and limiting gas turbine degradation phenomena. The obtained experimental results pave the way for the development of a modern monitoring strategy specifically tailored to the studied turbine, thus making a significant contribution to the real-time surveillance of gas turbines.

title: MVL-AD:A Multi-View Learning Framework for Class-Incremental Unknown Attack Detection
authors: Xukui Li, Guang Cheng, Wei Chen, Zhen Zhang, Zechen Xu, Xing Qiu
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Although traditional intrusion detection systems can identify unknown attacks based on established patterns, they are incapable of the fine-grained classification needed to distinguish one from another. Moreover, the prohibitive cost of adapting a detection model to new threats without degrading its existing capabilities severely impedes its effectiveness against emerging attacks. To address these challenges, we propose a Multi-View Learning Framework for Class-Incremental Unknown Attack Detection (MVL-AD). This framework designs a contrastive error autoencoder (CE-AE) for each class to build multiple differentiated learners. These learners calculate anomaly scores from diverse perspectives to comprehensively characterize the attack profile. We apply anomaly detection algorithms to the attack profiles to identify unknown attacks. These identified unknown attacks are classified into distinct categories using Mini-Batch K-Means, with the optimal number of clusters determined by the Calinski-Harabasz (CH) index. Furthermore, MVL-AD incorporates an adaptive updating mechanism to improve its detection performance on both known and unknown attacks. Extensive experiments demonstrate that MVL-AD outperforms state-of-the-art methods in stability, scalability, and practicability.

title: Numerical Simulation Study on Hot Air De-icing of High-Voltage Electrical Equipment in Substations
authors: Ying Guo, Qingda Liu, Xiaozhuo Guan, Rao Fu, Xu Liu, Tiebin Guo
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: In recent years, abnormal global climate change has led to frequent extreme weather events. Icing on power equipment caused by rain, snow, and freezing conditions has resulted in numerous disasters for power grids. After icing occurs at substations, safe and effective de-icing methods must be implemented to prevent severe icing failures. Traditional manual chipping methods may cause equipment damage and pose risks to personnel safety. To address this, this paper conducts numerical simulations of hot-air de-icing for high-voltage electrical equipment in substations. A computational model for hot-air de-icing of post insulators is established, employing a jet heat transfer model to perform segmented heat transfer calculations on the equivalent cylindrical segments of the entire post insulator. Based on an engineering computational model, numerical simulations utilize $\mathbf{1 1 0 k V}$ post insulators as calculation parameters for de-icing heat transfer analysis. Results indicate that hot air velocity, hot air temperature, and ambient temperature all influence de-icing effectiveness, with hot air velocity and temperature having the most significant impact. Reduced de-icing time comes at the cost of increased energy consumption. Practical engineering applications should comprehensively evaluate both de-icing duration and energy expenditure to determine optimal hot air de-icing parameters.

title: Toward Semantic-Aware Query Retrieval: Contextual Analysis and Prompt Optimization for the Government Research Bulletin (GRB) System in Taiwan
authors: Chia-Yi Chuang, Tzu-Yu Lin, Yu-Chun Chang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: This study proposes a scenario classification framework to enhance natural language query interpretation within the GRB (Government Research Bulletin) system. The framework is designed to map user queries to five predefined contextual categories based on semantic analysis and prompt reconstruction. To evaluate its effectiveness, we implemented a validation mechanism comparing system performance before and after prompt rephrasing, focusing on classification accuracy at both the category and scenario levels. The results demonstrate that prompt rephrasing improves contextual alignment, particularly in technically oriented queries. Nonetheless, challenges remain in accurately identifying scenarios related to fairness, risk, and application domains. This study represents a foundational step toward integrating natural language retrieval into GRB and offers practical insights for developing more user-responsive research information systems.

title: Causal Inference of Construction Environmental Factors on Worker Health: Stress Probability Modeling via Gaussian Process Networks
authors: S. Lee, G. Lee, S. Chi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Construction sites are dynamic where workers are exposed to multiple hazardous environmental factors, such as noise and dust, inducing acute stress responses. Existing regulatory guidelines focus on long-term exposure and lack tools to assess short-term stress under combined environmental conditions. To address this gap, this research proposes a framework for estimating the stress probability distribution of construction workers using only heart rate data. The process consists of three main tasks: (1) a heart rate–based stress state classification model estimates stress probability; (2) the relationship between environmental factors and estimated stress probability is quantified using Bayesian Ridge Regression; and (3) a Gaussian Process Network (GPN), weighted by regression-derived coefficients, models individual stress prediction uncertainty and is aggregated using a Mixture of Gaussians. The model reveals synergistic effects; stress probability significantly increases above 80 dB for noise and 11 μg/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> for dust, with compounded effects emerging when noise exceeds 80 dB and dust exceeds 8.75 μg/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>. These findings provide quantitative insights into acute stress under multiple environmental factors, supporting data-driven safety and environmental management on construction sites.

title: An Evaluation of Strategic Digital Transformation Models in Supply Chain Management
authors: Nirmani Dasanayake, Robert M. X. Wu, Samira Alvandi, Eva Cheng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Digital Transformation has become an inevitable factor catering to the resilience and agility in supply chains. Even though researchers have explored the adoption of different technologies in multiple functionalities within supply chains, current literature lacks a holistic view of the digital transformation process of supply chains, which entails the strategic adoption of technologies in supply chain operations. This study evaluates the status of digital transformation literature in supply chain management, thereby contributing to the body of knowledge by providing a synthesized evaluation of the digital transformation models and frameworks developed by researchers. Findings show that the existing digital transformation models lack the ability to guide the process with a holistic view, and that scholarly work is dispersed across different stages of the strategy management process.

title: Influence of Test Cables on Transformer Frequency Response Analysis and Development of a Winding Deformation Tester Based on Radio-Frequency Communication Technology
authors: Kai Gao, Zhen Meng, Jialin Li, Dalve Cai, Yishen Guo
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Frequency response analysis (FRA) of power transformers is a fundamental test for transformers. In practical on-site applications, long test cables are required to conveniently inject the test signal into the measuring instrument. At the same time, the response signal in this test can be as low as the microvolt level. Because of the test cables, the measurement of such small signals is strongly affected by the test environment, wiring conditions, and sudden external radio-frequency interference. It is therefore common that repeated measurements under ostensibly identical conditions yield inconsistent results, which complicates correct assessment of the transformer condition. From both theoretical analysis and experimental verification, this paper investigates the influence of test cables on transformer FRA measurements. A development concept for a multichannel transformer frequency response characteristic test device based on radio-frequency ($\mathbf{R F}$) communication technology is proposed, and a prototype has been developed. Trial applications on transformers and comparison with existing test data show that the prototype achieves good test performance.

title: SwCC: A Swapped-Contrastive Clustering Learning for Few-shot Website Fingerprinting Attacks
authors: Jing Bai, Gaopeng Gou, Zheyuan Gu, Wenqi Dong, Gang Xiong, Zhen Li, Zhenzhen Li, Qingya Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Website fingerprinting (WF) attacks exploit distinctive traffic patterns to identify the specific web page a user visits over anonymized connections. While traditional WF attacks have achieved impressive results, they are typically evaluated in abundant labeled data settings and assume that website traffic features remain static. This assumption is often unrealistic in real-world scenarios. Recent methods either rely on deep learning, which still requires large amounts of labeled data, or employ self-supervised pre-training to ease this demand. However, they leave clustering information crucial for few-shot WF attacks underexplored, leaving ample room for performance gains. In this paper, we propose a novel self-supervised pre-training model for few-shot WF attacks, called Swapped Contrastive Clustering (SwCC). SwCC proposes a comprehensive and principled data augmentation scheme, combining Tor-tailored transformations with statistical procedures to foster robust and discriminative feature learning for WF attacks. SwCC further introduces an innovative dual-level contrastive learning framework that jointly leverages instance-level and prototype-based objectives, which can further perform latent-space clustering on extracted features in WF attacks. Our pre-trained model can be fine-tuned in few-shot learning scenarios and achieves state-of-the-art(SOTA) performance on few-shot WF attack tasks. Under a 5-shot learning setting in a closed-world scenario, our SwCC achieves up to 83.5% accuracy when the evaluation traces are collected from an environment unseen by the WF adversary, outperforming the SOTA methods.

title: A Data-driven Evaluation of Early-Stage Startups based on the Integrative Framework of the Balanced Scorecard and RFM Analysis
authors: J. Lee, Y. Geum
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Identifying promising startups and supporting investment decisions has long been a critical research focus. Among various approaches, the MCDM-based scoring method has gained attention for incorporating multidimensional factors with interpretability. However, the absence of a structured framework for selecting evaluation criteria limits its ability to capture the distinct characteristics of startups. To address, this study proposes an integrated framework employing the balanced scorecard (BSC) to organize evaluation dimensions in a systematic manner. For each perspective, RFM-based methods are developed to assess elements such as investment history and human capital maturity. The proposed integrative framework enables a more systematic and effective assessment of early-stage startup, contributing to strategic decision making in high uncertainty environments.

title: Observer-based estimation for an essential oil extraction system
authors: E. Ramos Hernández, C.-M Astorga Zaragoza, J. Reyes Reyes, G.-L. Osorio Gordillo, I.-I Zetina Rios, F. Ramírez Rasgado
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: This study involved the design and simulation of a nonlinear observer to estimate the internal variables of hydrodistillation that cannot be measured directly, such as the mass of oil retained in the trichomes and in the aqueous layer. The methodology consisted of hydrodistillation as a nonlinear system subject to Lipschitz conditions and observability properties. Based on this framework, the structure of the observer was derived using algebraic parameterizations, and stability conditions were established using the second Lyapunov method. The simulation results demonstrated that the proposed observer was capable of accurately estimating the internal variables of the system. This approach can serve as a basis for designing monitoring and fault diagnosis systems, representing a step toward safer operation of oil extraction techniques.

title: Chaos of Functionalities: Understanding Security Risks in Heterogeneity of IoT Matter Controllers
authors: Yiwei Fang, Haoqiang Wang, Ze Jin, Qixu Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: The Matter protocol has rapidly become the new standard for secure and interoperable IoT connectivity, adopted by major industry players and integrated into millions of devices. A core feature of Matter is its ability to support device sharing across users and controllers. However, as vendors independently implement Matter and blend it with their proprietary ecosystems, significant inconsistencies emerge. These inconsistencies result in heterogeneous user capabilities depending on which Matter Controller (MC) or OEM app is used, introducing a new and largely unexplored class of security risks. In this work, we present the first systematic study on security risks stemming from heterogeneous Matter controller implementations in shared device environments. We analyze 18 major IoT vendors and uncover a novel category of vulnerabilities, which we term MCG (Matter Controller Gaps), where differences in controller capabilities can enable unauthorized access or stealthy device manipulation. To uncover these flaws at scale, we develop MCG-Checker, a semi-automated analysis tool that combines large language models and UI automation to detect control disparities across Matter controllers and OEM apps. Using MCG-Checker, we evaluate 14 Matter controllers and 8 OEM apps, discovering 5 previously unknown attack vectors affecting top vendors such as Google, Apple, and Amazon Alexa. Our work reveals critical design and implementation issues in current Matter deployments. We offer concrete recommendations for protocol designers, vendors, and end users to address these gaps, contributing to more secure and predictable IoT ecosystems.

title: Performance Simulation and Parameter Optimization of Permanent Magnet Disc Motors for Oil Pumping Units
authors: Yawei Duan, Chaodong Tan, Chaoluan Tan, Jian Song
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Disc-type permanent magnet motors are critical equipment for enhancing the efficiency and reliability of beam pumping units. This paper proposes a multi-objective optimization design method for motors integrating Kriging prediction models with the NSGA-II algorithm: an electromagnetic and thermal simulation model is established using Motor-CAD, a sample set is generated via Latin Hypercube Sampling (LHS), and prediction models for efficiency and cogging torque are constructed based on the Kriging algorithm. With efficiency maximization and cogging torque minimization as objectives, while constraining output torque and back EMF, the NSGA-II algorithm generates the Pareto optimal frontier and solves for the optimal solution. Research indicates that the optimized motor achieves an output torque of $2230.3 \mathrm{~N} \cdot \mathrm{~m}$, meeting the field requirement of $2230 \mathrm{~N} \cdot \mathrm{~m}$; Efficiency reached 94.64%, meeting energy-saving enhancement standards; cogging torque decreased to $13.21 \mathrm{~N} \cdot \mathrm{~m}$, outperforming the field requirement of $20 \mathrm{~N} \cdot \mathrm{~m}$ and improving motor operational stability. This methodology provides theoretical and engineering guidance for parameter optimization design of permanent magnet motors used in semi-direct drive pumping units.

title: FPGA-Based Harmonic Mitigation for Residential EV Charging Piles in Low-Voltage Distribution Networks
authors: Chao Zhang, Yongjie Tong, Yuetian Wang, Hong Zhang, Xu Tan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: This paper addresses harmonic pollution in lowvoltage distribution networks caused by residential EV charging piles in urban communities. The harmonic generation mechanism of charger front-end rectifiers is analyzed, and a multi-source, data-driven framework is established to characterize operating conditions and evaluate harmonic risk. On this basis, an FPGAoriented real-time detection and compensation strategy is designed, and a three-phase shunt active filter is modeled and tested in an electromagnetic transient simulation environment. Results show that the proposed scheme significantly reduces current and voltage distortion at the point of common coupling while maintaining reasonable device capacity and life-cycle cost. The electromagnetic transient simulation and harmonic analysis were conducted in MATLAB and PSCAD, enabling reproducible experimental configuration and model reconstruction for further research.

title: Addressing Shading Challenges: An Improved Carpet Weaver Optimization MPPT Method for Effective Tracking in Shaded Circumstances
authors: Bouguerra Assala, Badoud Abd Essalam, Mekheilef Saad, Abdelhak Samir Douli, Belkacem Ould Bouamama, Mahdi Boukerdja
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: Partial shading in solar energy systems presents a significant challenge for traditional maximum power point tracking (MPPT) methods, which often fail to identify the global maximum power point (GMPP) due to the presence of many local maxima in the power-voltage (P-V) curve. This paper introduces a novel modified metaheuristic-inspired Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) method, called the Carpet Weaver Optimization Approach (CWOA), specifically developed to enhance tracking efficiency in shaded settings. The proposed method employs a specific metaheuristic strategy to dynamically analyze the P-V curve and precisely distinguish between local and global maxima. The method utilizes dynamic discovery processes to ensure rapid convergence to the global maximum, regardless of differing shading patterns. Comparative simulation results indicate that the improved CWOA-based method significantly outperforms with an average efficiency of 98.09% and a mean tracking time of 0.86 seconds compared to traditional and other metaheuristic MPPT techniques, such as Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) and the Arithmetic Optimization Algorithm (AOA), showcasing enhanced tracking accuracy, swift response times, and increased power output. This work introduces an innovative method to augment the performance of photovoltaic systems in complex shadowing conditions, thereby raising the dependability and efficiency of solar energy extraction.

title: Face Recognition Based on Triangle Model Background Removal and DCT Pyramid decomposition
authors: Badreddine Alane, Djabir Mosbah, Leila Hellal
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: This study introduces a face recognition system that leverages a Triangle Model for background elimination, Discrete Cosine Transform (DCT) pyramid decomposition for feature extraction, and statistical analysis for dimensionality reduction, with classification handled by an artificial neural network (ANN). The Triangle Model focuses exclusively on the facial region by filtering out non-essential background content. Next, the DCT pyramid decomposes the image into multiple frequency levels, capturing detailed structural information. Statistical metrics, including mean, variance, and entropy, are applied to the low-frequency components, ensuring a compact feature representation. The refined features are then fed into a neural network, which is trained through backpropagation to classify different subjects accurately. Comprehensive evaluations on benchmark datasets such as ORL, Yale, and AR dataset demonstrate the system's effectiveness in achieving both high recognition accuracy and computational efficiency. Its strong performance across varying facial conditions confirms the suitability of the proposed method for practical face recognition applications.

title: Evaluation of Security and Usability in Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA): A Multi-Objective Optimization of YubiKey Integration Using Pareto Front and MCDM-AHP
authors: A. Aguilar, R. Polancos
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Aiming for an optimal equilibrium between security and usability presents a significant challenge in the implementation of hardware authentication devices, such as YubiKey, within cybersecurity frameworks. This delicate balance can be refined through methodologies including Pareto Front, Multi-Criteria Decision Making (MCDM), and the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP). This study investigates the application of these optimization strategies to strengthen both security and usability of a YubiKey, thereby mitigating risks while ensuring seamless user engagement. By adopting a systems-based approach, principles from industrial engineering are utilized to model, evaluate, and enhance the deployment of YubiKey across diverse industries, effectively addressing usability gaps without sacrificing security.

title: Research on Model Predictive Current Control Strategies for Dual Three-Phase Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motors
authors: Ze Li, Xiaodong Yao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: To overcome the high computational load and current tracking inaccuracies in conventional dual three-phase permanent magnet synchronous motor (DTP-PMSM) predictive control, this paper proposes an improved strategy (IMPROVEDMPCC) that enhances tracking precision while substantially reducing computational demands. A $\mathbf{1 5}^{\boldsymbol{\circ}}$ phase-shifted virtual voltage vector is designed to mitigate phase tracking deviation. Under steady-state conditions, candidate vectors are limited to the previous cycle’s optimal vector and its two adjacent vectors, reducing comparisons from 24 to 3 via sequential cost function evaluation. Simulations verify that the method maintains steadystate performance while significantly reducing computation time.

title: BookReconciler: An Open-Source Tool for Metadata Enrichment and Work-Level Clustering
authors: Matthew Miller, Dan Sinykin, Melanie Walsh
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries (JCDL)
abstract: We present BookReconciler , an open-source tool for enhancing and clustering book data. BookReconcilerallows users to take spreadsheets with minimal metadata, such as book title and author, and automatically 1)add authoritative, persistent identifiers like ISBNs 2)and cluster related Expressions and Manifestations of the same Work, e.g., different translations or editions. This enhancement makes it easier to combine related collections and analyze books at scale. The tool is currently designed as an extension for OpenRefine-a popular software application-and connects to major bibliographic services includ- ing the Library of Congress, VIAF, OCLC, HathiTrust, Google Books, and Wikidata. Our approach prioritizes human judgment. Through an interactive interface, users can manually evaluate matches and define the contours of a Work(e.g, to include translations or not).We evaluate reconciliation performance on datasets of U.S.prize-winning books and contemporary world fiction. BookReconcilerachieves near-perfect accuracy for U.S.works but lower performance for global texts, reflecting structural weaknesses in bibliographic infrastructures for non- English and global literature. Overall, BookReconciler supports the reuse of bibliographic data across domains and applications, contributing to ongoing work in digital libraries and digital humanities.

title: LLM-Based Active Learning for Identifying References to Archival Repositories
authors: Tokinori Suzuki
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries (JCDL)
abstract: Information about the contents of archival repositories can sometimes be found in the footnotes or endnotes of scholarly papers. In the field of history, these footnotes and endnotes are not standardized, sometimes providing more or less detailed descriptions. Identifying which footnotes and endnotes refer to archival repositories provides a foundation for subsequent mining tasks, such as analyzing the context in which specific archives are referenced. Archival references are relatively rare, occurring in about 1% of footnotes and endnotes in History papers, books, and theses. This sparsity, combined with the variable writing styles, makes it difficult to train a robust identifier for archival references. To address this, we propose an efficient sampling method using active learning together with large language models. Experiments demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms existing approaches based on support vector machines.

title: Research on Design and Control Methods of High-Efficiency De-icing Device for Substation Equipment
authors: Guangpu Wang, Fei Xiong, Dong Liang, Yuxin Zhang, Xinran Wang, Ligang Quan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: To effectively address the negative impact of substation equipment icing on the safe and stable operation of the power system in cold winter regions, this paper studies the design and control methods of efficient de-icing devices for substation equipment. First, this paper designs a new type of mechanical structure for a substation de-icing device. Through the compact arrangement and coordinated cooperation of various components, the de-icing device can achieve smooth and precise operation and flexible adjustment at multiple angles in the confined space of the substation, effectively improving the de-icing efficiency and practicality of the device. Secondly, this paper proposes a pose control strategy for the de-icing device based on iterative learning and the fuzzy PID controller. This effectively improves the refined control capability of the de-icing device, enabling precise, flexible, and efficient coordinated control of the lateral and longitudinal motions of the substation de-icing device. Finally, simulation analysis is conducted to verify the proposed de-icing device control method. The results show that the proposed control method has better control performance than traditional control methods.

title: Integration Framework for Contamination Control and Automation: A Multidomain DSM for Mini-Environments in Battery Manufacturing
authors: M. Heller, H. Y. Liao, S. Wessel
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: The implementation of mini-environments (MiE) for battery cell production (BCP) addresses increased challenges such as high production costs, elevated scrap rates and employee safety risks. To tackle these problems, this paper presents a Multidomain Design Structure Matrix (MDSM) that enables a transparent, reproducible and efficient integration process for MiE by systematically modeling the interdependencies between requirements and technological domains. The MDSM framework links key stakeholders including climate control, equipment engineering and BCP at both technical and project levels, thus fostering cross-domain alignment and integration. As an application case, the methodology is implemented in a project to develop a best-practice mini-environment, considering modular climate control systems and an innovative two-stage sealing airlock for contamination-free, just-in-time material transfer via autonomous mobile robots. The findings reveal the complex interdependencies on module level, support the development of complex MiE systems and yield clear design recommendations. The results of this work provide important insights and pave the way for further scaling and validation of mini-environment systems.

title: Fully Liquid-Metal-Printed SnO₂ Thin-Film Transistors With Al₂O₃ Dielectrics
authors: Runtong Guo, Yu Song, Annan Du, Jean-Pierre Raskin, Denis Flandre, Benjamin Iñiguez, Lei Liao, Guoli Li

Through experimental characterization and TCAD simulations, we find that the overall device performance initially degrades below <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$310~^{\circ }$</tex-math> </inline-formula>C due to increased oxygen vacancy (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${V}_{O}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>) concentration but recovers at higher temperatures owing to the reduction in <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${V}_{O}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> concentration and crystallization-induced suppression of interface defects. The LMP-SnO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> TFTs on SiO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>/p<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">+</sup>-Si substrate annealed at <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$600~^{\circ }$</tex-math> </inline-formula>C achieve a field-effect mobility of 10.35 cm<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${}^{{2}} \cdot $</tex-math> </inline-formula>V<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${}^{\text {-1}} \cdot $</tex-math> </inline-formula>s<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${}^{\text {-1}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>. The performance is further improved by implementing the LMP-Al<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>O<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub> gate dielectric, yielding a subthreshold swing (SS) of 654mV/dec and a threshold voltage of 0.95 V. Finally, a functional zero-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$V$</tex-math> </inline-formula> <sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">GS</sub>-load nMOS inverter unit, comprising both depletion and enhancement mode SnO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> TFTs, demonstrates the potential application of this LMP technique for integrated circuits. This work establishes a novel strategy for fabricating high-performance metal–oxide TFTs and circuits via fully LMP-based manufacturing.

title: POLARIS: Cross-Domain Access Control via Verifiable Identity and Policy-Based Authorization
authors: Aiyao Zhang, Xiaodong Lee, Zhixian Zhuang, Jiuqi Wei, Yufan Fu, Botao Peng
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Access control is a security mechanism designed to ensure that only authorized users can access specific resources. Cross-domain access control involves access to resources across different organizations, institutions, or applications. Traditional access control, however, which handles authentication and authorization separately in centralized environments, faces challenges in identity dispersion, privacy leakage, and diversified permission requirements, failing to adapt to cross-domain scenarios. Thus, there is an urgent need for a new access control mechanism that empowers autonomous control over user identity and resources, addressing the demands for privacy-preserving authentication and flexible authorization in cross-domain scenarios.To address cross-domain access control challenges, we propose POLARIS, a unified and extensible architecture that enables policy-based, verifiable and privacy-preserving access control across different domains. POLARIS features a structured commitment mechanism for reliable, fine-grained, policy-based identity disclosure. It further introduces VPPL, a lightweight policy language that supports issuer-bound evaluation of selectively revealed attributes. A dedicated session-level security mechanism ensures binding between authentication and access, enhancing confidentiality and resilience to replay attacks.We implement a working prototype and conduct comprehensive experiments, demonstrating that POLARIS effectively provides scalable, privacy-preserving, and interoperable access control across heterogeneous domains. Our results highlight the practical viability of POLARIS for enabling secure and privacy-preserving access control in decentralized, cross-domain environments.

title: DPDA: Decentralized Identity-Based Privacy-Preserving Data Aggregation for AIoT
authors: Can Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: The rapid development of Artificial Intelligence of Things (AIoT) has enabled widespread applications. Data aggregation is the typical scenario in AIoT that leverages the sensors and edge computing powers of IoT devices for training data collection and distributed model training. However, data aggregation in AIoT faces several security and privacy challenges that compromise the security and reliability. To address these issues, this paper proposes DPDA, a Decentralized Identity (DID)-based privacy-preserving data aggregation scheme for AIoT. DPDA utilizes DID and Paillier-based cryptosystem to ensure authenticity with privacy protection. Thorough analyses and experimental evaluations have proved that DPDA achieves confidentiality, source anonymity, and authentication, with low computational and communication overheads.

title: Quench Protection in Insulated REBCO Conductors: Design Optimization and Fast Detection via REBCO SQD
authors: Hajar Zgour, Walid Abdel Maksoud, Bertrand Baudouy, Antoine Guinet
abstract: This work was conducted within the framework of the exploratory French project PEPR SupraFusion, which aims to advance the field of fusion energy by developing High-Temperature Superconductor (HTS)-based demonstrators capable of storing significant energy while operating under high magnetic fields and currents. Ensuring a reliable protection during a quench in Insulated REBCO conductors is challenging : slow normal-zone propagation and validation delays allow the hotspot's temperature to reach damaging levels. We compare (i) conductor protection via copper-stabilizer optimization and (ii) a co-wound, REBCO superconducting quench detector (SQD) that is electrically isolated yet thermally coupled and intentionally deoxygenated to lower <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$T_{c}$</tex-math></inline-formula> and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$I_{c}$</tex-math></inline-formula> for an earlier transition. One-dimensional THEA modeling shows that a good choice of stabilizer cross-section makes the protection possible during quench events by keeping the temperature of the hotspot within a safe limit. The simulations also demonstrate that the use of a REBCO SQD enables the quench detection at lower temperatures.

title: Causal-Inspired Unsupervised Dynamic-Attribute Feature Disentanglement Network for HRRP Target Recognition
authors: Fan Zhang, Yuelei Xu, Huafeng Li, Wei Luo, Chunjia Zhu, Sijia Xia, Zhaoxiang Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: High-Resolution Range Profile (HRRP), which contains rich discriminative information about targets, is widely used in radar automatic target recognition. However, the aspect sensitivity of HRRP data limits recognition performance in scenarios with missing or varying aspects, while noise and other disturbances also distort HRRP waveforms, impairing recognition. To address these issues, inspired by causal theory, this paper proposes an HRRP target recognition framework comprising an Unsupervised Dynamic-Attribute Feature Disentanglement Network (UDAFD-Net) and an HRRP Recognition Network (HRRP-RecNet) in cascade. UDAFD-Net employs an asymmetric variational inference architecture to decompose HRRP sequence samples into dynamic features (related to aspect variations, noise, and other disturbances) and attribute features (solely linked to target types). A counterfactual regularization constraint is integrated into the Evidence Lower Bound (ELBO) loss to block spurious correlations between dynamic and attribute features, ensuring their independence. Finally, the disentangled attribute features and their corresponding type labels are used to train HRRP-RecNet, ensuring that recognition results depend only on the target's intrinsic attributes, free from irrelevant factors. Experiments on the aircraft electromagnetic simulation dataset and the measured dataset demonstrate that the proposed method achieves higher accuracy and stronger robustness in HRRP target recognition without requiring any aspect labels or prior knowledge of disturbances.

title: Bidirectional Cross-Modal Collaborative Alignment via Semantic-Guided Visual Embeddings for Partially Relevant Video Retrieval
authors: Huafeng Li, Jialong Zhao, Yafei Zhang, Jie Wen
abstract: Partially Relevant Video Retrieval (PRVR) aims to retrieve videos that match a given textual query only partially. This task is inherently challenging due to the modality gap between text and video, which is further exacerbated by the partial semantic correspondence between linguistic descriptions and visual content. To address these challenges, we propose a bidirectional cross-modal alignment mechanism that collaboratively optimizes both visual and textual modalities. In the visual modality, a major difficulty lies in the absence of visual cues that directly correspond to textual semantics, limiting the models ability to align visual representations with textual meanings under unsupervised conditions. To overcome this issue, we construct a semantic-visual association library, which stores paired visual and textual features with semantic annotations. During training, the model dynamically retrieves the most semantically similar visual samples from this library based on the current visual feature vector. These retrieved samples, preliminarily associated with semantics via cross-modal matching, are used to form dynamic anchors that guide visual representation learning. By leveraging these enriched visual features, the model progressively refines the visual representations to achieve better alignment with the corresponding textual inputs, thereby enhancing cross-modal consistency. In the textual modality, we enhance textual representations by integrating semantically aligned visual features selected from the same association library, further narrowing the modality gap. Extensive experiments on benchmark datasets under partial semantic correspondence scenarios demonstrate that our method achieves state-of-the-art performance. The source code of the paper is available at https://github.com/cyanlll/BOA.

title: CL-GIE v4.0: Blockchain-Anchored Cross-Layer Genomic Integrity with Hierarchical Bloom–Merkle Trees for Ethics-Aware, Explainable Personalized Gene Editing
authors: C Prabakaran, Kannadasan Rajendran
abstract: Personalized gene editing demands verifiable integrity, governance-aware decisioning, and forensics-grade auditability across heterogeneous evidence sources (CRISPR logs, phenotype outcomes, and ledger records). We present CL-GIE v4.0, a cross-layer genomic integrity evaluator that fuses: (i) a Hierarchical Bloom–Merkle Tree (HBMT) for O(log N) membership proofs and vertical consistency; (ii) an entropy–KL drift channel that detects distributional shifts across temporal, phenotypic, and edit-type features; (iii) lightweight structural checks (timestamp monotonicity, hash replay); and (iv) an interpretable ethics policy engine. HBMT yields succinct proofs (depth ≈ 14 on our test set) with verified roots, enabling forensics-ready attestations and chain anchoring. CL-GIE operates under tight latency budgets: per-record HBMT verification is ∼0.02 ms, while meta-model scoring remains sub-millisecond, sustaining real-time pipelines. Empirically, CL-GIE surpasses one-class, reconstruction, clustering, and rules baselines. A stacked variant attains state-of-the-art ROC (AUC= 0.991), while isotonic meta-calibration maximizes area under the precision–recall curve (AP = 0.852), reflecting robustness at low prevalence. Confusion matrices corroborate high recall and specificity (e.g., stacked: TP = 480, FN = 23, TN = 9398, FP = 99), aligning with clinical detection priorities and low false-positive exposure. An ablation-driven weight sweep shows that ethics signals and cross-layer drift are pivotal at the optimal operating point, with validation F1≈0.81–0.88 across calibrated and stacked settings. Radar and correlation analyses further indicate balanced gains across AUROC, AUPR, F1, specificity, and calibration metrics. Overall, CL-GIE delivers a principled, explainable, and audit-capable integrity layer for ethically governed gene-editing workflows, unifying cryptographic proofs, drift-aware detection, and policy transparency under a single evaluative framework.
