title: Polarization-Crosstalk-Tolerant Baud-Rate Timing Recovery for Coherent Optical Interconnects
authors: Siyu Gong, Qian Xiang, Yanfu Yang, Linsheng Fan, Yongchao Jin, Chen Cheng, Pengxi Yang, Jianwei Tang, Qun Zhang, Tianjian Zuo
abstract: Baud-rate sampling offers significant reductions in power consumption and implementation complexity for coherent data center interconnects (DCIs), but imposes stricter requirements on timing recovery. In this paper, we propose a polarization- crosstalk-tolerant baud-rate timing recovery scheme, termed nonlinear Mueller & Müller (NL-MM), tailored for coherent DCIs. By introducing a smooth nonlinear function into the timing error detector (TED), the proposed scheme alleviates the performance degradation observed in conventional sign-MM schemes under polarization crosstalk. Simulation results confirm strong robustness across various conditions, including polarization angle variations, phase rotations, amplified spontaneous emission (ASE) noise, and different normalized loop bandwidths (NLBWs). Specifically, the proposed scheme resolves the failure of sign-MM under severe polarization mixing, which causes distorted signal distributions and introduces multiple zero-crossings in the S-curve of the sign-MM, leading to incorrect timing lock positions. At a polarization angle of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$45^\circ$</tex-math></inline-formula>, it achieves a reduction in timing mean square error (MSE) of up to 37 dB compared to sign-MM. Experimental validation is conducted using a 70 km 118 Gbaud polarization-multiplexed 16QAM system. Under small NLBW, the proposed scheme incurs only a 0.8 dB OSNR penalty relative to an improved Gardner scheme (at 2 SPS). Under large NLBW, it delivers OSNR gains of 3.62 dB and 0.37 dB over the sign-MM and improved Gardner schemes, respectively, due to significantly reduced timing jitter. These results demonstrate the robustness and practical effectiveness of the proposed scheme for polarization- and phase-impaired coherent optical links.

title: Dashboard Development and Aspect-Based Sentiment Analysis for a Case-study Tour Operator in Thailand
authors: P. Chavalpatanapan, P. Phlaingam, N. Phumchusri
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: This paper presents the development of a data-driven analytical dashboard and the application of aspect-based sentiment analysis (ABSA) for a tour operator in Thailand. Phase 1 involved building an interactive dashboard using Looker Studio to monitor key business areas such as financials, customer origins, agent performance, and tour metrics. Visual tools like bar charts, line graphs, and word clouds supported decision-making, with secure access for sensitive data. User feedback confirmed its value in operational and strategic planning. Phase 2 applied ABSA to 14,709 TripAdvisor reviews using pre-trained language models. Reviews were categorized by five aspects—Food, Guide, Itinerary, Tuk Tuk, and Value for Money—with sentiment classified via RoBERTa. Results showed high customer satisfaction across all areas. The combined approach enhances service quality, resource planning, and customer insights for competitive advantage of the case-study company.

title: Uplink-Downlink Resource Optimization for STAR-RIS-Assisted ISCC Networks with NOMA
authors: Yangyang Xi, Yu Xu, Dingcheng Yang, Fahui Wu, Lin Xiao, Tiankui Zhang
abstract: To address the waste of spectrum resources caused by the separate operation of integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) and mobile edge computing (MEC), the integrated sensing, communication, and computing (ISCC) paradigm has been proposed. However ISCC systems are still facing serious channel fading and obstacle occlusion problems, which are expected to be solved by the emerging simultaneously transmitting and reflecting reconfigurable intelligent surface (STAR-RIS). In this paper, we propose a STAR-RIS-assisted ISCC framework, where the computational tasks from users are offloaded to a base station (BS) for processing with the assistance of a STAR-RIS, and the results are subsequently downloaded back to the corresponding users. Notably, target sensing operation is executed concurrently throughout the process of result downloading. To enhance communication efficiency, the non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) scheme is incorporated. The number of offloading bits of users is maximized by optimizing the uplink-downlink resource of the network, including the received beamforming vector, active beamforming vector, time slot, phase shift of STAR-RIS, and computational resource. In order to solve the highly complex non-convex problem, we employ the block coordinate descent (BCD) framework to decompose the proposed problem into three subproblems. The convex-concave procedure (CCCP) method is used to deal with the nonconvex constraints. For the rank-1 constraints, the semidefinite relaxation (SDR) approach and the penalty method are invoked. The numerical results show that: 1) the application of STAR-RIS significantly improves the offloading capability of the network, 2) the NOMA scheme significantly outperforms the orthogonal multiple access (OMA) scheme, and 3) comparing with other benchmark schemes, the proposed algorithm significantly improves the overall network performance.

title: DTAHF-Net: Domain-Trust Alignment and Hierarchical Fusion for Multimodal Fake News Detection
authors: Lexin Feng, Jiayin Wei, Youjun Lu, Fujian Feng
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: The pervasive presence of multimodal fake news significantly threatens network trustworthiness and information security, which urgently demands the development of advanced detection methodologies. However, existing methods encounter considerable challenges: (1) the complexity of integrating multi-granularity information and mitigating domain biases amplified by pretrained models; (2) the heterogeneity and inconsistency of domain-specific trust standards; (3) the formidable difficulty in migrating and aligning cross-modal trust, especially when handling modality conflicts and discrepancies; and (4) inadequate assurance of security and trustworthiness in information fusion mechanisms. To address these issues, this paper introduces DTAHF-Net, a novel framework for Domain-Trust Alignment and Hierarchical Fusion for Multimodal Fake News Detection. DTAHF-Net begins by extracting multi-granularity features via BERT, MAE, and CLIP. It subsequently incorporates an Adaptive Domain Trust Representation Layer for dynamic adaptation to domain-specific trustworthiness, followed by a Cross-Domain Trust Alignment Module employing consistency detection and contrastive learning for robust trust migration and alignment. Finally, a Secure Multi-View Fusion Layer with domain-adaptive gating enables trustworthy hierarchical fusion. Empirical evaluations conducted on three real-world datasets, encompassing both Chinese and English news, demonstrate that DTAHF-Net significantly outperforms state-of-the-art baseline models (e.g., MMDFND), achieving accuracy and F1-score improvements of 1.9% and 1.5%, respectively.

title: Improving the SEU Reliability of TMR Designs Implemented on SRAM-Based FPGAs with Redundant Module Restructuring
authors: Chidan Zhu, Jingjing Hu, Yuanhang Sun, Yu Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: To deploy SRAM-based FPGAs as platforms for aerospace applications, the reliability of designs should be ensured, since FPGAs are susceptible to radiation-induced single-event upsets (SEUs). SEUs can cause configuration corruption and further functional failure. Triple modular redundancy (TMR) is often used to mitigate this risk. However, common mode failure, which is an inherent flaw of the traditional TMR architecture, limits the effectiveness of mitigating SEUs. Therefore, aiming at CPU-centric TMR systems, we propose an approach to restructure the redundant modules in the TMR architecture. Three instruction set architecture (ISA)-heterogeneous CPUs, which are functionally equivalent, introduce difference into the utilization of configuration memory, and thus eliminate the common mode failure. Further, we propose an analytical method based on Markov model to estimate the SEU reliability for both TMR architectures, and efficiently prove the SEU reliability improvement of the ISA-heterogeneous TMR architecture. Finally, by investigating the derived SEU reliability, we offer guidance on how to design an ISA-heterogeneous TMR system to realize higher reliability.

title: Research on Power Measurement Algorithm for Voltage Sag Based on Db4 Wavelet Packet Transform
authors: Yu Su, Yingying Cheng, Tao Cheng, Wenli Chen, Min He, Feili Yang, Wenbo Yao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Voltage sag, as a typical power quality issue in ultrahigh voltage direct current (UHVDC) transmission systems, can cause sampling distortion and algorithm failure of power metering devices, thereby introducing significant measurement errors and seriously affecting the fairness of power trade settlements. Aiming at the limitations of the traditional Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) in processing transient signals such as voltage sag, this paper proposes an improved power measurement algorithm based on Db4 wavelet packet transform. Firstly, the influence mechanism of voltage sag on power measurement is analyzed, and a mathematical model of power error during sag is established. Subsequently, based on the wavelet multi-resolution decomposition theory, a wavelet packet transform signal processing model is constructed to effectively separate fundamental and distorted components through signal decomposition and reconstruction. Finally, simulation experiments are conducted to verify the algorithm performance. Two types of voltage sag signals (single variation and composite variation) are set up, and the measurement accuracy of fundamental power and distorted power is compared and analyzed. The results show that the algorithm achieves a measurement accuracy of the order of $10^{-2}$ under complex sag signal conditions, which can effectively extract sag characteristics, suppress measurement errors caused by transient interference, and provide technical support for high-precision power measurement under transient operating conditions of UHVDC transmission systems.

title: VLAH: A Lightweight and Verifiable Framework for Approximate Nearest Neighbor Search in High-Dimensional Space
authors: Yiping Teng, Yuyao Tang, Gang Wang, Shiqing Wang, Changze Li, Liang Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: The Approximate Nearest Neighbor (ANN) search is a cornerstone in high-dimensional data processing, which, however, remains challenging in outsourced scenarios due to potential result and data tampering. Recent studies on verifiable search have partially offered verification guarantees, while they suffer from limited scalability or fail to address result integrity simultaneously. In this paper, we propose VLAH, a lightweight and verifiable framework for ANN search. VLAH integrates locality-sensitive hashing with a compressed trie structure for efficient bucket verification and employs the in-bucket HNSW index to accelerate candidate retrieval. To ensure result integrity, we design a hybrid verification object that combines Merkle-based prefix proofs, neighbor-bucket consistency, and graph search trace validation. By integrating blockchain technology, we further enhance the integrity of the scheme. We theoretically analyze the complexity of our scheme and the correctness and integrity guarantees of the query results in lightweight verification. Experimental results on real high-dimensional datasets show that VLAH achieves competitive search performance with significantly reduced verification costs, bridging the gap between efficiency and verifiability in large-scale ANN systems.

title: Whether to Implement and How to Improve Drone Delivery Services: A Strategic Two-Echelon Location-Allocation-Fleet-Sizing Perspective
authors: Yating Feng, Zhiyu Xiang, Kexin Cao, Maohua Cai, Xinglu Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: This study evaluates the financial viability of drone-enabled delivery services through a strategic optimization framework addressing critical investment challenges. We define the studied problem as a two-echelon system incorporating three interdependent decisions: joint location optimization of automated kiosks and drone launchpads, two-step allocation (kiosk-launchpad and launchpad-demand area), and launchpad-specific drone fleet sizing. The problem is initially formulated as a profit-maximizing mixed-integer nonlinear program, which is then equivalently reformulated into a mixed-integer linear program to efficiently optimize the relevant decisions while ensuring computational traceability. Extensive numerical experiments based on Shenzhen data reveal that optimal deployment strategies yield stable profit margins of approximately 14–15%, providing quantitative validation of the economic potential of drone-based delivery systems. We also derive several valuable strategic insights based on the results. These insights reveal that in early-stage operations, enhancing infrastructure density is an effective strategy, while in more mature phases, stimulating demand becomes the key to further profitability growth. Additionally, profit volume is mainly driven by launchpad deployments (enabling service coverage), whereas profit margin is governed by the spatial efficiency (i.e., the deployments) of kiosk layouts (influencing delivery costs). Together, these findings offer practical and valuable guidance on whether and how to implement drone delivery systems, contributing to the ongoing development of the low-altitude logistics economy.

title: Enhancing Data Security in RISC-V Embedded Systems: A Lightweight Architecture
authors: Dunkai Mao, Lifeng Xi, Fujia Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Ensuring robust, hardware-level data security has become an urgent challenge, driven by the proliferation of Reduced Instruction Set Computer (RISC-V) architectures in resource-constrained embedded systems. This paper focuses on key security aspects such as memory safety and execution privilege control in embedded platforms. We present NanoSafe, a lightweight RV64IMAZicsr_Zifencei pipelined CPU architecture designed in-house. By designing a subset of interrupts/exceptions, integrating their handling process, and implementing a custom priority scheme, we have realized the necessary security mechanisms within this lightweight CPU structure. This design effectively thwarts attack primitives such as out-of-bounds memory access, illegal instruction execution, and privilege escalation. It is suitable for various application scenarios, including storage device controllers, low-power network devices, and educational platforms for computer architecture.

title: Smart Lighting and IoT Integration: Pioneering Solutions for Traffic Congestion Management – Case Study
authors: S. K. Lam, Y. K. Chan, C. C. Lee, W. F. Tang, S. L. Mak, K. W. Tsang, Y. Wang, Zhaobin Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: This study explores the integration of Smart Lighting and IoT technologies to address traffic congestion at drop-off areas of large public facilities. A Traffic Congestion Management System was designed and implemented on a 240-meter-long departure road in Hong Kong. The system utilizes laser-based occupancy sensors for high-accuracy detection, LED signage for dynamic driver guidance, and Power over Ethernet (PoE) technology for simplified installation and energy efficiency. Real-time data communication enables predictive analysis and preventative maintenance, ensuring optimal performance.Preliminary testing showed acceptable accuracy and precision, though a minor 2–4 second delay in LED sign activation was observed. Despite this, the system effectively improves traffic flow, reduces driver confusion, and minimizes delays. This study demonstrates the potential of Smart Lighting and IoT in traffic management and highlights opportunities for future research in Smart City applications.

title: Buckling-Based Self-Powered Sensor for Abnormal Temperature Monitoring
authors: K. Matsushita, H. Honma, A. Uesugi, K. Sugano, Y. Isono
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Micro and Miniature Power Systems, Self-Powered Sensors and Energy Autonomous Devices (PowerMEMS)
abstract: We developed a self-powered temperature sensor with an electrostatic parallel-plate bimetallic electrode that buckles at abnormal temperatures. An output of 148.8 µW was generated by electrostatic induction when the bimetallic electrode buckled at an abnormal temperature (85 °C), as determined by its dimensions. Temperature sensors in event-driven systems can be used to detect abnormal temperatures.

title: Research on Intelligent Defect Detection and Classification Method for Transmission Lines Based
authors: Shuai Guo, Xiangyu Zhao, Ruiye Zhou, Shang Cao, Huanming Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: This study aims to address the challenges of small target detection, complex background interference, and real-time performance requirements in transmission line defect detection. An improved intelligent recognition and classification method, YOLOv7-WiCo, based on YOLOv7, is proposed. The method enhances global feature extraction capabilities by embedding the Swin Transformer module, optimizes feature weights using the ECA-Net attention mechanism, and designs specialized anchor boxes to accommodate small targets. Additionally, Focal Loss and SIoU Loss are employed to tackle the issue of sample imbalance. Experimental results demonstrate that the model achieves a $\mathbf{m A P} \text{@} \mathbf{0. 5}$ of $\mathbf{8 1. 2 \%}$ (an improvement of $\mathbf{8. 7 \%}$ over the baseline), an inference speed of 98 FPS, and a small target defect detection accuracy of $85.3 \%$. The model maintains an accuracy rate of over $90 \%$ under different lighting conditions. This method effectively balances detection accuracy and speed, providing an integrated solution for defect recognition and damage classification, thus offering reliable technical support for intelligent operation and maintenance of transmission lines.

title: A Template Method for Installing State Inspection of Cable Harness Assembly Based on Residual Convolutional Neural Network
authors: Junfeng Wang, Shiwen Zhao, Cong Lu, Dongqing He, Xizhao Cao, Zhaoyong Zeng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: The installing status of cable harness seriously affect the quality of the mechatronic products. By analyzing the images of product assembly, a cable harness assembly error inspection method based on standard templates and residual convolutional neural network was proposed to address assembly issues such as missing plugs, missing clips, and poor consistency in laying paths of cables. Firstly, the process of cable assembly inspection method was introduced, which mainly included the standard template generation stage and the assembly error detection stage. Then, the generation process of the two templates for key components of cable harness and the standard cable laying path were elaborated based on the CAD model of the assembly. The key components template included the location information of the cable components. The laying path template included binary data of the cable path. A degree of overlap was proposed to check the consistency between cable design path and actual laying path. A simplified satellite assembly with cable harness was used to verify the proposed method and the effectiveness of the method was illustrated with the high precision.

title: Learning from LLM Disagreement in Retrieval Evaluation
authors: William A. Ingram, Bipasha Banerjee, Edward A. Fox
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries (JCDL)
abstract: Large language models (LLMs) are being integrated into information retrieval pipelines within digital library systems for tasks such as re-ranking and filtering. However, a challenge arises from the observed disagreement between different LLMs in borderline classification cases, raising concerns about how this variability impacts downstream retrieval and the integrity of digital library collections. This study examines disagreement between two open-weight LLMs, LLaMA and Qwen, when tasked with evaluating a corpus of scholarly abstracts based on their contribution to Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). We isolate subsets of documents where model disagreement occurs and examine their lexical properties, rank-order behavior, and classification predictability. Our results demonstrate that this model disagreement is not random: it concentrates in ambiguous cases, produces divergent top-k outputs under shared scoring functions, and is separable with AUCs above 0.74 using logistic regression. These findings suggest that LLM-based filtering introduces structured variability in document retrieval, even under controlled prompting and shared ranking logic. We propose using classification disagreement as an object of analysis in retrieval evaluation, particularly in subjective or thematic search tasks.

title: A Dual-Stage Anomaly Detection Framework for Stealthy Attacks in 5G Core Networks
authors: Xin Feng, Cong Li, Weizhi Meng, Zilong Wang, Xinsheng Ji
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: The N4 interface, which connects the Session Management Function (SMF) and the User Plane Function (UPF) via the PFCP protocol in the 5G core network, is vulnerable to attacks such as unauthorized access and signaling injection. These threats can lead to session interruptions and denial-of-service (DoS) attacks. Due to the stealthy nature of such anomalies, existing detection methods struggle with issues such as sample imbalance and ambiguous category boundaries. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a dual-stage anomaly detection framework based on the distribution characteristics of signaling. First, we statistically analyze the distributional differences between normal and abnormal PFCP signaling to uncover behavioral patterns and define precise categories of anomalies, each associated with a specific probabilistic model. Then, a Dual-Stage Abnormal Detection Framework (DSAF) is developed, integrating a KNN-based distance detector with a deep learning classifier to achieve hierarchical detection of abnormal signaling on the N4 interface. Experimental results on a real-world PFCP dataset demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms mainstream detection approaches in terms of accuracy, recall, and F1 score, providing solid theoretical and technical support for signaling security in 5G core networks.

title: Final Jump Impulses in Negative Stepped Leader Cloud to Ground Lightning
authors: Farouk A.M. Rizk
abstract: The paper constitutes a model of the final jump that occurs during the encounter between a negative downward stepped leader and an upward connecting leader in cloud to ground lightning. The gap is first covered by negative and positive streamers, followed by leader bridging. Voltage collapse yields substantial impulse current determined by both the gap and stepped leader characteristics. A model is formulated for the leader bridging and subsequent current impulse flow, during which the negative downward leader is simulated as a lossy transmission line. Within the range of variables investigated the following findings are reported. With neutral charge point in the cloud at a height of 4500 m, ambient ground field of 8 kV/m, a 10 m ground mast and prospective return stroke current in the range of 10-100 kA, the model resulted in final jump gaps in the range of 7-27 m. The average leader bridging speed is found to vary in the range of 5-16 m/μs. The final jump impulse current is evaluated in the 2-12 kA range corresponding to 10-20% of the subsequent prospective return stroke current. The final jump impulse current is therefore substantially larger than the preceding corona bursts. The input surge impedance of the downward leader at the instant of final jump varies in the range 1.6 kohm to 2.8 kohm. Results with a height of charge cloud point origin Hcs of 2500 m have been added and showed very significant increase in the final jump gap length and impulse current amplitude but a moderate reduction in the leader input surge impedance. The discharge phase of the final jump is therefore established as a distinct prerequisite for the formation of the return stroke. In principle the final jump impulse current can be measured on instrumented towers, discarding prior upward leader current and corona pulses from adjacent branches. It can also be estimated from remote electric field measurement, with due consideration to the specific speed of the resulting signal propagating along the stepped leader. In this paper whenever possible comparison of the model results with field measurement is made and found satisfactory.

title: A New Soil Moisture Retrieval with Considering the Underlying Surface Factors from CYGNSS
authors: Shuanggen Jin, Shuo Zhang, Qingyun Yan, Yan Jia, Zhounan Dong, Charafa El Rhadiouini
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Soil moisture is vital for studying hydrological processes, vegetation growth, and climate change. Recently, Global Navigation Satellite System-Reflectometry (GNSS-R) technology has shown great potential for soil moisture monitoring. However, most existing GNSS-R algorithms rely empirically on multiple land surface parameters, which increases model complexity and the risk of overfitting. This study investigates underlying surface influencing factors for soil moisture retrieval and developes a new soil moisture retrieval with considering the factors that influence the relationship between GNSS-R measurements and surface soil moisture, using Cyclone Global Navigation Satellite System (CYGNSS) data in the middle and lower reaches of the Yangtze River (23.5°N-35°N, 110°E-123°E). Monthly CYGNSS reflectivity and SMAP soil moisture data from 2019 to 2024 are analyzed with consideration of influencing factors such as elevation, slope, biomass, land use, tree height, and Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI). Results show the following key findings: (1) Reflectivity exhibits a significant correlation with soil moisture, with 84.05% displaying a positive correlation. (2) Over the six-year period from 2019 to 2024, the correlation between SMAP soil moisture and CYGNSS reflectivity shows clear seasonal variability, with lower correlations in spring and autumn and higher correlations in summer and winter, peaking in summer. (3) Geodetector analysis revealed that land use had the most significant effect on soil moisture in the single-factor analysis, while biomass and reflectivity had the strongest interaction in the two-factor analysis, characterized by nonlinear enhancement. (4) A retrieval scheme was designed based on the influencing factors, and its accuracy was validated using the eXtreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) machine learning algorithm. The root mean square error (RMSE) of the soil moisture retrieval using all selected features was 0.0526 cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>. The major feature group achieved an RMSE of 0.0527 cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>, while the minor feature group yielded an RMSE of 0.0611 cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>. Spatial RMSE analysis further demonstrated the effectiveness of Geodetector in guiding feature selection. The retrieval results were further validated using the SSM V2.0 high-resolution soil moisture product, which has been extensively evaluated against in situ measurements, demonstrating strong consistency and confirming the robustness and practical applicability of the proposed method.

title: Context-Based URL Classification for Open Access Datasets and Software in Scholarly Documents
authors: Lamia Salsabil, Rochana R. Obadage, Bipasha Banerjee, Yasasi Abeysinghe, Sawood Alam, Michael Färber, William Ingram, Edward Fox, Jian Wu
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries (JCDL)
abstract: This study presents a novel framework for automatically classifying open-access datasets and software (OADS) URLs in scholarly documents. Accurate classification of OADS-URLs is the first step in investigating the availability and preservability of OADS, a crucial step toward open science and computational reproducibility. Our framework, EnSU, leverages an ensemblebased approach to classify OADS-URLs by their citation contexts. The ensemble integrates three models: a Supervised Contrastive Learning model, a SciBERT-based model, and a BertGCN model. Our framework distinguishes the resource types (dataset vs. software) and providers (author vs. third-party). To train and evaluate EnSU, we compiled a dataset, OADS-1K, comprising 1,129 manually annotated sentences containing URLs along with their expanded contexts. Our model outperforms all baseline classifiers, including a large language model-based approach, with the best F 1 -score of 90%. The dataset and source code are publicly available at: https://github.com/lamps-lab/EnSU/tree/main.

title: CyberNER: A Harmonized STIX Corpus for Cybersecurity Named Entity Recognition
authors: Yasir Ech-Chammakhy, Anas Motii, Anass Rabii, Oussama Azrara, Jaafar Chbili
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Extracting structured intelligence via Named Entity Recognition (NER) is critical for cybersecurity, but the proliferation of datasets with incompatible annotation schemas hinders the development of comprehensive models. While combining these resources is desirable, we empirically demonstrate that naively concatenating them results in a noisy label space that severely degrades model performance. To overcome this critical limitation, we introduce CyberNER, a large-scale, unified corpus created by systematically harmonizing four prominent datasets (CyNER, DNRTI, APTNER, and Attacker) onto the STIX 2.1 standard. Our principled methodology resolves semantic ambiguities and consolidates over 50 disparate source tags into 21 coherent entity types. Our experiments show that models trained on CyberNER achieve a substantial performance gain, with a relative F1-score improvement of approximately 30% over the naive concatenation baseline. By publicly releasing the CyberNER corpus, we provide a crucial, standardized benchmark that enables the creation and rigorous comparison of more robust and generalizable entity extraction models for the cybersecurity domain.

title: Unmanned Aerial Vehicle-Assisted Inspection for Transportation Infrastructure Operation and Maintenance: A Review
authors: Xinyu Mei, Feng Xu, Zhipeng Zhang, Yongshuang Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Operation and maintenance (O&M) play a pivotal role in ensuring the safety and performance stability of transportation infrastructure, with effectiveness being a core objective in infrastructure management. Unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV), distinguished by its efficiency, safety, and high-precision inspection capabilities, demonstrates significant potential in transportation infrastructure O&M inspection, thereby replacing time- and labor-intensive manual inspection practices. This paper undertakes a comprehensive review of studies focusing on the inspection of various transportation infrastructure types utilizing UAVs during the O&M phase. The research employs a two-pronged approach: first, conducting a bibliometric analysis to identify research hotspots and developmental trends in the field; second, adopting a content-based analysis across three key dimensions—inspection objects, inspection methodologies, and inspection planning strategies. The results underscore the critical need for the development of multimodal data fusion technologies and dynamic UAV path planning approaches. This study contributed to deepening the understanding of the current progress and obstacles in UAV-based infrastructure O&M inspection and providing valuable insights for guiding future research directions, ultimately fostering the advancement of smarter and more sustainable transportation infrastructure management.

title: TVF-EMD with Parameter Optimization for Rolling Bearing Signal Denoising under Strong Noise Interference
authors: Mingyu Shen, Lixiang Duan, Na Zhang, Nafei Wang, Shuang Cai
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Under high-speed, heavy-load conditions, rolling bearing vibration signals face strong noise interference, complicating fault feature extraction due to mode mixing and noise residuals in traditional noise reduction methods. To tackle this issue, an adaptive TVF-EMD noise reduction method is proposed. A non-uniform B-spline time-varying filter dynamically tracks signal time-varying characteristics via cutoff frequency to suppress mode mixing. The Aquila Optimizer optimizes TVF-EMD’s bandwidth threshold and B-spline order, using the correlation coefficient of kurtosis as the fitness function to enhance decomposition accuracy. The JADE algorithm eliminates noise residuals in effective components, overcoming limitations of traditional single-channel noise reduction. Simulations show a 13.09 dB signal-to-noise ratio improvement under -15 dB strong noise interference. After noise reduction, the test signal’s envelope spectral eigenfrequency discrimination is significantly improved, offering an effective reference for bearing fault diagnosis.

title: Robust Unsupervised Video Foreground Segmentation via Penalized Bayesian Tensor Factorization
authors: Shenghao Xia, Yinwei Zhang, Biao Zhang, Jian Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Video foreground segmentation plays an essential role in separating moving objects from the background in video processing. It is challenging, especially when the video background is noisy and non-stationary. Tensor factorization has been widely adopted in foreground detection under static backgrounds owing to its efficacy in handling complex high-dimensional data, such as color images and videos. However, conventional tensor factorization is incapable of uncertainty quantification and foreground segmentation under a non-stationary background. To address this limitation, penalized Bayesian tensor factorization (PBTF) is proposed in this work to enhance the robustness of foreground segmentation under non-stationary background by explicitly leveraging temporal characteristics of the foreground into the segmentation, and to measure the uncertainty by considering the distributions of the tensor factorization model parameters. Its superior performance over state-of-the-art methods is demonstrated through multiple real-world case studies.

title: Deep Embedded Clustering (DEC)-based Chip Defect Map Classification and Machine Learning based Fab Data Imputation
authors: J. E. Ahn, D. A. Sun Ahn, H. G. Kim, K. W. Lee, M. G. Choi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: To improve semiconductor yield and quality, it is critical to both identify diverse defect patterns within each chip and ensure the consistency of process data for reliable defect analysis and yield prediction. Traditionally, defect map classification methods were limited to predefined defect types and specific fail grades, making it impossible to extract defect occurrence indices for newly emerging patterns in new products. Engineers had no choice but to manually review and count such defects chip by chip—a process impractical for high-volume production. Meanwhile, missing process data is often ignored or filled using simple statistics such as mean or median, reducing analysis accuracy. This paper proposes an integrated machine learning framework to automate chip defect map clustering and process data imputation. We utilize Deep Embedded Clustering (DEC) to classify multiple defect types per chip without predefined labels, learning latent representations from text-based fail grade and spatial data. Experimental results show the proposed models significantly improve classification speed, accuracy, and imputation fidelity, enabling real-time defect monitoring and process optimization even for new products and evolving chip designs.

title: End of Term Web Archive Dataset: Documenting the 2024 Presidential Transition
authors: Mark E. Phillips, Kristy K. Phillips, Sawood Alam
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries (JCDL)
abstract: This resource paper describes the EOT-2024 dataset, how it was created, and how it is presented as a resource for a wide range of computational uses. The EOT team has collected the federal.gov and public. mil domains during the transition of the executive branch of the United States federal government every four years since 2008. The 2024 dataset extends the available datasets of 2008, 2012, 2016, and 2020, adding 2.3 PB of web data to the previous 700 TB, resulting in one of the largest datasets of web data harvested with the intent of replayability of the source material at over 3 PB. This paper describes the timeline for collecting the material, the different crawling techniques used, and an overview of the six crawling partners’ contributions to the overall dataset.

title: Reshaping Wi-Fi Wireless Mesh Sensor Networks to enable irrigation automation and advanced sensors in broadacre farming
authors: Rodrigo Filev Maia, Carlos Ballester-Lurbe, Brenno Tondato, Gustavo Tercete, John Hornbuckle
abstract: Irrigation automation and IoT smart sensing improve water management and reduce labor in broadacre farming. This work investigates the feasibility of an innovative Wi-Fi Wireless Mesh Sensor Network (WMSN) architecture to provide large-scale coverage (up to ∼900 ha) and assesses its performance against the influence of crop canopy development. The study, conducted on two commercial rice farms, demonstrated the WMSN's effectiveness in providing stable coverage with 98.89% message success after one retransmission. The network maintained a signal strength (RSSI) above the −85 dBm operational threshold within 800 meters of a communication pod, with a stable mesh link established between pods up to 853 m apart. Results showed a strong negative linear correlation between rice canopy height and RSSI, with attenuation indices ranging from 2.34 to 2.88. Positioning the equipment 1.5 m above the canopy effectively mitigated the attenuation, achieving near free-space conditions.

title: LLM-Driven APT Analysis and Detection Based on Provenance Graph by Threat Pattern
authors: Yibin Fu, Zhaoyun Ding, Sheng Zhang, Deqi Cao, Yi Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: We propose a threat detection framework that enhances provenance-based APT analysis by combining event clustering with LLM-driven threat pattern extraction refinement. Our method is designed to work in conjunction with existing systems like Kairos, which able to detect anomaly time windows. We first group fine-grained events into semantic clusters to preserve behavioral context, then apply structured threat patterns to identify suspicious sequences. To improve precision, we introduce a two-stage refinement: relaxing matching constraints for high recall, followed by LLM-driven filtering to assess semantic plausibility in framework of MITRE based on "Part Chain of Pattern" assumption. Evaluated on CADETS E3 and THEIA E3 using defender-observable ground truth, our approach outperforms Kairos in precision and F1-score. The results show that integrating structured pattern matching with contextual language models can effectively enhance existing detection pipelines, offering a practical path toward more accurate and interpretable threat hunting.

title: Empirical Softplus-Based Fitting Function for Magnetic Field-Angle-Temperature Dependent Critical Current in Commercial REBCO Wires
authors: Kibum Choi, Jung Tae Lee, Jaemin Kim, Hyunsoo Park, Chaemin Im, Jonghoon Yoon, Dongwoo Lee, Seungyong Hahn
abstract: Accurately estimating the critical current of superconducting wires is essential for the reliable design and simulation of high-performance superconducting magnets. In particular, understanding its temperature dependence is vital for realistic quench simulations. Commercial REBCO wires-also known as 2G HTS wires or REBCO coated conductors-feature oriented crystalline structures in their REBCO layers. These orientations result in a critical current that varies with the angle of the applied magnetic field. Although several models exist for estimating the critical current of REBCO wires, a widely accepted fitting function that simultaneously accounts for magnetic field strength, field orientation, and temperature seems to be absent. In this work, we introduce an empirical fitting function based on the softplus formulation that captures all three dependencies. The proposed model is fitted to experimental data from various manufacturers and demonstrates good agreement across a wide range of temperatures and field orientations. Additionally, we discuss the quantification of uncertainties associated with both the fitted parameters and the predicted critical currents. By deriving analytical expressions for confidence intervals using a log-transformed regression framework, we provide statistical measures of reliability for each prediction. These uncertainty estimates are critical for ensuring safe and robust operation of superconducting systems, enabling probabilistic design margins and informed engineering decisions

title: Unifying Direct and Indirect Learning for Safe Control of Linear Systems
authors: Amir Modares, Niyousha Ghiasi, Bahare Kiumarsi, Hamidreza Modares
abstract: This paper develops learning-enabled safe controllers for linear systems subject to system uncertainties and bounded disturbances. Given the disturbance zonotope, the data based closed-loop dynamics (CLDs) are first characterized using a matrix zonotope (MZ), and refined through several steps to yield a constrained matrix zonotope (CMZ). This refinement is achieved by introducing conformal equality constraints that eliminate incompatible disturbance realizations. More precisely, prior knowledge and observed data are used separately to construct CMZ representations of disturbance sequences that conform to both data and prior knowledge, and are intersected by the initial MZ of the disturbance sequence, producing a refined CMZ. This approach reduces conservatism. To further reduce the conservativeness, we unify open-loop learning with closed-loop learning by presenting a novel set-membership identification method that models open loop dynamics as a CMZ. The prior knowledge serves as an initial feasible open-loop model set (FOLMS) ofthis CMZ, which is refined into a posterior set whenever new informative online data becomes available. This posterior FOLMS then adaptively replaces the prior knowledge set employed in the disturbance elimination of the closed-loop learning process. The resulting refined parameterized set of CLD is subsequently leveraged to directly and adaptively learn a controller that robustly enforces safety. Toward this goal, we formulate a linear programming problem that guarantees λ contractiveness of a polyhedral safe set. A simulation example is provided to validate the effectiveness of the proposed approach and support the theoretical results.

title: PSI-TR-ABE: A Traceable and Policy-Hidden Attribute-Based Encryption Scheme for Medical Data Sharing
authors: Ye Feng, Siqi Lu, Liujia Cai, Xingyun Hu, Xinxin Wang, Yongjuan Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Amidst rapid advancements in precision and translational medicine, cross-institutional and cross-regional sharing of medical research data is increasingly critical. However, such data contains sensitive patient privacy and institutional intellectual property, subject to stringent security and ethical constraints, while cloud adoption exacerbates data leakage risks – making the balance between data utility and privacy protection a core challenge. As a key solution for medical data sharing, existing Attribute-Based Encryption (ABE) schemes suffer from limitations including unidirectional privacy protection, difficulty in tracing key leakage, and inefficient policy matching. To address these, we propose PSI-TR-ABE, a Private Set Intersection-based Traceable Policy-Hidden ABE scheme, which integrates Private Set Intersection(PSI) protocols with Paillier homomorphic encryption to achieve bidirectional policy-attribute privacy protection, employs an Linear Secret Sharing Scheme(LSSS)-based policy pre-verification mechanism to reduce futile decryption, and embeds hashed user identities into key structures for precise traceability. Theoretical proofs and comparative evaluations demonstrate enhanced efficiency without compromising security, providing a novel solution for secure and efficient medical data sharing.

title: TrapLLM: An LLM-powered Interactive Log-based Honeypot for Real-world Network Attacks
authors: Yunjun Ma, Gangyan Zeng, Peng Zhang, Yuchen Huang, Fuyuan Zhang, Ran Lin, Huan Qian
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: With the continual escalation of cyberattack tactics, zero-day exploits and advanced persistent threats (APTs) characterized by high stealth and dynamic evolution have posed significant challenges to traditional honeypot systems. Existing approaches are limited in service fidelity, interactive intelligence, and awareness of attacker intent, making it difficult to effectively lure advanced attackers or reconstruct threat chains from massive volumes of log data. To address these challenges, this paper introduces large language models (LLMs) as the core driving force to construct an architecture that integrates log-driven data governance with dynamic response generation. Leveraging the semantic understanding and generative capabilities of LLMs, the proposed method enables fine-grained identification of attacker intent, reconstruction of event sequences, and adaptive responses driven by retrieval-augmented generation (RAG), thereby realizing an intelligent closed-loop defense. This innovative integration overcomes the constraints of traditional static rules and low interaction emulation, achieving attack intent analysis and adaptive deception response, and providing an efficient pathway for proactive threat hunting. During a 25day deployment in a real production network environment, the system utilized 25 diversion nodes and 8 types of emulated services to capture over 1.39 million raw attack logs. Analysis revealed multiple attack attempts targeting 9 known Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) vulnerabilities, along with a substantial number of high-severity attacks for which specific CVE identifiers could not be determined. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach significantly improves both the accuracy of threat awareness and the timeliness of response, providing reliable support for the evolution of intelligent defense mechanisms.

title: FedProbe: Attacking Federated Model Ownership Verification via Fine-Grained Watermark Detection and Erasure
authors: Kunlong Jin, Youliang Tian, Lujia Shi
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) enables collaborative model training across multiple parties while preserving data privacy. It has been widely adopted in sensitive domains such as healthcare and finance. As a result, the trained models themselves have become critical intellectual property. To prevent unauthorized use or distribution, watermarking techniques are commonly employed to verify model ownership. However, these mechanisms introduce new attack surfaces. Existing attacks typically assume the presence of watermarks and focus on their removal or forgery, overlooking a critical preliminary step: detecting whether a watermark exists. Furthermore, current approaches often rely on coarse-grained perturbation strategies that degrade model performance, limiting the practicality of such attacks. This paper proposes FedProbe, an attack framework from the perspective of an internal FL participant. FedProbe aims to detect and selectively remove embedded watermarks while minimizing the impact on model utility. It first detects the presence of a watermark by combining minimal inversion perturbation optimization with outlier detection. Then, it identifies critical pathways by analyzing neuron-level response differences under reversed triggers and performs fine-grained interventions via targeted neuron-level parameter replacement. Experimental results show that FedProbe achieves over 99% confidence in watermark detection across three mainstream datasets and various watermarking methods. Simultaneously, it reduces watermark verification success rates to 24% while keeping primary task performance degradation within 3%, demonstrating strong generalizability and robustness.

title: Efficient and Privacy-Preserving (α, β)-Core Community Search over Encrypted Bipartite Graphs
authors: Xiaoxian Liu, Chen Chen, Xueqiao Liu, Xiaoyang Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Bipartite graphs are instrumental for modeling interactions between heterogeneous entities. When outsourcing (α, β)-core community search to the cloud, preserving structural and query privacy is critical. Prior solutions, while aiming to protect privacy, often incur high communication overhead, rely on strong assumptions such as dual non-colluding servers, and may remain vulnerable to leakage of fine-grained access patterns or result sizes. We propose BiCore-Index PHE, an index-driven encrypted query framework under a practical proxy-cloud architecture. Our scheme stores two compact encrypted tables with precomputed thresholds and evaluates traversal in a branch-free manner using bitwise equality (BCDA), proxy-assisted oblivious comparisons (OGTC), and a ciphertext-level MUX controlled by encrypted type bits, thereby mitigating access-pattern leakage under the bounded-leakage model defined in our leakage function. On two real-world graphs, BiCore-Index PHE consistently outperforms a re-implemented state-of-the-art baseline: query time improves by about 10× and traversal iterations drop by over 90%. Communication is reduced by more than 96%. Index encryption remains <5s and token generation <6μs on the largest subsets, exhibiting near-linear scalability. We prove simulation-based security under the semi-honest, non-colluding proxy–cloud model, showing that each party’s view can be efficiently simulated from its specified leakage function, ensuring confidentiality of the graph, query parameters, and intermediate traversal states.

title: Height Knowledge Guided Open-pit Mine Extraction Network for High Resolution Remote Sensing Imagery
authors: Jia Liao, Ruoyu Yang, Qi Guo, Kaiyi Xiao, Yinhe Liu
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: The detection of open-pit mines from high-resolution remote sensing imagery holds significant ecological and economic importance. Previous methods treated open-pit mines as simple land cover types for extraction, often leading to confusion with bare land due to similarities in texture and color. This paper proposes a height knowledge-embedded network for open-pit mine extraction, namely MHNet, leveraging elevation information to enhance mine detection. The framework consists of two key components: mine height simulation and height knowledge embedding. To obtain elevation information, an height simulator is introduced to model the elevation variations of mines. Through joint learning, the framework simultaneously supervises the localization of open-pit mines and the learning of elevation variations, enabling the extraction of more robust mine features. The proposed method automatically simulates pseudo-labels for elevation estimation using the mining patterns of open pit mines, making the proposed framework compatible with arbitrary semantic segmentation models and eliminating the need for additional sample collection costs. The proposed method demonstrates superior performance on a self-constructed high-resolution remote sensing open-pit mine extraction dataset.

title: Semantic Map Completion: Learning Object Distributions for Better Navigation
authors: Zongwu Xie, Yiming Ji, Kaijie Yun, Yang Liu, Zhengpu Wang, Xiaokai Zhou
