title: ET-FS: Functional Specialization Method for Multi-Task Learning in Encrypted Traffic Classification
authors: Xinzhu Feng, Gaopeng Gou, Chang Liu, Zheyuan Gu, Wenqi Dong, Famei He, Xuren Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Pre-trained Transformer models have demonstrated remarkable ability in learning generalizable feature representations for encrypted traffic analysis, driving the development of effective methods in this field. Their separate hidden and output layer architecture supports efficient multi-task joint classification. However, in real-world multi-task scenarios, these models face challenges due to high computational overhead and performance degradation on individual tasks during joint training. To address these, we introduce ET-FS (Encrypted Traffic Classification via Functional Specialization), a novel three-stage framework for efficient multi-task training in encrypted traffic classification. In the first stage, ET-FS constructs a multi-task joint model based on pre-trained encrypted traffic models and task groups, followed by joint fine-tuning using single-task labeled datasets. In the second stage, we propose an innovative method to assess the nature of tasks within the model and groups, allowing identification of optimal parameters. In the third stage, we leverage the functional specialization of multi-head attention in Transformer architectures, introducing a partially frozen multi-task fine-tuning strategy. Specifically, during the final phase of training, only a selected proportion of task-related attention heads are updated, while irrelevant heads are frozen, mitigating gradient interference between tasks. Experimental results show that the ET-FS Final Model, trained with the proposed framework, is applicable across diverse scenarios. With sufficient resources, it surpasses baselines on all tasks and metrics, achieving 93% accuracy for app classification, 98% for service classification, and over 99% for other tasks. Even with limited resources and imbalanced datasets, it maintains robust performance and good generalization, highlighting its practical potential for encrypted traffic classification.

title: Application research of blind source separation algorithm in radar anti main lobe interference
authors: Min Duan, Kun Zhang, Bin Deng, Shilin Deng, Yichi Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Blind Source Separation (BSS) has the technical advantage of blind adaptation and has high application value in anti main lobe interference of radar equipment. This article analyzes the radar main lobe interference signal model and the radar anti main lobe interference algorithm based on FastICA. Through simulation experiments, it has been confirmed that the blind source separation method has good anti-interference performance against radar main lobe interference signals.

title: Large Language Model hallucination mitigation in three industrial use cases
authors: Petri Tikka, Jaakko Karjalainen, Andrea Alesani, Vladimir Goriachev
abstract: Large-language models (LLMs) can produce factually false or ungrounded information. This occurs when the language model, being fundamentally a statistical model, generates inaccurate or non-existent information with high confidence in response to a given query. This phenomenon is particularly dangerous in safety-critical systems and involves risks when LLMs are used to access or control hardware such as robots, sensors, and other internet-of-things (IoT) applications. Additionally, in automation-rich industrial environments, effective human–machine cooperation depends on maintaining a shared and adaptive understanding of complex situations. Distributed Situation Awareness (DSA) provides a framework for how awareness emerges collectively across networks of operators, robots, sensors, digital interfaces, and LLM based Artificial Intelligent (AI) systems. LLMs can fuse fragmented data streams into coherent, actionable context, enabling Extended Reality (XR) technologies to strengthen DSA by embedding digital cues into physical workflows. While this process improves coordination and adaptability, it also makes reliable and verifiable model outputs essential, as hallucinations can erode operator trust and compromise distributed decision-making. Therefore, mitigation of hallucinations becomes essential for sustaining stable human–AI teaming. We present three industrial projects where LLMs are at the forefront, highlighting practical approaches for hallucination mitigation and demonstrating a transition from online to offline model.

title: An Improved Physics-guided Interpretable Inception Network and Its Application in Bearing Fault Diagnosis
authors: Jingyuan Wu, Diwang Ruan, Yiliang Qian
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: In industrial applications, obtaining sufficient fault samples is challenging due to factors like sensor installation difficulties and limited fault occurrence. Consequently, small sample size becomes an inevitable obstacle for data-driven fault diagnosis. The Inception network demonstrates strong performance in bearing fault diagnosis, particularly under small sample conditions owing to its structural advantages. However, the commonly used Inception network suffers from poor interpretability and is prone to overfitting. To address these issues, this paper proposes a physics-guided Inception network (PG-Inception), leveraging the physical characteristics of bearing vibration signals to guide the design of its parameters and structure. First, the input length and size are designed based on rules derived from the fault characteristic frequency and shaft rotation frequency. Next, by analyzing the acceleration response within a single fault period and considering possible fault types, the convolution kernel size and the number of parallel branches in PG-Inception are determined. Finally, the effectiveness of PG-Inception is validated using the Case Western Reserve University (CWRU) and the Paderborn University (PU) bearing dataset. The experimental results indicate that under small sample conditions, PG-Inception achieves significantly higher accuracy, faster convergence, and stronger stability compared to the baseline Inception, validating the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed method.

title: TAR – PCH: Traceable and Revocable Blockchain Rewriting via Partial Policy-Hiding Chameleon Hashing under Cloud Assistance
authors: Lifeng Guo, Jingjing Xie, Runtao Zhang, Wei-Chuen Yau
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: The immutability of blockchain, while essential for ensuring data integrity and traceability, presents challenges in scenarios requiring data modification, such as regulatory compliance with the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and correction of erroneous transactions. To address this, we propose TAR−PCH, a novel chameleon hash scheme that enables fine-grained, policy-controlled rewriting of blockchain data under cloud-assisted environments. Our construction extends the Policy-Based Chameleon Hash (PCH) framework by incorporating partial policy hiding, user-level and attribute-level revocation, and traceability of malicious users. Leveraging efficient attribute-based encryption and white-box tracing, TAR−PCH enforces strong access control and accountability while outsourcing costly operations to the cloud. We formalize its security via indistinguishability and collision-resistance models, and our implementation demonstrates practical performance and scalability compared to existing schemes.

title: A Robust and Efficient Authentication Protocol for Intelligent Systems in Smart Healthcare IoMT
authors: Zaid Ameen Abduljabbar, Vincent Omollo Nyangaresi, Mustafa A. Al Sibahee, Junchao Ma, Zaid Alaa Hussien, Ali Hasan Ali, Husam A. Neamah, Ahmed Ali Ahmed
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: The Internet of Medical Things (IoMT) holds the promise of cutting costs and improving both efficiency and quality of healthcare systems. In IoMT, billions of sensitive patient physiological data are exchanged among the patients and healthcare facilities. Since open channels are used during these exchanges, attackers can compromise this data, posing serious consequences which can be fatal. Although a myriad of techniques have been developed to mitigate these threats, they are either inefficient or lack some pertinent security features. In this paper, we leverage on lightweight cryptographic primitives to develop an authentication protocol that is not only efficient but also robust against typical IoMT threats. The performance evaluation carried out shows that our approach reduced the computation complexity by 58.26% while thwarting threats such as session key disclosure, privileged insider, offline guessing, replay, side-channeling and session hijacking. In addition, the formal security analysis using Burrows–Abadi–Needham (BAN) logic demonstrates the robustness of the mutual authentication procedures.

title: A High-Performance ReLU-Based Hardware Accelerator with Simplified Quantization for Efficient Vision Transformers on Edge Devices
authors: Yu-Wen Peng, Pin-Chieh Hsieh, Yu-Cheng Fan
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 8th International Conference on Computational Intelligence and Intelligent Systems
abstract: None

title: Privacy-Preserving and Puncturable Bilateral Access Control from Lattices for Cloud-Assisted IoV
authors: Xinrui Yang, Ying Gao, Jie Chen
abstract: Cloud-assisted Internet of Vehicles (IoV) enables real-time data collection and processing through vehicle–cloud collaboration, thereby improving traffic scheduling efficiency and safety. However, ensuring data privacy and verifying data authenticity remain major challenges in such systems. Although existing primitives such as matchmaking encryption (ME) provide partial protection, they still lack quantum resistance and forward security for historical data. To address this limitation, we propose a lattice-based puncturable identity-based match-making encryption (PIB-ME) scheme, and design a revocable data sharing system with bilateral access control (RDSS-BAC) tailored for cloud-assisted IoV. We formalize the definition and security model of PIB-ME and prove its security under the RLWE assumption. The proposed PIB-ME enables bilateral access control between communicating vehicles, supports key puncturing for flexible revocation, and achieves post-quantum security. Security analysis demonstrates that, in addition to privacy and authenticity, the scheme resists tampering, collusion, and quantum attacks. Finally, theoretical complexity analysis and experimental evaluation confirm the efficiency and practicality of our scheme in cloud-assisted IoV scenarios.

title: Flatness-Aware Attack: Enhancing Adversarial Transferability via Local Region Stability
authors: Kejun Zhang, Yufan Yang, Jiahao Cheng, Meijiao Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Transfer-based attacks generate adversarial examples on surrogate models to deceive unseen models, enabling practical black-box attacks and drawing widespread attention. Recent efforts improve transferability by introducing gradient diversity or input transformations, but often overlook the geometric structure of the loss landscape. In this paper, we propose a novel method, Flatness-Aware Attack (FAA), which explicitly models the local stability of adversarial regions to enhance transferability. FAA incorporates two regularization terms to penalize sharp loss increases and gradient amplification within the perturbation neighborhood, encouraging the adversarial example to lie in flatter regions that generalize across models. A first-order approximation strategy is adopted to efficiently optimize the regularization without introducing high computational cost. FAA is lightweight and easily compatible with existing attack frameworks and plug-and-play. Extensive experiments on ImageNet demonstrate that FAA significantly improves transferability on both standard and adversarially trained models. Furthermore, combining FAA with input transformation techniques consistently yields better performance, verifying its broad applicability.

title: SoK: Credential-Based Trust Management in Decentralized Ledger Systems
authors: Yanna Jiang, Haiyu Deng, Qin Wang, Guangsheng Yu, Xu Wang, Yilin Sai, Shiping Chen, Wei Ni, Ren Ping Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Trust management systems (TMS) are crucial for managing trust in distributed environments. The rise of decentralized systems and blockchain has sparked interest in credential-based decentralized trust management systems (DTMS). This paper bridges the gap between theory and practice through a systematic review of credential-based DTMS. We analyze existing DTMS solutions through multiple dimensions, including their architectural designs, credential mechanisms, and trust evaluation models. Our survey provides a detailed taxonomy of credential-based DTMS approaches and establishes comprehensive evaluation criteria for assessing DTMS implementations. Through extensive analysis of current systems and implementations, we identify critical challenges and promising research directions in the field. Our examination offers valuable insights for researchers and practitioners working on DTMS, particularly in areas such as access control, reputation systems, and blockchain-based trust frameworks.

title: Aerodynamic Configuration Design of a Flying Car Fuselage Inspired by Whale Biomimicry
authors: Fan Ruyi, Ye Xinyi, Chen Yanyu, Xu Chuqian, Tian Fengnian
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Inspired by the fluid dynamics characteristics of whales, this study proposes a bionic design scheme for flying car fuselages. Through CFD numerical simulations, the lift-to-drag characteristics of the fuselage were analyzed within a range of attack angles (-5° to 5°). The results show that at the cruising speed of 300 km/h, the fuselage achieves a maximum lift-to-drag ratio of 13.25 at a 5° attack angle, representing a 14.3% improvement compared to the initial 2° attack angle. This study provides new insights for aerodynamic layout design in flying cars.

authors: Lavanya M, M Balasubramanian, V Logapriya, P.K.Devan, P.Usha Rani, G B Santhi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: This research work study focuses on evaluating the delamination factor (Fd) of the machined holes made on jute fibre epoxy polymer composites filled with SiC particles, machined using the abrasive water jet. The delamination factor (Fd) was predicted using machine learning algorithms. In this research, 3 machine learning models (i) Decision Tree (DT), (ii) Random Forest (RF), and (iii) XGBoost algorithm. From this work, it was observed that XGBOOST achieved the highest coefficient of determination (R2 = 0.9562) and the lowest error values (MAE = 0.0095, MSE = 0.0005, RMSE = 0.0234), outperforming the others in terms of accuracy. By contrast, DT performed the worst (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>=0.8491), whereas RF obtained an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.9060. This work reported that XG Boost algorithm predicted better delamination factor (Fd) in SiC-filled jute fibre epoxy composites. This advancement not only supports improved data-driven decision-making in material research but also aligns with the goals of Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure by promoting technologically advanced analytical methods, and Responsible Consumption and Production by enabling optimized material design and more efficient resource utilization.

title: Research on Propagation Models in Supply Chain Risk Propagation
authors: Yao Yuehui, Yang Naiding, Zhai Junfan, Huang Yuheng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: The volatile global situation has subjected supply chain networks to continuous shocks. In the study of risk propagation within supply chain networks, relevant propagation models play an irreplaceable role. To better understand risk propagation in supply chain networks and these related models, this study introduces and compares the most classic single-layer SIR model and the currently popular double-layer SIR-UAU model, presenting simulation diagrams of node state changes. This aims to enable the public to gain a preliminary understanding of the relevant models and strengthen the dissemination of propagation models. At the same time, it also proposes conjectures for the further development of these models.

title: Exploring Subtle Manipulation Vulnerabilities in Federated Distillation
authors: Peiyan Chen, Changsheng Wan, Hao Zou, Tian Wen, Zhiyuan Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Federated Distillation (FD) offers significant advantages over conventional Federated Learning (FL) by transmitting model outputs (logits) instead of model parameters, reducing communication costs and supporting heterogeneous model architectures. However, FD systems remain vulnerable to poisoning attacks, where local logits are manipulated to corrupt the global aggregation process. The current defense mechanism, represented by SVAFD, attempts to counter malicious updates using cosine similarity. However, we find that such a method fails to detect subtle perturbations and scale variations in logits. To expose these weaknesses, we propose the Federated Distillation Similarity-Based Attack (FDSA), a three-stage attack comprising peak shuffle, mean regression, and dynamic scaling. FDSA subtly manipulates client logits to evade detection while significantly degrading the robustness of server-side aggregation. By altering class priorities, increasing logit entropy, and dynamically adjusting scaling factors, FDSA maintains high cosine similarity to mask its malicious intent. Experiments on FMNIST and SVHN show that FDSA surpasses five state-of-the-art baseline attacks in reducing model accuracy, with ablation studies confirming its robustness across diverse settings. The source code of this paper is available at https://github.com/SHOWY118/FDSA.

title: Retrieval-Augmented Generation-Based Adaptive State Enhancement for Federated Split Learning
authors: Boyang Dong, Xiukun Yan, Kai Zeng
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Federated learning (FL) enables collaborative model training across distributed data sources through local computations and aggregation of model parameters, thereby preserving data privacy. Federated split learning (FSL) extends this paradigm by partitioning deep neural networks and transmitting only intermediate feature representations instead of raw data, thus offering dual-layered privacy protection while mitigating computational bottlenecks. However, identifying optimal split points in dynamic and heterogeneous environments to balance model performance, privacy preservation, and computational efficiency remains a significant challenge. To address these limitations, this paper proposes an adaptive state augmentation method based on retrieval-augmented generation (RAG). Our method employs dynamic k-values and relevance scoring to retrieve key historical states from a memory repository, fuses current and historical features using an hourglass encoder and soft attention mechanisms, and generates high-fidelity augmented states via a residual-derived decision module. The resulting augmented states incorporate historical contextual insights, enhancing the agent’s environmental awareness and enabling more precise and reliable split decisions. Empirical evaluations demonstrate that, compared to conventional reinforcement learning techniques, the proposed method maintains model accuracy while reducing average training time by 25%–40% and significantly mitigating load imbalances and vulnerability to data leakage.

title: From Speech to LaTeX: Large Language Models for Mathematical Accessibility in Digital Libraries
authors: Abigail Pitcairn, Clayton Durepos, Nicholas Largey, Behrooz Mansouri
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries (JCDL)
abstract: This paper introduces a system for converting spoken mathematics into correctly formatted LaTeX, advancing accessibility and discoverability of mathematical content in digital libraries. The pipeline integrates two stages: automatic speech recognition (ASR) with models such as Whisper, followed by large language models (LLMs) fine-tuned to identify and translate mathematical expressions into LaTeX syntax. Several LLMs (CodeT5, CodeT5+, CodeLLaMA, and QWEN2.5-Math) are evaluated using Word Error Rate (WER), Character Error Rate (CER), BLEU, sacreBLEU, and the LaTeX-specific TeXBLEU metric. Training and testing rely on the MathBridge dataset, supplemented with a new audio subset of 1,000 samples recorded under consumer-grade conditions to simulate real-world usage. Results show statistically significant differences across models, with trade-offs between transcription accuracy and LaTeX formatting quality. These findings offer guidance for selecting LLMs in speech-to-LaTeX (S2L) systems and contribute open resources to support future research in mathematical accessibility and digital scholarly communication.

title: Enhancing Personalized Shopping in the Metaverse: A Fuzzy Multi-criteria Decision Model for Luxury Retail Layout Optimization
authors: Hoi Yan Lam, G.T.S. Ho, Lap Wong, Daniel Y. Mo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Globalization and market competition has transformed luxury retail from a traditional to an ecommerce business model. However, providing customers with exclusive personalization and immersive experience through an e-commerce platform is a challenge. To provide a better shopping experience, luxury retailers have been developing virtual stores using the metaverse. Using real-time reconfigured product layouts, the retailer can dynamically change the display of a large number of products for customers. However, luxury retailers have difficulty changing the evaluation criteria for personalized and data-driven customer experiences because of the changing environment from two- to three-dimensional. Therefore, this study proposes a fuzzy-based metaverse retail layout optimization model to enhance dynamic product layouts in luxury retail environments by considering six real-time behavioral criteria. The results show that the proposed model can guide strategic product placement and improve the virtual shopping experience of customers. This study enhances metaverse commerce, luxury retail, and intelligent decision systems that offer a practical approach to digital transformation.

title: Evaluation of Human Resource Practices for Enhancing Supply Chain Agility: A BWM Approach
authors: Shipra Pandey, Ritesh Deore
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: In today’s fast-changing business environment shaped by disruptions, global competition, and digital transformation, supply chain agility (SCA) is crucial for ensuring organizational resilience and long-term success. Although operational and technological drivers of agility have been extensively studied, the strategic contribution of human resource (HR) practices to SCA remains relatively unexplored. This study assesses and ranks seven key HR practices-Training & Development, Performance Management, Employee Empowerment, Talent Acquisition & Retention, Communication & Collaboration, Flexible Work Arrangements, and Strategic Workforce Planning-using the Best-Worst Method (BWM), a multi-criteria decision-making (MCDM) tool. Drawing on expert opinions from HR and supply chain domains, Performance Management was found to be the most impactful, followed by Training & Development and Employee Empowerment. The findings underscore the importance of performance-driven systems, continuous learning, and employee autonomy in boosting supply chain flexibility and responsiveness. This study provides a structured approach for decision-makers to align HR strategies with agility goals and enriches theory by incorporating human capital into the SCA framework. Future research can apply hybrid MCDM methods across varied industries and regions.

title: High-Stability Clock Recovery Circuit Based on Adaptive Bandwidth Phase-Locked Loop (PLL)
authors: Yunfeng Zhao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: As demands for clock accuracy and jitter tolerance increase in high-speed data communications, traditional phaselocked loops (PLLs) with fixed bandwidth have reached a bottleneck for stability and adaptivity in complex environments. In this paper, a high-stability clock recovery circuit is proposed based on an adaptive-bandwidth PLL model, improved from the classic second-order analog PLL model. It builds a hybrid control structure with loop filtering that includes both dual-path and gain scheduling mechanisms, and a digital control module based on real-time phase noise estimation techniques geared to dynamically change the bandwidth to quickly compensate for either frequency offset or jitter. At the same time, a nonlinear phase detector with a quantization error structure is designed to relate to lock robustness, even under burst data and a spread-spectrum signal. The model represents a hybrid of the high-speed response capabilities of the analog domain and adaptive capabilities of the digital domain under highly-precise recovery performance across various data patterns and SNR levels. Experimental results indicate that this proposed AB-PLL circuit improves lock-in time by 32.4% over traditional architectures.

title: Improved LEACH Protocol for Energy-Saving in Wireless Sensor Networks: A Review
authors: Abdelhamid Benchikh, Mohammed Kaddi, Mohammed Omari
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: Wireless sensor networks (WSN) have become critical in monitoring and collecting data in various fields of our contemporary lives, such as healthcare, smart cities, and environmental sensing. However, these networks suffer from the limited energy resources of the sensor nodes that rely on non-rechargeable and non-replaceable batteries, which poses a significant challenge to the network's lifetime and performance. Researchers proposed the Low Energy Adaptive Clustering Hierarchy (LEACH) protocol based on an energy-efficient clustering approach for wireless sensor networks. Despite its advantages in rationalizing energy consumption, it suffers from issues such as early node death and uneven load distribution due to the random selection of cluster heads. This paper presents a review of various recently proposed protocols in scientific studies based on LEACH, highlighting the improvements made to reduce energy consumption and extend network lifetime, such as cluster head selection mechanisms, hybrid clustering techniques, and multi-hop communication. The study analyzes different optimization strategies by comparing their performance based on metrics, such as energy efficiency, network lifetime, and the amount of data transmitted. Finally, this review points to the current challenges in developing more robust and adaptive clustering protocols in energy-constrained wireless sensor network environments.

title: A Real-Time Defense Framework Using PPPO in Deep Reinforcement Learning for CyberBattleSim
authors: Yixuan Cao, Aniket Mahanti, Ranesh Naha
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: As networks become more complex and interconnected, they grow more vulnerable to sophisticated cyberattacks. CyberBattleSim provides a simulation platform for modeling complex attack-defense interactions. This paper presents a real-time defense framework based on deep reinforcement learning, integrating Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) and Asynchronous Advantage Actor-Critic (A3C). While prior research has primarily focused on improving attacker strategies such as Rapid ActorCritic (RAC) and Double Deep Q-Learning (DDQL), this work shifts attention to defender adaptability. The proposed Parallel Proximal Policy Optimization (PPPO) framework combines PPO’s policy stability with A3C’s asynchronous parallelism to enable rapid adaptation to evolving threats. Simulation results demonstrate that PPPO outperforms baseline approaches, including Deep Q-Learning and random policies in terms of cumulative rewards and network availability. Notably, PPPO maintains high availability even under multiple attacker scenarios. Real-time evaluations reveal a peak response latency of 0.005 seconds when utilizing five parallel agents. Comparative experiments further highlight the efficiency of GPU-based implementations, which achieve significantly faster training than CPU-based versions. These findings underscore the effectiveness and scalability of PPPO in enabling adaptive, autonomous defense mechanisms. This study contributes to advancing deep reinforcement learning applications in cybersecurity by providing a robust and real-time defense strategy capable of mitigating unknown and dynamic attacks in complex network environments.

title: Cooperative Multi-robot Pick-and-place Systems Via Layout and Motion Optimization Using Evolutionary Algorithms
authors: M. Kaimujjaman, T. Nishi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: This paper presents a framework for cooperative task execution in multi-robotic pick-and-place systems through integrated layout and motion optimization using evolutionary algorithms. The proposed approach targets coordinated manipulation scenarios where multiple robotic arms collaboratively transfer objects across work zones, requiring precise placement, handover, and reachability. To address spatial constraints and inter-robot coordination challenges, a two-stage optimization process is introduced. In the first stage, a Genetic Algorithm (GA) determines optimal robot placements within a discretized workspace, ensuring reachable zones and equidistant alignment for task sharing. In the second stage, joint-space motion planning is performed using trajectory interpolation to generate feasible, synchronized motions for each robot. The system is implemented in the Unity simulation environment using Niryo NED robotic arms, and supports dynamic task execution including pick, handover, and place operations across multiple cycles. Experimental results demonstrate successful coordination among three robots with realistic joint movements and collision-free transitions. The framework provides a scalable and intuitive method for designing collaborative robotic systems, with implications for smart manufacturing cells and autonomous manipulation workflows.

title: A System Dynamics Approach to Explore the Relationship of Infrastructure, Regulation, and Market on CNG and LNG Supply Chain Performance: A Case Study of Indonesia
authors: Dliyaa Ul Haq, Bertha Maya Sopha, Wangi Pandan Sari
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: This study employs a system dynamics approach using a Causal Loop Diagram (CLD) to explore the complex interactions among infrastructure development, regulatory policies, and market behavior in the supply chain system of Compressed Natural Gas (CNG) and Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) in Indonesia. The CLD identifies twelve major feedback loops across six interrelated subsystems: Distribution & Logistics, Demand & Consumption, Cost & Investment, Regulation & Policy, Technology & Innovation, and Industry & Market Adoption. These loops reflect the reinforcing and balancing dynamics that affect supply chain performance indicators such as cost efficiency, responsiveness, scalability, and sustainability. Key findings reveal that infrastructure limitations, regulatory delays, and investment uncertainties are primary constraints to optimal distribution. Based on the CLD analysis, five policy recommendations are proposed to enhance supply chain performance: aligning infrastructure investment with regional demand, performance-based subsidy allocation, digital innovation in logistics, adoption-driven policy design, and regulatory streamlining. The results provide a structured framework for energy policymakers and stakeholders to improve the effectiveness and resilience of Indonesia’s natural gas distribution system during its clean energy transition.

title: Offline Reinforcement Learning under Selective Dataset Constraints for Steel Quality Optimization
authors: Y. Huang, Z. Chen, D. Zhou, E. Pan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Optimization technology faces challenges such as safety and environmental applicability in the steel production process. The safety requirements of hot rolling production make it impossible for the optimization model to interact with the actual system in real-time. At the same time, the complex process parameters are challenging to general optimization models. To address the problem, an offline reinforcement learning model is proposed to optimize the control parameters and improve the quality of the steel strips. Based on real steel strip production data, an offline reinforcement learning dataset is constructed using keypoint truncation and graded reward design. A selective dataset-constrained offline reinforcement learning method is proposed to achieve conditional selection of the optimal action from the entire offline dataset. The Fitted Q-Evaluation method is used to evaluate model performance. The proposed optimization framework realizes the optimization and evaluation of rolling control parameters in a completely offline state. The experimental results show that the proposed model has a better optimization effect on the control parameters and provides effective support for improving the quality of steel strips.

title: NIED: A Corpus for Numeric Information Extraction from Dataset Descriptions
authors: Moriyuki Kamoto, Akihiro Tamura, Marie Katsurai
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries (JCDL)
abstract: Most machine learning dataset documentation is unstructured, hindering search by quantitative criteria. We address this challenge with a new task: extracting numerical information from dataset descriptions to better organize metadata. We introduce NIED, an annotated corpus comprising 3,926 dataset descriptions from papers and repositories. We propose a two-tier labeling scheme that separates numerical entities from contextual non-numerical ones. Using this framework, we benchmark seven pre-trained language models in a two-stage extraction pipeline; the best model achieves F1 scores of 72.0% for numerical entities and 71.4% for non-numerical entities. Our resource enables standardized evaluation and supports the development of tools for dataset discovery and comparison based on quantitative characteristics.

title: Blockchain-Verified Attribute-Based Keyword Search with User-Generated Keys in Multi-owner Setting for IoT
authors: Zongmin Wang, Qiang Wang, Fucai Zhou, Bao Li, Jian Xu, Haoyan Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: With the rapid advancement of Internet of Things (IoT) technology, the security and utilization of data outsourced to the cloud is a prerequisite for IoT application in actual production. Attribute-based keyword search (ABKS) has emerged as a powerful primitive for fine-grained search over encrypted data for IoT. While recent advanced ABKS schemes support more abundant functions and query structures, they do not consider multi-owner setting. Moreover, these schemes typically rely on a single trusted attribute authority for user certificate verification and private key distribution. This centralization creates a single point of failure and raises security concerns, such as key escrow. Furthermore, the existence of malicious entities necessitates verification mechanisms. However, most existing approaches introduce unvetted third-party validators, leading to reliability issues and privacy risks. Nevertheless, in numerous schemes, malicious entities persist in operational status, thereby compromising systemic security. To address these challenges, we propose ABKS with user-generated keys (ABKS-UGK), which decentralizes key generation to individual data users, fundamentally resolving the key escrow vulnerabilities in traditional schemes. It not only leverages blockchain’s immutability for secure result verification, but also incorporates a revocation mechanism against malicious entities. Extensive experimental evaluations demonstrate its efficiency and reliability, making it suitable for secure, verifiable data sharing in real world.

title: Performance Evaluation for Lithium-ion Battery Based on Health Indicators: A Review
authors: Chun Su, Ran Xia
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Accurate performance evaluation is crucial for such systems that are powered by Lithium-ion (Li-ion) battery. However, it is difficult to evaluate the performance of Li-ion battery with online approaches due to its complicated degradation mechanisms and environmental impacts. Health indicators (HIs) can commit to solve such issues, and they can provide abundant information on battery’s degradation and current performance. By conducting a literature review, this paper summarizes existing HIs of Li-ion battery. Based on their extraction methods, the HIs are classified into direct HIs and indirect HIs. After that, the methods to realize state of health (SOH) estimation and remaining useful life (RUL) prediction of Li-ion battery with HIs are summarized. It is found that direct HIs are more popularly used thanks to their simple calculation process and good accuracy of prediction; while indirect HIs are less adopted due to its complexity in the extraction and processing, and they are more suitable for complex working conditions due to its inclusion of degradation mechanisms. Finally, future directions for the development of performance evaluation of Li-ion battery are proposed.

title: A Comprehensive Assessment Method for Power Quality Based on Combined Weighting Using AHPEntropy Weighting Approach
authors: Yongsheng Ju, Yanjun Feng, Zhifeng Wang, Xin Zhang, Anlong Hu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: To enhance the accuracy and objectivity of comprehensive power quality assessment in new power systems, this study proposes a combined approach integrating AHPentropy weighting and improved TOPSIS. First, evaluation indicators are selected across multiple dimensions to establish a scientific power quality assessment framework. Second, the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) is employed to determine the subjective weights aggregating expert evaluations, while the Entropy Weighting Method ensures the objectivity of evaluation indicators. Combined weighting is then applied to establish comprehensive weights. Subsequently, an improved TOPSIS evaluation model is established by introducing gray correlation to enhance the single Euclidean distance metric, thereby addressing the limitations of the original criterion. Simultaneously, the assessment values obtained from the model are used to compare the quality of power supply, yielding a comprehensive and objective overall evaluation result. Finally, case studies validate that the proposed method overcomes the limitations of singleweighting approaches, minimizes information loss, and brings weighting closer to actual outcomes, demonstrating the capability to accurately and effectively achieve comprehensive power quality assessment.

title: CyberSOIE-LLM: Cybersecurity Semi-Open Information Extraction with Large Language Models
authors: Xinzheng Liu, Zhaoyun Ding
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs) are increasing in frequency and sophistication, rendering traditional defenses inadequate against the pronounced asymmetry inherent in contemporary cybersecurity. Cyber Threat Intelligence (CTI) is widely viewed as pivotal for transitioning from reactive to proactive defence; however, the exponential growth of unstructured CTI far exceeds the speed of manual analysis. We introduce CyberSOIE-LLM, the first cybersecurity-oriented Semi-Open Information Extraction framework that employs Large Language Models as domain experts to extract security knowledge from CTI efficiently, automatically and accurately. The framework unites three synergistic modules. Generator blends external knowledge enhancement with Chain-of-Thought (CoT) prompting to produce initial triples. Refiner enforces precision through multi-level rule- and semantics-based validation coupled with self-correction. Unifier externally aligns and internally normalises relation labels, yielding high-quality, low-redundancy cybersecurity triples. Extensive experiments on four Chinese–English CTI benchmarks show that CyberSOIE-LLM significantly surpasses state-of-the-art baselines, providing a scalable and trustworthy knowledge substrate for dynamic, proactive defence.

title: A Trigger Protection Circuit to Reduce Residual Voltage for Reversely Switched Dynistor
authors: Aoming Ge, Zhiwei Kang, Ning Wang, Wenbo Yang, Liang Li, Yiliang Lv, Tao Peng
abstract: Reversely switched dynistor (RSD) is a two-terminal semiconductor switch with high critical switched current rising rate and peak forward current, and is triggered by the reverse pre charge current which is generated through the pre-charge capacitor and pre-charge circuit. If the trigger charge is not sufficient, the residual voltage can occur on RSD at turn-on, increasing the power loss and even leading to damage. In this study, a trigger protection circuit is proposed, to protect RSD from being damaged by high power loss caused by high residual voltages at insufficient trigger charges through connecting a trigger protection branch in parallel. In the experiments, the peak residual voltage of the RSD is reduced by up to 55.6% under insufficient trigger charges—from 1800 V to 800 V. Under this condition, the trigger protection circuit shunts the RSD current, reducing the RSD current rising rate and residual voltage. On the other hand, the trigger protection circuit also protects the RSD by preventing its turn-on during the discharge process under extremely insufficient trigger conditions. In this situation, the residual voltage of the RSD approaches the charging voltage of the main capacitor and the impedance of RSD branch is high, diverting nearly all the main current through the trigger protection branch, reducing the power loss of RSD significantly. More importantly, the shunting effect of the trigger protection branch to the main current is small at sufficient trigger charges. The trigger protection circuit provides the protection for the normal and safe operations of RSD in pulsed power applications.

title: 3rd International Workshop on Digital Language Archives
authors: Oksana L. Zavalina, Shobhana L. Chelliah, Mary Burke
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries (JCDL)
abstract: This virtual workshop on digital language archives digital libraries that steward, curate, and provide online access to language materials - continues (after the initial JCDL LangArc 2021 and LangArc 2023 workshops) addressing the evolving needs of those who access, manage, and contribute to digital language archives. LangArc 2025 explores a wide range of issues related to digital language archives. Among these are challenges and opportunities; sustainable strategies for working with language communities and researchers on facilitating depositing and improving accessibility; organizing information and enhancing descriptive metadata, usability, information architecture and retrieval; quality assurance; ethical issues; ways of encouraging reuse of deposited materials in research, education, and outreach; integration of emerging technologies into digital language archival workflows; and academic coursework and other training for those who develop and maintain digital language archives. This workshop is expected to advance and sustain interdisciplinary partnerships between information professionals and researchers, linguists, historians, anthropologists, educators, language communities (notably Indigenous and underrepresented), students, and other interested audiences, which are crucial for the development of digital language archives.

title: Enhancing Cosmetic Review Clustering with Independent Topic Analysis and Word Embedding
authors: Takahiro Nishigaki, Yui Sudo, Takashi Ito, Takashi Onoda
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: In the era of user-generated content, cosmetic product reviews have become a crucial source of information for consumers. However, the overwhelming volume of such reviews makes it difficult to extract meaningful insights. While several topic modeling methods have been proposed to address this issue, including the combination of Independent Topic Analysis (ITA) and Word2Vec, their effectiveness in the context of cosmetic reviews has not been sufficiently evaluated. This study conducts a comprehensive comparison of five topic modeling approaches—LDA, LSI, LSI+Word2Vec, ITA, and ITA+Word2Vec—using both quantitative metrics and user evaluations. The results show that ITA+Word2Vec achieves the highest topic independence, lowest word overlap, and superior user satisfaction in terms of topic clarity and review relevance. These findings highlight the practical value of ITA+Word2Vec for organizing and interpreting large-scale cosmetic review data.

title: A Longitudinal Dataset of URLs Sampled From the Wayback Machine
authors: Kritika Garg, Sawood Alam, Dietrich Ayala, Michele C. Weigle, Michael L. Nelson
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries (JCDL)
abstract: We present a longitudinal dataset of 27.3 million URLs sampled from the Internet Archive’s (IA) Wayback Machine, comprising approximately 3.8 billion archived web pages (mementos) spanning 1996-2021. Our goal was to construct a sample to revisit fundamental questions about the size, nature, and persistence of the publicly archivable web, in particular, reconsidering the question, “How long does a web page last?” Although every web collection inevitably carries some bias, our sampling aimed to reduce imbalance by accounting for temporal coverage, domain frequency, URL depth, and MIME type. The dataset originates from IA’s ZipNum index, and includes URLs for HTML pages selected based on filename extensions for human interaction. Employing IA’s CDX API, we categorized URLs by their first capture date and MIME type, focusing on 92 million entries with text/html types. To balance the archival representation over the years, we extracted top-level URLs from deep links for earlier years where archiving was sparse. We aimed for consistent yearly sampling, with a target of 1 million URLs first archived during each of the 26 years of our study. Oversampling from popular domains like Yahoo and Twitter was addressed through logarithmic-scale downsampling. Various sampling strategies were employed to ensure a balanced representation across domains and time periods. This dataset, featuring TimeMaps of 27.3 million URLs, serves as a valuable resource for web archive studies and invites further exploration of web page durability and archival practices over time. Researchers can utilize the dataset to replicate sampling strategies and conduct new inquiries into the archived web.

title: Spare Parts Inventory Control Considering Holding-time-dependent Obsolescence Cost and Reactive Transshipment for a Multi-location Manufacturer
authors: Chang Liu, Feiran Cai, Meimei Zheng, Tangbin Xia
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: This paper considers a multi-location multi-item spare parts inventory problem considering holding-time-dependent obsolescence costs. The enterprise regards spare parts, the holding time of which is beyond a certain period, as obsolete parts. Thus, the quantity of obsolete parts depends on the holding time in inventory and is influenced by the withdrawal rule of spare parts. This paper measures the quantity of obsolete spare parts under two different rules. It is proved that the FIFO rule results in a lower number of obsolete parts than random withdrawal rule. Based on the obsolescence costs calculated under the FIFO rule, a two- stage model for spare parts order and reactive transshipment is developed under centralized management for a manufacturer operating multiple factories. The model minimizes the total cost of transshipment, ordering, and obsolescence under maximum inventory constraint. The effectiveness of the proposed model is validated through a real-world case study, demonstrating significant cost reductions compared to the current optimized (s, S) policy. Numerical results further indicate that the advantages of the proposed model become more pronounced when emergency order costs are high.

title: Extending the Framework of the Power Dynamics in Augmented Reality and Mixed Reality Aided Collaborative Design – A Systematic Review From 2014-2023
authors: Xu Yue, Wang Mingming, Gao Weiyue, Duh Henry
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: This paper extends the distribution and focus of Power Dynamics Framework for AR/MR-aided design collaboration through a systematic review to deal with the increasingly power dynamics issues in design collaboration. Our research reveals five critical implications for practitioners: Leadership Domination, Independent Thinking, Inclusive Engagement, Collective Negotiation, and Progressive Hierarchies. Based on these implications, we also propose future research directions from these implications, including equitable power compromise, collective consultation techniques, rapid modeling integration, Access-Manipulation alignment, and collective copyright impacts. Our work offers a structured framework to optimize design collaboration while presenting insights for optimizing the development of AR/MR Immersive tools to effectively engage design stakeholders.

title: SPFuzz: Program-State-Aware Fuzzing for Mail Protocols
authors: Hangzhou Fei, Xiaobing Xiong, Hui Shu
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Mail has become a crucial tool in daily work and communication, making the security testing of mail protocols essential for identifying potential vulnerabilities. Fuzzing, as one of the most widely adopted vulnerability discovery techniques, has evolved into an automated and mature method extensively applied in both software and protocol testing across industry. Recently, several fuzzers targeting network protocols have been proposed; however, they suffer from notable limitations. These include insufficient or imprecise representations of protocol states, often relying on generalized state models that fail to capture the specific internal states of individual protocols.In this paper, we address these limitations by proposing SPFuzz, a state-aware fuzzing approach for mail protocols based on program states. We investigate typical implementations of mail protocol services to determine how their internal program states interact with clients. First, we model the program state using key variables; then, we perform compile-time instrumentation to track these variables and infer runtime state transitions of the mail protocol implementations. Finally, we leverage the state information to prioritize test cases that are more likely to trigger new states and apply state feedback to refine the mutation strategy of a coverage-guided fuzzer. We implemented a prototype of SPFuzz and evaluated it on multiple real-world mail protocol programs. Experimental results demonstrate that SPFuzz significantly outperforms state-of-the-art fuzzers, including AFLNET and StateAFL, in terms of both code and state coverage. Specifically, SPFuzz achieves average improvements of 148.75% in the number of discovered states, 7.09% in state space coverage, 43.98% in map density, and 11.48% in branch coverage.

title: 5GC-PDA:A Novel Proactive Defense Architecture for Enhancing 5G Core Network Security
authors: Xingxing Liao, Wei You, Jie Yang, Jian Tao, Runhan Feng, Xinsheng Ji
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: The arrival of 5G era brings great convenience and unprecedented opportunities to human society under the new technical features of ultra-high speed, ultra-low latency, and mega-connectivity. As the management hub and "brain" of the 5G network architecture, the security of the core network is paramount. However, its evolution towards cloudification has led to frequent cybersecurity incidents; an attack on the 5G core network could trigger severe consequences. To address this, this paper first systematically analyzes potential vulnerabilities and attack paths within the 5G core network from an attacker’s perspective. Subsequently, an endogenous proactive defense architecture, grounded in the principles of dynamism, heterogeneity, and redundancy, is proposed. The working mechanism of this architecture is elaborated in detail, alongside a theoretical analysis of its security properties. To validate the efficacy of the proposed architecture, defensive performance was first compared across different schemes via simulation. The results demonstrate that our architecture achieves optimal defensive performance while significantly increasing the attacker’s cost. Furthermore, the proposed architecture was implemented on the Unified Data Management (UDM) network function within the open-source free5gc platform, and its enhanced protective capability was assessed through real-world attack testing. Experimental results indicate that the architecture effectively elevates the overall security posture of the 5G core network, introducing only marginal performance overhead.

title: Study on Alternating Current Field Measurement Technique to Detect Cracks in Fusion Zone of T91/TP347H Dissimilar Steel Joint
authors: Yuntao Li, Benli Wan, Shuangsheng Yan, Chao Shi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: To detect the circumferential crack in the fusion zone between the ASME SA-213 T91 and the nonmagnetic Austenite weld of the butt-welded joint between ASME SA-213 T91/ ASME SA-213TP347H dissimilar steel superheater tubes in the power plant boiler, Alternating Current Field Measurement technique was introduced, a reference standard and a simulating sample prepared, and experiments on studying the probe selection, the crack indication feature, the crack depth sizing ability, the influence of liftoff, and the detectability of the actual crack, were held. The results show that it is flexible for Alternating Current Field Measurement technique to detect the crack with the $\mathbf{5 0 - k H z}$ probe, the crack indication featured by a cosine $\boldsymbol{B}_{\mathbf{x}}$-curve, a negative-sine $\boldsymbol{B}_{\mathrm{z}}$-curve and a butterfly $\boldsymbol{B}_{\mathrm{xz}}$ plot, different from the abrupt liftoff of 20 mm, and the detection sensitivity being the notch with a length of 10 mm, a width of 0.25 mm and a depth of 0.5 mm, but there is a large measurement error up to $420 \%$ to directly size the depth of the crack by the depth-sizing arithmetic model of Austenite Steel of the Assist software with the $50-\mathrm{kHz}$ probe, due to a large electromagnetic property difference between the dissimilarsteel joint and the Austenite steel.

title: HiFi-XAI: A Fidelity-Aware, LLM-Powered Framework for Trustworthy Intrusion Detection
authors: Avinash Awasthi, Pritam Vediya, Hemant Miranka, Ramesh Babu Battula, Priyadarsi Nanda
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: The increasing deployment of complex "black box" AI models in anomaly-based Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) for future networks has opened up a trust gap that requires human-interpretable explanations in order for analysts to feel confident in acting on alerts. Current approaches to Explainable AI (XAI), such as SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) and LIME (Local Interpretable Model-agnostic Explanations), do not properly address the challenges inherent in the problem domain. These techniques fundamentally fail from a fidelity standpoint due to their incorrect assumption of independence between features that results in untrustworthy explanations, which are fundamentally based on correlated network data. We address these shortcomings by proposing HiFi-XAI, which leverages a new, novel framework to provide faithful and semantically rich explanations. HiFi-XAI introduces a model-agnostic Conditional Value Attribution Explanation (CVAE), a method based on probabilistic Shapley values that models feature dependencies to ensure explanations are derived from plausible data distributions. These high-fidelity attributions are then translated into actionable, natural-language narratives by a fine-tuned Large Language Model (LLM). We validate our framework through allaware scenario feature ablation studies on the CICIDS2017 and CICIOT2023 datasets. This demonstrates that CVAE consistently identifies more impactful features than SHAP and LIME across five anomaly-based IDS models. Furthermore, we deploy the HiFi-XAI to prove its practical feasibility and test it on a resource-constrained Raspberry Pi 4. Our work presents a complete, end-to-end solution for building trust in AI-driven IDS.

title: Privacy-Preserving Facial Authentication with Hybrid Fuzzy Commitment and Cancelable Transformation
authors: Weilai Guo, Shuaichao Song, Yeming Yang, Yuming Liao, Jiyuan Li, Songhui Guo
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: The widespread deployment of deep learning-based face recognition systems raises significant concerns regarding the security and privacy of their stored facial templates. Unlike passwords, a compromised template is irrevocable and can be inverted to reconstruct the user’s original biometric data, leading to permanent privacy loss. To address this problem, various biometric cryptosystems based on fuzzy commitment(FC) have been introduced. However, FC suffers from two critical challenges when applied to facial templates: the real-valued templates and their high intra-class variations, which typically exceed the error-correction capacity of FC. Our scheme addresses these issues by binarizing the deep features via Sliding Window Grouping MinHash, subsequently applying a Fisher score-based mask to select stable bits, ultimately minimizing intra-class dissimilarity to enable robust matching with LDPC codes. Extensive experiments were conducted on publicly available benchmark datasets, including LFW, ColorFERET, CASIA-WebFace, and FEI. The results demonstrate that our scheme achieves high authentication accuracy while also fulfilling the critical security requirements for template protection: irreversibility, revocability, and unlinkability.

title: Jailbreaking Multimodal Large Language Models via Consistent Cross-Modal Backgrounds
authors: Meng Yang, Peirou Liang, Zhiqian Wu, Yong Liao
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Multimodal large language models (MLLMs) have shown remarkable capability in vision–language understanding but remain vulnerable to jailbreak attacks that bypass safety alignment. Existing methods often rely on structured input manipulations such as cross-modal signal shifting, adversarial visual injection, or semantic rephrasing, which compromise naturalness and degrade under stronger defenses. To address this, we propose Consistent Cross-Modal Backgrounds Attack (CCB-A), a jailbreak strategy that embeds benign and semantically aligned background cues across both image and text modalities. Leveraging such consistency, CCB-A dilutes safety-sensitive signals and subtly redirects model attention away from harmful content while maintaining semantic coherence. We evaluate CCB-A on six representative MLLMs, including both commercial and open-source systems, across MM-SafetyBench and HADES. Experiments show that CCB-A consistently surpasses strong baselines in harmfulness and attack success rate. Ablation and defense analyses further reveal that cross-modal semantic consistency is the key driver of its effectiveness, while current defense mechanisms remain insufficiently robust, suggesting that exploiting consistency across modalities constitutes an effective yet previously overlooked jailbreak strategy that exposes a critical vulnerability in current alignment techniques.

title: Ownership vs Sharing Economy Models in Mobile-Integrated Services: Cost-Based Optimization from the Provider’s Perspective
authors: A. Benhamimid, M. Hadid, A. Elomri, N. Aydin, A. El Omri
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Mobile-integrated services (MIS), a cross-industry concept applied in healthcare, education, and administration, consists of deploying mobile units for service delivery. The approach is promoted as cost-efficient and customer centric. While the feasibility, implementation, and impact are studied in the literature, ownership schemes of mobile units have received limited attention. This paper aims to address the ownership dilemma of mobile units by developing two mathematical models for cost-effective MIS deployment. The first model considers all mobile units owned and operated by the service provider. The second adopts a mixed strategy, allowing for the temporary sharing (leasing) units when needed to minimize the total costs while satisfying demand across multiple locations overtime. A comparative analysis based on numerical example demonstrates under which conditions each ownership scheme is most advantageous.

title: From Fragmentation to Framework: Advancing IoT enabled Asset Management in the Rail Sector
authors: S. Alvandi, P.D Karningsih
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: The Australian rail sector is a critical enabler of national economic productivity, especially in mining and resource logistics. Ensuring the availability, reliability, and performance of rolling stock assets such as locomotives and wagons is fundamental to maintaining competitiveness in global commodity markets. However, asset management practices across the sector are marked by fragmentation, data silos, and inconsistent adoption of digital technologies, particularly those leveraging the Internet of Things (IoT). This research first analyses the current state of IoT-enabled asset management in the Australian rail sector, using a combined lens of the ISO 55000 Asset Management Standard and IoT technologies to identify strategic gaps and opportunities. The analysis reveals a critical need for a unified, standards-aligned approach that effectively integrates technological innovation with strategic asset management practices. In response, the study proposes an integrated conceptual framework to enhance strategic alignment through IoT enabled asset management. Overall, this research contributes valuable insights into the digital transformation of asset management in the rail industry, addressing the systemic challenges of integration, standardization, and long-term strategic planning.

title: Adaptive Interception Strategies of Unmanned Surface Vehicle Defender for Coastal and Port Security
authors: Nur Hamid, Willy Dharmawan, Haitham Saleh, Sami El Ferik
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: The rapid development of unmanned surface vehicles (USVs) in coastal and port security highlights the need for cutting-edge defense strategies against the highly potential attackers. Motivated by this issue, this paper presents an adaptive, state-machine-based framework for USV defenders for coastal area protection tasks. The main approach dynamically transitions between three operational states: patrol, intercept, and engage. During the interception phase, rather than going directly to the attacker's location, the proposed method calculates an adaptive blocking distance based on the real-time prediction of the attacker's trajectory and a radial approach mechanism ensures that the defender stably covers along the line between the center of the protected area and the attacker. This approach can effectively prevent the attacker from reaching the center of the protected area. Experimental results with 3D simulator (with realistic physics and water dynamic implementation) show that the proposed mechanism effectively intercepts the attacker's progress with shorter path length, competitive path smoothness performance, and shows potential for practical applications in coastal and port defense applications. This study contributes to developing intelligent control strategies for autonomous maritime defense systems.

title: Research on Model Predictive Control Strategy for LNG Liquefaction Unit Considering Refrigeration Cycle Coupling
authors: Aixiang Tang, Renchu He
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: With growing global energy demand, the natural gas liquefaction process, as a clean energy source, has gained significant attention. This paper investigates the simulation and advanced control system design for the liquefaction process. First, this paper introduces the process flow and control requirements, analyzing the coupling effects from the refrigeration cycle. Then, modeling is carried out using Aspen HYSYS, and a decouplingbased control strategy is proposed to reduce these effects. Finally, by comparing different control strategies, the results demonstrate that the proposed method improves process safety, stability, and system sensitivity.

title: Requirements Elicitation for a Methodology to Systematically Identify, Evaluate, and Select Suitable AI-Based Solutions in Manufacturing Companies
authors: C. Colsman, J. Stang, P. Jordan, C. Reuter
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: German manufacturing companies are currently confronted with rising cost and quality pressures, increasing efficiency demands, and a growing shortage of skilled labor. The adoption of artificial intelligence (Al) presents considerable potential to address these challenges. However, despite this recognized potential, many manufacturing companies struggle with low adoption rates due to the absence of coherent Al strategies, limited in-house expertise, and uncertainty about how Al can specifically address operational challenges. As a result, they often fail to identify and evaluate suitable AI-based solutions for their specific needs. This study presents the results of a systematic requirements elicitation process that forms the foundation for a future methodology to support the structured identification, evaluation, and selection of AI-based solutions in manufacturing companies. The requirements were derived through a systematic literature review and subsequently validated and enriched through semi-structured expert interviews. The resulting requirements catalog offers a structured basis for guiding the future development of this methodology.

title: Leader-Follower Federated Learning Framework: Heterogeneous Federated Learning based on Asymmetric Distillation
authors: Lina Ge, Haisong Zhu, Ming Jiang, Zhe Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Federated learning enables collaborative model training across multiple parties while preserving data privacy. Traditional frameworks assume the server only aggregates models, making them unsuitable for leader-follower scenarios. To address this, we propose a leader-follower federated learning framework, where the server, with limited data but strong computational capacity, leverages client data for additional training. We introduce Federated Asymmetric Distillation (FedAD) to accommodate distinct server and client objectives: the server employs a weak-to-strong distillation strategy to correct inaccuracies from client models, while clients use Not-True Distillation to mitigate catastrophic forgetting. Comparative and ablation experiments show that, after federated training, the Res110-20 model improves accuracy by 14.55%, 7.15%, and 4.80% on CIFAR100, CIFAR10, and MNIST, respectively.
