title: Numerical Analysis of Unreacted Nb $_{3}$ Sn Wires Under Compression
authors: M. Bracco, J. Bijlsma, J. Baumann, T. Boutboul, S. Farinon, E. Gautheron, S. C. Hopkins
abstract: Particle accelerator magnets mainly use Nb-Ti (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$T_{C}$</tex-math></inline-formula> = 9 K, <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$B_{c2}$</tex-math></inline-formula> = 14 T), but future machines like FCC-hh will require fields near 14 T. This drives a shift to higher-performance superconductors, with Nb <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$_{3}$</tex-math></inline-formula> Sn as the baseline choice. Nb <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$_{3}$</tex-math></inline-formula> Sn high-field magnets are fabricated by winding Rutherford cables made from wires containing Nb <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$_{3}$</tex-math></inline-formula> Sn precursor materials. During the cabling process, these wires undergo deformation, which increases the likelihood of degradation of their transport properties after reaction. Understanding how unreacted wires behave during uniaxial rolling is essential to optimize and validate designs of Nb <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$_{3}$</tex-math></inline-formula> Sn wires and cables. To investigate this, a collaboration between the Genoa branch of INFN and CERN is developing a finite element model to simulate the behavior of these wires. This study will focus on the impact of deformation during cabling on unreacted wires. Two-dimensional models of wire cross-sections, some idealized and symmetrical, and others based on SEM images of commercial RRP wires, will be presented. The study will explore differences between these models and quantitatively compare simulation results for the deformed geometry and stress and strain state with data obtained from image analysis of wire cross-sections.

title: Essential Sensors and Fault Detection Algorithms for Manufacturing Processes
authors: Ben Ko, Bagus Nugroho, Kevin Otto
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Comprehensive fault detection in manufacturing processes often relies on added sensors to detect individual faults, creating added cost to the equipment. Modern machine learning data methods can be applied to detect multiple faults within patterns of data from several sensors, thereby reducing the number of added sensors needed. The problem then becomes to find a cost-effective set of sensors that can detect the maximum number of faults with the minimum number of sensors. We develop here an optimization trade-off strategy to compare the fault detection capability against the number of sensors needed given alternative fault detection algorithms. For a plastic extrusion process with four faults, we find all faults can be detected with five sensors, 90% of the faults can be detected with four sensors, and one can be detected with a single sensor of (barrel temperature). The approach can be applied to decide upon the number of sensors desired for the fault coverage needed.

title: Vertical Air Motion Retrieval from Frequency-Modulated Continuous-Wave-Radar Rain Measurements
authors: A. Salcedo-Bosch, F. Rocadenbosch, A. García-García, C. López-Martínez, R. L. Tanamachi, D. T. Dawson, S. J. Frasier
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Vertically pointing S-band Doppler radars measure reflectivity-velocity spectra, where the falling velocity of raindrops appears as a shift along the velocity axis. However, in convective rain scenarios, vertical air motion (VAM) introduces errors into radar-derived products, including drop size distribution, rain rate, and reflectivity factor. This study presents an enhanced forward-model retrieval method for estimating VAM velocity and retrieving these radar products. The forward estimator employs a parameterized Gamma distribution and an unknown VAM velocity to estimate the radar-observed aliased reflectivity-velocity profile. Building on previous work by the authors, this paper introduces a mathematical formulation for the aliased radar reflectivity along with first application of the method to a real measurement case from VORTEX-SE 2017 campaign.

title: Hierarchical Ring Signatures with Hidden Signature Functionality over Blockchain Infrastructure
authors: Łukasz Krzywiecki, Witold Karaś, Adam Niezgoda, Karol Niczyj
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a modification to the hierarchical signature scheme that enhances the scalability and integrity of the resulting anonymous signature hierarchy, while introducing a new feature: the ability to hide additional signatures. We leverage blockchain infrastructure and smart contracts to improve the integrity of the hierarchy, address scalability challenges, and facilitate efficient node verification. We conceptualize the blockchain as a management layer that enables the selective revelation of non-signers within a ring of nodes by disclosing their ephemeral values. This process refines the anonymity set and allows for the recovery of hidden signatures. Furthermore, we present a performance analysis based on a proof-of-concept implementation of hierarchical signatures on the Ethereum blockchain, evaluating operational costs to demonstrate the scheme's efficiency.

title: Splicing Strategy based Chunk Level Deduplication Scheme for Cloud Storage
authors: Xin Tang, Haixin Chen, Siyu He, Yamin Yang, Luchao Jin
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Random chunks generation attack is a more sophisticated form of side-channel attack, where a deduplication request containing one or more target chunks and several randomly generated non-duplicate chunks is able to be constructed. Once the number of required chunks or linear combinations in response is equal to that of the non-duplicate chunks, the existence privacy of target chunks is immediately exposed. Once such an attack is launched in a hybrid mode, which means some of the target chunks are replaced with public ones with known existence, the probability of privacy exposure further increases. In order to address these challenges, we propose a novel splicing strategy based chunk level deduplication scheme, which effectively protects the existence privacy of target chunks. Specifically, with the help of short hash functions, we introduce a secure splicing strategy for tags that divides query tags into multiple ternary tag groups in an unpredictable manner from the perspective of the attacker, which is the basis for chunk splicing. Furthermore, a response table is constructed accordingly to require uploading of the corresponding number of linear combinations based on the number of non-duplicate tag groups, which is able to introduce obfuscation in a lightweight way. Security analysis and experimental results demonstrate that the proposed scheme can effectively resist the aforementioned attacks with controllable overhead, regardless of the number of target chunks in request.

title: Finite-sample guarantees for data-driven forward-backward operator methods
authors: Filippo Fabiani, Barbara Franci
abstract: We establish finite sample certificates on the quality of solutions produced by data-based forward-backward (FB) operator splitting schemes. As frequently happens in stochastic regimes, we consider the problem of finding a zero of the sum of two operators, where one is either unavailable in closed form or computationally expensive to evaluate, and shall therefore be approximated using a finite number of noisy oracle samples. Under the lens of algorithmic stability, we then derive probabilistic bounds on the distance between a true zero and the FB output without making specific assumptions about the underlying data distribution. We show that under weaker conditions ensuring the convergence of FB schemes, stability bounds grow proportionally to the number of iterations. Conversely, stronger assumptions yield stability guarantees that are independent of the iteration count. We then specialize our results to a popular FB stochastic Nash equilibrium seeking algorithm and validate our theoretical bounds on a control problem for smart grids, where the energy price uncertainty is approximated by means of historical data.

title: Enhancing Supply Chain Resilience through the Assessment of Stakeholder Attribute Dynamics
authors: Charuni Wijayasingha, H. Niles Perera, Jayani Ishara Sudusinghe
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Resilient supply chain serves as vital for organizations to minimize supply chain disruptions and maintain efficiency during operations. This study introduces a data-driven stakeholder assessment approach aimed at strengthening supply chain resilience through improved stakeholder classification. Addressing the limitations of traditional models, such as subjectivity and limited attributed consideration. The study utilized power-interest matrix and an unsupervised machine learning technique, specifically the Partitional Medoids (PAM) algorithm, to systematically cluster stakeholders based on critical attributes. Conducted as a case study within a multinational food and beverage company focused on packaging recycling project, the research involved surveys, expert interviews, and Monte Carlo simulations to ensure robust stakeholder analysis. Results demonstrated that multi-attribute clustering enhances the precision of stakeholder categorization across supply chain. Key emphasizes the importance of proactive stakeholder management in enhancing visibility, flexibility and decision-making capabilities. This study provided a practical framework that can be adapted across industries to support resilience, adaptive, and sustainable supply chain systems through advanced stakeholder engagement.

title: Improvement of Out-Going Car Flow Rate Using Discrete-Event Simulation: Case Study of Chiang Mai University
authors: T. Phongthiya, P. Mongkolkittaveepol, C. Meekarm
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: This study tackles recurrent congestion at Chiang Mai University’s Irrigation Canal Gate using a Discrete-Event Simulation (DES) in Arena combined with industrial engineering strategies (Theory of Constraints (TOC) and the ECRS approach: Eliminate-Combine-Rearrange-Simplify). Real peak period observations (Oct–Dec 2023; 16:00–18:00) informed model structure, parameter estimation, and validation. We tested three measures – (1) eliminating conflicting turns at an upstream intersection, (2) enforcing a continuous left turn for outbound vehicles, and (3) installing lane dividers to reduce last minute weaving – both individually and in combinations (seven scenarios). The best performing option (1+2) increased outbound throughput by 4.05% and shortened the average delay per vehicle by 10.8 seconds (from 2.06 to 1.88 minutes). While modest per vehicle, benefits recur daily and translate into fuel savings (40.43 THB/day) and CO₂ reductions (3.07 kg/day) in the evening peak alone.

title: Research on a Joint Strategy of Advance Selling and resalable returns based on arrival rate and value perception function
authors: Xiaowen Sun
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Based on the consumer arrival rate and consumer value perception function of the product, the joint strategy of advance selling and resalable returns of the product is given. Under the premise that the repurchased products can be re-sold, the optimal expected return of this strategy is obtained. The results show that the optimal pre-sale price is affected by the repurchase price, and the optimal repurchase price is not affected by the pre-sale price. The new joint strategy of advance selling and resalable returns can enhance the certainty of market demand, reduce the inventory risk of retailers, improve retailers' earnings, and solve some problems existing in the current research. It is an optimized joint strategy of advance selling and resalable returns.

title: Design and Implementation of Communication Nodes Based on STM32 and APL Ethernet Technology
authors: Bingjun Yan, Mingxu Gang, Bo Hu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Aiming at the problems of limited transmission in traditional industrial network and difficult coordination between power supply and communication, a communication node based on STM32 and APL Ethernet technology is designed and implemented. The node realizes data transmission and control by three modules: power management, physical layer controller and master control. The power management module provides stability for long-term operation; The physical layer controller completes the signal conversion and data frame transmission between the network and the main control module; The main control module takes stm32f407zet6 as the core, analyzes and sends the control command to the sensor and sends the collected data group frame to the single pair of twisted pair Ethernet. Finally, a test verification platform is built for functional testing. The test results show that the communication node can communicate stably, and the packet loss rate of data transmission is $\leq 0.01 \%$, which meets the design requirements.

title: Service Innovation Model: A Framework for Systematic Innovation
authors: P. J. Kunwar, J. Majava, J Harkonen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Although services and service innovation have received considerable scholarly attention, there remains a lack of a comprehensive and widely adopted framework to guide service innovation systematically. This gap is particularly significant given the persistent challenges that service-based businesses face, such as adapting to evolving customer needs, leveraging emerging technologies, and developing innovative business models that generate new value. To address this deficiency, this qualitative study employs abductive reasoning and a multiple-case study approach to explore how service innovation can be more effectively understood and managed. Drawing on data from six diverse testbed companies, the research identifies key components critical to service innovation and synthesizes them into a generic service innovation model (SIM). The SIM provides a structured framework for organizations to systematically plan, organize, and monitor service innovation activities. It aims to support firms in understanding how service innovation occurs, how it can be implemented, and how it contributes to sustainable competitive advantage.

title: A Transferable Adversarial Attack Framework for Object Detection via Spatial-Frequency Information Masking
authors: Zhipeng Lyu, Xiumei Li, Junmei Sun
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Object detectors based on convolutional neural networks (CNNs) have been widely applied for autonomous driving and industrial defect detection. Recent studies have shown that they are vulnerable to adversarial examples. Existing attack methods rely on the output of the object detector’s detection head to generate adversarial examples, which limits their applicability. Furthermore, optimizing the loss function of the object detector to generate adversarial perturbations can cause the perturbations to overfit to the source object detector, reducing the transferability of adversarial examples. To address these issues, we propose a novel adversarial example generation framework consisting of a spatial-frequency information masking (SFIM) method and two independent attack branches. The SFIM method masks partial spatial and frequency domain information of the augmented examples to generate diverse adversarial examples. The two independent attack branches, one targeting the backbone network and the other targeting the region proposal network (RPN), are fused with the SFIM method. The two attack branches do not rely on the output of the object detector’s detection head and are applicable to different attack scenarios. Extensive experiments on the PASCAL VOC and MS COCO datasets show that the adversarial examples generated by the proposed framework are highly transferable and can effectively attack black-box detectors of different architectures.

title: Research Progress on the Innovation of Power Electronic Topologies for Electric Vehicle Motor Drives
authors: Xibei Shi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: To systematically reveal the development trends of the field of power electronic topologies for electric vehicle motor drives in recent years, this study takes relevant literature indexed in the Web of Science database from 2015 to 2025 as the research object, and conducts quantitative analysis and visualization research using VOSviewer and CiteSpace software. By constructing co-occurrence networks at the author, institution, and national levels, combined with technical methods such as keyword density analysis and keyword burst detection, this study comprehensively sorts out the core research directions, key technological breakthroughs, and evolutionary trends in the field, thereby condensing mainstream research hotspots and accurately capturing the development dynamics of the field. The research results show that: (1) a relatively sound collaborative innovation network of authors and institutional cooperation system has been established in the field; (2) the Matthew effect in research output is significant, with core achievements highly concentrated in a few technological powers; (3) over the past decade, the research on technological applications in this field has continued to deepen, the research dimensions have been continuously expanded, and both the research depth and innovation intensity have achieved leapfrog development.

title: Fading Noise Reduction in Distributed Acoustic Sensing with Singular Value Decomposition-Nonlocal Means Filtering
authors: Fei Peng, Binbo Xiong, Yujie Zhang, Qiang Miao
abstract: Optical fiber distributed acoustic sensing (DAS) has attracted substantial interest for enabling extensive acoustic measurements. Among the most commonly deployed DAS technologies, the phase-sensitive optical time domain reflectometer encounters a key challenge: fading noise renders DAS incapable of recovering weak acoustic signals. Compared to commonly used image denoising methods such as block-matching 3D and 2D bilateral filtering, nonlocal means filtering (NLM) has been shown to effectively remove fading noise by leveraging the correlation of phase in the space-time domain, providing superior denoising performance. However, conventional NLM can lead to excessive smoothing of phase signals due to fading noise, thereby reducing the system’s spatial resolution. This paper proposes an SVD-NLM algorithm, which requires no training and does not modify the optical system hardware. It utilizes the singular value decomposition (SVD) characteristics to separate noise from signal to optimize the selection of singular values through parallel analysis, and conducts similarity measurement on the singular value vectors, ultimately weighting the low-rank reconstructed signals based on their similarity coefficients to yield the denoised signal. Through experiments, we confirmed that the proposed SVD-NLM achieves higher performance in suppressing fading noise without sacrificing spatial resolution, while avoiding the excessive smoothing issue associated with traditional NLM, the results show a peak signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR) of 31.751 dB and a structural similarity index (SSIM) of 0.9612. Finally, by connecting the DAS device to the underground optical fiber network on campus and processing the extracted vehicle trajectory signals with SVD-NLM, we have demonstrated the practical effectiveness of the proposed algorith.

title: An Omnidirectional Antenna for Sparse Circular-Ring Phased Array Antenna
authors: Xudong Wang, Xu Chu, Sheng Feng, Qian Chen, Quan Shui, Jing Gao, Zhixiang Huang, Lixia Yang, Wei Wang, Yingsong Li
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: In this letter, a high gain omnidirectional antenna with low gain ripple and a uniformly distributed sparse circular-ring phased array antenna (SCPAA) with a prime number of elements are proposed. The omnidirectional antenna, consisting of 12 head-to-end connected elements, exhibits a cosecant-squared radiation pattern in the elevation direction and an omnidirectional radiation pattern in the azimuth direction. The proposed SCPAA with 17 elements arranged on a 4 m diameter circular-ring exhibits a minimum sidelobe level of -7.65 dB and good 360° scanning performance. The measured VSWRs of the omnidirectional antenna elements are less than 2.0 over the 1.02–1.10 GHz band. In the azimuth direction, the minimum gain reaches 6.29 dBi at 1.06 GHz. The measured gain ripples of No.2 and No.11 antenna elements are ±0.52 dB and ±0.15 dB, respectively. In the elevation direction, the cosecant squared beam covers an airspace of 58° with a low sidelobe level of -22.3 dB. Compared with conventional mechanically scanned secondary surveillance radar (SSR) antennas, the proposed SCPAA has lower development and maintenance costs and enables higher data rates.

title: Efficient Wireless Data Transfer Strategies for Energy-Autonomous Environmental Sensor Probes
authors: Y. Sirumugai Karunakaran, U. Shinde, P. Woias, U. Shinde
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Micro and Miniature Power Systems, Self-Powered Sensors and Energy Autonomous Devices (PowerMEMS)
abstract: Energy-autonomous wireless sensor nodes (WSNs) face challenges in environmental monitoring due to energy constraints, transmission efficiency, and regulatory compliance of the used transmission standard. This paper presents a LoRaWAN payload optimization strategy addressing these limitations for a star-type network of energy-autonomous WSNs. By leveraging intelligent batching, data type optimization, and measurement aggregation, consecutive cycles are combined into single frames, thus fully exploiting the full capability of allowed data rates in the EU868 frequency band. Fixed-point representation and redundancy elimination reduce payload size by 31.8% (88→57 bytes). Transmission energy drops by 50% (3552→1776 mJ/day), with full temporal resolution preserved. Duty cycle utilization decreases from 9.6% to 4.8%, lowering collision probability and enhancing scalability in dense deployments.

title: Method for Monitoring and Intelligent Fault Repair of Secure Operating Systems for Power Grid Informatization Terminals
authors: Tong Li, Shuai Ren, Dongyu Li, Jian Chen, Zhanguo Wang, Weiwei Zou
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: For the security operating system of the power grid information innovation terminal, the monitoring system status in the regular inspection mode relies too much on experience. Therefore, this paper studies the monitoring and intelligent fault repair methods for the security operating system of the power grid information innovation terminal. Deploy real-time monitoring architecture, integrate security requirements and potential faults, configure multiple lightweight sensors, and achieve comprehensive monitoring. Detect anomalies through real-time monitoring of information and perform secure operating system fault diagnosis. Carry out fault layered repair, focusing on the key issues of eliminating error states and restoring execution states, following strict standards, and adopting corresponding repair strategies for different fault levels to build a complete fault recovery system and promote the construction of power grid informationization. The experimental results show that in terms of security indicators, the attack interception rate of this method reaches 92.3%, with only 2 data leaks and 0 unauthorized peripheral access, and a compliance rate of 99.7%; The fault monitoring delay experiment showed that all three types of fault monitoring delays were controlled within $\mathbf{0. 2} \boldsymbol{\sim} \mathbf{0. 9 m s}$. After repair, the fault rates of $\mathbf{1 2}$ types of power grids were significantly reduced, and this method has practical application value.

title: Verifiable and Robust Distributed Deep Learning based on Blockchain Infrastructure
authors: Mikołaj Pietrek, Łukasz Krzywiecki, Karol Niczyj, Witold Karaś
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: In this paper we propose a novel method for achieving verifiable and robust distributed deep learning. Agents verify model correctness and detect attacks, while a blockchain enforces consensus. The approach comprises two core elements: a suite of local validation mechanisms that produce unique "integrity signatures" from trained models, and a smart contract-driven protocol for managing node participation and collective validation. We designed and assessed several validator types, including those analyzing confusion matrices, model parameters, and responses to targeted input perturbations. A prototype was implemented with TensorFlow and Ethereum to evaluate the system’s resilience. Through extensive experiments on Fashion-MNIST with MLP and CNN models under data poisoning attacks, we demonstrate the method’s efficacy. A key finding is that a validator using test set confusion matrices can reliably identify malicious nodes, achieving perfect recall and a low false positive rate against single-class poisoning attacks. Our method successfully identifies and rejects malicious contributions, ensuring the integrity of the collaborative learning process.

title: Microwave Polarization-Controlled NV Center Superheterodyne Magnetic Detection System
authors: Chun Li, Dong Feng, Maoheng Jing, Xiaoxia Li, Wenhao Lu, Yihui Luo
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: NV-center magnetometry faces limits from microwave-field inhomogeneity and unmodeled nonlinear responses at high dynamic range. This work introduces a superheterodyne magnetic detection system with microwave polarization control to overcome these bottlenecks. The system integrates: (1) a planar helical antenna with tunable polarization, providing spatially uniform microwave fields and improving NV spin-drive efficiency; (2) a phase-locked microwave source combined with superheterodyne downconversion to enhance long-term frequency stability and suppress environmental noise; (3) a nonlinear sensitivity model based on Rabi dynamics with a real-time drift-correction algorithm. Experiments show 20 $\mathrm{pT} / \sqrt{ } \mathrm{Hz}$ sensitivity over $10 \mathrm{~Hz}-1 \mathrm{MHz}$, nonlinear error $(\lt)2 \%$, and $(\lt) \pm 0.1 \mathrm{pT}$ drift over 100 hours, substantially outperforming existing methods. The proposed approach offers a robust technical and theoretical foundation for high-precision NV magnetometers in complex environments.

title: Research on Incipient Fault Section Location in Distribution Networks based on Pearson Correlation and Probabilistic Mapping
authors: Mingming Xu, Ruirui Xie, Xuan Dong, Zhaoru Han, Yuehui Hu, Xiaobin Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: With the growing demand for reliable power supply, early detection and proactive elimination of such faults are critical to reducing outage incidents. However, the weak signatures of incipient faults are highly susceptible to noise, which compromises the reliability of fault section location. This paper investigates the directional characteristics of zero-sequence signals, which exhibit strong robustness under varying signal strengths, and proposes two location features: the correlation between zero-sequence current and the derivative of zerosequence voltage, and the dot product of zero-sequence current and zero-sequence voltage. An improved Variational Mode Decomposition (VMD) algorithm is further employed to extract accurate low-frequency harmonics, ensuring the applicability of the features under different neutral grounding modes. Theoretically, the proposed features from the fault section reach maximum and minimum values, respectively. By jointly applying these features and mapping them into fault probabilities via the Laplace distribution, the adaptability of fault location under diverse discharge patterns is significantly improved. Validation using physical experiments and actual fault recordings confirms the effectiveness and reliability of the proposed method.

title: Bridging the Gap between Client Expectations and Perceptions of Service Quality: Insights from IT Employees to Better Understand Client Needs
authors: Venkateswarlu Nalluri, Sai Manideep Appana, Jing-Rong Chang, Long-Sheng Chen, Sripathi Kalvakolanu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: This study evaluates Service Quality (SQ) gaps on Information Technology (IT) services using an advanced Fuzzy logic approach. Combining the SERVQUAL model with Interval-Valued Pythagorean Fuzzy Logic (IVPFL) offers a more precise assessment of clients' expectations and perceptions. A survey was administered to 47 IT employees, and the responses were analyzed using the IVPFL method. This method effectively addresses uncertainty and subjectivity in employees’ evaluations. The findings reveal that tangibility, empathy, and assurance are key factors influencing clients’ satisfaction, while significant gaps exist in reliability and order processing. The IVPFL model enhances traditional SQ assessments by providing a more detailed understanding of expectation-perception gaps. The study offers valuable insights for IT firms to optimize service delivery, improve operational efficiency, and personalize clients’ experiences. Therefore, addressing these gaps can help IT businesses strengthen their competitive position and boost clients’ loyalty.

title: Post-Quantum Anonymity of Key Encapsulation Mechanism and Its Applications in Password Authenticated Key Exchange Protocols
authors: JiaYv An, Yankun Gao, Lei Han
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Driven by advances in the standardization of NIST’s Post-Quantum Cryptography (PQC) algorithms, research on constructing Password Authenticated Key Exchange (PAKE) protocols using Key Encapsulation Mechanisms (KEMs) has gained considerable attention. Several PAKE protocols have established precise security requirements for the underlying KEM. Arriaga et al. introduced a PAKE protocol called CHIC, which requires the KEM to achieve anonymity under plaintext-checkable attacks (ANO-1PCA). An anonymous KEM does not leak any information about which public key was used for encryption. It protects the identities and privacy of participants and is critical in preventing identity-guessing attacks, therefore, anonymity is also called key-privacy. The anonymity of NIST PQC Round-3 candidates has recently been analyzed, some of which satisfied ANO-CCA.Huguenin-Dumittan and Vaudenay proposed two efficient constructions, T<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">CH</inf> and T<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">H</inf>, to create KEM from public-key encryption (PKE) schemes. Jiang et al. introduced T<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">RH</inf> based on T<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">H</inf>. These constructions can transform any OW-CPA PKE into an IND-qCCA KEM efficiently and avoid re-encryption. However, prior to this work, no research has been conducted to determine whether these constructions preserve or lift anonymity.In this paper, we proved that for any OW-CPA, DS-IND PKE, the construction KEM<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">RH</inf> = T<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">RH</inf>[PKE,H] achieves ANO1-CCA in the quantum random oracle model (QROM). We then construct a KEM called Kyber<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">RH</inf>, and provide an algorithm for the CHIC protocol using Kyber<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">RH</inf>.

title: Proactive Federated Backdoor Unlearning via Two-Phase Optimization and State Replacement
authors: Ze Chai, Yijing Lin, Zhipeng Gao, Zhiqiang Xie, Dusit Niyato
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Federated Learning has garnered significant attention in practical applications due to its privacy-preserving properties but faces serious threats from backdoor attacks. Current defenses primarily rely on server-side anomaly detection and robust aggregation, but lack systematic strategies for proactively erasing backdoors from the perspective of attackers. To bridge this gap, we propose an efficient and stealthy federated backdoor removal framework. Specifically, our method incorporates a two-stage training approach: reinforced negative learning and positive memory recovery. In addition, we intro-duce a hybrid regularization strategy that combines dynamic L1 regularization with Elastic Weight Consolidation, together with a synchronized differential amplification mechanism for both weights and buffers and a global norm clipping strategy. These components collectively effectively erase backdoor effects, maintain main-task accuracy, and significantly reduce detection risk on the server side. Experimental evaluations demonstrate that, compared to existing backdoor unlearning methods, our approach decreases the success rate of the backdoor attack by up to 11% without compromising the primary precision. Furthermore, our method substantially improves the stealthiness of the update, reducing the L2 norm fluctuations to less than 33% of the baseline levels.

title: ChatNVD: Advancing Cybersecurity Vulnerability Assessment with Large Language Models
authors: Shivansh Chopra, Hussain Ahmad, Diksha Goel, Claudia Szabo
abstract: The increasing frequency and sophistication of cybersecurity vulnerabilities in software systems underscores the need for robust and reliable vulnerability assessment methods. However, existing approaches often rely on highly technical and abstract frameworks, limiting accessibility for practitioners and increasing the risk of exploitation. In this paper, we introduce ChatNVD, a support tool powered by Large Language Models (LLMs) that leverages the National Vulnerability Database (NVD) to enhance the accessibility of vulnerability information. We develop three variants of ChatNVD using GPT-4o Mini (OpenAI), LLaMA 3 (Meta), and Gemini 1.5 Pro (Google). To evaluate their performance, we design a benchmark of structured queries derived from real CVE records, covering temporal, descriptive, and metric-based attributes. Our results show that GPT-4o Mini consistently outperforms the other models, achieving over 92% exact-match accuracy with lower hallucination and error rates. These findings demonstrate the potential of lightweight, retrieval-augmented LLM workflows for supporting vulnerability management and operational decision-making in cybersecurity contexts.

title: Distributed Robust Output-Constrained Control of Unknown Nonlinear Multiagent Systems Under Switching Topologies
authors: Hai-Xiu Xie, Jin-Xi Zhang, Tianyou Chai, Zhongmei Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Signal and Information Processing over Networks
abstract: The leader-following problem for the heterogeneous nonlinear multiagent systems under output constraints is investigated in this paper. It is focused on the cases where the underlying communication graph is directed and switching, and each agent is a multi-input multi-output block-triangular system with totally unknown and inherently nonlinear dynamics. They render the existing distributed control solutions infeasible. To surmount this challenge, a novel distributed mixed control strategy, composed of a group of robust decoupling constrained controllers and a set of PI-type gain adaption-based controllers, is developed in this paper. It ensures that the outputs of each follower evolve inside the prescribed constraint bands and track the leader outputs with the tunable settling time and accuracy, despite the topology switching. Moreover, it exhibits a prominent simplicity, in spite of the severe model uncertainties, without parameter identification, function approximation, disturbance estimation, or derivative calculation or estimation. The theoretical findings are illustrated by a comparative simulation on a team of planar mobile robots.

title: Contour Matching-Based Non-Diffuse Reflection Noise Point Cloud Detection Method
authors: Xin Sui, Guibin Liu, Changqiang Wang, Jiaxin Gao
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: To mitigate the impact of non-diffuse reflection noise in light detection and ranging (LiDAR) point clouds on the mapping accuracy of simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM) technology, this paper proposes a contour-matching-based method for detecting non-diffuse reflection noise in point clouds. First, based on the clustering segmentation results of a single-frame point cloud, all independent point cloud clusters are projected onto the X–Z and Y–Z planes. Then, the Alpha Shape (AS) algorithm is applied to extract the two-dimensional contours of each projected point cloud cluster, and corresponding feature vectors are constructed based on the geometric properties of these contours. Finally, by leveraging the symmetry properties of non-diffuse reflection point cloud clusters, non-diffuse reflection noise points are identified through the computation of cosine similarity (CS) between feature vectors. Experimental results indicate that the proposed method achieves a correct removal rate of 91.44% for non-diffuse noise points and a false removal rate of 5.77% for non-noise points. Compared with similar approaches, the correct detection rate of non-diffuse noise points is improved by 2.71%, while the false detection rate of non-noise points is reduced by 1.49%. Each point cloud frame is processed in 0.0741 seconds. The proposed approach effectively eliminates non-diffuse reflection noise points in point cloud data, mitigating the adverse impact of non-diffuse objects on LiDAR data quality.

title: RESA: RLWE-Based Efficient Secure Aggregation For Federated Learning
authors: Ziming Wang, Liang Zhang, Hang Zhou, Haibin Kan, Jiheng Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: With the widespread application of federated learning in sensitive domains such as healthcare and finance, preserving the privacy of participants’ local data while maintaining model performance has become a critical challenge. Existing secure aggregation schemes based on homomorphic encryption or pairwise masking still suffer from substantial computational and communication overhead. To address this problem, this paper presents RESA, an efficient secure aggregation protocol based on Ring Learning with Errors (RLWE) encryption. By replacing pairwise masking with the RLWE-based encryption scheme, gradients can be efficiently encrypted and decrypted. Furthermore, by combining Paillier homomorphic encryption with the homomorphic pseudorandom generator (HPRG) to aggregate all clients’ RLWE keys, our scheme effectively protects the privacy of honest clients. Also, the proposed protocol is resilient to client dropouts due to the application of secret sharing. The experimental results show that the proposed protocol achieves 5-10× speedup in the server-side computation, compared to Bell et al. (USENIX Security’23).

title: Exploring Behavioral Interventions toward Electronic Waste Recycling using Comprehensive Action Determination Model
authors: Annissa Novelinda Putriyani, Bertha Maya Sopha, Naly Rakoto, Muhammad Arif Wibisono
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: The rising global demand for electronics intensifies the generation of electronic waste. The present study investigates the factors influencing recycling behavior and analyzes behavioral interventions that promote e-waste recycling, utilizing the Comprehensive Action Determination Model (CADM), which encompasses five psychological mechanisms: ecological behavior, situational influences, habitual processes, intentional processes, and normative processes. An empirical study including 271 individuals on Java Island was conducted in August 2024. The primary findings, derived from SEM-PLS, indicate that e-waste recycling behavior is highly affected by habit and the perceived difficulty or ease of engaging in e-waste recycling activities. The absence of e-waste recycling infrastructure impedes behavior and elucidates the intention-behavior gap. The findings suggest that the behavioral intervention promoting e-waste recycling can focus on developing e-waste recycling infrastructure, ensuring easy access to this infrastructure, providing sufficient information to overcome practical challenges, and enhancing individuals' self-efficacy to translate intentions into concrete actions, together with fostering habits that sustain commitment in daily routines, and building norms.

title: Federated Function-on-function Regression with an Efficient Gradient Boosting Algorithm for Privacy-Preserving Telemedicine
authors: Yu Ding, Carlos Costa, Bing Si
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) is an emerging computing paradigm to collaboratively train Machine Learning (ML) models across multi-source data while preserving privacy. The major challenge of “meaningful” implementation of FL for any ML model is how to guarantee that the federated ML model can achieve comparable performance compared to the global model trained using the combined data. Moreover, there are very limited studies on FL of functional regression models that analyze functional data, a commonly encountered type of data in many fields. This study develops the first-of-its-kind federated Gradient Boosting algorithm with the Least Squares Approximation (fed-GB-LSA) for efficient, privacy-preserving federated learning of the function-on-function regression with several distinct merits: (1) The GB-based algorithm allows the sparse selection of multivariate functional and non-functional features in the function-on-function regression prediction, which is not straightforward in the functional regression; (2) The parameter estimation by the GB algorithm results in separate sub-optimization problems with explicitly analytical solutions for each of the features, providing an efficient estimation algorithm for the function-on-function regression; (3) The LSA-enabled fed-GB provides a “one-shot” approach for FL that is communicationally and statistically efficient, providing theoretical guarantees to the federated model’s performance without data sharing across local servers. The proposed fed-GB-LSA is tested in extensive simulation studies by considering real-world challenges such as device heterogeneity and applied in a real-world dataset for privacy-preserving telemonitoring of Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA).

title: Intelligent PID based Model-free Control for Energy-Efficient Speed Regulation of Electric Vehicles
authors: Laid Sehili, Ouarda Hamaidi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: In this research, a model-free control technique is developed for energy-efficient speed regulation of electric vehicles, formulated within the intelligent PD (iPD) framework. Unlike conventional PID controllers that rely on accurate plant models and extensive tuning, the iPD-MFC employs real-time algebraic estimation of system dynamics, thereby enhancing adaptability and reducing modeling dependency. Simulation studies conducted under standard driving cycles, including urban, suburban, and highway scenarios, demonstrate that the proposed controller achieves superior tracking accuracy with lower energy consumption compared to a classical PID. In addition, robustness evaluations under road grade variations and rolling resistance uncertainties confirm the ability of the MFC to maintain stable and efficient performance despite significant disturbances. The results obtained highlight the effectiveness of the suggested approach as a reliable and energy-efficient solution for electric vehicle speed regulation.

title: PIRL: A Robust and Privacy-Preserving Learning Method from an Information-Theoretic Perspective
authors: Guangyuan Liu, Shigong Long
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: While machine learning models have demonstrated powerful capabilities in widespread applications, they also reveal serious vulnerabilities in both adversarial robustness and privacy preservation. Although existing studies have attempted to build unified frameworks to simultaneously address these two major challenges, their privacy protections often rely on empirical defenses tailored to specific attacks—such as attribute inference—and lack formal, universal security guarantees. To fill this gap, we propose PIRL (Privacy-Preserving Information-theoretic Robust Learning), an information-theoretic representation learning framework designed to achieve jointly provable robustness and formal differential privacy (DP) guarantees. Our core idea is to learn a stochastic representation rigorously constrained by (ϵ,δ)-differential privacy through a unified optimization objective. This representation is forced to "forget" private information while being guided to preserve utility information essential for downstream tasks and to resist adversarial perturbations. We theoretically derive and characterize the intrinsic trade-offs among the model’s task utility, certified robustness, and differential privacy budget (ϵ,δ). Furthermore, we design a practical end-to-end training algorithm and conduct extensive experiments on multiple benchmark datasets. Experimental results show that, compared to existing methods, our framework achieves a superior Pareto frontier balancing these three core metrics.

title: Language Models and Bidirectional Recurrent Neural Networks for Arabic Named Entity Recognition
authors: Soumia Khedimi, Abdelghani Bouziane, Djelloul Bouchiha
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: This paper addresses the challenges of Arabic Named Entity Recognition (ANER), leveraging the performance of the pretrained language model and the deep neural networks. Our approach involves extracting contextualized embeddings from Arabic text using the AraELECTRA pre-trained language model, combined with the Bidirectional Gated Recurrent Unit (BGRU), to capture dependencies from past and future contexts effectively. The findings of this approach are promising, with an accuracy of 98,91 % and an F1-score of 98.9% on the CLEANANERcorp dataset.

title: A Radiation-Scattering-Integrated Metasurface Antenna with Simultaneous Ultra-wideband RCS Reduction and Circularly Polarized Radiation
authors: Xi Gao, Ying Hui Guo, Qiang Cheng
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: A radiation-scattering-integrated metasurface antenna is proposed to simultaneously achieve ultra-wideband radar cross section reduction (RCSR) and circularly polarized radiation. The unit cell of the proposed metasurface consists of a paperclip-shaped radiator, two right-angled metallic strips, and two parasitic metallic strips. When the unit cells are arranged into a checkerboard metasurface antenna and excited by a sequentially rotated feed network, the antenna simultaneously achieves ultra-wideband circularly polarized radiation and RCSR performances. Moreover, the RCSR bandwidth fully covers the antenna's radiation bandwidth. Simulation results indicate that the antenna exhibits a –10 dB impedance bandwidth of 57.72% (6.68–12.1 GHz), a 3 dB axial ratio (AR) bandwidth of 50.82% (6.75–11.35 GHz), and a peak realized gain of 16.72 dBic. In addition, the antenna achieves a monostatic RCSR greater than 10 dB from 5.6 to 15.1 GHz under normal incidence. Experimental results validate the proposed antenna's radiation and scattering performance.

title: Design and Performance of Grid Emulators for Renewable Grid-Integration: Topology and InverterSide Control
authors: Kesheng Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: With the continuous growth of renewable energy installations, large-scale integration of power electronic converters introduces low-inertia and weak-damping characteristics to the grid, challenging system stability. Therefore, compatibility and robustness tests are necessary before these devices are connected to the power system. A grid emulator can generate reference voltages corresponding to faulted or disturbed conditions through a programmable power supply or a real-time simulation system, and subsequently amplifying them into three-phase voltages via a voltage-source converter to support real power exchange with the device under test. This paper investigates several representative power stage configurations, including centralized three-phase fullbridge converters, cascaded H-bridges, and input-parallel/outputseries topologies. The analysis illustrates the advantages of modular multilevel converter in voltage resolution and waveform fidelity. At the control level, voltage hysteresis control, PI control, PR/QPR control, repetitive control, and sliding-mode control are examined with respect to dynamic tracking behavior and disturbance rejection. These results provide a technical reference for topology selection and controller optimization in PHIL-based grid emulators. Finally, the key limitations of present grid emulators are identified, together with directions for future improvement.

title: 3D trajectory personalization privacy protection method based on multi-feature classification and spatio-temporal attention
authors: Ding Mu, Mengyao Zhang, Zihan Wang, Yexiong Shang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: With the rise of Urban Air Mobility and drone logistics, three-dimensional trajectory data has become a core production factor in the low-altitude economy. However, 3D trajectories often contain sensitive information, and data cloud platforms may pose privacy leakage risks during data release. To address this, this paper proposes a method of personalized privacy protection for 3D data. It evaluates the similarity between trajectory points by integrating multi-dimensional features such as longitude, latitude, altitude, and speed, dynamically classifies trajectory points in 3D space, and computes category centers. A trajectory point evaluation model incorporating spatio-temporal characteristics is constructed to calculate and output the privacy utility evaluation values of trajectory points. Additionally, a personalized protection strategy is introduced, which dynamically allocates privacy budgets based on the distance from trajectory points to 3D category centers and their privacy utility evaluation values, achieving personalized privacy protection while balancing privacy and data usability.Experiments show that the method described in this paper significantly improves trajectory usability and privacy protection performance, demonstrating a good balance between privacy protection and data utility.

title: DeFiAD: A Unified Method for Early-Stage Domain Abuse Detection Through Automated Deep Feature Interaction
authors: Zhaojun Dai, Xiaodong Lee, Yufan Fu, Botao Peng
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: As a key infrastructure of the Internet, the Domain Name System (DNS) is frequently abused because of its open-ness, which makes early detection of domain abuse a critical task in cybersecurity. However, most existing methods rely on external data sources such as webpage content or long-term DNS resolution logs, which are unavailable at the registration stage, delaying detection and limiting adaptability across attack types. To overcome these limitations, we propose DeFiAD, a unified framework for early-stage domain abuse detection that relies solely on multi-source static information available at registration, enabling detection at the beginning of the domain lifecycle. We first introduce UDIRP, a unified domain information representation paradigm, which maps multi-source heterogeneous DNS native data into three subspaces for model understanding, forming a unified multi-channel representation. Building on this representation, we design DCINet, a Deep & Cross Network–based feature interaction model that effectively learns and integrates multi-source heterogeneous features, improving robustness and adaptability across diverse domain abuse types. Experiments on phishing, DGA, and mixed-abuse datasets show that DeFiAD consistently achieves the best overall performance, improving detection accuracy by 4%–10% over existing methods while maintaining high inference efficiency, highlighting its practicality for timely deployment.

title: Deployment Optimization of Mobile Automated External Defibrillators: Spatiotemporal Characterized Model and Adjusted ALNS Algorithm
authors: Hanxiao Jiang, Kexin Cao, Mingchuan Yang, Wai Kin Victor Chan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Mobile Automated External Defibrillators (AEDs) offer enhanced dynamic coverage and greater mobility compared to stationary AEDs, significantly reducing the response time for Out-of-Hospital Cardiac Arrest (OHCA) incidents. This study focuses on optimizing the deployment of mobile AEDs by determining the minimal fleet size necessary to meet coverage requirements. We formulate this problem as an integer programming model that minimizes the number of vehicles while ensuring both overall and time-specific coverage thresholds are met. The precision required for vehicle location introduces substantial computational complexity. To address this, we develop an Adaptive Large Neighborhood Search (ALNS) algorithm equipped with problem-specific operators to improve solution efficiency. Numerical experiments using Shenzhen’s historical vehicle trajectory data show that the ALNS algorithm outperforms Gurobi, achieving faster computation with minimal gaps in solution quality. Sensitivity analysis demonstrates that fleet size increases with both coverage thresholds and time window scale. This work offers actionable insights for optimizing the large-scale deployment of mobile AED systems in urban environments.

title: MAPF scenario modelling for human-robot collaboration
authors: Xuan Tian, Yaoguang Hu, Jingfei Wang, Xiaonan Yang, Jianxin Yang, Xiang Hu, Wenping Xu, Mingyu Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: With the rapid development of artificial intelligence, the multi-agent pathfinding problem (MAPF) has emerged in recent years. It is regarded as an NP-Hard problem that involves coordinating the movements of multiple agents within the same environment to perform different tasks. In recent years, MAPF has found numerous applications in automated industrial scenarios, prompting the proposal of several learning-based methods to solve MAPF challenges. In fact, in industrial application scenarios, the completion of complex tasks can be hampered by the robots' limited observational abilities to perceive their environment. Therefore, it is necessary to combine the flexibility of humans with intelligent manufacturing to achieve high levels of flexibility, efficiency, and safety through human-machine collaboration. This study proposes a model for human-machine collaboration in MAPF scenarios, based on the characteristics of human-machine interactions. The effectiveness of a multi-agent reinforcement learning algorithm in addressing dynamic MAPF problems in human-machine collaboration is verified. Finally, building on the classical multi-agent reinforcement learning algorithm MAA2C, the A*-MAA2C algorithm is proposed. Ablation experiments have verified its superiority over the standard MAA2C algorithm.

title: Ultrasonic B-Scan Image Classification for Defect Detection in Non-Destructive Testing
authors: Merabet Nedjemeddine Ammar, Madaoui Lotfi, Zairi Hadjer, Djerir Wahiba, Halimi Rafik, Rezzoug Amine, Cheurfa Said
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: This paper investigates the classification of ultrasonic B-scan images for defect detection in nondestructive testing (NDT). The study employs the ML-NDT dataset, which contains phased array B scan images of 316L stainless steel welds with real and simulated flaws. Five statistical features are extracted from the images in the time domain: maximum amplitude, mean, standard deviation, energy, and skewness. To capture both global patterns and localized variations, the features are computed using spatial subdivisions with 1×1, 2×2, and 3×3 grids. The resulting feature vectors are classified using Support Vector Machines (SVM), k-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) and Random Forest (RF). The experimental results show that the highest performance is obtained with SVM applied to 2×2 local features, achieving an F1 score of 99. 5%. Compared with deep learning approaches, the proposed method offers high accuracy, low computational requirements, and interpretability, making it suitable for real-time and resource-constrained NDT applications.

title: Investigating the Tertiary Academic Outcomes through Technological Quality Control in Knowledge Management System
authors: D. T. Luong, T. T. H. Truong, Q. H. Pham
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Knowledge Management Systems (KMS) play an increasingly significant role in reshaping higher education; however, their effectiveness relies heavily on ensuring their quality. This study examines the key factors contributing to KMS success, with a particular focus on how they influence student satisfaction with the system (KMS-learner satisfaction or KLS) and their academic outcomes (AO) in Vietnamese higher education. Building on concepts from the DeLone & McLean Information System Success Model (ISSM) and the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM), this research proposes and empirically tests a model. This model explores the links between System Quality (SQ), Lecturer Quality (LQ), and Course Quality (CQ), their impact on Perceived Usefulness (PU), and how PU subsequently affects KLS and AO. The findings indicate that all three quality dimensions greatly enhance Perceived Usefulness, which in turn positively influences both KMS-learner satisfaction and academic outcomes.

title: A Blockchain-Enabled AIoT Framework for Secure Metaverse in Wireless Communication Networks
authors: Danhuai Zhao, Chen Tian, Zhenyu Ju, Yi Rong, Xiaoming He, Wanting Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: The wireless communication network, comprising billions of cloud, edge, and end devices, enables emerging applications such as the metaverse—an immersive virtual environment where experiences and user interactions converge. However, user interactions in the metaverse generate substantial amounts of private data (e.g., identity, location), raising significant privacy concerns despite their utility in training machine learning models. Artificial Intelligence of Things (AIoT) offers solutions to these challenges, with Federated Learning (FL) serving as a decentralized framework that enables collaborative model training without exposing local data. Nevertheless, deploying FL in large-scale environments like the metaverse increases vulnerability to malicious attacks. To address this issue, we propose a blockchain-based FL architecture that enhances trust and security. The architecture integrates a multi-task FL strategy with blockchain sharding to boost system throughput and reduce resource consumption. By partitioning the blockchain into smaller shards, we lower computational demands and enable concurrent training of multiple models, improving efficiency. We also design a shard creation algorithm based on bipartite matching and a bandwidth scheduling mechanism that prioritizes reliable devices with informative data. Experimental results show that our architecture outperforms existing baselines across multiple evaluation metrics.

title: Two-MOSFETs-Based Memristor Emulator for Ultra-High-Frequency Signal Processing
authors: Gouranga Mandal, Pulak Mondal, Mourina Ghosh, Sung-Mo Kang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems
abstract: This article proposes a novel memristor emulator design capable of operating in the ultra-high-frequency range. The proposed memristor emulator, implemented using two nMOS transistors and a grounded MOS-capacitor, is designed and simulated in the Analog Design Environment of Cadence Virtuoso using a 90nm CMOS technology. It achieves a maximum operating frequency of 3 GHz, with a power consumption of 13.52 μW. The robustness of the proposed memristor emulator is validated through extensive simulations, including temperature variations, process corners, capacitance variations, and different combinations. Additionally, short-term non-volatility analysis has been conducted to evaluate its memory characteristics. The layout of the proposed memristor emulator is presented, along with pre-layout and post-layout simulations. Furthermore, hardware validation has been performed using commercial ICs (IRF840). Applications such as an 8:3 encoder, an adaptive neural network, and a ring oscillator circuit using the proposed memristor emulator are also reported in this article. The simulation results confirm that the memristive encoder functions correctly at 2 GHz and the ring oscillator generates an oscillation frequency greater than 2 GHz, demonstrating the emulator’s suitability for ultra-high-frequency applications.

title: A Threshold Distributed Key Generation and Dynamic Key Management Scheme in Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: Wenhui Kong, Pengfei Wen, Bo Li, Heng Gao, Runshan Hu, Ning Hu, Xingjun Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Wireless sensor networks (WSNs) are a crucial component of the Internet of Things (IoT). In recent years, the increasing number of smart devices communicating through WSNs has fueled growing research in this area. While WSNs hold great potential for development, they also face several challenges, such as ensuring key security and facilitating key updates. In this paper, we propose a threshold distributed key generation (TDKG) scheme based on verifiable secret sharing. Additionally, we present a dynamic key management scheme that utilizes the vector commitment to ensure that the secret key generated by smart devices cannot be arbitrarily altered. Subsequently, we describe the ECC-based instantiation schemes for TDKG and key management. Besides, the security analysis demonstrates that our proposed scheme offers enhanced security properties compared to existing approaches, while also achieving good performance in terms of time and communication costs.

title: Distributed Secure Consensus Tracking for Multi-Agent Systems: From Asymptotic to finite-/fixed-Time Convergence
authors: Xuqiang Lei, Guanghui Wen, Marios M. Polycarpou
abstract: This paper investigates the problem of distributed secure consensus tracking for leader-following multi-agent systems under the presence of sparse data anomalies in the networks. An extra auxiliary function is designed and employed to formulate the interaction gains to mitigate the impact of such unknown sparse anomalies. Different from conventional anomaly detection and isolation methods, the introduction of the auxiliary function can alleviate the wasteful expansion of global sparse anomaly detectors and facilitate non-smooth control. Consequently, we formulate a new design framework for secure consensus protocols, enabling all followers to realize asymptotic and even finite-/fixed-time tracking to the leader. Finally, some simulation examples are presented to illustrate the effectiveness of the theoretical results.
