title: Sliding mode control of flying-capacitor voltage in serial multi-cell DC-DC converters
authors: Abdelkader Garmat, Kamel Guesmi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: The growing demand for efficient high-power conversion has driven research on multi-cell DC–DC converters, where the main challenge is flying-capacitor voltage balancing, motivating robust control solutions. In this paper, a sliding mode control (SMC) approach is proposed to achieve accurate capacitor voltage balancing in a serial multi-cell converter. The controller is designed to ensure stable operation, rapid dynamic response, and robustness against disturbances. Its design follows three main stages: the selection of the appropriate sliding surface, the establishment of the convergence conditions to ensure the system stability, and the derivation of the control law. The effectiveness of the proposed SMC strategy is evaluated through simulations under severe operating conditions, including large variations in supply voltage and load resistance. The results confirm the proposed SMC accuracy of voltage balancing, its rapid transient response, and its high disturbance rejection, making it a competitive solution for advanced high-performance power conversion applications.

title: Automated Risk assessment approach using D-Higraph integrated into DCS apllied on Fired heater
authors: El Arkam Mechhoud, Riad Bendib, Abdulaziz Alshareef
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: The objective of this paper is to develop an automated framework for risk assessment based on functional modeling approach. The D-higraph is used for functional modeling, failures analysis and their causalities relationship. The approach is applied to the dryer heater 30 F1 unit located in Skikda refinery – Algeria- , the control of this refinery is assured by a Distributed Control System (DCS) type Yokogawa CENTUM VP. The integration of this framework on the plant DCS will enhance the reliability and accuracy of accident analysis, offering a comprehensive framework for identifying potential risks and failure scenarios.

title: PV Power Output Prediction Using Machine Learning: An Accuracy Assessment Based on Feature Pattern Selection
authors: Abderraouf Bouakkaz, Adel Lahsasna, Salim Haddad
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: Accurate photovoltaic (PV) power prediction is essential for efficient grid management. Due to the intermittent nature of solar radiation, unreliable predictions can cause energy imbalances and grid instability. Thus, enhancing prediction accuracy is crucial to ensure the reliability and efficiency of solar energy systems. In this context, this paper presents an evaluation of the prediction accuracy of PV energy production using two machine learning models: Random Forest (RF) and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks. Both models were trained on real data measurement of solar irradiance (E), ambient temperature (T<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">amb</inf>), and wind speed (Ws). To better assess the factors affecting model performance, various combinations of input features were explored. In particular, the cell temperature (T<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">c</inf>) was added as an additional variable, as it directly represents the real operating conditions of PV modules. Incorporating this feature helps capture thermal losses and efficiency fluctuations caused by temperature variations, thereby improving the alignment between the predicted and true PV power outputs. The models were evaluated using Root Mean Square Error (RMSE), Mean Absolute Error (MAE), and Mean Relative Error (MRE). Results indicate that incorporating the predicted PV cell temperature (T<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">c</inf>) as an additional input feature reduced the RMSE by 10.25% for the RF model (from 9.221 to 8.276) and by 3.75% for the LSTM model (from 24.332 to 23.420). These results confirm that employing diverse feature patterns enhances enhance the accuracy forecasting of PV power production, emphasizing the critical role of feature selection in optimizing model performance.

title: Programming Languages and Tools for AI and Data Science Professionals in Johannesburg
authors: T. T. Olaokun, J. Nkuna, A. Pradhan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: The study explores the adoption of the Fourth Industrial Revolution (4IR) in Johannesburg, with a particular focus on skills development and training in AI and data science sectors. The study used a qualitative method to analyze responses obtained through interviews from fifty educators, professionals, and industry experts in Johannesburg, South Africa. It examined the programming languages and tools commonly known, recommended and used by professionals. The study revealed that despite having strong foundational skills in programming and statistics, gaps remain in advanced areas such as deep learning, big data frameworks, and machine learning operations. Respondents highlight the need for improved practical training on data preprocessing, model deployment, ethical governance, and more localized datasets and policy frameworks. Existing training programs offer robust curricula in foundational data science and sector-specific applications, but they vary in their coverage of emerging AI techniques and ethical considerations. The study recommends targeted investments in hands-on, contextually relevant training, developing African-centric data and regulatory resources, and stronger partnerships between academia, industry, and government to build a workforce capable of driving inclusive and sustainable 4IR innovation.

title: A Comparative Study of Automatic Number Plate Recognition (ANPR) Methods
authors: Zelikha Hasna Belhamri, Sabria Goumiri, Sofia Chergui, Abderrazak Sebaa
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: Automatic Number Plate Recognition (ANPR) has become a key component of intelligent transportation systems, urban mobility, and security applications. This paper presents a comparative study of ANPR methods, covering detection, segmentation, and recognition stages. We review both traditional approaches, such as connected component analysis, template matching, and projection methods, and modern deep learning techniques, including CNNs, RNN/CRNN models, and object detectors such as YOLO and SSD. A multi-criteria analysis is conducted to evaluate accuracy, inference time, robustness, hardware requirements, and interpretability, highlighting the trade-offs between classical and deep learning–based solutions. Furthermore, commonly used public datasets and their limitations are discussed, along with the main challenges of real-world deployment, such as lighting variations, occlusion, distortions, and multilingual plate diversity. Finally, the paper outlines future research directions, emphasizing advanced architectures, local dataset development, hybrid pipelines, model optimization, and explainability to enable robust and efficient ANPR systems for practical applications.

title: Application of transfer learning algorithm based on Pre-trained Model in Rate of Penetration prediction
authors: Zhenxin Zhang, Han Meng, Botao Lin, Xueyin Han, Junjie Shentu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Accurate rate of penetration (ROP) prediction is essential for optimizing drilling parameters, shortening drilling cycles, and reducing costs. Existing approaches typically fall into two categories: (1) All-for-One, which uses data from previously drilled wells to predict ROP in a new well. While this approach captures overall trends, it often fails to reflect well-specific characteristics; and (2) Continuous Learning, which updates predictions in real time using the new well’s own data. Although more adaptive, this method suffers from delayed responses and instability when encountering sudden formation changes. To overcome these limitations, this paper proposes a pre-trained + fine-tuned model framework. The method first pre-trains a BPNN on multiple wells from the same block to learn general ROP patterns. It then applies a sliding-window fine-tuning strategy on data from the new well, updating only the parameters of a secondary fine-tuning model while keeping the pre-trained model frozen. This design explicitly separates inter-well invariant knowledge from intra-well specific knowledge, maintaining both stability and adaptability. Experiments on field data from Bohai Oilfield demonstrate that the proposed method consistently outperforms both single-scenario approaches. Compared with All-for-One and Continuous Learning, it reduces root mean squared error by 34.3% and 49.6%, respectively, lowers mean absolute error by 45.9% and 24.6%, and achieves an $\mathbf{R}^{2}$ of 0.88. Owing to its lightweight architecture and fast fine-tuning, the model is well suited to real-time applications under limited on-site computing resources, thereby supporting intelligent drilling parameter optimization.

title: Opening a Can of Worms: A Comprehensive View into the Android Debug Bridge Malware
authors: Huancheng Hu, Christian Doerr
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: The proliferation of affordable Android-based IoT devices has led to their widespread integration into residential environments. However, Android Debug Bridge (ADB), the official developer tool that provides root-level access, is often misconfigured on low-end Android devices, with the port left open by default. This exposure enables remote compromise and turns devices into tools for cryptomining and botnet attacks, fueling large-scale malware campaigns. Despite years of widespread exploitation, there has been no systematic and quantitative understanding of how ADB-based worms exploit, propagate, and persist at scale. We present the first comprehensive study of ADB-targeting worms, analyzing over seven years of real-world data encompassing 1.7 million infected IPs and more than 6 billion compromise attempts. Our analysis uncovers three distinct propagation phases and shows that infections are disproportionately concentrated among residential devices. Through device firmware analysis, we reveal that ADB access is factory-enabled on several market-leading low-end Android TV boxes. We further show that infection patterns are tightly coupled with human activity cycles. To further explore the infection behavior quantitatively, we introduce a Graph Neural Network (GNN)-based simulation framework which is built and validated from real-world data. The model reveals how synchronized user behavior accelerates propagation and shows that timely mitigation can significantly reduce infection scale.

title: Automated Oil Spill Detection and Segmentation in Marine Ecosystems using Drone-captured Images and Attention-enhanced Convolutional Architectures
authors: Priyadarshini R, Sowmya Kamath S
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Oil spills pose significant environmental threats to marine ecosystems, affecting aquatic life and altering water quality parameters. Accurate and reliable detection methods are crucial for mitigating environmental damage. In this article, we focus on the use of advanced convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to detect oil spills in marine imagery. Various preprocessing techniques and model architectures, including U-Net with different encoders and attention mechanisms were evaluated on a standard dataset containing drone images categorized into background, water, oil, and other classes. Additionally, our approach incorporates a novel technique for accurate detection of look-alike oil spills with Squeeze-and-Excitation blocks, demonstrating superior performance in suppressing inherent noise in drone imagery. The proposed approach effectively addresses the greater complexity and variability of drone data when compared to conventional SAR data. Among the models tested, the SE-U-Net model achieved the best class-wise performance due to its enhanced feature extraction performance and the ability to capture channel-wise interdependencies. We also analyze the strengths and limitations of each convolutional approach, to aid the development of accurate and efficient image segmentation models for environmental monitoring.

title: Efficient Arbitrary-Scale Image Super-Resolution via Functional Tensor Decomposition
authors: Guancheng Zhou, Yisi Luo, Xile Zhao, Deyu Meng
abstract: Existing arbitrary-scale super-resolution (ASSR) methods suffer from quadratic computational complexity w.r.t. image scale due to the reliance on multi-layer perceptrons (MLPs) to query dense spatial coordinate matrices. The inefficiency becomes particularly pronounced when extending to high-dimensional imaging modalities. To address these limitations, we propose a novel functional tensor decomposition (FTD) framework that fundamentally reconfigures the computational paradigm for ASSR. Specifically, we propose 1) a separation mechanism that employs distinct MLPs to query separable spatial coordinate vectors, substantially reducing decoder MLP invocations, and 2) functional tensor Tucker or CP decompositions for efficient factor matrix integration. The FTD framework delivers three key advantages: 1) Superior scalability to high-dimensional imaging modalities, such as hyperspectral images (HSIs), by virtue of the FTD design; 2) Significantly enhanced inference speed across scales; 3) Faster convergence towards a desired training model. Extensive experiments validate FTD's exceptional performance in HSI joint spatial-spectral ASSR, achieving up to 90.04% reduction in inference time and substantial performance improvements. For conventional image ASSR, our method improves both inference speed and convergence efficiency, achieving up to 88.82% inference time reduction and superior few-shot generalization capabilities due to faster convergence.

title: Applying System Archetypes to Analyze Port Congestion
authors: Y. Chai, Z. H. Munim, I. Gunawan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: A harbour or port represents a strategically vital geographic asset, with far-reaching implications for the economic development and social infrastructure of a city or even an entire nation. However, port congestion has become a persistent and complex issue that not only slows down daily maritime operations but also diminishes the broader strategic value of ports—particularly their role in emergency response and urban resilience. Conventional governance approaches typically rely on standardized interventions, which often fail to address the systemic and structural root causes of port congestion. Therefore, this study adopts a systems thinking approach to explore the recurring behavioral patterns that underline port congestion. By utilizing system thinking approach and the causal loop diagrams (CLD), the study analyses the feedback mechanisms and systemic archetypes contributing to port congestion. The findings suggest that many traditional countermeasures merely mitigate surface-level symptoms and, in some cases, worsen congestion in the long-run.

title: Resource Allocation and Optimization in Low-altitude D2D Communication Networks
authors: Changyuan Ji, Zongyan Li, Chen Yang, Hao Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: In emergency scenarios, such as natural disasters where communication infrastructure is damaged, unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) can serve as aerial base stations, providing emergency coverage for internet of things (IoT) devices. This study adapts device-to-device (D2D) communication to the low-altitude environment, where UAVs act as flexible communication hubs, ensuring reliable data transmission in areas where traditional infrastructure is unavailable. The resource allocation challenges for D2D communication in low-altitude disaster response scenarios are addressed, where UAVs provide critical network coverage. To tackle these dynamic challenges, this paper proposes a Q-learning-based resource allocation method that operates in such complex environments. Under identical conditions compared with optimal methods, simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method improves energy and spectral efficiency, achieving approximately 11%–15% enhancement in system throughput. These results demonstrate the viability of UAVs as mobile base stations for expanding communication coverage in low-altitude economies, and they emphasize the importance of efficient resource management for D2D communication in such settings.

title: Advancing Milk Quality Prediction: Dynamic Stacking Ensemble with Quality-Aware Adaptive Sampling
authors: Nadia Hoggas, Ouassila Hioual, Amel Hebboul
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: Predicting milk quality is essential for the dairy industry, as it directly impacts production efficiency, safety standards, and consumer satisfaction. This study presents a novel hybrid machine learning framework that combines a Modified Stacking Ensemble (MSE) with Quality-Aware Adaptive Sampling (QA-ADASYN) to enhance predictive performance and address class imbalance. The MSE integrates diverse base learners through a dynamically weighted meta-model informed by feature importance. At the same time, QA-ADASYN generates synthetic samples near decision boundaries of underrepresented classes, such as high-grade milk. To enhance model transparency and support explainable AI, we apply SHAP (SHapley Additive Explanations) to interpret feature contributions. The SHAP analysis confirms that features like pH and temperature are dominant predictors of milk quality. Furthermore, we conduct 5-fold cross-validation, yielding an average accuracy of 99.6% ± 0.05%, confirming the model's robustness and generalizability. Our framework achieves 100% classification accuracy on the validation set and 98.9% accuracy on an external noisy dataset, demonstrating both precision and resilience. This interpretable and scalable solution sets a new benchmark for intelligent dairy quality control, with strong potential for real-time deployment and sensor integration.

title: Consideration of topic extraction in lyrics search required by users
authors: Kanon Yukimura, Takashi Ito, Takahiro Nishigaki, Takashi Onoda
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: A topic-based lyrics retrieval system has been proposed in related work. However, the words composing the topics are similar, and the system doesn’t consider the intelligibility of the differences between topics. Therefore, in this study, we focused on the understandability of topics and compared three methods: Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA), Principal Component Analysis (PCA), and Independent Topic Analysis (ITA). Experimental results showed that ITA had the highest independence among topics and the least word overlap. Furthermore, subject experiments also confirmed that the topic ratio by ITA was evaluated to adequately represent the characteristics of the lyrics, and that it is capable of extracting topics that are easy for users to understand.

title: Application of Machine Learning for Predicting kerf angle (Ka) in Abrasive Water Jet Machining in glass fibre epoxy composites
authors: Lavanya M
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: Glass fibre-reinforced polymeric composites (GFRP) are used in various aircraft structures, wind energy, sports, structural, and automotive applications. Holes were made in the fabricated composites using the parameters (abrasive jet pressure, standoff distance, and nozzle diameter) to evaluate the kerf angle (Ka). In this work, 3 machine learning methods, such as decision tree, random forest, and XG Boost algorithm used for predicting the kerf angle in the machined holes. The confusion matrix analysis revealed that all three algorithms demonstrated strong predictive capabilities, with XGBoost showing the highest consistency by correctly classifying most instances across all classes. Regression analysis showed that XGBoost achieved superior performance with the lowest MAE (0.00738) and MSE (0.00057). In contrast, the Decision Tree model achieved an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>=1 compared to XGBoost. Random Forest also performed well with moderate error values (MAE: 0.172933, MSE: 0.0484) and an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.667, though slightly lower than the other models. From a classification perspective, XGBoost and Decision Tree both achieved balanced performance with precision, recall, and F1-scores of 0.80, while Random Forest demonstrated the highest precision (1.0) and accuracy (0.90), making it effective in distinguishing between kerf angle classes. However, the strong robustness and low error values achieved by XGBoost demonstrate that it delivers the most effective balance between predictive accuracy and reliability for kerf angle estimation. This enhanced modelling capability supports Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure by enabling advanced, data-driven process optimization, while also contributing to Responsible Consumption and Production through improved efficiency and reduced waste in machining operations.

title: Partial homogenization methods to simulate HTS tapes using the H and T-A formulations
authors: Inês S. P. Peixoto, Dmitry Sotnikov, Luis F. D. Bucho, João F. P. Fernandes, Silvio Vaschetto, Paulo J. da Costa Branco, Douglas Araujo, Bernhard Auchmann
abstract: REBCO coated conductor tapes are a promising technology for developing high-field accelerator magnets since their increased current carrying capacity and operational temperature allows achieving higher-fields and current levels with higher thermal margin. Superconducting materials still present challenges associated with their non-negligible losses in transient conditions, hence, finite element analyses become essential to design feasible superconducting systems. The H formulation is known in literature for its accuracy, while the T-A formulation offers computational efficiency. Nonetheless, both methods remain computationally demanding, especially when the superconducting tapes are modelled considering the extreme aspect ratios of different materials in the layered tapes. Homogenized models have been proposed to reduce computational requirements, however, modelling all layers as a single domain can impose the current to flow through all conducting layers rather than only the REBCO layer, even when its resistivity is very low. This study presents a comparative analysis using the H and the T-A formulations for a partially homogenized model, where the superconducting layer is modelled independently from the remaining conducting layers, and a fully homogenized model. The models' accuracy for transport loss estimation in transient conditions is discussed and compared with experimental loss measurements for a REBCO tape powered with AC currents.

title: A Knowledge Assistant for Semiconductor Fault Diagnosis Using an LLM-Enhanced Case-Based Reasoning Framework
authors: Hyunseop Park, Hyungjae Yoo, Junho Lee, Jaegun Kim, Hyunwoo Cha, Minah Park, Davin Lee, Sungmin Cho, Euisuk Kum
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Semiconductor manufacturing is increasingly complex, making defect diagnosis and resolution more challenging. As a result, engineers require extensive domain knowledge and expertise to effectively analyze failures and implement corrective actions. This study proposes an LLM-enhanced Knowledge Assistant based on a Case-Based Reasoning (CBR) framework to improve semiconductor fault diagnosis. The CBR framework systematically accumulates and reuses semiconductor-related question-and-answer (QA) data, while LLMs enhance case retrieval and adaptation for more accurate defect analysis. Experimental evaluations show that our approach improves response accuracy by 27% and increases user satisfaction by 0.94 points on a 5-point scale, compared to the baseline model. This research accelerates defect resolution by enabling real-time knowledge acquisition and reuse, enhancing semiconductor manufacturing efficiency.

title: TrustSciAgent: Towards Rigorous and Trustworthy Agents for Scientific Research
authors: Yang Li, Meng Wang, Mengting Zhang, Zhixiong Zhang, Guangyin Zhang, Hanyu Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Large language models have enabled automated agents to tackle complex scientific research tasks, yet most existing approaches struggle to deliver scientifically rigorous and verifiable outputs. In this work, we propose a novel agent framework, TrustSciAgent, which introduces a unified evidence–reasoning–validation pipeline explicitly governed by newly formulated scientific research trustworthiness principles. TrustSciAgent structurally organizes the entire research process into pre-research, in-research, and post-research phases, ensuring that each stage strictly adheres to these principles. This design compels the agent to generate transparent, logically sound reasoning chains and deliver auditable scientific conclusions. Comprehensive experiments across four scientific domains and three representative language models demonstrate that TrustSciAgent consistently improves both the structural completeness and the correctness of reasoning outputs, outperforming standard LLM-based agents. Our results provide strong evidence that embedding domain-agnostic trustworthiness principles into the agent workflow is critical for enabling credible, generalizable, and verifiable automated scientific research.

title: Table Structure-Aware Learning for Handwritten OCR Correction in Noisy Industrial Documents
authors: J. Hong, S. Yu, J. Kim, J. Park, S. Moon
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: This study aims to improve OCR performance on handwritten table-based documents from industrial sites by utilizing structural and contextual features. Inspired by human reading behavior, the proposed framework builds a graph of inter-block relationships using a GNN, capturing layout patterns such as row alignment and repeated inspection phrases. These structure-informed features are integrated into an LLM to perform semantic correction based on contextual flow. The method is suited for inspection reports with irregular handwriting and noisy layouts, where conventional OCR often fails. By combining structural cues and semantic context, the approach enhances text correction accuracy. Performance will be evaluated using Character Error Rate (CER), Word Error Rate (WER), and F1-score for graph-based structure prediction. This framework demonstrates the practical potential of structure- and context-aware correction for digitizing handwritten industrial documents.

title: Feasibility Assessment of Piezoelectric Energy Harvesting from Aircraft Landing Gear for Powering Onboard Sensors
authors: Samuel Metson, Md Shamim Ahmed, Yu Jia
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Micro and Miniature Power Systems, Self-Powered Sensors and Energy Autonomous Devices (PowerMEMS)
abstract: Current battery technologies are environmentally damaging, whilst their need for replacement and maintenance wastes time and resources. Piezoelectric technology offers a sustainable alternative by capturing wasted energy during aircraft operation. This paper investigates the feasibility of using piezoelectric energy harvesters mounted on aircraft landing gear to generate electrical power for onboard sensors. A PZT harvester was attached to the main strut of a 3D-printed scale landing gear model and subjected to DO-160-derived vibrational data to experimentally simulate in-flight conditions. The harvester demonstrated a resonant frequency of 203 Hz, producing a maximum power of 9.5 μW at an optimal resistance of 20 kΩ. Results indicate that landing gear placement yields higher normalised power density compared with previously studied locations such as the wing root and fuselage. Further experimentation should utilise vibrational data from taxi, take-off, and landing conditions, and employ greater amplitudes to produce more realistic voltages.

title: LLM-Facilitated Persona-Based Delphi Method for Multi-Criteria Idea Evaluation
authors: Riku Nagumo, Kouya Kitagawa, Hiroshi Maruyama, Hiroyuki Matsuyama, Hajime Sasaki
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: This study proposes a novel multi-perspective idea evaluation framework by combining the traditional Delphi method with AI-generated personas and Large Language Models (LLMs). Unlike conventional approaches that rely on predefined evaluation criteria, our method enables each persona to independently select and apply its own criteria based on unique attributes. Through iterative rounds facilitated by an LLM, evaluations converge while retaining diversity and minimizing bias. We demonstrate this approach through the assessment of multiple product ideas, highlighting how persona attributes such as age and gender influence evaluation perspectives. The results suggest this framework enhances both the efficiency and inclusivity of early-stage idea screening and consensus building.

title: Personalized Operator Assignment Method for Fair Workload Distribution in Industry 5.0 Job Shop Scheduling
authors: H. Hudaifah, H. H. Saleh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Conventional job shop scheduling approaches frequently overlook operator well-being. This work proposes Hierarchical Optimization for Dynamic Operator Assignment (HODA), a personalized assignment method that balances operator workloads by leveraging physiological operator data including age, weight, height, and heart rate. The Adaptive Neuro-Fuzzy Inference System (ANFIS) estimates each operator’s energy expenditure, and the Ant Workload Balance Optimizer (AWBO) allocates tasks to minimize the variance of cumulative workloads among operators. Experimental results show that HODA outperforms two benchmark methods and is practical for industrial deployment thanks to its modular design and the widespread availability of affordable wearable devices for hearth rate monitoring. By accurately capturing the actual effort experience by operator, energy expenditure metrics provide a more reliable measure of workload than task duration alone, aligning with human-centric scheduling of Industry 5.0.

title: Multi-Channel Attacks on Dilithium: Bridging Power Gaps with EM-Guided Synthetic Traces
authors: Qikang Fan, Jingdian Ming, Yiwen Gao, Yongbin Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Multi-Channel Fusion Attacks (MCFAs) boosts the effectiveness of side-channel cryptanalysis by combining information leakages from multiple channels such as power and electromagnetic (EM) leakages. However, current MFCAs require the same number of traces across the channels, which poses a critical constraint that does not necessarily hold in practical scenarios. For instance, acquiring contactless EM traces is considerably easier than obtaining power traces. Consequently, an attacker can collect many more EM traces, but a considerable portion of them must be discarded due to this constraint. To address the constraint of requiring equal numbers of traces across channels while fully utilizing the otherwise discarded EM traces, we propose a novel multi-channel fusion framework. This framework leverages a machine learning model to synthesize the missing power traces, thereby aligning the number of traces in the power and EM channels. As a result, it maximizes the utilization efficiency of the available traces. Specifically, we introduce GTL, a hybrid generative adversarial network that integrates Transformer and LSTM architectures for effective trace synthesis. We present the first MCFAs against the postquantum cryptographic scheme CRYSTALS-Dilithium. Experimental results show that, compared with existing MCFAs, our approach reduces the required number of traces by more than 50%.

title: VMPL-KMI: Protecting Kernel Module Integrity within Confidential VMs
authors: Benshan Mei, Wenhao Wang, Dongdai Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Confidential Virtual Machines (CVMs), such as AMD SEV, offer external protection but lack a privilege hierarchy, making them vulnerable to susceptible loadable kernel modules (LKMs). Although the Integrity Measurement Architecture (IMA) checks load-time integrity, it is prone to kernel exploits. While AMD SEV-SNP’s VM Privilege Levels (VMPLs) offer hardware-enforced intra-CVM isolation, they remain underexploited for kernel protection. This paper presents VMPL-KMI, utilizing VMPLs to enforce both load-time measurement and runtime protection of LKMs. By maintaining MList in the most privileged VMPL0 and synchronizing integrity checks with memory protection, VMPL-KMI prevents tampering and eliminates Time-Of-Check-to-Time-Of-Use (TOCTTOU) vulnerabilities. To minimize the overhead, we introduce a service protocol based on the Secure VM Service Module (SVSM) standard, reducing verification to a single interaction. Experimental results demonstrate practical efficiency: 5–10% overhead for small modules (over 20% for larger ones) during loading and less than 5% during unloading.

title: A Curved Transmitting-Coil Array for Multi-Dimensional Wireless Power Transfer in 3D Cylindrical Space
authors: Ruihan Ma, Shuang Li, Chang Liu, Yu Xiao, Ming Liu, Chengbin Ma
abstract: In recent years, high-frequency wireless power transfer (WPT), such as operating at 6.78 MHz (MHz), has attracted increasing attention due to its improved spatial freedom. In applications such as pipeline inspection robots and medical implants, the transmitting (Tx) coils are usually attached to curved surfaces, and the receiving device often undergoes multi-degree-of-freedom rotations during movement (i.e., positional and angular misalignment). Therefore, this article develops a staggered and overlapping curved Tx-coil array design to achieve a uniform magnetic field distribution in three-dimensional (3D) directions in cylindrical space. The staggered layout is periodic and spatially scalable, overcoming the spatial limitations of traditional designs; the overlapping of each individual curved Tx coil also suppresses the cross-coupling inside the coil array in the 3D direction. In addition, Tx input current phase modulation is applied to shape the magnetic field in the cylindrical space. Finally, the concept of the staggered curved coil array is implemented and verified in a 6.78 MHz WPT experimental system. The results show that the design greatly improves the spatial freedom of power transfer in 3D cylindrical space with a static and pre-optimized manner (i.e., no adaptation), especially showing high tolerance to rotations with position and angle misalignment. For instance, when charging a planar receiver with misaligned position and 20<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$^{\circ }$</tex-math></inline-formula> titled angle, the coefficient of variation of the received output voltage is reduced to 6.5% over a 360<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$^{\circ }$</tex-math></inline-formula> rotation.

title: AI/ML Based QoS Recommendations for Energy Optimization in 6G Networks
authors: Sara Ghasvarianjahromi, Abbas Kiani, Amanda Xiang, John Kaippallimalil, Tony Saboorian, Nirwan Ansari
abstract: The evolution of 5G networks toward 6G introduces new challenges in simultaneously meeting stringent QoS requirements and improving energy efficiency. In this paper, we propose an AI/ML-based framework that leverages 3GPP-defined functions— specifically, NWDAF, EIF, and SSF— to generate customized per-UE latency recommendations. These recommendations are incorporated into an optimization framework that jointly performs energy-aware UP-path adjustment and transmit-power control. Through simulations, we demonstrate that this method achieves superior energyâ“latency performance compared to traditional baselines, positioning it as a strong candidate for 6G networks.

title: Reversible Logic-based RO-PUF Architecture with Enhanced Security Against Modeling and EM Side-channel Attacks
authors: Ubair Ali, Ambika Prasad Shah
abstract: Protecting hardware devices from counterfeiting and attacks has led to the wide adoption of Physical Unclonable Function (PUF) as a hardware security primitive, which is used to generate unique circuit signatures. In this work, we proposed a Reversible-Logic (RL) system featuring a Ring Oscillator (RO) based PUF that enhances randomness, reliability, non-linearity, and resistance to machine-learning (ML), deep-learning (DL), and side channel attacks (SCA). The proposed design is implemented on an FPGA board and evaluated across different temperatures. Experimental results show that the proposed design achieves 49.70% uniformity, 49.99% uniqueness, and 50.90% bit aliasing at the room temperature. Also, Bit Error Rate (BER), Reliability, and Key error rate (KER) are calculated at various temperatures, and the significant results obtained are 0.002, 99.85%, and 0.046 at 40°C, respectively. In addition, the proposed RO-PUF successfully passes all 15 NIST randomness tests. Further ML and DL models were used to evaluate the modeling resistance, and the proposed design shows the best accuracy of 49.85%, which is close to a random guess, confirming the modeling resilience of our design. The proposed design was further evaluated under EM side channel analysis, demonstrating that it successfully conceals 96.85% information.

title: MPC-Based Speed Tracking for PMSM Electric Vehicles
authors: Amira Lakhdara, Tahar Bahi, Yousra Izgheche, Salima Lekhchine
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: This paper investigates speed control of an electric vehicle driven by a permanent magnet synchronous motor. Three widely used control strategies are examined and compared: a conventional proportional integral controller, a robust sliding mode controller and model predictive control. Simulation results indicate that SMC provides accurate tracking but generates noticeable high-frequency oscillations in the control signals. In contrast, MPC significantly reduces these oscillations thanks to its predictive action and explicit consideration of system constraints. The proposed MPC strategy is evaluated under several representative driving conditions, including vehicle start-up, constant-speed cruising, hill climbing, gradual braking, stop-and-go traffic, and rapid acceleration for overtaking. All scenarios are implemented in the MATLAB/Simulink environment using a detailed EV and PMSM model. The results demonstrate that MPC offers improved speed tracking, smoother torque and current responses, and better overall driving comfort compared with the PI and SMC approaches.

title: A 590-Nanosecond 757-Gbps FPGA Lossy Compressed Network
authors: Michihiro Koibuchi, Takumi Honda, Naoto Fukumoto, Shoichi Hirasawa, Koji Nakano
publish: IEEE Transactions on Parallel and Distributed Systems
abstract: Inter-FPGA communication bandwidth has become a limiting factor in scaling memory-intensive workloads on FPGA-based systems. While modern FPGAs integrate high- bandwidth memory (HBM) to increase local memory throughput, network interfaces often lag behind, creating an imbalance between computation and communication resources. Data compression is a technique to increase effective communication bandwidth by reducing the amount of data transferred, but existing solutions struggle to meet the performance and operation latency requirements of FPGA-based platforms. This paper presents a high- throughput lossy compression framework that enables sub-microsecond latency communication in FPGA clusters. The proposed design addresses the challenge of aligning variable-length compressed data with fixed-width network channels by using transpose circuits, memory-bank reordering, and word- wise operations. A run-length encoding scheme with bounded error is employed to compress floating-point and fixed-point data without relying on complex fine-grained bit-level manipulations, enabling low-latency and scalable implementation. The proposed architecture is implemented on a custom Stratix 10 MX2100 FPGA card equipped with eight 50 Gbps network ports and silicon photonics transceivers. The system achieves up to 757 Gbps of aggregate bandwidth per FPGA in collective communication operations. Compression and decompression are performed within 590 ns total latency, while maintaining the quality of results in a GradAllReduce workload for deep learning.

title: Research on the Resilience Evolution of Knowledge Networks Considering Key Node Failure
authors: Zhai Junfan, Yang Naiding, Huang Yuheng, Yao Yuehui
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Amid growing global technological competition and increasing emphasis on technology localization, R&D networks are facing rising risks of technical disruption, often manifested through the failure of nodes within the knowledge network. This study explores how knowledge network resilience changes under different node failure scenarios. The findings show: (1) The three failure scenarios vary in their impact on network resilience, with the gravity model-based scenario causing the most significant degradation. (2) Knowledge elements of moderate centrality tend to contribute more to maintaining network resilience than highly advanced or specialized components. These insights provide a theoretical foundation for enterprises to develop adaptive scenarios in response to both internal and external shocks.

title: A Vector-Based Extension of the Taguchi’s T-Method for Directional Data Analysis
authors: Yuga Takao, Hiroki Iwamoto, Yasushi Nagata
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: This study presents an enhanced method of Taguchi’s T-method, tailored for directional (circular) data. While the conventional T-method is effective for linear data analysis, it encounters challenges with angular data due to its inherent circularity, which can distort predictions when angles are treated as scalar values. To address this limitation, we propose a modified T-method that incorporates vector-based weighting and circular normalization, thereby preserving angular relationships more accurately. Simulation experiments were conducted to compare the original and improved methods, revealing significant improvements in estimation accuracy, particularly for the Tb-method variant. Additionally, the proposed method was applied to real-world wind direction data, successfully predicting wind directions using data from nearby observation points. In this practical application, the modified T-method outperformed not only the original versions but also circular multiple regression. These results suggest that the improved T-method offers a robust and accurate alternative for analyzing and predicting circular data, with practical implications for fields such as meteorology, oceanography, and other domains where directional data is prevalent.

title: A Revised Dynamic Electric Carbon Factor Calculation Method Integrated with Green Electricity and Green Certificate Trading
authors: Qingshen Gong, Yuan Li, Guojun Lan, Xiangyang Man, Jie Chen, Yingxiao Chen, Yunbao Jiang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: With the comprehensive transition of China’s energy policy from dual control on energy consumption to dual control on carbon emission, the establishment of a robust carbon emission statistical and accounting system has become an urgent priority. However, the current static method for calculating electric carbon factor, which is annual, homogenized, and outdated, fails to reflect the temporal variability and spatial disparities of carbon emissions. Furthermore, it does not account for the impacts of green electricity and green certificate transactions. To address these issues, this paper proposes a revised dynamic electric carbon factor calculation method that incorporates the effects of green electricity and green certificate transactions. First, the relationships between green certificates, green electricity, and carbon emission offsets are analyzed in detail. A more precise green certificate carbon emission offset model is developed based on the marginal carbon emission factor. Subsequently, a revised dynamic electric carbon factor calculation method is proposed, which accounts for the influence of trading behaviors, based on the principles of carbon responsibility allocation for transaction and non-transaction flows. Finally, a case study is conducted using the PJM-5 bus system to validate the rationality and effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: HCFMaNet: A Novel Holistic Cross-modal Fusion Mamba Network for Multi-modal Medical Image Fusion
authors: Xinjian Wei, Yu Qiu, Jing Xu, Jun Zhang
abstract: Multi-modal medical image fusion synthesizes functional and structural features from different imaging modalities, providing comprehensive and accurate information for subsequent analysis. Existing fusion techniques based on Transformer often suffer from reduced accuracy and efficiency due to local perceptual limitations and cross-modal computational complexity. Recently, Mamba has proven effective in various uni-modal tasks due to its exceptional ability to model long-range dependency. However, the straightforward and effective cross-modal information flow and interaction based on Mamba remains underdeveloped in multi-modal fusion. In this paper, we propose a novel Holistic Cross-modal Fusion Mamba Network for multi-modal medical image fusion, namely HCFMaNet. HCFMaNet introduces a new local-aware Mamba which perceives local positional relationships while modeling long-range dependency, thereby capturing richer inter-modal local-global feature representations. Additionally, a novel holistic cross-modal fusion Mamba is designed for explicit cross-modal perception and interaction both in spatial and channel dimensions by cross-spatial interaction and the proposed channel exchange embedding mechanism. Extensive experiments across various medical fusion sub-tasks demonstrate the high accuracy (avg.+22.4%) and effectiveness (avg.+92.7%) of our proposed method. Furthermore, HCFMaNet can be applied to other image fusion tasks, such as multi-exposure and visual-infrared fusion, yielding precise fusion outcomes.

title: Numerical Study on Seismic Responses of HV Power Transformer
authors: Xiaojie Yang, Yongfu Ma, Zibin Li, Wang Zhu, Jiyun Ren, Xiaohan Liang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: This paper addresses the seismic safety of large oilimmersed high-voltage (HV) transformers. An HV transformer from an actual engineering project is selected as the study object, and a refined three-dimensional transformer-bushing finite element model, including the tank, bushings, and accessories, is established. Using ABAQUS, modal analysis and multi-groundmotion time-history analyses are carried out. The results show that the first five natural frequencies of the system fall within $5.32-10.06 \mathrm{~Hz}$, which lies in the predominant frequency range of typical earthquake excitations, indicating a pronounced risk of dynamic amplification. Under the input of two recorded and two artificial ground motions ($\mathrm{PGA}=0.2 \mathrm{~g}$, with triaxial components in the ratio 1:0.85:0.65), the study focuses on the displacement and acceleration responses at the tops of the 220 kV and 110 kV bushings, as well as the stress response at the bushing bases. The maximum displacement and acceleration of the 220 kV bushing reach 21.97 mm and $8.82 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$, respectively, and the maximum stress at its base is 6.27 MPa. Compared with the porcelain bushing’s flexural strength of 40 MPa, this corresponds to a safety factor of 6.38, which is significantly higher than the value of 2.0 recommended by the Chinese code GB 50260-2013, indicating that brittle failure of the bushing is not the controlling condition under design-level earthquakes. The findings provide useful reference for seismic design, vulnerability assessment, and retrofit optimization of high-voltage transformers.

authors: N/A

title: Adaptive Safety Control of Nonlinearly Parameterized Systems via Logic-based Switching
authors: Lijun Long, Siyu Tang
abstract: This paper investigates the problem of adaptive safety control for a class of nonlinearly parameterized systems. A novel adaptive safety control strategy for the problem studied is established to guarantee system safety, in which a logic switching mechanism is designed to replace parameter update law and a barrier function with a high relative degree with respect to the control input is considered. Also, a high-order parameterized control barrier function is introduced, which can accommodate nonlinearly parameterized systems of arbitrary relative degrees. The proposed strategy permits removal of two common restrictions in traditional adaptive safety control, in which a priori bound of unknown parameters is usually required to be known, or initial parameter estimation error must be within a known compact set, and the parameterization is restricted to a linear parameterization. Moreover, the proposed strategy is extended to high relative degree multiple safety constraints. Finally, two examples are provided to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed design strategy.

title: Application of FPGA-Based Embedded Real-Time Control System in the Dynamic Stability Optimization of Photovoltaic Inverters
authors: Zijun Song, Chenrui Zhang, Yichen Yuan, Zheng Cao, Yihao Zhang, Zhihang Sun
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: With the rise of photovoltaic systems connected to the power grid, the dynamic stability of inverters under changing levels of solar radiation and load disturbances has become a growing concern. To address this concern, this study presents a new method for controlling the inverter by developing a predictive disturbance suppression module and an adaptive stability margin regulator based on the traditional voltage-current dual-loop synchronous rotating frame (SRF) control algorithm. The new hybrid control core integrates model predictive control (MPC) with Lyapunov dynamic margin assessment and employs a multirate scheduling mechanism and a computational time for real-time control laws of less than ten microseconds implemented in VHDL to allow for the quick reconfiguration of poles and zeros in the time domain and the online re-identification of parameters. A novel event-triggered adaptive damping injection mechanism was also developed to reduce oscillations in weak grids and islanding events. Laboratory tests were performed using a 3 kW photovoltaic inverter system, and performance results indicated a reduction of 42.3% in overshoot compared to traditional Proportional Integral (PI) controllers following IEC 62116 test standards.

title: Defending Federated Learning against Backdoor Attacks by Inspecting Sparsity-Guided Out-of-Distribution Model Behavior
authors: Songgao Tu
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Federated learning (FL) enables collaborative model training while preserving data privacy, but it is vulnerable to backdoor attacks, where malicious clients inject hidden triggers to manipulate model behavior. Existing defenses often rely on parameter inspection, which risks privacy leakage and may fail to detect stealthy attacks. In this work, we propose a novel defense method by inspecting sparsity-guided out-of-distribution model behavior, dubbed as ISGOOD, which is well-grounded in the principle "You are what you do," focusing on model behavior rather than raw parameters to identify malicious clientsSpecifically, ISGOOD constructs adversarial out-of-distribution (OOD) test samples by perturbing K OOD data samples to target K classes via the aggregated model. It then applies N sparsity masks to each client model, capturing K×K×N-dimensional soft-max output features on the OOD samples. Next, an anomaly detection algorithm can identify clients with deviant behavioral patterns, which are excluded from aggregation. This approach avoids direct parameter inspection, preserving privacy while exposing inconsistent behavior of back-doored modelsExtensive experiments on four benchmark datasets MNIST, Fashion-MNIST, CIFAR-10, and Tiny-Imagenet validate that ISGOOD can effectively defend against backdoor attacks by distinguishing malicious clients through their OOD behavior. It maintains high accuracy on legitimate tasks while robustly mitigating attacks, demonstrating superior privacy-preserving capabilities and generalizability across datasets. This work provides a new perspective for securing FL systems by leveraging behavioral signatures.

title: TCP-Awareness Augmented Robust TLS Traffic Classification: A Hybrid Deep Learning Approach
authors: Yewa Li, Yitan Huang, Bo Jiang, Zhigang Lu, Zelin Cui
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: The Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol, while securing network communications via encryption, poses significant challenges to traffic classification. Traditional TLS traffic classification methods often suffer from performance degradation in complex and dynamic network environments due to their dependence on specific network conditions, limited exploitation of TCP protocol semantics, and insufficient robustness validation. To address these issues, we propose a TCP-awareness augmented TLS traffic classification approach based on hybrid deep learning. The method introduces three traffic augmentation algorithms—subsequence duplication, subsequence shifting, and packet size variation—that model realistic traffic variations induced by TCP mechanisms. A Traffic Invariant Extractor, built on BYOL self-supervised learning, is employed to capture stable representations from augmented variants and improve feature generalization across environments. Experimental results demonstrate consistent improvements: average accuracy gains of 5.51%–10.22% across different environments, with reductions in performance variance up to 79.2%. These findings highlight the importance of incorporating TCP semantics into encrypted traffic analysis and provide a practical direction for enhancing the robustness of TLS traffic classification in diverse deployment scenarios.

title: TeGCN:Temporal Evolution-Aware Trust Evaluation for Dynamic Social Networks
authors: Chunhui Liu, Geming Xia, Chaodong Yu, Yuze Zhang, Jiawen Wu, Hongwei Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Dynamic trust evaluation in online social networks is of great significance for applications such as recommendation systems, financial risk control, and e-commerce, but it remains a challenging research problem. Most existing methods are based on static network topologies or simple temporal modeling, making it difficult to effectively capture the dynamic evolution laws of trust relationships. To address this issue, this paper proposes a dynamic graph neural network-based trust evaluation model, TeGCN, for predicting dynamic trust relationships in social networks. TeGCN consists of a spatial aggregation unit, a gated temporal evolution unit, and a joint prediction unit. In the spatial aggregation unit, node spatial feature representations are generated through linear transformation after concatenating features of neighbor nodes and forward/backward edge attribute information via average aggregation. The gated temporal evolution unit employs a Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) to model the temporal evolution of trust relationships and introduces a dynamic weight adjustment mechanism to enhance feature extraction at key time steps. Finally, the joint prediction unit integrates spatio-temporal features, performs nonlinear mapping through a multi-layer perceptron (MLP), and outputs the probability distribution of node trust levels to achieve end-to-end dynamic trust prediction. Experiments based on two real dynamic trust network datasets, Bitcoin-Alpha and Bitcoin-OTC, verify the effectiveness of TeGCN. The results show that TeGCN significantly outperforms existing baseline models in key metrics such as F1-score, AUC, and ACC, especially in highly dynamic scenarios.

title: Social Project Portfolio Selection in a Public Project- Based Organization for Infrastructural Development
authors: Akinlo Olorunju Mogbojuri, Oludolapo Akanni Olanrewaju
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Social projects are defined by goals that, when achieved, profit the public. The aims are predominantly insubstantial, including societal and technical effects and many others, without considering possible economic value as their sole appraisal. In societal or common sphere, the aim is generally to enhance the collection's attribute about the societal effect of selected projects. This study developed a goal programming (GP) model and genetic algorithm (GA) to select projects for infrastructural growth to improve the social life of the host communities. The developed models selected 58 out of 59 polyclinic projects, 97 out of 103 school projects, and 77 out of 80 housing and hostel projects, which produced a total of 11,378 potential jobs for residents of the host towns, alongside a total cash flow in Nigerian Naira (NGN) NGN796.460 million. The study and approach capable of selecting enormous projects, generating numerous optimal results for decision-makers regarding project selection, and estimating the social impact of the chosen projects which will enhance the social project portfolio selection problem.

title: MAT-VB: MAthematical Text-Vision Benchmark
authors: Behrooz Mansouri, Aidan Bell, Nicholas Largey, Abigail Pitcairn
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries (JCDL)
abstract: This paper introduces the Mathematical Text-Vision Benchmark (MAT-VB) for evaluating mathematical image captioning and text-to-image retrieval. The benchmark contains 4,000 image-caption pairs from Wikipedia mathematical content, split into 3,600 training and 400 test samples. For image captioning, QWEN and LLaMA models are evaluated in pretrained and fine-tuned settings, with results showing consistent improvements from fine-tuning across evaluation metrics. For text-to-image retrieval, the benchmark provides 400 queries in two formats: caption queries using original captions and natural language queries with human-authored queries. Long-Clip and LLM2CLIP models are evaluated, with Long-Clip showing significant performance gains from fine-tuning while LLM2CLIP demonstrates minimal improvement. MAT-VB addresses the gap in mathematical multimodal evaluation, providing a novel benchmark for mathematical information processing systems.

title: FedPPA: Progressive Parameter Alignment for Personalized Federated Learning
authors: Maulidi Adi Prasetia, Muhamad Risqi U. Saputra, Guntur Dharma Putra
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) is designed as a decentralized, privacy-preserving machine learning paradigm that enables multiple clients to collaboratively train a model without sharing their data. In real-world scenarios, however, clients often have heterogeneous computational resources and hold non-independent and identically distributed data (non-IID), which poses significant challenges during training. Personalized Federated Learning (PFL) has emerged to address these issues by customizing models for each client based on their unique data distribution. Despite its potential, existing PFL approaches typically overlook the coexistence of model and data heterogeneity arising from clients with diverse computational capabilities. To overcome this limitation, we propose a novel method, called Progressive Parameter Alignment (FedPPA), which progressively aligns the weights of common layers across clients with the global model’s weights. Our approach not only mitigates inconsistencies between global and local models during client updates, but also preserves client’s local knowledge, thereby enhancing personalization robustness in non-IID settings. To further enhance the global model performance while retaining strong personalization, we also integrate entropy-based weighted averaging into the FedPPA framework. Experiments on three image classification datasets, including MNIST, FMNIST, and CIFAR-10, demonstrate that FedPPA consistently outperforms existing FL algorithms, achieving superior performance in personalized adaptation.

title: Intelligent Recognition Method and System for Power Grid Flood based on Ground Monitoring Video
authors: Shunchao Dong, Guoliang Yue, Sihang Zhang, Ruidong He, Jiangbo Tian, Jingpu Ge
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: With the increasing frequency of extreme climate events, flood disasters have become a significant threat to the safe operation of power grid infrastructure. Traditional monitoring methods, which rely on manual inspection and single-point sensors, suffer from response lag, insufficient coverage, and fragmented information. To address these challenges, this paper proposes an intelligent recognition method and system for power grid floods based on ground monitoring video. The system integrates computer vision, multi-source data fusion, and Geographic Information System (GIS) technologies. It utilizes a customized YOLO-based deep learning model to perform real-time identification of flood features such as accumulated water, submerged areas, and transmission tower bases from ground monitoring videos. Furthermore, the system fuses video data with meteorological rainfall data and GIS layers to construct a dynamic, unified spatio-temporal situational map. Experimental results and system deployment demonstrate that the proposed solution achieves high-precision flood recognition, supports historical backtracking, and automatically generates vectorized early warning information, thereby shifting power grid disaster prevention from passive response to active defense.

title: OUF: Oblivious Universal Function with domain specific optimizations
authors: Victor Delfour, Marc-Olivier Killijian
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: The growing need for secure computation has spurred interest in cryptographic techniques that operate on encrypted data without revealing its content. Fully Homomorphic Encryption (FHE), especially LWE-based schemes, enables such processing while preserving confidentiality. Decentralized computing offers scalable resources without requiring in-house servers, but it relies heavily on the confidentiality guarantees of underlying schemes. While many existing protocols successfully protect input privacy, function confidentiality remains a largely overlooked but crucial aspect of secure delegated computation.In this work, we present a novel Oblivious Universal Function (OUF) scheme that enables a client to outsource computation of an arbitrary function to an untrusted server while hiding both the input data and the function being applied. Our construction leverages LWE-based FHE and a virtual-tape evaluation model to support composable, non-interactive, and reusable function execution. Crucially, the server remains oblivious not only to the encrypted inputs but also to the structure, type, and identity of the function it is executing. OUF thus bridges the gap between theoretical privacy guarantees and practical secure computation in decentralized environments.

title: Cable Charged State Detection: A Method Based on Magnetic Field Using LSTM Networks
authors: Xiong Cai, Wulin Miao, Shuzhi Dai, Jiong Hu, Lifeng Huang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: This paper presents a novel approach for detecting the charged state of cables based on magnetic field measurements using Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks. The core idea is to capture the magnetic field strength around cables, which exhibits distinct patterns when the cable is charged due to alternating current inducing a stable varying magnetic field, versus uncharged states where only ambient environmental fields are present. We collect real-world data using Hall-effect sensors positioned around power cables in a controlled laboratory environment to create timeseries magnetic field readings from multiple channels. Feature engineering extracts amplitude, frequency spectra, and statistical moments, fed into an LSTM model for binary classification. The model is trained with dropout for robustness and evaluated under varying environmental conditions. Experimental results show high accuracy of $95.5 \%$ for LSTM, outperforming baselines like Random Forest $(92.5 \%)$ and SVM $(91.0 \%)$. ROC curves indicate an AUC of $\mathbf{0. 9 8}$ for LSTM. Environmental interference analysis demonstrates resilience up to moderate levels of external magnetic disturbances. Ablation studies confirm the importance of full features and dropout. This method, inspired by recent advancements in electromagnetic sensing, offers a non-intrusive, real-time solution for cable state monitoring in power systems, enhancing safety and reliability. Future work could integrate additional sensor modalities for field deployment.

title: The Role of Physicality: Definitive Causes for Challenges in Adopting Agile Practices in Hardware Development
authors: A. P. Schlegel, F. J. Guenther, S. Weiss, A. Koch
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Companies in the hardware domain are faced with an accelerating pace of change in contextual factors that demand greater adaptability from people and processes. Therefore, the hardware development domain is adopting agile methodologies from software development, where they have proven beneficial. In this study, we examine the constraints on this adoption in the hardware domain, providing a basis for future support measures. We propose and discuss five constraints stemming directly from the physicality of products. These constraints are developed through the analysis of a generic development task to ensure objectivity, a quality that has been lacking in the fragmented research landscape until now. We argue that these immutable constraints must be orchestrated rather than overcome through naive methodology transfer, requiring organizations to adopt constraint-aware approaches that selectively adapt agile practices based on compatibility with physical realities.
