title: System reconfiguration under open-circuit faults based on five/four-legs converter using zero-sequence voltage
authors: Khaled Sahraoui, Bachir Gaoui, Lakhdar Mokrani
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: The objective of this paper is to study, through simulation, the fault-tolerant control of a double-stage Pulse-Width Modulation (PWM) AC/DC/AC converter supplying a three-phase asynchronous motor with rotor-flux orientation. we will examine fault-tolerant topologies for AC/DC/AC converters without redundant legs (6/5-leg and 5/4-leg topologies) to ensure continuity of service in the event a switch failure. After a fault occurs, appropriate reconfiguration of the 6/5-leg converter enables continued operation with the 5 healthy legs. The control must be modified when switching from a 6-leg topology to a 5-leg topology using triacs and a specific PWM scheme. However, this topology can have faults in its switches. To address this, we will study the 5/4-leg topology by modifying the control so that the converter continues to operate with the 5 healthy legs. However, this topology may have faults in its switches. The fault-tolerant 5-legconverter topology has a specific feature following the occurrence of a fault. Depending on the location of the fault, the reconfiguration can lead to three different 4-leg topologies. In the following sections, the 6/5-leg and 5/4-leg topologies will be studied in detail.

title: Transformer Hotspot Temperature Prediction Based on Improved Dynamic Thermal Circuit Model
authors: Qinzheng Wu, Tianguang Lu, Zhenwei Zhang, Shaocong Wu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Hot spot temperature and top oil temperature of power transformers are important factors affecting their load capacity and operational safety. Therefore, accurate calculation of transformer operating temperature is of great significance. This paper adopts a thermoelectric analogy method to establish an improved dynamic thermal circuit model for transformers, taking into full account the effects of environmental factors, core heat capacity, nonlinear thermal resistance, and oil viscosity changes with temperature, based on the traditional thermal circuit model. The calculation results of the improved model, the traditional thermal circuit model, and the actual temperature measurement data of the step-down transformer are compared. The results show that the top oil temperature and winding hot spot temperature calculated by the improved model have high accuracy, verifying the effectiveness of the model.

title: Adaptive Bipartite Formation Control for Nonlinear Multi-Unmanned Ground Vehicle Systems Under Sensor Attacks
authors: Lu Yin, Jie Lan, Zhiyao Ma
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: This paper addresses the adaptive resilient bipartite formation control problem for second-order nonlinear multi-unmanned ground vehicle systems under sensor data attacks, where system states become unmeasurable due to attacks and nonlinear dynamics are unknown. To solve this issue, the distributed resilient control method based on an adaptive fuzzy observer is proposed. Specifically, a distributed observer is designed to estimate the attacked states online, and adaptive technology is utilized to compensate for the unknown dynamics and the impact of attacks. This method can still achieve the preset bipartite time-varying formation under continuous attacks and ensure that the observation error is uniformly bounded. The Lyapunov function is constructed via linear matrix inequalities, and the stability of the closed-loop system is strictly proven. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method can maintain the formation configuration with stable observation errors under attacks of varying intensities.

title: A Comparative Study of the Effect of Rainfall on Ground Resistance at Different Depths
authors: Yi Chang, Peng Gao, Bo Sun, Mu Liu, Haoquan Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: The grounding resistance of lightning protection systems serves as a key parameter that mirrors the current dissipation efficiency within building structures. Despite technical guidelines discouraging testing right after rainfall, given precipitation’s effect on grounding resistance, the varied influence of rainfall on grounding resistance at different depths has not been thoroughly examined. This research explores how precipitation impacts grounding resistance at diverse burial depths through daily fixed-point measurements carried out between October 2021 and September 2022 at the Ziyang Meteorological Bureau site. By employing mathematical statistics alongside stepwise regression analysis, data from four test points with grounding electrode depths of $2.5 \mathrm{~m}, 2.0 \mathrm{~m}, 1.5 \mathrm{~m}$, and 0.5 m were analyzed. Findings reveal that the monthly averages of grounding resistance and soil resistivity are inversely related to monthly rainfall. For deeper grounding electrodes $(\geq 1.5 \mathrm{~m})$, the decrease in grounding resistance rises linearly with rainfall up to $\mathbf{2 5. 0 ~ m m}$, after which it levels off. Conversely, shallower electrodes ($\boldsymbol{x} \mathbf{0. 5 ~ m}$) display a more intricate reaction due to meteorological elements like sunlight, wind, and temperature, showing an initial rise in resistance reduction followed by a slow stabilization. A regression model was formulated to measure the connection between rainfall and grounding resistance reduction. These outcomes offer accurate technical backing for lightning protection device testing, risk evaluation, and engineering design.

title: Incremental Input-to-State Stability for Discontinuous Dynamical Systems with First-Order Projection Elements
authors: S.J.A.M. van den Eijnden, M.F. Heertjes, H. Nijmeijer, W.P.M.H. Heemels
abstract: The notion of incremental stability provides a powerful tool for the analysis and design of nonlinear systems. This paper is concerned with establishing incremental stability properties for a class of discontinuous dynamical systems that are formed by the feedback interconnection of a linear time-invariant plant (possibly including linear control elements) and a first-order projection-based element. This class of control systems has received a lot of attention due to its abilities to overcome fundamental performance limitations of linear control and recent successes in industrial motion control. By deriving and exploiting dissipativity properties of the projection element's discontinuous vector field that hold only in certain subregions of its incremental input-output space, a tailored piecewise quadratic incremental Lyapunov function is constructed by appropriately “connecting” local incremental quadratic storage functions. Based on this result, conditions for guaranteeing incremental input-to-state stability of the considered class of discontinuous dynamical systems are formulated in the form of numerically tractable linear matrix inequalities. The benefits of these results are demonstrated through a numerical case-study showing “nonlinear” Bode-plots for accurate steady-state performance analysis.

title: Linking Policies for the Permanent Web
authors: Patrick Le, Quang Bui, Alexander Grigorian, Alexey Kuraev, Thiyazan Salman, Tu H. Nguyen, Mat Kelly, Sawood Alam
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries (JCDL)
abstract: Earlier approaches such as InterPlanetary Wayback (IPWB) demonstrated how archived content could be stored in the InterPlanetary File System (IPFS) but still required a centralized index to resolve resources. We evaluate the feasibility of the InterPlanetary Archival Record Object (IPARO), a framework proposed to eliminate the dependency on local indexes in decentralized web archiving. IPARO addresses this limitation by embedding version-linked references directly into archival objects stored in IPFS and using the InterPlanetary Name System (IPNS) for discovery of the latest versions. This design enables traversal of a resource’s version history entirely within the decentralized network. In this paper, we simulate the construction and resolution of IPARO chains to assess their practicality for replaying archived Web content without centralized infrastructure. Our evaluation examines integrity and availability under various conditions. Results show that IPARO retains the benefits of distributed storage while eliminating reliance on local indexes, offering a scalable and robust model for decentralized preservation.

title: Proposal of a Fingering Estimation Method for Piano Beginners combining SVM and DP
authors: Toshihiro Tomizuka, Takahiro Nishigaki
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: In research on fingerings estimation for beginner piano scores, there is a problem that it is difficult to consider the degree of difficulty of fingerings during performance, such as avoiding continuous use of the same finger. In a related study, a method using SVM that considers the difficulty of fingerings during performance was proposed. The estimation accuracy was better than the previous method. However, this method uses ground truth labels as input features. And this method did not consider the notes after the estimated notes, so unnatural finger movements were selected. In this study, we propose a method that uses the estimated data for the features. And we propose the method that combines the prediction results of SVM and dynamic programming to prevent the selection of unnatural finger movements. In addition to the conventional agreement rate, RMSE is employed to assess the naturalness of the predicted fingerings. The application of the proposed method to real data confirms that the agreement rate increases and the RMSE is halved compared to related work.

title: Research on Cascading Failure Control and Resilience in Power Grid Based on Key Node
authors: Gengchen Zhang, Min Zhao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Existing cascading failure control schemes treat nodes homogeneously in the load redistribution process of faulty nodes, failing to consider the differences between key nodes and ordinary nodes, which results in poor network invulnerability. To solve the above problem, this study aims to improve the invulnerability of power grids and proposes a new cascading failure control strategy for power grids combined with key node sequences. The strategy utilizes key node sequences and integrates the power information of the node itself and its neighbor nodes to construct a key-node-based fault load redistribution model. Simulation results show that the load redistribution strategy proposed in this study can effectively improve the invulnerability of common power grids.

title: Temperature Dependence of Resistivity and Noise in Electrodeposited Bismuth Samples for X-ray Transition-Edge Sensors
authors: A. Mauro, O. Quaranta, N. Coppola, L. Gades, A. Galdi, M. G. Adesso, T. Guruswamy, L. Maritato, A. Miceli, S. Pagano, C. Barone
abstract: A combination of gold and bismuth is commonly used as absorber for X-ray transition-edge sensors, due to high atomic numbers and, consequently large cross sections, and to their complementary thermal properties. Since Au conductivity dominates, especially at cryogenic temperatures, electrodeposited bismuth films have been grown over sputtered gold, so that bismuth forms a bridge on the gold fingers and, therefore, the conductivity contribution from the underlying Au layer can be removed. Resistance as a function of the temperature has been investigated for pristine and annealed samples, both with and without a dc magnetic field. A general behavior has been observed, thus evidencing three different zones. At high temperatures a metal regime, described in terms of a Fermi liquid model, is identified. In an intermediate temperature region, a hysteretic and irreversible insulating-type resistance is observed. While, at low temperatures a resistance plateau appears. To better understand the electrical conduction properties, noise measurements have been also performed. Two possible models have been considered to interpret experimental data in the intermediate temperature region: Fluctuation-Induced Tunneling and Quantum Interference Effects. The analysis here reported gives indication on the granular structure of the investigated films, which could be represented as random networks of tunneling junctions, where the nodes are the conducting pathways connecting different junctions. In these regions, temperature-induced intergranular processes could be effectively detected giving additional information on the prediction of the ultimate energy resolving capabilities of detectors with bismuth absorbers.

title: Analysis of Cryptocurrency Safety via Time-Series Analysis and Feature-Based Classification
authors: Hiroki Igarashi, Takashi Hasuike
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: In this study, we propose a methodology to identify relatively safe cryptocurrencies by analyzing trading volume and price data. Rather than relying solely on historical data prediction, we employ autoregressive (AR) and autoregressive conditional heteroskedasticity (ARCH) models to generate future time-series data and combine these with past observations to improve analytical accuracy. We then extract a set of statistical and temporal features from both volume and price, apply principal component analysis for dimensionality reduction, and enhance signal clarity. Finally, we perform density - based spatial clustering (DBSCAN) to categorize assets as safe or unsafe. Experiments using 2023 and Q1 2024 data demonstrate classification precision exceeding 97%, confirming the method’s robustness even with limited samples. By integrating well-established models in a novel workflow, our approach offers both high interpretability and operational feasibility for real-time risk monitoring. Future work will explore the incorporation of exogenous market signals and extension to multi-asset portfolios.

title: Joint User Activity, Delay, and Data Detection for Heterogeneous Asynchronous Massive Random Access
authors: Nan Zhao, Mengqi Yu, Yuanfan Jin
abstract: Massive random access is a key challenge in massive machine-type communications (mMTC), which aims to support connectivity for a large number of devices. Most existing studies assume strict user synchronization; however, this assumption is often unrealistic in practical scenarios without base station coordination. To address the issue of random access in asynchronous scenarios, this paper proposes two innovative algorithms. First, we propose a detection algorithm based on generalized approximate message passing with the sum product algorithm (GAMP-SPA). By incorporating user delay characteristics into a factor graph model and performing iterative message updates, the algorithm progressively converges to the optimal posterior probability distribution, thereby enabling joint detection of user activity, delay, and transmitted data. Second, we propose AMP-Net, a model-driven approximate message passing network that integrates deep neural architectures with message passing principles to reduce reliance on prior knowledge of both channel state information (CSI) and user activity patterns. Simulation results demonstrate that the two proposed algorithms achieve superior performance in asynchronous scenarios, significantly outperforming traditional compressed sensing algorithms in non-coherent joint detection tasks.

title: Online Reliability Assessment of Nuclear Power Components via Mechanistic and Data-Driven Modeling
authors: Xiangyu Jiang, Yixiong Feng, Zhiwu Li, MengChu Zhou, Xuanyu Wu, Jianrong Tan
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Reliability assessment is essential for ensuring the stable operation of industrial systems. This study presents a hybrid reliability assessment framework that integrates mechanism-based and data-driven approaches for online degradation evaluation. A representative degradation mode— impact fatigue—is investigated to demonstrate the method. The mechanistic component is formulated by using crack propagation theory and Miner’s cumulative damage rule; while the data-driven one employs a generalized power-law Wiener process with an additive nonlinear drift. Both sources of information are fused through an evolving unscented Kalman filter that performs optimal and unbiased online state estimation via prediction and observation updates. In the proposed framework, the Wiener process serves as the state equation, and the mechanistic model functions as the measurement equation. The reliability of impact fatigue is further evaluated by using the inverse Gaussian distribution, which is inherently associated with the Wiener process. Application to a thrust bearing in the main pump of a pressurized water reactor demonstrates the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed method over existing ones.

title: Nonlinear Filter Design for Phase-Coded Waveforms in MIMO Radar Using Wavelet Transform Neural Networks
authors: Zizhou Qiu, Keqing Duan, Zhipeng Liao, Wei Shen, Ye Lai
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Phase-coded waveforms are widely used in multiple-input-multiple-output (MIMO) radar systems, but ideal orthogonal coding is difficult to realize in practice. Non-orthogonality among waveforms introduces phase distortion and signal-to-noise ratio loss, while Doppler sensitivity further degrades system performance due to modulation-induced mismatch. To address these issues, this paper develops a unified MIMO radar signal model under non-orthogonal phase coding and analyzes the effects of waveform non-orthogonality and Doppler modulation on matched filter outputs. A signal recovery network CANet, combining convolutional neural networks with an attention mechanism, is proposed to remove phase-coding modulation and restore the signal spectrum, thereby providing reliable time-frequency priors for subsequent filter design. To cope with errors in time–frequency estimation, resolution limitations, and complex multi-target scenarios, we further propose WUNet, a nonlinear filter that integrates wavelet-based feature fusion with a UNet architecture. WUNet exploits both time-frequency and phase-amplitude features in the encoder and enables effective waveform separation and accurate phase recovery in the decoder. Simulation results verify that the proposed approach significantly mitigates the adverse impact of waveform non-orthogonality and Doppler sensitivity on MIMO radar performance.

title: High Spatial Resolution of GRACE-Derived Ice Mass Change reveals Glacier-scale mass loss in Greenland Ice Sheet
authors: Zhuoya Shi, Zemin Wang, Baojun Zhang, Manman Luo, Shuang Wu, Jiachun An, Haojian Wu, Chunxia Zhou
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: The Gravity Recovery and Climate Experiment (GRACE) and its follower GRACE-Follow On (GRACE-FO) act as a reliable tool to detect the Earth's surface mass change. However, its discontinuity between GRACE and GRACE-FO limits its applicability for long term analysis. Its coarse spatial resolution (∼300 km) of GRACE and GRACE-FO (GRACE/GFO) hampers detailed understanding of ice mass change response mechanisms to climate change at spatial scales below 200,000 km2. Additionally, researches in downscaling GRACE-derived ice mass change in the Greenland ice sheet (GrIS) remains limited. Based on the continuous reconstructed GRACE/GFO data, we firstly compared the performance of geographically weighted regression (GWR) and random forest (RF) to downscale GRACE/GFO from 0.25°×0.25° to 5 km×5 km at a spatial global scale (SGS) in GrIS. This study presents the first application of such high-resolution downscaling to the reconstructed GRACE/GFO results over the GrIS. Finally, the SGS-GWR outperformed SGS-RF in capturing reasonable and finer signals of ice mass change. And downscaled results from SGS-GWR fit well with original GRACE/GFO mascon solutions and other independent estimates, achieving mean correlation coefficients and mean root mean square error at 0.98/2.68 cm by considering the nonstationarity heterogeneity of variables. Based on the continuous and high-resolution ice mass change, glacier-scale analysis of climatic forcing mechanisms, such as Greenland Blocking through its modulation of runoff, snowfall, rainfall, and solid ice discharge in 2012 and 2019, represents a novel contribution.

title: Finder6: Efficient IPv6 Addresses Scanning Based on Hostname Correlation in IPv6-Only Network
authors: Ce Sun, Liancheng Zhang, Ruijuan Wang, Yakai Fang, Hongtao Zhang, Haojie Zhu, Luyang Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Existing on-link IPv6 address scanning technologies based on IPv6-only information rely on protocol features such as ICMPv6, MLD, and other protocol features to induce responses. However, these scanning packets are easily intercepted by the default security mechanisms of modern operating systems (OSs), leading to issues such as low OS coverage and incomplete IPv6 address scan results of alive nodes. On-link IPv6 address scanning technologies based on dual-stack correlation information overly rely on IPv4 networks, resulting in low IPv6 address scanning efficiency and inability to operate in IPv6-only networks. To this end, we propose an efficient IPv6 addresses scanning technology based on hostname correlation in IPv6-only network (HFinder6), which passively captures DHCPv6 Solicit messages sent by both currently alive and newly joined nodes, and constructs Router Advertisement messages of neighbor discovery protocol to trigger alive nodes to proactively send DHCPv6 Solicit messages, enabling the rapid acquisition of hostname information for on-link nodes. Subsequently, the IPv6 address information is queried in parallel using the mDNS protocol and LLMNR protocol, thereby achieving efficient scanning of IPv6 addresses for alive nodes in IPv6-only network. A typical IPv6-only and dual-stack network environment was established, comprising 14 versions of OSs such as Windows and Linux. HFinder6 was tested in this environment and compared with 4 IPv6 address scanning scripts based on IPv6-only information from the Nmap tool and 3 IPv6 address scanning tools based on dual-stack correlation information (e.g., LinkScan6, LLMNR6, and FScan6). Experimental results show that HFinder6 can discover 31 IPv6 addresses across 12 OS versions in an average of just 10.19 seconds within IPv6-only network. In terms of OS coverage and IPv6 address scanning completeness, HFinder6 performs on par with FScan6 and outperforms 6 other scripts and tools, successfully identifies at more 9 additional OS versions and scans 27 more IPv6 addresses, thereby enhancing the completeness of IPv6 address scanning by up to 7.76 times. Moreover, in terms of IPv6 address scanning efficiency, HFinder6 can identify 2.23 more IPv6 addresses per second, outperforming 7 other scripts and tools.

title: Fuel Consumption Prediction of Non-Coplanar Orbital Transfer Using Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Nacera Bekhadda, Boulanouar Khouane, J. Eddine Benmansour, Rima Roubache
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: Addressing the non-coplanar orbital transfer using conventional approaches, whether analytical or numerical, poses significant challenges for instance, time-consuming computations, complexity in handling complex nonlinear dynamics, and heavy reliance on initial guesses. In this paper, machine learning (ML) techniques are proposed as an alternative solution to these challenges. Primarily, this study aims to implement and assess ML frameworks to build models capable of accurately predicting fuel consumption during the two-impulse non-coplanar orbital transfer of a geostationary spacecraft from low earth circular orbit. The dataset has been meticulously collected from the mission planning tool STK (System Tool Kit), capturing a diverse range of mission parameters and providing high-quality training samples for machine learning. After generating the dataset, four ML techniques, such as Random Forest (RF), Decision Trees (DTs), Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost), as well as simple Artificial Neural Network (ANN) have been applied to accurately estimate this critical metric of interest (fuel consumption). The results clearly demonstrate that these techniques excel in providing rapid and accurate estimations and also have illustrated splendid results with high evaluation metrics, including minimum RMSE and greater correlation coefficients (R2). Comparative analysis has been conducted to evaluate the predictability of these models. It is noteworthy that ANN exhibits superior performance compared to other selected ML models.

title: DSPACE Real-Time Implementation of MPPT-Based direct Method
authors: Zebiri Fouad, Choudar Adel, Bentouhami Larafi, Kessal Abedelhalim
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: This paper presents a practical implementation of Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) for photovoltaic (PV) systems using the dSPACE DS1104 real-time control platform. The study begins with the design and sizing of the passive components of a boost DC-DC converter, namely the inductor and output capacitor, based on theoretical analysis and ripple constraints. These components were then realized and tested in the laboratory. Following this, the dynamic behavior of the PV module and the converter was evaluated under open-loop conditions to establish baseline performance. Finally, an MPPT control algorithm based on the Perturb and Observe (P&O) method was developed in MATLAB/Simulink and implemented in real-time using dSPACE. Experimental results confirm the system’s ability to accurately track the maximum power point under varying solar irradiance, with stable performance and effective energy extraction. This work demonstrates a complete design-to-implementation process of an MPPT-controlled PV system in a practical setting.

title: Transient Analysis of Long-Distance Subsea Power Supply and Distribution Systems Based on Distributed Parameter Modeling
authors: Dayong Wang, Haizhu Wang, Niantao Zhang, Yinzhi Ma, Lvyin Niu, Wei Yang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: As the scale of subsea oil and gas field development continues expanding, the power distribution distance of subsea power systems increases significantly. Lead to subsea cables having strong distributed-parameter characteristics. Subsea power systems generate complex electromagnetic transient processes under operating conditions such as power-on and power-off, as well as the load off-grid and grid-connected, highly prone to overvoltage phenomena, which pose potential threats to the safe operation of subsea electrical equipment. To elucidate the underlying mechanisms, the distributed parameter model and transient characterization of long-distance subsea power systems are investigated in this study. First, a distributed parameter model of the subsea power network is established based on the structural attributes of long-distance subsea cables. Second, to reduce computational complexity, the method of characteristics is employed to solve the distributed parameter model, transforming the partial differential equations into ordinary differential equations propagated along characteristic lines, thereby enabling efficient extraction of the system’s voltage and current transient responses. Finally, a case study based on an actual subsea oilfield power system is conducted; the simulation successfully reproduces a field-recorded overvoltage fault, demonstrating that the proposed distributed parameter model and solution approach possess high engineering applicability and predictive accuracy. The distributed parameter model and method of characteristics solution developed in this paper effectively disclose the transient mechanisms of long-distance subsea power systems, furnishing a reliable technical reference for the engineering design of power supply infrastructures in subsea oil and gas fields.

title: Advances in Nanostructured Materials for Energy Storage Applications: A Materials Science and Engineering Perspective
authors: O. A. Afolabi, O. A. Olanrewaju
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Advancement in technological innovations is rising globally, which calls for a need to understand the effects of materials involved in the manufacturing of these products, such as lithium batteries and hydrogen storage. The advent of electric vehicles and portable electronic devices has stimulated the need for energy storage materials (ESM). These ESMs can be batteries and supercapacitors with higher power density and energy density capacity. Furthermore, ESM is essential for the exploitation of renewable energy sources and for efficient, clean, cost-effective, and adaptable energy use. As a result, energy storage materials encompass a broad spectrum of substances that have been carefully selected, organized, and allocated for specific applications and have been the focus of intense research, development, as well as industrialization. Energy storage relies heavily on MSE since improvements in material performance and characteristics have a direct impact on the lifespan, capacity, and efficiency of energy storage devices. This study presents an overview of the applications of advanced nanostructured materials in energy storage devices with focus on batteries (lithium-ion, sodium-ion, and lead-acid), supercapacitors, fuel cells, hydrogen storage, and thermal energy storage by observing several literatures. Additionally, it highlighted the use of cost-effective energy storage devices.

title: Accurate Classification of Multiple Faults in Induction Motor using CNN-based Features and Dimensionality Reduction
authors: Ahmed Chennana, Abdurrahman Ünsal, Noureddine Bessous, Ahmed Chaouki Megherbi, Ali Teta, Salim Sbaa, Derradji Bakria, El Ouanas Belabbaci
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: This paper proposes an intelligent diagnostic framework that detects complex multi-fault scenarios in three-phase induction motors by converting vibration signals into their time-frequency representations using Continuous Wavelet Transform, deep feature extraction through VGG16, EfficientNet-B0, and ResNet50 convolutional neural networks, dimensionality reduction using Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA), and classification using Support Vector Machine (SVM) and Random Forest (RF). This methodology was able to diagnose simultaneous mechanical faults such as rotor eccentricity, broken bars, and bearing defects with superior diagnostic accuracy by Python-based experimental validation, hence providing a sound basis for predictive maintenance that minimizes downtime and reduces maintenance costs related to industrial rotating machinery.

title: Applications of Industry 4.0 Technologies In Labor-Intensive Manufacturing
authors: E. Shen, S. Abdoli
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Industry 4.0 (I4.0) technologies have been adopted by manufacturing industries. This is significant to labor-intensive markets as replacing human capital may impact production performance. The current applications and challenges of I4.0 technologies is investigated, followed by utilization of a multi-criteria decision-analysis model as a tool to assist in selecting the most appropriate I4.0 technologies using the key performance parameters provided. A case study based on industrial expert opinion is conducted to assess the preference between six I4.0 technologies over nine criteria covering scopes of performance, safety, cost, maintenance and sustainability. By weighing the criteria in their significance, Data Analytics & AI was found to be most preferable in their scenario, followed by Cyber Physical System and Digital Twin. The evaluation ranking will assist manufacturers to assess all relevant technological alternatives accordingly.

title: Dynamic Characteristics of an Islanded DC Microgrid Incorporating Energy Storage-Based Virtual Inertia Control
authors: Yao Cheng
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: To address the issue of bus voltage susceptibility to power fluctuations in low-inertia DC microgrids, this paper proposes a virtual inertia control strategy for energy storage converters based on improved model predictive control. Firstly, a power-loop-free virtual DC machine (VDCM) control is introduced into the voltage outer loop to provide virtual inertia and damping for the DC microgrid, which simplifies the control structure while retaining the inertia and damping functions. Secondly, model predictive control (MPC) with delay compensation is applied in the current inner loop. A system model is established for simulation. Results demonstrate that, compared with traditional virtual inertia control strategies, the proposed approach yields smaller DC bus voltage fluctuations, faster voltage recovery, and superior dynamic performance.

title: Experimental Evaluation of Cantilever-Upward and Cantilever-Downward Broadband Rotational Energy Harvesters Under Diverse Noise Environments
authors: Md Shamim Ahmed, Mark Longden, Xianghong Ma, Yu Jia
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Micro and Miniature Power Systems, Self-Powered Sensors and Energy Autonomous Devices (PowerMEMS)
abstract: This paper investigates the experimental evaluation of broadband rotational energy harvesting systems using cantilever-upward and cantilever-downward configurations subjected to diverse vibration noise environments. Leveraging piezoelectric polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) materials for energy conversion, the study compares the energy harvesting potential of these two designs under conditions representative of aerospace and automotive applications. Results demonstrate that orientation and bi-stability significantly influence performance, with the cantilever-downward harvester achieving peak average power of 57.77 μW under aerospace in elevation conditions, while the cantilever-upward harvester achieved 52.31 μW under Forth Road Bridge noise. Both systems exhibit selective frequency responses and reduced efficiency at higher vibration amplitudes. This research highlights the role of cantilever orientation in optimizing rotational energy harvesting and informs the design of future vibration-powered devices.

title: Intelligent Quality Management in Industrial Screwing Processes: From Rule-Based Control to Data-Driven Paradigms
authors: N. West, M. Henkies, R. Mura, J. Deuse
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Industrial manufacturing is experiencing a paradigm shift from rule-based statistical process control toward data-driven quality management systems. This transformation is particularly relevant for screwing processes, one of the most critical joining methods in manufacturing. While statistical process control has dominated quality assurance for decades, increasing customization, complex error patterns, and growing data volumes push traditional approaches beyond their limits. Machine learning-based anomaly detection offers transformative potential extending far beyond binary good/bad classification, enabling process optimization, predictive maintenance, and adaptive control. This paper examines current research, identifies key limitations of rule-based approaches, and outlines emerging opportunities in data-driven quality management. Key challenges include limited dataset availability, insufficient integration capabilities, and poor transferability between applications. Addressing these challenges enables transition toward intelligent quality systems that fundamentally transform manufacturing quality management.

title: A Hybrid Time-Event Driven ESO Based on a Low-Precision Position Sensor for ADRC of Electric Machine Drives
authors: Zihan Zhang, Qiwu Wang, Jianbo Gao, Yu Li, Wei Wang, Guofeng Dong
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Under harsh operating conditions, electric machines are typically equipped with robust but low-precision position sensors. However, such sensors may lead to significant velocity quantization noise while operating in the low-velocity regime, creating an inherent trade-off between control bandwidth and velocity jitters. To address this challenge, this paper proposes an active disturbance rejection control (ADRC) strategy based on a time-event hybrid driven extended state observer (TEHESO). The proposed observer performs correction only when the position sensor is updated, while maintaining a low-noise prediction mode at other times. Simulation results verify the improved performance of the proposed method in low-velocity regions while also confirming its feasibility across the entire velocity range.

title: A Wideband Double-Layer Rectangular Dielectric Transmitarray Designed Using Deep Learning
authors: Ayse Sari, Bin Li, Liang Liang Cui, Yuan Chao Shi, Kwok Wa Leung
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: A simple, wideband double-layer dielectric transmitarray (DTA) is proposed and systematically investigated. The unit cell comprises two stacked rectangular dielectric blocks with variable dimensions. Both transmission and resonance behaviors of the unit cell are analyzed. It is found that the phase-variation range increases monotonically with frequency. Weak transmissions can be observed at the lower and upper gain edge of the DTA, which is attributed to small phase-variation range of non-resonance mode, as well as the energy confinement of the resonance modes, respectively. It is favorable that the lower and upper gain edge can be adjusted independently, which greatly facilitates the wideband DTA design. A deep learning framework of both forward and inverse neural networks is used for fast unit-cell dimension prediction, and genetic algorithm is subsequently applied to optimize the multi-frequency reference phases. A double-layer 20× 20 DTA is designed and fabricated using ceramic-based 3-D printing technology. The measured peak gain is 24 dBi at 33GHz with aperture efficiency of 46%. As compared to the reported wideband DTAs, wider 1-dB and 3-dB gain bandwidths of 34.8% and 42.6% are obtained, respectively.

title: A Dynamic Co-Frequency Interference Analysis Model Based on Time-Elevation Interference Spectrum for NGSO Mega-Constellations
authors: Zhaoyang Su, Kai Wang, Yuchen Cai, Lipeng Ning, Liu Liu, Tao Zhou, Bo Ai
abstract: In recent years, satellite internet has been widely recognized as a key component of future integrated space-air-ground networks. With advancements in satellite miniaturization and launch technologies, mega-constellations have become a growing trend. The increasing number of satellites in constellations presents challenges for interference analysis. This paper proposes a novel interference analysis method based on time-elevation interference spectrum. The proposed method can provide a more comprehensive analysis for NGSO mega-constellations by considering the aggregated dynamic interference under the time-elevation domain. The interference characteristics under different orbital inclination, orbital plane numbers, orbital height, and ground station latitude are analyzed. Furthermore, the probability distributions of interference are derived based on the joint distribution of satellites and ground stations. The outage probabilities and throughput are also analyzed to measure the system’s availability. Through the validation of STK and the Monte Carlo method, our method has high accuracy.

title: Software-Defined Product Architecture: Status, Challenges, and Future Perspectives
authors: J. Lee, J. Kim, S. J. Park, J. Lee, B. Song, S. K. Moon
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: The rise of Software-Defined Products (SDPs) marks a significant shift in product development, where software rather than hardware determines core functionalities, differentiation, and value. This review provides technological insights into the current landscape, challenges and potential direction of SDPs. First, representative applications and trends in automotive, consumer electronics, and medical device sectors are reviewed to illustrate the current status of SDPs. Next, four key technologies including hardware-software decoupling, AI-driven product design and development, modular digital twins and digital manufacturing are investigated and proposed to achieve SDPs. Furthermore, potential challenges in implementing these technologies are examined, along with proposed components of building Software-Defined Product Architecture (SDPA). The review concludes by highlighting future research needs, including advanced hardware abstraction for standardization, adaptive intelligence for transparency, a unified data layer, a redefined product module architecture, and security and governance for system resilience.

title: TrustIoT: Building Trust in Human-Thing Interactions for Healthcare Systems Using Machine Learning
authors: Abir Al-Ansari, Kristiaan D’Août, Valerio Selis
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Internet of Things (IoT) health monitoring devices allow the collection of data while performing various daily physical activities. These devices are not only affordable but also capable of collecting a wide variety of data, such as physiological data and environmental information. In the case of IoT healthcare systems, it is important to know which activity is performed to determine if there is any abnormality in a person’s physical behaviour during the activity, which may ultimately provide an indication of the person’s health condition. Human Activity Recognition (HAR) methods can be used to recognise activities. HAR is a field of identifying and categorising activities using Artificial Intelligence (AI), which uses raw data collected from different devices equipped with sensors such as cameras, accelerometers, gyroscopes, etc. The unique patterns and characteristics exhibited in human physical behaviours, such as gait, enable the identification of individuals with the use of a technology known as behavioural biometrics. This paper presents and evaluates HAR and user detection models, which serve as the foundation for constructing a trust model. The HAR binary classification proposed method achieved an accuracy of 97.5%, a precision of 97.7%, a recall of 97.5% and an F1 score of 97.6%. Additionally, the user detection model achieved an accuracy and a recall of 82.1% a precision of 91.6% and an F1 score of 85.7%. We then detail the methodology for calculating and updating trust scores over time and defining trust levels in the IoT system. Once trust is established, the system can provide reliable information regarding the individual’s health condition.

title:
UC Secure Privacy-Preserving and Auditable Transaction System for Permissioned Blockchains
                    <sup>*</sup>
authors: Su Hang, Guo ZhaoZhong, Xu Maozhi
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: The inherent tension between transactional privacy and auditing compliance presents a significant challenge to the widespread adoption of permissioned blockchain systems, particularly in highly regulated sectors such as finance. Existing approaches often suffer from inadequate privacy protection, rigid audit frameworks, or excessive computational and user interaction overhead. This paper introduces a novel permissioned blockchain transaction system specifically designed to address these challenges. Our design guarantees complete anonymity for sender and receiver identities as well as transaction amounts. Additionally, we implement a streamlined, non-interactive audit mechanism that allows authorized entities to inspect transactions without participant involvement. A key innovation is certifier-aided balance reconciliation, which significantly enhances transaction efficiency, usability, and scalability by eliminating the need for direct communication between participants. Through a formal security proof within the universal composable framework, we demonstrate the robust ability of the system to reconcile privacy requirements with compliance obligations.

title: Get in Shape: Prevent Over-smoothing of CNN-based Sentinel-2 Classification with Large Pre-trained Segment Anything Model
authors: Jan Svoboda, Bertrand le Saux, Peter Naylor, Josef Laštovička, Přemysl Štych
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Land Cover (LC) classification remains challenging, even with advanced machine learning (ML) techniques. Pixel-wise Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) are currently widely used for image classification. However, CNNs outputs often suffer from blurry boundaries and poorly segmented shapes. Hence, ad-hoc post-processing may be required to reduce over-smoothing. Conversely, it adds complexity to the classification process. Fortunately, generic foundation models like the Segment Anything Model (SAM), trained on large datasets, have become available. In this study, we propose a novel approach that combines outputs from locally trained CNN models and from the SAM model. We tested the approach on a mosaic of Sentinel-2 (S-2) images with a 10 m resolution, covering four neighboring first-level administrative units in Czechia. S-2 mosaic was classified according to the Land Use, Land-use Change, and Forestry (LULUCF) nomenclature using CNNs. Separately, this mosaic was segmented by SAM. The SAM output segments were assigned the dominant LC class from the CNN classification. The annotated segments were then overlaid on the original CNN classification to address over-smoothing. This approach resulted in an approximate two-percent improvement in overall accuracy (OA) and significantly enhancing the boundary delineation of LC objects in classification outputs, in terms of F1, precision, and recall. The reported two-percent improvement is meaningful because it was achieved on top of an already strong baseline (86.87 % overall accuracy), making further gains inherently difficult. LULUCF information is critical for monitoring compliance with the Paris Agreement. So, the ability to segment S-2 images into objects that align with LULUCF nomenclature could support future annual LULUCF reporting to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change.

title: BIMIM: Band-Independent Masked Image Modeling with Transformer for Multi-Spectral Satellite Imagery
authors: Jia Song, Luosheng Xia
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Self-supervised learning (SSL) offers a promising solution to reduce reliance on labeled data. Among SSL approaches, Masked Image Modeling (MIM) has demonstrated significant potential in remote sensing applications such as scene classification and semantic segmentation, owing to its ability to capture pixel-level details. However, existing MIM frameworks, originally designed for natural images, struggle to adapt to the spectral-spatial characteristics of multi-spectral satellite imagery. While recent studies have introduced spectral-enhanced MIM SSL methods, most rely on band-group embedding, which imposes constraints on band utilization flexibility in downstream fine-tuning tasks and limits the granularity of spectral feature learning. To address these challenges, this study proposes Band-Independent Masked Image Modeling (BIMIM) with Transformer, a novel self-supervised learning framework specifically designed for multi-spectral satellite imagery. BIMIM not only enables finer band-specific spectral feature extraction, allowing for more effective capture of subtle spectral variations, but also introduces spatially random masking at the single-band level, facilitating more efficient inter-band feature learning. Extensive experiments on publicly available remote sensing datasets demonstrate that BIMIM achieves state-of-the-art performance in downstream tasks such as scene classification and semantic segmentation. This study provides a new perspective on SSL for multi-spectral remote sensing, paving the way for more effective spectral-spatial feature extraction and adaptation in self-supervised learning frameworks.

title: Supply Chain Anomaly Detection by using Simulation and Machine Learning
authors: Tatsuya Inaba
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Supply chain (SC) anomalies have become increasingly prevalent due to the emergence of global pandemics and the increase of natural disasters. While recent advances in machine learning have demonstrated strong capabilities in detecting state transitions such as SC anomalies, its application to infrequent events remains challenging, primarily due to the difficulty of acquiring sufficient training data. To address this limitation, this study proposes a novel SC anomaly detection method that integrates SC simulation and machine learning techniques. Through evaluation using a hypothetical scenario, the proposed method was shown to effectively identify SC anomalies, and parameters influencing performance were examined. These findings suggest that further refinement of the proposed approach may enhance anomaly detection in more complex and dynamic supply chain environments.

title: ProfilE: Self-Supervised Communication Relationship Profiling for Imbalanced Smart Grid Anomaly Detection
authors: Haimiao Li, Changbo Tian, Runqing Zhang, Shiyi Yuan, Bo Sun
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Smart grids, as critical national infrastructure, require robust cybersecurity. However, traditional anomaly detection methods face inherent challenges: the scarcity of labeled attack samples due to power grid traffic characteristics, which results in highly imbalanced datasets. To overcome these limitations, this paper introduces ProfilE, a novel self-supervised anomaly detection model. The framework consists of three core modules: an encoder module is responsible for fusing historical, topological, and statistical features to generate multi-dimensional feature embeddings; a self-supervised module generates corrupted samples to mitigate the reliance on labeled data; and a Profile Module utilizes these embeddings to learn and construct a communication relationship profile that characterizes normal network behavior. By using the reconstruction error from the profile module for anomaly detection, ProfilE fundamentally eliminates reliance on labeled data. Experimental evaluations on the CICModbus2023 and CICIDS2017 datasets demonstrate that ProfilE performs better than existing baseline methods in imbalanced smart grid environments. Notably, in scenarios with scarce attack samples, its Macro F1 outperforms baselines, fully validating its effectiveness and robustness in real-world power grid settings.

title: Leveraging large language models for SQL behavior-based database intrusion detection
authors: Meital Shlezinger, Shay Akirav, Lei Zhou, Liang Guo, Avi Kessel, Guoliang Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Database systems are extensively used to store critical data across various domains. However, the frequency of abnormal database access behaviors, such as database intrusion by internal and external attacks, continues to rise. Internal masqueraders often have greater organizational knowledge, making it easier to mimic employee behavior effectively. In contrast, external masqueraders may behave differently due to their lack of familiarity with the organization. Current approaches lack the granularity needed to detect anomalies at the operational level, frequently misclassifying entire sequences of operations as anomalies, even though most operations are likely to represent normal behavior. On the other hand, some anomalous behaviors often resemble normal activities, making them difficult for existing detection methods to identify. This paper introduces a two-tiered anomaly detection approach for Structured Query Language (SQL) using the Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (BERT) model, specifically DistilBERT, a more efficient, pre-trained version. Our method combines both unsupervised and supervised machine learning techniques to accurately identify anomalous activities while minimizing the need for data labeling. First, the unsupervised method uses ensemble anomaly detectors that flag embedding vectors distant from learned normal patterns of typical user behavior across the database (out-of-scope queries). Second, the supervised method uses fine-tuned transformer-based models to detect internal attacks with high precision (in-scope queries), using role-labeled classification, even on limited labeled SQL data. Our findings make a significant contribution by providing an effective solution for safeguarding critical database systems from sophisticated threats.

title: A discrete flower pollination algorithm for Twin Automatic Stacking Cranes scheduling
authors: H. P. Hsu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: This research first formulates the Twin Automatic Stacking Cranes (TASC) problem as a mixed-integer linear programming (MILP) model, aiming to minimize the total processing time and the reshuffling time of container tasks. In addition, it considers sequence constraints of container tasks, safety distances, and conflict avoidance for TASC operations. To handle large-scale instances, a discrete flower pollination algorithm (DFPA) is proposed in combination with an overlap resolution procedure as an alternative solution method to obtain high-quality feasible solutions. Experiments were conducted to compare the DFPA with the standard flower pollination algorithm (FPA), the genetic algorithm (GA), and the first-come, first-served (FCFS) approach. The results show that DFPA outperforms the other methods.

title: User Demands Based Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning Satellite Handover Strategy*
authors: Qiyun Yu, Yanrong Lu, Weiwei Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: With the dramatic increase in the number of low Earth orbit (LEO) satellites, satellite handover strategies have become a research hot topic. However, most existing schemes largely ignore the problem of users’ personalized needs. To address this issue, we propose a handover scheme that combines user dynamic demands with multi-agent reinforcement learning. Specifically, we first construct a user dynamic preference matrix to extract user preference factors. Then, we use the entropy method combined with confidence intervals to dynamically calculate the attribute weights that satellites provide to users. This approach effectively eliminates the uncertainty of weight allocation and the influence of subjective assignment. By weighted fusion of user preferences and attribute weights, we establish a multi-attribute optimization model. Additionally, we design a distributed multi-agent QMIX (Q-mixing) reinforcement learning framework. In this framework, each user is regarded as a separate agent. The multi-attribute optimization model is used as the reward function for reinforcement learning, and collaborative optimization of handover strategies is achieved through asynchronous learning and a global reward mechanism. Simulation results show that our scheme achieves user satisfaction exceeding 60% for approximately 80% of users. It also provides higher signal quality and lower delay, while avoiding unnecessary handovers.

title: Research on On-line Perception Method and Device of Transformer On-load Tap Changer Based on Electromagnetic Transient Multidimensional Information Fusion
authors: Yuancheng Zhu, Qi Zhang, Xiaoyu Li, Guowei Li, Lijun Yin
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: To address the problem that traditional singlesignal monitoring methods struggle to comprehensively assess the health status of transformer on-load tap changers (OLTCs), this paper proposes an online sensing method and device based on the fusion of electromagnetic transient multidimensional information. This method synchronously collects vibration, drive motor current, ultra-high-frequency electromagnetic wave, and sound signals to construct a multidimensional transient information spectrum, and uses a high-precision clock source to ensure spatiotemporal consistency of the signals. By combining a onedimensional convolutional neural network with a graph neural network in a deep learning model, adaptive weighting and deep fusion of multi-source heterogeneous features are realized, enabling comprehensive diagnosis and early fault warning of OLTC mechanical condition, contact electrical life, and insulation status. Experiments show that the proposed method can effectively identify potential fault features, significantly improving diagnostic accuracy compared to traditional methods, and providing advanced technical support for OLTC conditionbased maintenance and full lifecycle management.

title: Study on the energy scheduling strategy of a new energy microgrid cluster in an oilfield under the dual-carbon background
authors: Hao Xu, Li Ji, Jinghao Cai
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Under China’s dual-carbon goals, the share of new energy generation in the power grid has been increasing year by year. To promote the local consumption of distributed photovoltaic (PV) power within the Oilfield Energy Supply System (OESS) and alleviate the problem of PV curtailment, this paper proposes an energy regulation strategy based on the Stackelberg game principle. A “multi-buyer-multi-seller” OESS architecture is constructed, in which the PV-rich oilfield new energy microgrids (ONMs, Oilfield New Energy Microgrids) act as leaders and the PV-deficient ONMs act as followers. Through price and energy interactions between the upper and lower layers, the green power penetration rate is improved while minimizing the overall power supply cost. Case studies verify that the proposed method effectively promotes local PV consumption, significantly reduces the PV curtailment rate, and achieves the goals of clean substitution, green and low-carbon operation, energy saving, and environmental protection for the OESS.

title: A Prediction Model for Icing Thickness of Transmission and Substation Lines Based on WOA-BiLSTM
authors: Lidan Zhang, Yuxin Zhang, Guangpu Wang, Xu Liu, Tianyu Zhang, Songnan Pang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: To mitigate the negative impact of icing on transmission and substation lines under complex winter weather conditions, this paper proposes a WOA-BiLSTM-based prediction model for icing thickness. First, a feature selection method based on the Maximum Information Coefficient (MIC) is employed to identify the meteorological variables that are strongly correlated with icing thickness, enabling effective feature selection and dimensionality reduction. Second, a Bidirectional Long ShortTerm Memory (BiLSTM)-based prediction model is developed to capture the strong temporal dependencies and learn the temporal dynamics of the icing process, thereby improving the accuracy of icing-thickness prediction. Third, the Whale Optimization Algorithm (WOA) is utilized to optimize key BiLSTM hyperparameters, including the number of hidden-layer neurons, the learning rate, and the number of training epochs, resulting in an optimal hyperparameter configuration and further enhancing prediction performance. Finally, a case study demonstrates that the proposed model achieves higher prediction accuracy than existing prediction models.

title: VCR: Fast Private Set Intersection with Improved VOLE and CRT-Batching
authors: Weizhan Jing, Xiaojun Chen, Xudong Chen, Ye Dong, Yaxi Yang, Qiang Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Private set intersection (PSI) allows two participants to compute the intersection of their private sets without revealing any additional information beyond the intersection itself. It is known that oblivious linear evaluation (OLE) can be used to construct the online efficient PSI protocol. However, oblivious transfer (OT) and fully homomorphic encryption (FHE)-based offline OLE generation are expensive, and the online computational complexity is super-linear and still a heavy burden for large-scale sets. In this paper, we propose VCR, an efficient PSI protocol from vector OLE (VOLE) with the offline-online paradigm. Concretely, we first propose the batched short VOLE protocol to reduce offline overhead for generating VOLE tuples. Then, we design a batched private membership test protocol from pre-computed VOLE to accelerate the online computation. Experiments demonstrate that VCR outperforms prior art. Compared to state-of-the-art work, we reduce the total communication costs (resp. running time) by 341× and 9.1× (resp. 6.5× and 2.5×) on average for OT and FHE-based protocols.

title: UAV Assisted Multi-Attack Detection Method for Vehicular Ad Hoc Networks
authors: Junhui Zhang, Na Fan, Liping Ye, Jianghui Hu, Yexiong Shang, Yu Shi
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: As a crucial component of intelligent transportation systems, Vehicular Ad Hoc Networks (VANETs) are increasingly exposed to severe cybersecurity threats, particularly hybrid attacks such as Denial of Service (DoS), black hole attacks, and Sybil identity spoofing. In high-density traffic environments, Road Side Units (RSUs) often suffer from heavy loads, which limits their responsiveness and accuracy in attack detection. To address this issue, this paper proposes a UAV-assisted intelligent multi-attack detection model. By introducing unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) as mobile auxiliary nodes, the model dynamically offloads traffic monitoring and data processing tasks from RSUs, thereby alleviating resource bottlenecks. Building on this, a hybrid detection architecture is designed that combines Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and Deep Q-Networks (DQN). The CNN is employed to extract spatiotemporal traffic features, including vehicle port traffic density, node forwarding rate distributions, and identity activity levels, while convolutional filters capture potential abnormal patterns. The DQN further optimizes attack detection through Q-learning-based decision making. The simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms existing approaches in detecting diverse types of attack, significantly improving detection accuracy and reducing response latency.

title: Immersive Metaverse for Critical Minerals Supply Chain Education: A Conceptual Framework Architecture
authors: Oshadhi K. Herath, Deepesh C. Jayasekara, Ryosuke Harakawa, Masahiro Iwahashi, Mukesh Kumar, Tadachika Nakayama
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: In order to provide the ecosystem-level knowledge required for a competent workforce, this paper presents a conceptual framework for an immersive metaverse platform designed specifically for critical minerals supply chain education. The framework utilizes a Cyber-Physical-Social System (CPSS) architecture, which integrates physical mining activities, subsequent supply chain stages, their cyber representations, and human social interactions into a unified virtual world. A cross-industry case study analysis informs the design by identifying the implications and challenges of using immersive technologies such as virtual and augmented reality to enhance learning. Based on this study, the paper describes a multilayer CPSS-based metaverse, including its architecture, essential learning modules, and necessary facilitation technologies. These layers include the physical, cyber, network, and social layers. The main purpose of this architecture is to enable experiential learning, foster collaboration, workforce development, and drive innovation in managing critical mineral supply chains.

title: DEA-Based Performance Assessment of Teams in the 2024-2025 European Volleyball Women’s Champions League
authors: Xu Wang, Tengfei Shao, Takashi Hasuike
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Among volleyball leagues worldwide, the European Volleyball Women’s Champions League stands out for its high level of competition and entertainment value, as it brings together top athletes from various countries. This study focuses on the recently concluded 2024-2025 season and assesses the overall performance of the 20 participating teams using Data Envelopment Analysis (DEA), a methodology from operations research used for efficiency evaluation and improvement. The analysis considers five key technical aspects of volleyball: scoring ability, serving effectiveness, reception quality, attacking efficiency, and blocking performance. By analyzing single-season data, DEA not only ranks team performance but also reveals the causes of inefficiency and provides suggestions to help underperforming teams improve their tactical formation for the next season. Furthermore, a detailed analysis using the dual DEA model highlights the critical role of serve-receive techniques in winning matches, which aligns closely with the current tactical emphasis in modern women’s volleyball.

title: Proposal of an Evaluation Framework for Small Investment Projects
authors: T.M.R. Fagá, J.M.O. Cunha
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: The escalating allocation of European cohesion funds to small-scale projects exposes a critical methodological gap: existing evaluation frameworks are often too complex or resource-intensive for their effective assessment. This paper proposes an integrated socio-economic evaluation framework that combines design evaluation, economic analysis, and risk management into an accessible Excel<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">©</sup>-based platform tool. Designed for simplicity and adaptability, the tool enables diverse technical analyses without requiring advanced computational resources. The methodology synthesizes these elements into a single tool, deliberately prioritizing practical applicability without sacrificing analytical rigor. The design phase incorporates participatory approaches, developed through stakeholder consultations and theory-of-change workshops, to ensure alignment with local priorities and enhance usability for non-technical users. The economic analysis allows for assessing financial viability. It facilitates robust financial viability assessments and incorporates risk management features that utilize qualitative matrices and scenario modelling to address challenges and uncertainties such as climate variability and market volatility. A case study in Northern Portugal, focusing on vineyard restructuring, demonstrates the tool’s capacity to support decision-making processes, which illustrates the tool's capacity to support transparent decision-making, evaluate trade-offs, and prioritize interventions. The key contribution of this research is a validated framework that democratizes sophisticated analysis for resource-constrained settings. It has a clear theoretical implication for participatory evaluation models and practical implications for policymakers and managing authorities, highlighting its scalability and potential for integration into regional cohesion policy. The study also discusses limitations and pathways for future adaptation to other socio-economic contexts.

title: Improved Rsqrt for Faster Secure Neural Networks Inference
authors: Jiafu Liu, YeDong, Yuqi Zhou, Jun Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Reciprocal square root (Rsqrt) plays a critical role in batch normalization (BN) layers of convolutional neural networks (CNNs). However, existing Rsqrt implementations within secure multi-party computation (MPC) exhibit significant limitations in computational precision and operational range, forcing MPC-based privacy-preserving machine learning solutions to either constrain secure BN operations or omit them entirely, resulting in non-negligible accuracy loss. This work redesigns the MPC-based Rsqrt protocol by combining Newton’s iterative method with optimized bidirectional power bounding. The proposed protocol achieves enhanced precision and extends the operational range to [2<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−10</sup>, 2<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">9</sup>] in the ring ${{\mathbb{Z}}_{{2^{64}}}}$. A complete BN protocol is further constructed based on the improved Rsqrt for secure inference. The protocol is validated through secure inference experiments on CNNs containing multiple BN layers. Results demonstrate average errors below 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−3</sup> between plaintext and ciphertext inference. This work significantly advances MPC-based privacy-preserving machine learning by improving both the precision and efficiency of Rsqrt-dependent operations.

title: Peak Characteristics of a Hairpin Winding Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motor with Dual-strand Pins
authors: Mengyuan Zhang, Lijun Zhang, Yu Gong, Han Guo
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: With the rapid growth of electric vehicles, demand for high-performance motors has surged, driving trends toward higher efficiency and power density. Hairpin windings are widely adopted for high slot fill factor and low direct current (DC) resistance, but they face high alternating current (AC) losses from skin and proximity effects and overheating risks at elevated speeds. This paper proposes an innovative hairpin winding that splits two top conductors into four flat strands. A new evaluation method for peak performance with constant temperature rise by means of speed-dependent current limitation is presented. A temperature-sensor-equipped prototype was built and tested, demonstrating improved efficiency and thermal management, offering valuable insights for motor advancement.

title: Optimizing Last-Mile Delivery Efficiency through a Multi-Vehicle and MultiArea Collaboration Model
authors: S. H. Lu, C. C. Chang, R. Raj
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: The rapid growth of e-commerce has heightened the need for logistics companies to improve package delivery efficiency. In conventional delivery models, vehicle speed is often constrained by urban speed regulations and the difficulty of locating available parking spaces. Unlike previous studies that focus on trucks collaborating with a single type of auxiliary vehicle, this paper explores a multivehicle approach by integrating a truck with two distinct types of delivery vehicles—a drone and a robot—and determining the most suitable deployment scenario for each. To address this problem, a heuristic algorithm is proposed to solve the Multiple Area and Multiple Vehicle Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP-MAMV). Experimental results show that deploying robots for deliveries in high-density urban areas can significantly enhance efficiency, while in lower- density regions, drones outperform robots in executing last- mile deliveries.

title: Optimized Path Planning for Cooperative Data Collection of UAV and UGV on Construction sites
authors: S. Lee, J. Hong, S. Moon
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Efficient and accurate data acquisition is essential for constructing digital twins in construction environments characterized by complex structures and physical constraints. While UAV and UGV each offer strengths in coverage and mobility, relying on a single platform often leads to incomplete and inefficient map generation. This study proposes a cooperative path planning framework that integrates UAV and UGV to optimize exploration efficiency and maximize spatial coverage. The proposed method considers the complementary sensing and mobility characteristics of each platform to enhance data collection efficiency while ensuring comprehensive site coverage. Compared to the conventional operator-guided approach, the proposed method achieved a 20% reduction in total exploration distance and a 35% reduction in exploration time. Despite a 23% decrease in point density, the resulting point cloud successfully preserved critical structural and ground-level details with sufficient accuracy. This research presents a practical and scalable approach to data acquisition for digital twin construction in large-scale and complex construction sites.

title: A 40 nm Buffer-Free 7T-SRAM Analog Charge-Domain CIM Macro With Merging Timing Based On Time-Row Division Strategy
authors: Linjun Jiang, Jianxin Wu, Sifan Sun, Changyu Li, Wang Kang, He Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Very Large Scale Integration (VLSI) Systems
abstract: Computing-in-memory (CIM) macros based on static random access memory (SRAM) are meant to increase capacity while improving energy efficiency and reducing computing latency. However, traditional analog designs still face several key challenges, including long computing latency from separated computing phases, negative voltage fluctuations from massive parallel computing, and low bitcell density from additional transistors and capacitors for multiplication. On the other hand, only time-aligned inputs are supported in the works. To overcome the above challenges, this work proposes a buffer-free 7T-SRAM charge-domain CIM macro. It has four key features: 1) a compact 7T SRAM bitcell structure for high-energy efficiency; 2) a configurable input unit to support different sizes of input activations; 3) a time-row division (RD) strategy to support real-time processing and alleviate negative voltage fluctuations; and 4) a merging timing to conceal the input phase for high throughput. The fabricated 512-Kb SRAM-CIM macro in 40 nm achieves 79.3–290.4 Tops/W at 4-bit precision.
