title: Comparative Analysis of Regulatory Focus in Autonomous Vehicles (AVs) and Maritime Autonomous Surface Ships (MASS)
authors: T. E. Kim, J-U Schröder-Hinrichs
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: The increasing deployment of autonomous systems in transportation is reshaping how mobility systems operate and how regulatory frameworks must evolve to facilitate the shift from human-driven to AI-operated systems. This study presents a comparative analysis of regulatory discourse in two transport sectors at the frontier of automation: Autonomous Vehicles (AVs) and Maritime Autonomous Surface Ships (MASS). We used Natural Language Processing (NLP) and lifecycle phase mapping to extract and visualize the distribution of regulatory attention across key governance stages from standards development to testing, certification, liability and international harmonization. Gradient spectrum plots and semantic concept maps revealed significant asymmetries. These findings suggest a temporal lag in maritime governance and inform the importance of differentiated and phase-aware governance strategies in cross-sectoral technological transitions.

title: Dual Gradient Evaluation-Based Defense Method Against Poisoning Attacks in Federated Learning
authors: Zhuangzhuang Zhang, Xinhai Yan, Libing Wu, Bingyi Liu, Enshu Wang, Jianping Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Federated learning (FL), as an emerging distributed machine learning paradigm, aims to achieve collaborative training of a global model without sharing clients’ local data, thereby addressing user privacy and data silo issues. However, due to the distributed architecture of FL and the invisibility of local training, it is highly susceptible to poisoning attacks. While numerous poisoning defense methods have been proposed, they often suffer from limited defense effectiveness and overly strong security assumptions. To address this problem, we propose FedTPD, a dual gradient evaluation-based defense method against poisoning attacks in FL. Specifically, we first design an adaptive representative gradient selection mechanism, which involves adaptively clustering local gradients and selecting representative gradients from different clusters. Secondly, we propose a client-assisted model evaluation mechanism, wherein a reliable client is selected as an evaluator to assess the representative gradients from various clusters. Finally, we develop a bias-corrected model aggregation mechanism that aggregates the local gradients of each cluster based on the trust scores of their representative gradients, thereby reducing the impact of poisoning attacks on the global model. Experimental results on three typical datasets demonstrate that the proposed FedTPD can effectively resist various poisoning attacks. In particular, compared with state-of-the-art methods, the global model’s maximum and average accuracies on the CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 datasets are improved by 2.79%–28.15% and 0.79%–31.34%, and 3.48%–22.18% and 2.56%–22.06%, respectively.

title: Design Of an Advanced Optimal Sliding Mode Controller for a Laboratory Process Using Metaheuristic approaches
authors: Riad Bendib, Elarkam Mechhoud, Chaima Rechache, Manar Belkoli, Abdelhamid Djari, Abdelazuz Alshareef
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: Traditional optimization techniques often struggle to address the complexity and high-dimensional nature of modern control systems. In this context, artificial intelligence (AI)-based optimization methods, such as Genetic Algorithms (GA) and Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), offer promising alternatives for fine-tuning the parameters of Sliding Mode Controllers (SMCs). This study investigates the comparative effectiveness of AI-driven optimization algorithms in minimizing tracking errors and enhancing the robustness of SMCs under external disturbances and system uncertainties. Emphasis is placed on the implementation of Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) and GA for optimizing sliding mode control within industrial automation environments. The overarching objective is to improve control system performance by achieving superior tracking accuracy, faster convergence, and enhanced resilience against nonlinearities and perturbations.

title: Security of LLM Agents: A Case Study Approach
authors: Casey Fan, Diyana Tial, Vladislav Dubrovenski, Mengtao Zhang, Yugyung Lee, Dianxiang Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: As large language models (LLMs) evolve into autonomous agents equipped with tools and communication capabilities, they are increasingly deployed in multi-agent systems (MASs) to perform complex tasks. While these systems offer new levels of functionality and efficiency, their security risks remain underexplored. In this paper, we present a focused security analysis of LLM agents by implementing six representative attacks on two real-world MASs. These attacks expose structural and behavioral vulnerabilities unique to agent-based systems. We also introduce and evaluate defensive mechanisms such as fine-tuned agent behaviors, access control via the NGAC (Next Generation Access Control) standard, and a novel "sanity checker" agent for validating agent outputs. Our findings highlight the urgent need for robust, standardized security frameworks for LLM-based MASs and suggest promising directions for future research in agent-level threat modeling and mitigation.

title: Automated Attack Graph Construction for Cross-host Threat Detection Using Cyber Threat Intelligence
authors: Chen Ling, Yifei Li, Ziqing Feng, Bin Liu, Qiuyun Wang, Liling Xin, Zhengwei Jiang, Huamin Feng
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Cyber Threat Intelligence (CTI) reports provide valuable insights into cyber threats. However, manually constructing attack graphs from the unstructured CTI reports requires significant human effort. With the development of Large Language Models (LLMs), researchers have begun to harness LLMs for attack graph construction from CTI reports. Nevertheless, existing works mainly focus on describing abstract and high-level attack behaviors through these graphs, which cannot be used as query graphs for threat detection based on graph matching, as provenance graphs are at the system level. Moreover, these works do not consider modeling cross-host attack behaviors. To address these problems, we propose a novel method for automatically constructing attack graphs from CTI reports. We utilize prompt engineering, and leverage the in-context learning ability of LLMs to generate attack graphs. In this method, we first restructure the CTI report by grouping continuous sentences with the same tactics, and then use multiple LLMs to extract entities and relations. Finally, we use an LLM to integrate all the results. We also design a cross-host threat detection algorithm using the generated attack graphs. The evaluation results show that our method constructs attack graphs with an average conversion rate of 72.4%. It also achieves nearly 94.8% precision and 96.5% recall for IoC and relation extraction compared with manually labeled results.

title: A hybrid spatio-temporal model for probabilistic mapping of soil salinity in arid regions
authors: Gulzira Abdikerimova, Dana Khamitova, Gulbakhar Yussupova, Zhanar Akhmetova, Zhanar Azhibekova, Moldir Yessenova, Nurgul Uzakkyzy, Assemgul Tynykulova, Aigulim Bayegizova
abstract: Soil salinity is a key driver of land degradation in arid regions and remains a severe constraint to sustainable agriculture. Field-based observations are limited in space and time, making it challenging to track seasonal and internal changes. This study presents an innovative hybrid probabilistic framework for assessing soil salinity using multi-source satellite and climate data. A quasi-temporal dataset for 2020 to 2025 was created from Sentinel-2 surface reflectance, ERA5-Land hydroclimatic variables, terrain features, and distance to water. A physically interpretable feature set was developed using spectral indices, soil moisture gradients, aridity indicators, water balance metrics, and combined spectral and climatic interactions. Soil conditions were classified into three regimes (NORMA, SALINE, SAND) using a unified decision scheme based on NDVI, NDMI, and BSI. The hybrid model estimates the probability of transitions between soil regimes across years and regions. Its performance was tested using stratified and group cross-validation, temporal hold-out (2020 to 2023 for training and 2024 to 2025 for testing), and strict external validation based on independent AOI sites. The model achieved stable results with an Accuracy of about 0.97, Macro-F1 of about 0.97, and ROC AUC above 0.97. The proposed approach provides an AI-driven, interpretable, and scalable solution for monitoring soil salinity and supporting land and water management.

title: Assessing the Impact of Post-Quantum Digital Signature Algorithms on Blockchains
authors: Alison Gonçalves Schemitt, Henrique Fan da Silva, Roben Castagna Lunardi, Diego Kreutz, Rodrigo Brandão Mansilha, Avelino Francisco Zorzo
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: The advent of quantum computing poses a threat to the security of traditional encryption algorithms. This has motivated the development of post-quantum cryptography (PQC). In 2024, the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) standardized several PQC algorithms, marking an important milestone in the transition toward quantum-resistant security. Blockchain systems fundamentally rely on cryptographic primitives to guarantee data integrity and transaction authenticity. However, widely used algorithms such as ECDSA, employed in Bitcoin, Ethereum, and other networks, are vulnerable to quantum attacks. Although adopting PQC is essential for long-term security, its computational overhead in blockchain environments remains largely unexplored. In this work, we propose a methodology for benchmarking both PQC and traditional cryptographic algorithms in blockchain contexts. We measure signature generation and verification times across diverse computational environments and simulate their impact at scale. Our evaluation focuses on PQC digital signature schemes (ML-DSA, Dilithium, Falcon, Mayo, SLH-DSA, SPHINCS+, and Cross) across security levels 1 to 5, comparing them to ECDSA, the current standard in Bitcoin and Ethereum. Our results indicate that PQC algorithms introduce only minor performance overhead at security level 1, while in some scenarios they significantly outperform ECDSA at higher security levels. For instance, ML-DSA achieves a verification time of 0.14 ms on an ARM-based laptop at level 5, compared to 0.88 ms for ECDSA. We also provide an open-source implementation to ensure reproducibility and to encourage further research.

title: Research on the Design of Object Measurement Device Based on Monocular Vision
authors: Yan Yu, Peixiong Wu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: With the rapid development of industrial automation and smart warehousing, there is a growing and urgent demand for low-cost, high-efficiency non-contact measurement technologies. Traditional measurement methods are often plagued by issues such as low efficiency or high cost. This study aims to design and implement a monocular vision measurement device to address the technical challenges of achieving real-time and accurate target recognition and measurement in resourceconstrained environments, thereby meeting the application requirements for low power consumption and strong environmental adaptability in industrial settings. This research utilizes the STM32F103C8T6 microcontroller as the core controller to construct a hardware platform comprising a machine vision module, a power supply current measurement circuit, and a 7-inch serial HMI display. Based on the principle of monocular vision ranging and incorporating a digital recognition algorithm, the system calculates the target’s distance and geometric dimensions. Furthermore, the device integrates a current measurement circuit for real-time power consumption monitoring and delivers the visual output of measurement results via the serial display. Test results demonstrate that the device can effectively identify specific targets, achieving an average error rate of less than 5% for both distance and side length measurements, while maintaining overall power consumption at a low level. This validates the feasibility and reliability of the device design. This study provides a practical and easily deployable measurement solution for scenarios such as smart warehousing and industrial online inspection, promoting the wider adoption of machine vision technology in the embedded field.

title: Inverted Design of Vibrational Energy Harvester with a Printed Circuit Board Used as an Additive Mass
authors: S. Miyazato, H. Honma, H. Toshiyoshi, A. Uesugi, K. Sugano, Y. Isono
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Micro and Miniature Power Systems, Self-Powered Sensors and Energy Autonomous Devices (PowerMEMS)
abstract: In this study, we developed a vibrational energy harvester using a 22 g printed circuit board as the additive mass of the vibrator. Consequently, the kinetic energy of the vibrator increased, resulting in a large output from slight vibrations. By using a printed circuit board (PCB), which is commonly used as a mass instead of a separate additive mass, we increase in the mass without introducing any dead space in the element. The fabricated energy harvester delivered an output power of 0.8 μW under 4 mG external vibrations. The normalized power density (NPD) was measured as 26.1 mW/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>/G<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>.

title: Safety-Aware DRL Training Based on Reachability Analysis
authors: Yixuan Yang, Min Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: The growing adoption of deep reinforcement learning (DRL) in safety-critical domains like autonomous driving has been hindered by the fundamental conflict between performance optimization and safety assurance. While DRL excels in high-dimensional state spaces and long-term planning, unexpected safety violations pose catastrophic risks. This work introduces a novel safety-aware DRL framework that integrates formal reachability analysis into the training pipeline. Our approach features two innovations: 1) a pre-trained reachability analysis module quantifying runtime safety risks through reachable state set computation, and 2) dynamic safety constraints enabling real-time policy adaptation. By embedding safety verification into the optimization loop, our method systematically balances exploration efficiency with risk mitigation. Empirical validation in autonomous driving scenarios demonstrates superior safety performance compared to conventional DRL methods, achieving significant collision avoidance while maintaining competitive efficiency. This framework bridges formal verification and DRL, providing a safety-aware solution for safety-critical systems. Future work will focus on computational efficiency optimization in dense obstacle environments.

title: PathFed: Trustworthy and Efficient Federated Aggregation via Path Attention
authors: Manzhou Li, Xinjin Ge, Yan Li, Yan Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: A trustworthy and communication-efficient federated aggregation method, PathFed, is proposed based on a path attention mechanism. By constructing path embedding representations and assigning attention-based scores to identify high-value update trajectories, PathFed integrates Top-K sparse aggregation with an adaptive scheduling strategy to jointly optimize communication overhead and model performance. Experimental evaluations on CIFAR-10, FEMNIST, and Sensor Data demonstrate that PathFed achieves accuracies of 77.45%, 87.56%, and 81.34%, respectively, consistently outperforming mainstream baselines such as FedAvg and FedProx. Furthermore, PathFed reduces the required communication rounds to 110 and compresses total transmission volume to 990MB, achieving significant communication savings. Under adversarial settings with 20% of clients exhibiting malicious behavior, PathFed maintains an accuracy of 75.96% with a standard deviation of only 1.84, highlighting its robustness, resilience to non-IID conditions, and strong generalization in untrusted federated environments.

title: When Voices Deceive: Evaluating and Improving the Robustness of Audio Deepfake Detectors Under Adversarial Attacks
authors: Karla Schäfer, Leon Ludwig
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Like humans, who are susceptible to illusions, adversarial attacks can deceive audio deepfake detectors into making incorrect judgements. We trained and tested various detection tools against different types of adversarial attack that have been developed in recent years. Previous studies have used the equal error rate to evaluate the effectiveness of a given attack. As it is important to determine whether an attack is effective at tricking the detector into classifying spoofs as bona-fide or vice versa, we used various evaluation metrics to perform a more in-depth analysis. We investigated three adversarial attacks: FGSM, PGDL2 and Malafide. Furthermore, we created an adaptive version of Malafide with filter sizes that change depending on the success of a given attack. The detection models used were LCNN, SpecRNet, RawNet3 and an SSL-based detector consisting of a combination of Wav2Vec2 and AASIST. This selection provides a broad range of detector structures. All detectors were affected by FGSM and PGDL2 in the white box setting; LCNN and SpecRNet the most. Malafide led to a deterioration in white and black box settings, fooling LCNN and SpecRNet into classifying spoofs as bona-fide. Conversely, RawNet3 and Wav2Vec2+AASIST were tricked by Malafide into classifying bona-fide samples as spoofs, resulting in a high number of false alarms while still correctly identifying spoofs. Both models were affected by the filter size; higher-quality degradation in the samples led to worse results, with Wav2Vec2+AASIST being more affected than RawNet3. Through adaptive adversarial training, the detectors partially improved their performance while maintaining their performance on the original data.

title: An Approach Based on SOGI Observer to Improve the Dynamic Performance of Repetitive Control in Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motors
authors: Yuanming Zhang, Lingjun Lu, Jian Yang, Mi Dong, Jun Leng, Qilong Liang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: To address the degradation in harmonic suppression performance of conventional fractional-order repetitive control (FORC) during dynamic processes such as sudden speed changes, arising from the internal model erroneously learning non-periodic transient disturbances, this paper proposes an enhanced FORC control strategy based on second-order generalized integrator (SOGI) feedforward observation. This method utilizes SOGIs as harmonic observers to real-time extract real periodic harmonic components from the motor current feedback, which are injected into the FORC as input, thereby decoupling harmonic suppression from fundamental control and eliminating transient interference at the source. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed strategy effectively maintains the superior steady-state accuracy of conventional FORC while significantly enhancing the system’s dynamic response speed and harmonic suppression stability.

title: Determination of Attribute Weights for Path Planning Based on Dominance Relation Rough Set
authors: Yuhao Shan, Hongzhi Wang, Bing Wu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: When designing path planning algorithms, factors such as voyage distance and safety need to be comprehensively considered. However, the allocation ratio of these factors in the cost function is a crucial link that determines the quality of the path. Existing attribute weight allocation methods mainly rely on subjective assignment, and the cost function takes into account relatively few attribute factors. Therefore, this paper first identifies typical samples for attribute decision-making based on prior environmental information, then establishes a preferenceoriented attribute decision table, and performs operations such as positive transformation and dimensionless processing on the decision table. To avoid contradictions in attribute decisionmaking caused by subjective factors, a consistency check is conducted on the dominance relation decision system. Based on the upper and lower approximation sets, the importance among attribute subsets is determined, and finally, a set of attribute weights with different attribute preferences is obtained. The attribute weights (with specific preferences) determined by the dominance relation rough set are combined with the ant colony algorithm to conduct 3D path planning simulations, which verify the effectiveness of this attribute weight determination method.

title: MalShield: Enhancing Android Malware Detection with Stateful Defense against Query Attacks
authors: Hengyu Zhang, Guang Cheng, Yuyang Zhou, Zongyao Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Machine learning (ML) models for Android malware detection face escalating threats from adversarial query attacks, which iteratively perturb malware samples guided solely by model outputs. Existing stateful defenses primarily detect such attacks by analyzing query similarities or distribution anomalies. However, these methods are less effective in the malware domain, where discrete feature spaces and strict functional constraints combine with their reliance on only a single similarity or distribution metric, making it difficult to capture the varied patterns of query-based attacks. In this paper, we introduce MalShield, a stateful defense model that monitors the query stream through an adaptive sliding window, which adjusts its span according to the incoming query rate to preserve relevant context and enable real-time computation of multiple anomaly indicators. We design multiple complementary anomaly indicators, such as similarity decay and feature growth, to capture both temporal patterns and deviations in feature space, enabling more sensitive detection of query attacks. The K-of-N voting rule alerts only when enough indicators agree, cutting false positives and adapting to varied query attacks, thus providing robust, interpretable defense without changing the classifier. Experiments on Androzoo and Drebin datasets, against eight black-box query attacks, show MalShield achieves more than 96% reduction in evasion rates, surpassing existing stateful defenses and at best outperforms existing defense models by 100%.

title: A Digital Twin Approach to Adaptive Control Melt-Penetration for Large-Scale Structural Components Through Two-stage Metal Additive Manufacturing
authors: Huangyi Qu, Mingjun Chen, Yi Wang, Yi Cai
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Metal Additive Manufacturing is increasingly used in heavy industry for fabricating large-scale structural components by sequentially layering metal material based on digital 3D models. However, deviations in process parameters can cause significant material and operational losses. To address these challenges, a two-stage additive manufacturing strategy is proposed, integrating an initial standardized production phase followed by targeted customizations using Wire Arc Additive Manufacturing, specifically Tungsten Inert Gas welding. Despite WAAM’s advantages like stable arcs and high thermal efficiency, real-time melt depth control is complicated by arc illumination, electromagnetic interference, and elevated temperatures. This paper introduces a digital twin framework integrating geometric reconstruction via Neural Radiance Fields with analytical temperature-field modeling, enabling accurate melt pool depth prediction and immediate process parameter adjustments. Experimental evaluations yielded a NeRF reconstruction SSIM of 93.80% and a PSNR of 36.09 dB, achieving 95.31% accuracy in weld penetration prediction during welding process. The developed approach presents a rapid, precise, and cost-effective solution, significantly enhancing the manufacturing adaptability and quality assurance of large-scale structural components in heavy industry applications.

title: RecZTA: A Reputation-Based Architecture with Dual-Layer PEPs for Zero Trust Access
authors: Zhi Lin, Lin Yan, Zan Zhou, Yongfeng Yu, Penghui Xiao, Shujie Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Traditional bounded-based security models are difficult to cope with the challenges brought by dynamic cloud, microservices, and remote working environments. Although Zero Trust Architecture (ZTA) emphasizes "never trust, always verify", existing Policy Enforcement Point (PEP) deployments usually lack defense in depth and real-time health status assessment. To overcome these shortcomings, we propose RecZTA, a reputation-driven dual-layer PEP architecture under a unified control plane. The first layer is the service proxy, which is responsible for filtering and forwarding the initial traffic. The second layer is the resource access gateway, which is responsible for secondary security verification and service access authorization. RecZTA uses a multi-dimensional reputation model to realize real-time monitoring of service agents and rapid intrusion perception. Simulation results show that RecZTA can detect agent intrusion earlier than the existing zero trust models (device gateway model, resource portal model and enclave model), while maintaining low latency and low resource consumption, which verifies the feasibility and robustness of RecZTA in complex environments.

title: An Integrated Control Strategy for High-Frequency and Low-Frequency Circulating Current Suppression in Parallel Converters
authors: Chuanyue Shen, Jianbo Gao, Qiwu Wang, Wei Wang, Qingzhuo Li, Guofeng Dong, Guoxing Zhang, Yu Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: For parallel converters, circulating currents can be generally classified into high-frequency and low-frequency components. High-frequency circulating current (HFCC) are mainly attributed to carrier asynchronization, while lowfrequency circulating current (LFCC) typically results from zerosequence voltage mismatches between converters. This paper proposes a collaborative control strategy aimed at suppressing both HFCC and LFCC. Initially, the underlying mechanism of HFCC due to carrier asynchrony is analyzed in detail. Building on this understanding, a method is introduced, which uses the HFCC information to dynamically adjust the carrier frequency, eliminating phase discrepancies and realize carrier synchronization. For the suppression of LFCC, this method involves adjusting the dwell time of zero vectors to minimize the zero-sequence voltage difference among parallel converters. Ultimately, both compensators are integrated into a unified collaborative control framework. The experimental results obtained from relevant tests confirm that the proposed method can effectively reduce both HFCC and LFCC and improve the overall operation efficiency of the system.

title: Data-Driven Topology Identification and Parameter Estimation for Distribution Networks via Multi-Scale Feature Enhancement
authors: Guoxin Li, Sirui Cao, Tianyu Xu, Haozhe Ma, Jiarun Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: This paper presents an integrated framework for distribution network topology identification and parameter estimation using multi-scale variational mode decomposition. By decomposing smart meter measurements into three frequency bands and constructing correlation-weighted similarity metrics, the proposed method achieves high topology accuracy on a 5 node test network. Physics-informed optimization yields mean line parameter estimation errors of 2.24 V with X/R ratios within [1.272, 1.333]. SHAP analysis reveals voltage magnitudes and load demands as critical features, with nonlinear dependencies at identified thresholds. Experimental validation on $\mathbf{1, 0 0 0}$-sample datasets confirms the framework’s effectiveness for practical grid applications.

title: Metal Particle Movement Behavior under DC Voltage: The Influence of Surface Charges Accumulating on a Truncated Insulator
authors: Jianyi Xue, Zhiyi Guo, Zhengyang Li, Zecheng Wu, Bowen Xing, Aihua Zhao, Dan Hu, Zhong Fu, Yufei Fu, Hucheng Liang, Tao Wen, Lijian Ding
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
abstract: Metal particle contamination is a critical factor killing the security of DC insulation system. The movement process of metal particle becomes complicated under DC voltages due to the existence of accumulated charges on insulator surface. In order to obtain the correlation between the surface charges and metal particle behavior, a metal particle movement simulation model is established. The metal particle lifting voltage is both measured experimentally and calculated by simulation, and the little difference demonstrates the effectiveness of the simulation model. Then the effects of surface charges on a truncated insulation with different polarities on the metal particle motion characteristics are investigated. The influence mechanism of surface charges on particle movement is revealed. The results show that the homo-charges increase the electric field near the grounded electrode. After colliding with electrode near high-field region, metal particle carries more charges, leading to a reduction in the lifting voltage. However, when the amounts of homo-charges reach a certain level, metal particle tends to move towards the insulator. Conversely, hetero-charges increase the particle lifting voltage and enable it to move away from the insulator. Besides, the electrode roughness changes the random reflection angle of the metal particle after colliding, making the motion characteristics of metal particle more complicated. We hope this study could deepen the understandings of interaction between surface charges and metal particle movement.

title: Scalable rGO&#x2013;Ni Hybrid Yarn Sensors for Durable and Sensitive Wearable Electronics_supp4-3654231.docx
authors: Abdul Rauf Shaikh
abstract: Wearable electronics, particularly strain sensors, are essential for applications in health monitoring and human-machine interfaces. However, challenges remain in achieving sensors that balance high sensitivity, mechanical flexibility, and durability under dynamic deformations and environmental stressors like washing and humidity. Existing materials often suffer from limitations in conductivity, mechanical flexibility, and long-term stability. This study introduces a novel hybrid composite sensor composed of reduced graphene oxide (rGO) and nickel (Ni) coatings on spandex-cotton (CoSP) yarn, encapsulated in polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS). The synergistic combination of rGO and Ni significantly enhances the sensor’s mechanical strength, electrical conductivity, and strain sensitivity. The PDMS coating further ensures long-term durability, protecting the conductive network from oxidation and degradation. The rGO–Ni–CoSP/PDMS composite exhibits a tensile strength of 534 MPa and an elongation at break of 595%. The sensor shows excellent piezoresistive behavior with a gauge factor of -6.11 at 100% strain and maintains over 90% of its initial conductivity after 50 wash cycles. Additionally, the sensor demonstrates stable, repeatable resistance changes after 15,000 stretching cycles, with negligible hysteresis, confirming its high reliability and durability. This research presents a significant advancement in wearable strain sensors, offering a robust, sensitive, and environmentally stable solution. The sensor’s ability to monitor physiological activities such as respiration, pulse, and muscle movements highlights its potential for applications in healthcare, wearable robotics, and personalized health monitoring. Additionally, a mathematical model was established and experimentally validated, providing predictive insight into the strain-dependent resistance behavior of the hybrid yarn sensor.

title: Towards a Deep Understanding and Practical Guideline on the SameSite Policy
authors: Shuang Wu, Ying Yu, Yan Liu, Xiangyu Gao, Zhe Qu
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: The SameSite cookie policy was introduced to mitigate CSRF attacks and XS-Leaks. However, its adoption across web browsers remains hampered by misconfigurations, inconsistent behavior, and limited developer awareness. In this paper, we explore the challenges with SameSite deployment and address three key research questions: (1) intra- and inter-browser inconsistencies; (2) whether SameSite can replace anti-CSRF tokens; and (3) the role of SameSite in XS-Leaks mitigation. To answer these questions, we examine the evolution of SameSite in some popular websites. Our observations reveal inconsistent default policies across browsers that lead to divergent behavior. In addition, we demonstrate that relying solely on SameSite is insufficient to defend against CSRF attacks, while using the anti-CSRF token introduces a 300% overhead. We also clarify the scope against XS-Leaks. To assess developer awareness, we surveyed 92 website developers and found significant knowledge gaps in SameSite configuration. Therefore, we propose a unified guideline for developers, offering context-aware security recommendations by mapping cookie categories to specific website functionalities. We validate the guideline through experiments on real-world websites, a custom-built test site, and developer interviews. Results demonstrate improvements in both security and efficiency.

title: ReviewGuard: Enhancing Deficient Peer Review Detection via LLM-Driven Data Augmentation
authors: Haoxuan Zhang, Ruochi Li, Sarthak Shrestha, Shree Harshini Mamidala, Revanth Putta, Arka Krishan Aggarwal, Ting Xiao, Junhua Ding, Haihua Chen
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries (JCDL)
abstract: Peer review serves as the gatekeeper of science, yet the surge in submissions and widespread adoption of large language models (LLMs) in scholarly evaluation present unprecedented challenges. While recent work has focused on using LLMs to improve review efficiency, unchecked deficient reviews from both human experts and AI systems threaten to systematically undermine academic integrity. To address this issue, we introduce ReviewGuard, an automated system for detecting and categorizing deficient reviews through a four-stage LLM-driven framework: data collection from ICLR and NeurIPS on OpenReview, GPT-4.1 annotation with human validation, synthetic data augmentation yielding $\mathbf{6, 6 3 4}$ papers with 24,657 real and 46,438 synthetic reviews, and fine-tuning of encoderbased models and open-source LLMs. Feature analysis reveals that deficient reviews exhibit lower rating scores, higher self-reported confidence, reduced structural complexity, and more negative sentiment than sufficient reviews. AI-generated text detection shows dramatic increases in AI-authored reviews since ChatGPT’s emergence. Mixed training with synthetic and real data substantially improves detection performance-for example, Qwen 3-8B achieves recall of 0.6653 and F1 of 0.7073, up from 0.5499 and 0.5606 respectively. This study presents the first LLMdriven system for detecting deficient peer reviews, providing evidence to inform AI governance in peer review. Code, prompts, and data are available at GitHub Repository.

title: Optimization Configuration of the PV-Hydrogen Coupling System Based on Second-Order Cone Programming
authors: Ning Zhang, Jiatian Gan, Jun Yang, Jingang Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Under the “dual-carbon” goals, the high proportion of distributed photovoltaic (PV) integration presents challenges for energy balance and power quality in distribution networks. To address the issue of ignoring power flow constraints in energy storage configurations, which leads to unreasonable site selection and capacity allocation, this paper develops an optimized microgrid model that couples photovoltaic generation, gas turbine power generation, and hydrogen energy storage systems (electrolyzers/hydrogen storage tanks/fuel cells). The model aims to minimize the annual total operating cost while considering both economic and operational constraints, and utilizes Second-Order Cone Relaxation (SOCR) techniques to solve the nonlinear power flow problem. The performance of three configuration schemes is compared based on a modified IEEE-33 node system. The results show that, under the optimal configuration, line losses are reduced by 3.46% and 2.55% compared to the traditional schemes, and the voltage fluctuation range is decreased by 6.23% and 4.76%. These improvements occur with almost no change in operating costs, significantly enhancing the power quality. The findings verify the effectiveness of the PV-gas turbine-hydrogen energy storage coupled system in improving the economic efficiency and stability of distribution network operations.

title: Experimental Investigations on F- Mode / discharging of Modified Reversible PEM fuel cell with integrated Carbon Nitride as Electrode
authors: Surjeet Singh, Perminderjit Singh, Amandeep Singh Oberoi, Puneet Chawla
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: This paper examines the advancements in hydrogen storage materials and methods from an electrochemical standpoint, focusing on fundamental principles, using carbon nitride as storage material. Under these investigations a modified reversible fuel cell (MRFC) using carbon nitride as a medium for electrochemical hydrogen storage is developed. The carbon nitride-based electrode is fabricated using carbon nitride powder and a PTFE binder. The MRFC is tested for its performance, and the results show a 1.15 wt.% electrochemical hydrogen storage capacity while discharging fuel cell, comparable to traditional metal hydride-based materials. The charging capacity is 2.664 wt.% and the discharge capacity is found to be 1.15 wt.%, calculated using maximum current shown by ammeter while discharging. Hydrogen recovered is half of what was reported in 2018, but with the average values experimental data, 0.3636 w% of hydrogen is recovered. This is the first instance of a carbon nitride-based hydrogen storage electrode is employed in an MRFC, that highlights the potential of porous carbon nitride as a candidate for reversible electrochemical hydrogen adsorption

title: DeepLancet: Effectively Detecting Deep Learning Library Bugs via LLM-assisted Testcase Generation
authors: Zihao Luo, Baojian Hua
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Deep learning libraries such as PyTorch and TensorFlow are essential for building security-critical downstream deep learning applications. Bugs in these libraries compromise their correctness, robustness, and security, thereby undermining the reliability of downstream applications. Unfortunately, effectively detecting bugs in deep learning library remains challenging, as existing approaches often fail to generate effective test cases due to their inability to synthesize complex input constraints that govern deep learning library functions.In this paper, we present DeepLancet, the first approach for effectively detecting deep learning library bugs by leveraging large language models (LLMs) to systematically parse documentation and thereby assist in the generation of high-quality test cases. Our key observation is that mainstream deep learning libraries typically provide comprehensive and well-structured documentation, which contains detailed descriptions of input constraints that we can effectively synthesize and leverage to generate syntactically valid and semantically correct test cases. Specifically, we first synthesize function constraint descriptions from the documentation by leveraging LLMs. We then generate rigorous constraints which are leveraged to generate test cases through an attribution-based approach in Python. Finally, we employ a differential testing approach on CPU and GPU to detect bugs. We build a software prototype for DeepLancet, and our evaluation results demonstrate that DeepLancet is effective in uncovering previously unknown real-world bugs: it successfully uncovers 20 bugs in the latest release of PyTorch, including 7 previously unknown ones. Moreover, we compare DeepLancet with DocTer, a state-of-the-art technique that also leverages documentation for constraint extraction, and the results indicate that DeepLancet can extract more comprehensive constraints, thereby uncovering 3 more bugs that were missed by DocTer.

title: Adaptive Multi-Feature Hierarchical Framework for Generative Model Attribution
authors: Ruoying Wang, Linghui Li, Xiaotian Si, Kaiguo Yuan, Zhaoyu Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: The rapid progress of generative adversarial networks (GANs) and diffusion models (DMs) has enabled photorealistic image synthesis, raising critical concerns about image authenticity verification and source attribution. Existing hierarchical detection frameworks remain constrained by error propagation, weak cross-layer information sharing, and limited discriminative power for highly similar architectures. To address these challenges, we propose a multi-feature adaptive hierarchical framework for fine-grained attribution of AI-generated images. The framework first unifies complementary representations from frequency, noise, color, and semantic domains through a multi-feature extraction module, providing richer cues beyond conventional designs. We then introduces adaptive mechanisms—including dynamic decisionmaking, confidence-weighted fusion, and dual-path classification—that mitigate cascading errors and enable flexible dependency control across layers. Extensive experiments on a large-scale dataset validate the effectiveness of our approach, showing clear improvements over conventional methods and state-of-the-art detectors, particularly in distinguishing confusable GAN variants such as ProGAN, StyleGAN, and StyleGAN2. These results demonstrate the robustness and scalability of the proposed design for reliable AIGC detection and model attribution.

title: MEM-UNet: Morphology-Enhanced 3D Mamba UNet for Esophagus Segmentation
authors: Chao-Chia Lin, Shanq-Jang Ruan, Yu-Jen Wang
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Accurate segmentation of medical images, particularly for anatomical structures with irregular shapes and low contrast such as the esophagus, remains a significant challenge. To address this issue, we propose MEM-UNet, a robust 3D Mamba-based UNet framework enhanced by mathematical morphology. Our approach adapts the State Space Model (SSM) in Mamba to support three-dimensional CT volumes, establishing an effective 3D perception backbone for the UNet architecture. In addition, we incorporate Morphology-Aware Spatial-Channel Attention (MASCA) blocks into the skip connections, where Morphology-Enhanced Spatial Convolution (MESC) augments spatial representations while Squeeze-and-Excitation (SE) highlights channel- wise features. This integration effectively leverages the shape-awareness provided by morphological operations, thus improving boundary precision. To further refine segmentation, we introduce a Morphology-Enhanced Decision (MED) layer that sharpens contour boundaries and performs voxel-level classification with high precision. Extensive experiments on SegTHOR and BTCV datasets demonstrate that MEM-UNet surpasses state-of-the-art models, achieving Dice Similarity Coefficient (DSC) scores of 87.42% and 74.86% for multi-organ segmentation, and 78.94% and 67.70% for esophagus segmentation, respectively. Ablation studies confirm the effectiveness of the proposed components and highlight the benefits of integrating mathematical morphology into our pipeline. The implementation is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://gitfront.io/r/cheee123/DDTJhrf3LRMd/MEM-UNet/</uri>.

title: Research on Model Predictive Control for Hybrid Ships Based on Operational Condition Recognition
authors: Wenhui Lai, Jiang You
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: To enhance the control performance of the energy management strategy for hybrid ships, an online operating condition recognition method was integrated with a real-time optimization strategy. A hybrid ship energy management strategy was proposed based on the k-means clustering algorithm and model predictive control (MPC). A series-type hybrid ship was selected as the research object. An online operating condition recognition model was constructed and trained using the $\mathbf{k}$-means clustering algorithm. This approach improved prediction accuracy through classification and identification of ship operating conditions. During control, this method was utilized to identify the sailing condition online. Corresponding predictive models were selected according to the identified condition. More accurate energy allocation decisions were provided. Simulation results demonstrated that the proposed strategy satisfied the ship’s power demand. It also achieved satisfactory control performance and fuel economy. Compared with the single-predictive-model model predictive control strategy, the proposed method reduced fuel consumption by approximately $0.7 \%$. Its fuel consumption was closer to that of the control strategy based on dynamic programming.

title: System Architecture and IoT Technologies for Intelligent Inspection Using Humanoid Robots
authors: Hong Tang, Shuang Li, Xuesong Lang, Fucun Huang, Ke Huang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: With the accelerating digitalization of critical infrastructures such as power grids, petrochemical plants, and rail transit, humanoid robots are emerging as promising carriers for high-precision inspection thanks to their human-like locomotion and environmental adaptability. This paper investigates the “system architecture and IoT technologies for intelligent inspection using humanoid robots” and proposes an integrated “cloud-edge-robot-device” framework. Within this framework, we design key techniques for multi-source perception fusion, motion planning under energy constraints, task coordination, and IoT-based communication. By introducing state-space modeling, optimal control, energy management, and network delay analysis, we quantitatively describe and analyze the humanoid robot’s path planning, energy consumption, and real-time communication performance in complex substations and industrial sites. A simulation platform and a small-scale field testbed are built to evaluate inspection efficiency, system availability, and communication reliability. Experimental results show that the proposed architecture and IoT technologies can significantly improve inspection efficiency and reduce energy consumption while maintaining safety, providing a feasible pathway for large-scale deployment of humanoid robots in power and other industrial sectors.

title: LDInfer: Landmarks Inference-Based for Facial Forgery Detection of Different Quality
authors: Jiaxin Jiang, Zhiwen Chen, Hui Zhou, Wenjun Yan, Tianshuo Jiao, Bohan Tan, Zhuo Zhang, Hao Chen, Zheng Qin
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: The harm caused by deepfakes is becoming increasingly serious, including financial fraud, guiding political public opinion, and more. The vast majority of deepfake detection methods typically perform well on uncompressed deepfake videos, achieving satisfactory results. However, when facing deepfake videos with different compression rates, the effectiveness of certain detection methods will significantly decrease, and they may even be unable to detect compressed videos. To address this challenge, we introduce a new detection mechanism: landmarks inference mechanism. Based on this, we propose a simple and efficient model LDInfer for inferring landmarks to achieve deepfake video detection. Our method utilizes the inference between facial landmarks and their preceding and succeeding frames to improve detection accuracy, which remains effective even in compressed deepfake videos. This method first infers landmarks and verifies their authenticity using the correlation between landmarks in the previous and subsequent frames. Even if the video is compressed, the correlation between facial landmarks in the preceding and following frames remains high. Comparative experiments show that our method outperforms existing methods at various compression rates.

title: Energy-Aware VM Consolidation Using Similarity-Driven Intelligence in Green Cloud Environments
authors: Nirmal Kr Biswas, Debashis Das, Sourav Banerjee, Utpal Biswas
abstract: Cloud computing is currently playing an essential role in supporting emerging sectors such as smart energy, intelligent transportation, and large-scale distributed systems. The scalability and adaptability features of cloud computing are efficiently enable resource utilization and continuous data exchange in dynamic and heterogeneous environments. However, the increasing demand for cloud services has raised the energy consumption of cloud data centers, which has a critical environmental impact. Therefore, sustainable resource management tactics have become crucial in today's world. Dynamic Virtual Machine (VM) consolidation is one of the major tactics for sustainable resource management in the green cloud computing environment. Herein, a novel dynamic Energy-Aware Cosine Similarity Learning Network (ECSLN) is proposed to predict the overutilized host. Further, an Impact Factor-Based VM Selection (IFBVMS) method is proposed to select VMs for migration, and an ECSLN-Packed Placement method for VM placement into hosts. The main aim of the proposed VM consolidation is to maximize energy efficiency while preserving compliance with Service Level Agreements (SLAs) for sustainable environments. The experimental evaluation using real-world traces like PlanetLab, Bitbrains, and Alibaba Cluster 2020 workload validates that the proposed VM consolidation methods significantly reduce energy consumption and SLA violation compared to the existing methods for sustainable environments. The evaluation shows that the proposed ECSLN-based consolidation framework enables green cloud infrastructure by intelligently balancing energy consumption, SLA violation, and performance of cloud data centers.

title: Validated Model for Magnetoelectric Wireless Power Transmit Antenna
authors: Somayeh Motaee, Shad Roundy
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Micro and Miniature Power Systems, Self-Powered Sensors and Energy Autonomous Devices (PowerMEMS)
abstract: Magnetoelectric composites can be an attractive solution for wireless power transfer when a combination of small size and low frequency are desired. In this work, we develop an analytical model that accounts for mechanical dynamics, magneto-mechanical coupling, and electromechanical coupling. We validate this model experimentally using a 5-layer, self-biased, ME composite. The model effectively predicts the radiated magnetic field around the magnetoelectric antenna. This model is a valuable tool in the development of a full magnetoelectric wireless power transfer or communication link.

title: LPI-based Power and Dwell Time Allocation for Target Tracking via Manifold Optimization
authors: Yipeng Zhong, Jinfeng Hu, Kai Zhong, Kaizhi Ruan, Jing Guo, Jie Wu, Jiacheng Gou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: In modern electronic warfare environments, resource allocation can improve the tracking accuracy and anti-interception capability of radar networks. The main challenge is to coordinate the transmit power of each radar to reduce the Posterior Cramér-Rao lower bound (PCRLB) while ensuring low interception. The problem is difficult to solve due to the non-convex nature of the low interception constraint. Existing methods are mainly divided into heuristic methods and convex relaxation methods (CRM), but they are computationally expensive or have large relaxation losses. We note that real sphere manifolds naturally satisfy the transmit power constraint and the dwell time constraint, while the exact penalty term is suitable for handling the low intercept constraint. Using these properties, we propose an exact penalty manifold optimization (EPMO) framework for power and dwell time allocation. First, the exact penalty term is introduced and the real sphere product manifold (RSPM) is constructed to transform the original problem into an unconstrained problem. Then, we derive a parallel limited Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno (PL-BFGS) algorithm to solve the problem. Compared with existing methods, this method has the following advantages: i) the tracking accuracy is improved by 6% compared to SPG; ii) the computation time is reduced by an order of magnitude compared to PSO and by about 40% compared to SPG.

title: Hierarchical Decision Mamba Meets Agentic AI: A Novel Approach for RAN Slicing in 6G
authors: Md Arafat Habib, Medhat Elsayed, Majid Bavand, Pedro Enrique Iturria Rivera, Yigit Ozcan, Melike Erol-Kantarci
abstract: Radio Access Network (RAN) slicing enables multiple logical networks to exist on top of the same physical infrastructure by allocating resources to distinct service groups, where radio resource scheduling plays a key role in ensuring compliance with slice-specific Service-Level Agreements (SLAs). Existing configuration-based or intent-driven Reinforcement Learning (RL) approaches usually rely on static mappings and SLA conversions. The current literature does not integrate natural language understanding with coordinated decision-making. To address these limitations, we propose an Agentic AI framework for 6G RAN slicing, driven by a super agent built using Hierarchical Decision Mamba (HDM) controllers and a Large Language Model (LLM). The super agent interprets operator intents and translates them into actionable goals using the LLM, which are used by HDM to coordinate inter-slice, intra-slice, and self-healing agents. Compared to transformer-based and reward-driven baselines, the proposed Agentic AI framework demonstrates consistent improvements across key performance indicators, including higher throughput, improved cell-edge performance, and reduced latency across different slices.

title: Quality Management And Industry 4.0 Capabilities For Industrial Decarbonisation Maturity Models: Evidence From Australian Manufacturing Companies
authors: F. M. B de Moraes, J. Sebastian, Q. M. Pham, G. L. Tortorella, A. Trianni
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: The increase in environmental impacts resulting from unsustainable production practices has been significant in Australia, one of the developed countries with the highest carbon emissions per capita. Additionally, the underdeveloped Australian manufacturing industry requires investing in efficient (Quality Management, QM), innovative (Industry 4.0, I4.0), and sustainable (Industrial Decarbonisation, ID) practices to advance organisational maturity. This study builds on a preliminary investigation of 49 capabilities and examines their relationship with specific practices in the QM-I4.0-ID sphere. It further develops an empirical case study through structured interviews with experts from diverse Australian manufacturing industries to validate the model, highlighting the critical enablers in operational performance and carbon reduction strategies. Findings indicate that QM practices are well established in Australian manufacturing, yet with an intermediate expertise level. Some I4.0 technologies (e.g. additive manufacturing) are occasionally implemented and while there is awareness of the need for ID strategies, these are often perceived as driven by governmental pressures. Finally, it proposes a maturity matrix with 11 dimensions and 3 levels to support decision-makers into the adoption of advanced quality and digital strategies towards decarbonisation.

title: Actuation Using 3D-Printable Near-Infrared-Responsive Composites – A Miniaturized Body for a Caterpillar Robot
authors: Alicja MusiaŁ, Katarzyna Wilczewska, Karolina U. Laszczyk, Weronika Chuda, Tymon Janisz, Damian Nowak, Piotr Kamedulski, Rafał Walczak
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Micro and Miniature Power Systems, Self-Powered Sensors and Energy Autonomous Devices (PowerMEMS)
abstract: This paper details the development of a 3D-printable near-infrared-responsive composite that was applied for the miniaturized caterpillar robot’s body enabling its mobility. We present here modelling, fabrication and actuation of the mentioned mini-robot body.

title: Application of Machine Learning for Predicting Surface Roughness (Ra) in Abrasive Water Jet Machined Ti-6Al-4V MMCs
authors: Lavanya M, M Balasubramanian, S Priyadarsini, P.K.Devan, P.Usha Rani, P B Edwin Prabhakar
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: In this work, Titanium aluminium alloy was machined using abrasive water jet machining (AWJM). Average surface roughness (Ra) evaluated on the machine holes used by the L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">18</inf> orthogonal array. Random forest (RF), Decision tree (DT), and XG Boost machine learning predicted algorithms were used for predicting the Ra machined holes on the Ti-6Al-4V metal matrix composites. This research reported that, DT has the lowest MAE (0.0260) and best R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> (0.9626), demonstrating greater prediction accuracy. RF has a slightly higher MAE (0.0432) but lower MSE (0.1713) than DT, with a R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.9380. XGBoost has the lowest MSE (0.0837) and an excellent R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> (0.9583), but its MAE (0.290) is much higher. Machining aluminium alloy metal matrix composites (MMCs) through Abrasive Water Jet Machining (AWJM) provides a sustainable, high-precision manufacturing approach. This technique supports Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure by promoting advanced and efficient machining technologies, and contributes to Responsible Consumption and Production by reducing environmental impact and encouraging cleaner, resource-efficient processing methods.

title: Surface Potential Control of Self-Assembled Electrets Using Corona Discharge Post-Processing
authors: Minori Morihata, Mitsuto Kojima, Hiroki Naruo, Yuya Tanaka, Daisuke Yamane
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Micro and Miniature Power Systems, Self-Powered Sensors and Energy Autonomous Devices (PowerMEMS)
abstract: This paper is the first to report on the controllability of the surface potential of self-assembled electrets (SAEs) subjected to corona discharge. We experimentally demonstrate that the surface potential of SAE thin films changes in response to variations in needle electrode voltage (V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">N</inf>) and discharge time during corona discharge. These findings offer new insights for designing micro-electro-mechanical systems (MEMS) vibration energy harvesters (VEHs) and other devices utilizing SAEs.

title: Totally Mass and Interference Decoupling in Dual-Stage Nanopositioning: A Novel High-Speed Parallel-Actuation Strategy
authors: Chengsi Huang, Hui Tang, Yingjie Jia, Zhishen Liao, Huanhao Cai, Zhi-Xin Yang
abstract: Dual-stage nanopositioning systems are highly appealing for nanomanipulation owing to their large range, high speed, and high accuracy. In this article, a novel parallel-actuation dual-stage nanopositioning strategy (PDNS) is proposed to enhance the high-speed tracking performance by avoiding the inherent issues of series-actuation and improving the current parallel-actuation schemes. First, the issues of current dual-stage nanopositioning schemes in high-speed tracking are analyzed, followed by the conceptual presentation of PDNS. Next, for implementation of PDNS, the mechanical design and modeling of a nanopositioner are demonstrated. To achieve high-speed tracking controls, a complementary filter-based dual-stage controller is developed. Then, the designed parameters are simultaneously optimized by a new integrated mechanical-control codesign method, considering the mechanical and control specifications together. Finally, a series of experiments have been successfully conducted to validate the effectiveness of proposed PDNS. The results indicate that the lumped mass and interference behavior in dual-stage system have been decoupled by 99.09% and 99.33%, respectively. Furthermore, the proposed method improves the tracking accuracy of triangular trajectories by 27.96% at 5 Hz and 42.47% at 100 Hz, compared to series-actuation scheme. All the results uniformly confirm that the proposed PDNS has effectively enhanced the high-speed tracking performance of dual-stage nanopositioning system.

title: Toward Dolphin-Inspired Frictional Drag Reduction: A Novel Actuator Device for Boundary Layer Modulation
authors: Silvia Matt, Hongyang Shi, Austin Thombs, Weilin Hou, Thassyo Pinto, Xiaobo Tan
abstract: Drag reduction is of significant interest in the design of marine vehicles. Viscoelastic boundary materials and compliant surfaces, such as those found in dolphin skin, have the potential to reduce frictional drag by delaying the transition from laminar to turbulent flow and minimizing turbulence. To investigate the effect of boundary modulation on turbulence, we developed and tested a novel device that generates wave-like deformations on a flow boundary. This device, enabled by a 5×5 voice coil motor array, was embedded in the wall of a flow channel and overlaid with a flexible membrane in direct contact with the water. The boundary displacement was quantified using a computer vision approach. The deformable membrane system was tested across a range of flow tank speeds and boundary actuation patterns, and the impact on near-boundary velocity was assessed. The resulting data indicate that boundary actuation alters the boundary layer velocity and turbulent stresses both under the region of actuation and in its wake. The effect was most pronounced in regions with boundary layer coherent structures, and certain actuation parameters were consistent with a reduction in frictional drag. A numerical model of the flow tank showed a 10% reduction in average shear stress over the actuated boundary and one actuation wave period, supporting the laboratory experiments and corroborating the findings. This work supports efforts to develop dolphin-inspired methods to reduce near-boundary turbulence and drag, which, if successfully applied in a natural environment, can lead to more energy-efficient platforms and underwater vehicles.
