title: A Data-Driven Framework for Predictive Maintenance to Enhance Supply Chains Resilience Across Industrial Systems
authors: Mariem Mhiri, Mohamed Kharbeche, Mohamed Haouari
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: This paper proposes a data-driven framework for predictive maintenance to enhance supply chains resilience in industrial systems. The approach involves two main stages. First, data is collected via IoT sensors and digital twins or simulation tools. This data trains a binary classification machine learning (ML) model to predict system success or failure. In the second stage, a predictive model forecasts future operating conditions, which are evaluated by the ML model to determine the system’s operational state. Two predictive methods are implemented: Vector Autoregression (VAR) for linear dynamics and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks for non-linear behavior. The framework is validated on a cryogenic heat exchanger, critical equipment in natural gas liquefaction. Results show both models enable early failure detection and reduce cumulative downtime. However, LSTM incurs higher computational time due to its complexity, while VAR offers faster performance. These results illustrate key trade-offs between predictive accuracy and efficiency in maintenance planning.

title: Passive Model Predictive Cooperative Interaction Control for Bimanual Humanoid Manipulation_supp1-3654808.mp4
authors: Fei Chen
abstract: Dual-arm humanoid robots are poised to transform industrial manufacturing automation in human-centric environments. However, unlocking this potential requires a unified framework that can simultaneously handle coupled bimanual coordination, versatile physical interaction, and safety. We introduce Passive Model Predictive Cooperative Interaction Control (P-MPCIC), a framework that co-optimizes task performance and interaction safety under a formal passivity guarantee. P-MPCIC integrates model predictive control for the bimanual subsystem within a whole-body architecture and uses a coupling matrix to enforce synchronization objectives across relative motion and force distribution. For interaction prediction, the framework incorporates a composite robot-environment model that combines parallel and series impedance dynamics, yielding a linear state-space predictor. Passivity is enforced as a constraint on the energy balance at the interaction port, preventing destabilizing energy generation from the controller. We verify the framework’s core principles through planar simulations and demonstrate its practical effectiveness on a 7-DoF dual-arm humanoid.

title: Research on a Model-Driven Approach for Integrated Analysis of Power System Frequency Response Based on Initial Predictions
authors: Ou Zhang, Xiaoyu Zhou, Xingcheng Yu, Xuefeng Wu, Xue Jiang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: With a high proportion of new energy sources integrated into the power system, system inertia decreases, making frequency stability issues increasingly prominent. Traditional purely model-driven frequency response analysis methods are limited by model accuracy and parameter precision, whereas purely data-driven methods rely on large amounts of labeled data and lack physical interpretability. To address this, this paper proposes a model-data fusion-driven frequency response analysis method. This method first uses a simplified physical model for initial frequency response prediction, providing high-confidence physical constraints and initial states for subsequent data analysis. On this basis, a data-driven model is introduced, using the residual from the initial prediction of the previous stage as the learning target to achieve precise compensation for unmodeled dynamics and uncertainties in the physical model. Simulation results on the New England 10-machine 39-bus system show that the proposed fusion method significantly improves the prediction accuracy of the frequency nadir, steady-state frequency, and dynamic trajectories compared to using either a pure physical model or a pure data-driven model alone, combining both physical transparency and adaptive capability.

title: Linear Polytopic Positive Invariance
authors: Saša V. Raković, Sixing Zhang
abstract: This article revisits verification of positive invariance for polytopic sets with respect to linear dynamics. The existing necessary and sufficient conditions are applicable only to fixed candidate polytopic sets. This article derives alternative necessary and sufficient conditions for two main representations of polytopic sets. These novel necessary and sufficient conditions are derived by utilizing Minkowski function in primal setting and support function in dual setting. Developed results enable direct positive invariance verification of fixed candidate polytopic sets, as well as enhanced positive invariance verification allowing for a structurally constrained redesign of candidate polytopic sets. The established necessary and sufficient conditions admit algebraic reformulations as feasibility checks of numerically appealing systems of affine inequalities and equalities indicating strongly their high numerical potential.

title: Two-disk synthesis of coherent quantum passive equalizers for channels with Hamiltonian uncertainty
authors: Shuixin Xiao, Weichao Liang, Daoyi Dong, Ian R. Petersen, Valery Ugrinovskii
abstract: The coherent equalization problem involves designing a quantum system that serves as a mean-square near-optimal filter for a given quantum communication channel. Previous work on coherent equalization has typically assumed that the system parameters are known without uncertainty. In this work, we address the problem of coherent passive equalization with uncertainty in the Hamiltonian. Utilizing an S-procedure method, we remodel the passive quantum system with uncertainty as a scaled closed-loop state-space representation with parameter dependencies. We then propose a two-disk synthesis approach for coherent passive equalizers. Numerical examples based on a single optical cavity system and on two-cavity systems with beam splitters demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed two-disk synthesis method for coherent equalization of passive quantum systems.

title: A Robust ML-Based Diagnostic Procedure for Rotating Machinery under Varying Noise, Speed, and Load Conditions
authors: Issam Attoui, Nadir Fergani, Adel Boudiaf
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: In this study, a robust diagnostic procedure for rotating machinery is proposed, combining frequency-domain signal analysis, dimensionality reduction, and machine learning classification. The method is designed to perform reliably under challenging industrial conditions, including variable loads, rotational speeds, and signal-to-noise ratios. To confirm the robustness and efficiency of this approach, we propose a comparative evaluation with multiple feature reduction techniques (e.g., PCA, ICA, LDA, SVD, RP, KMeans) and classifiers (e.g., SVM, KNN). The diagnostic performance was assessed across various noisy environments and operating scenarios using the CWRU bearing dataset. Results highlight the most effective combinations of techniques, offering valuable insights into optimal configurations for real-world fault diagnosis applications.

title: A Hybrid Modelling and Co-simulation Approach Based Lab-scale Digital Twin for Flexible Robotic Assembly Cell in Academia
authors: Z. Jin, R. M. Marian, J. S. Chahl
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: In building the smart manufacturing paradigm, the digital twin is playing a significant role in integrating various production assets and processes. In this paper, we propose a hybrid modelling approach for developing digital twin systems in a robotic flexible assembly context. The combined modelling approach of physics-based and data driven-based approach leads to a higher level of model fidelity of the system. The proposed strategy also enables a co-simulation configuration for the system. The proposed method is implemented in a lab-scale robotic assembly cell in academia. Two key features, bi-directional data transmission and data-driven anomaly detection strategy, of the digital twin system are then validated and discussed.

title: A Modular, Inherently Safe High-Frequency Bipolar Nanosecond Pulse Generator for Complex Dynamic Biological Loads
authors: Rongrong Liu, Zhengyi Zhong, Yuyi Guo, Yuwen Han, Jinsong Guo, Fukun Shi, Shuqun Wu, Junfeng Rao, Jie Zhuang
abstract: This paper presents a modular, high-frequency bipolar nanosecond pulse generator (nsPG) featuring a dual-layer intrinsic safety design for complex dynamic biological loads. The proposed hybrid architecture synergistically integrates a solid-state Marx generator with a step-up pulse transformer, creating a compact and component-efficient power electronics platform. Key innovations include an inductor-based charging scheme that halves the semiconductor switch count and a multi-faceted passive protection strategy that not only leverages the transformer's volt-second limit to suppress long-pulse faults but also architecturally precludes catastrophic DC shoot-through failures. The prototype delivers a flexible output of 0-±11 kV and 100–500 ns pulses with a 500 kHz burst frequency, achieving an electrical efficiency of 94.85% on resistive loads. Crucially, the generator's robustness was validated through in vivo and ex vivo experiments. The results demonstrated that the nsPG maintained exceptional waveform fidelity despite a drastic 80.27% impedance collapse in the potato model (from 2.488 kΩ to 491.0 Ω at 10 kHz) and a 6.17% real-time dynamic reduction in the mouse model (from 412.0 Ω to 386.6 Ω over the initial ten pulses). This work demonstrates a robust and safe power electronics solution for a broad class of complex, low-impedance loads, positioning it as a key enabling technology for a challenging class of emerging industrial and scientific applications.

title: B-CvT: A Style Transfer Framework for Content Preservation and Fairness in Skin Lesion Imaging
authors: Minoru Tarumi, Jaya Pathak, Amitesh Singh Rajput, Jagat Sesh Challa, Vinay Chamola
abstract: There exists a significant lack of diversity based on skin tone representation in medical imaging, which contributes to delayed cancer diagnoses and poor outcomes for skin cancers in people of color. Current diagnostic systems predominantly feature lighter skin tones, which hinders accurate pathology identification on darker skin. Neural style transfer has emerged as a promising technique to address this data imbalance by artificially expanding the diversity of skin tone representations in medical image datasets. However, existing methods often disrupt critical diagnostic features through artifacts or structural deformations. To address this problem, we present a branched convolutional vision transformer (B-CvT) encoder coupled with a convolutional transformer decoder to enable precise skin tone transfer. The architecture preserves pathological content by employing dedicated encoder branches to disentangle style (skin tone) from content (lesion morphology), reinforced by a Wasserstein distance-based similarity loss that enforces clean feature separation in latent space. Quantitative evaluation demonstrates superior performance, surpassing state-of-the-art style transfer methods with the best Learned Perceptual Image Patch Similarity (LPIPS) of 0.320 and Structural Similarity Index Measure (SSIM) of 0.803. When used as a data augmentation technique, the proposed method improves the fairness of the model in cancer diagnostics by reducing the Equalized Odds between different skin tones by 0.09 without compromising overall accuracy. This provides a high-fidelity image synthesis tool and a method for developing more equitable AI diagnostic models, addressing a critical gap in dermatological representation by preserving the core pathological content essential for downstream diagnostic tasks.

title: Review of MobileNet variants for effective Land Use Land Cover classification : A Study with Light Weight models
authors: Prathik Kumaar. B, A Deepak, V. Rajinikanth
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: Accurate classification of Land Use and Land Cover (LULC) is essential for effective environmental assessment, urban planning, and agricultural monitoring. This research employs the EuroSAT dataset, which is based on Sentinel-2 satellite imagery, to evaluate the performance of three lightweight deep learning models: MobileNetV1, MobileNetV2, and MobileNetV3 large. The results indicate that MobileNetV1 delivers the highest classification accuracy at 92%, followed by MobileNetV2 with 87%, while MobileNetV3 shows significantly lower performance at 27%, rendering it less suitable for practical use in this context. Additionally, the study examines the computational efficiency of each model by analyzing their training and evaluation times. Future efforts will focus on optimizing lightweight model architectures and exploring hybrid methods to improve scalability and accuracy in remote sensing tasks.

title: Effect of Cross-Linking Agent on Stretchable Elastomer Electret for Energy Harvesting
authors: R. Horibe, R. Wang, Y. Gu, K. Suzuki, T. Miyoshi, Y. Suzuki
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Micro and Miniature Power Systems, Self-Powered Sensors and Energy Autonomous Devices (PowerMEMS)
abstract: This paper reports on a novel stretchable electret for kinetic energy harvesters. We made a novel perfluoroelastomer FFKM cross-linked with triazine. We found that FFKM/triazine gives a record-high surface charge potential of 1.5 mC/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> as a stretchable electret, which is 7.5 times that of the base FFKM.

title: Robust Unsupervised Speaker-profile Analytics with Large Language Model-embedding-based Text Mining and Outlier Detection for Seed-stage High-tech Startup Recruiting
authors: Yushi Nakaya, Shuichi Ishida
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Efficient identification of individuals who can become core members of an organization while adapting to uncertain organizational changes is critically important in the seed stage in startups, where it is often difficult to allocate sufficient time for hiring and training. Although previous studies have investigated such identification based on utterances during meetings, these approaches lack robustness against variations in meeting participants and contexts, making their practical implementation highly challenging. Consequently, this study proposes an analysis method based on clustering with large language model-derived embedding vectors, which remain robust even when speakers or meeting topics change. Furthermore, the trained weights can be easily reused, enabling organizations to perform such analyses at low cost and with minimal effort.

title: Forecast-driven and simulation-based decision support for weather-sensitive project scheduling
authors: S. Eberlein, S. Schukraft, J. F. Uhlenkamp, A. R. Sair, M. Freitag
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Many supply chain processes involve weather-sensitive outdoor activities, e.g., transportation or construction. However, research in forecast-driven methods that not only provide alerts but also offer dynamic decision support and automatic rescheduling at the level of individual tasks is still limited. Based on the case of modular healthcare construction, we develop a forecast-driven planning support tool that integrates real-time weather forecasts and historical climate data into project scheduling. The tool automatically evaluates each task’s feasibility against weather constraints. In its current state, it provides continuous monitoring of weather conditions and issues alerts when weather thresholds are likely to be exceeded. Current development focuses on the automated replanning capabilities and simulation-based scenario evaluation. The implementation uses an object-oriented Python framework and open-source weather APIs. To outline the potential of the method, we demonstrate intermediate results using the case of a modular healthcare facility provider.

title: Flow-Based Screen-Shooting Robust Watermarking with Invertible Noise Simulation Network
authors: Pei Gan, Xuehu Yan, Hu Deng, Rongtao Liao, Feng Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Recent years have seen the rapid development of smartphone cameras, enabling high-quality capture of on-screen content and facilitating widespread unauthorized duplication of digital content. While screen-captured images are ubiquitous in daily sharing and commercial activities, the lack of robust copyright protection mechanisms for this specific scenario remains a critical challenge. The copyrights of image creators cannot be effectively safeguarded. Traditional robust watermarking approaches, which primarily focus on digital noise, often fail to resist the unique distortions during the screen-shooting process, such as luminance distortion, perspective distortion, and moiré distortion. To address this challenge, we propose a flow-based screen-shooting robust watermarking framework, whose architecture is comprised of a flow-based watermark network and an invertible denoising network. Additionally, we constructed a screen-shooting noise image dataset and constructed an invertible noise simulation network to model the screen-shooting noise. The network achieves invertible noise modeling through a bidirectional process. The forward process simulates the noise, and the backward process removes the noise. Experimental results demonstrate that, compared to existing robust watermarking methods, our method achieves superior robustness against screen-shooting noise. The invertible noise simulation network exhibits excellent denoising capabilities, and the average PSNR of the watermarked images is up to 39 dB, the watermark information extraction accuracy is up to 98%, ensuring both high imperceptibility and robustness.

title: APT-GCM: Advanced Persistent Threats Detection via Graph Contrastive Masked Representation Learning
authors: Mengkun Zhao, Jing Liu, Wenqiang Hao, Xiaobing Pei
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Advanced Persistent Threats(APTs) are targeted, stealthy, and highly sophisticated cyberattacks posing serious risks to critical infrastructure and sensitive data. In recent years, researchers increasingly focus on constructing provenance graphs from system logs to represent information flows, aiming to detect APTs through such semantically rich structured data. Although provenance graph-based APT detection techniques have shown effectiveness, they still suffer from several limitations: First, most of these methods require real-world APT data and prior expert knowledge; Second, they generally focusing on fine-grained local information while neglecting global information, resulting in in-sufficient extraction of rich contextual information and thus high false positive rates; Third, their detection performance degrades against evasion strategies, indicating insufficient robustness.To address these problems, this paper proposes Advanced Persistent Threat Detection via Graph Contrastive Masked Autoencoder (APT-GCM), a self-supervised learning-based detection model. APT-GCM leverages a graph contrastive masked autoencoder to learn node representations from benign provenance graphs, transforming malicious nodes detection into an outlier detection problem. It integrates the advantages of masked graph autoencoder and graph contrastive learning for extracting both local and global graph information through a dual-branch structure, learning deep implicit features of provenance graph nodes. Additionally, a uniformity loss is introduced to optimize the embedding distribution and improve discriminability. To further improve robustness, a complementary view augmentation module is incorporated, which constructs a complementary view of the masked view and performs feature alignment of masked nodes, strengthening the model’s ability to extract stable semantic information from diverse perspectives and thus improving its robustness against evasion attacks. We evaluate APT-GCM on three sub-datasets from the widely used DARPA E3 dataset, and experimental results demonstrate that APT-GCM outperforms state-of-the-art detection methods.

title: Consumers’ Attitudes towards Circular Fashion: Survey-based Analysis on Second-Hand Shopping, Renting and Repairing
authors: C. Romero Espel, S. M. Chankov
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: The fashion industry’s carbon footprint is growing. The application of circular economy principles can help reduce waste and negative environmental impacts. Still, consumer attitudes towards circular fashion applications such as clothes resale, rentals, and repairs are not yet fully understood. Thus, the purpose of this paper is to investigate the factors influencing consumer attitudes towards circular fashion, specifically second-hand shopping, fashion rentals, and garment repairs. Employing a survey, we study the impact of factors such as quality, brand reputation, price, and sustainability on consumers' choices. Results show that consumers place a high premium on quality, often prioritizing it over the brand. Interestingly, hygiene, quality and price stand out as crucial considerations for engaging in secondhand and rental markets. On the other hand, price of the repair, quality and original value are the key drivers for repairing fashion items. Thus, we provide insights for businesses looking to embrace circular economy models.

title: Multi-Disciplinary Dataset Discovery from Citation-Verified Literature Contexts
authors: Zhiyin Tan, Changxu Duan
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries (JCDL)
abstract: Identifying suitable datasets for a research question remains challenging because existing dataset search engines rely heavily on metadata quality and keyword overlap, which often fail to capture the semantic intent of scientific investigation. We introduce a literature-driven framework that discovers datasets from citation contexts in scientific papers, enabling retrieval grounded in actual research use rather than metadata availability. Our approach combines large-scale citation-context extraction, schema-guided dataset recognition with Large Language Models, and provenance-preserving entity resolution. We evaluate the system on eight survey-derived computer science queries and find that it achieves substantially higher recall than Google Dataset Search and DataCite Commons, with normalized recall ranging from an average of 47.47% to a highest value of 81.82%. Beyond recovering gold-standard datasets, the method also surfaces additional datasets not documented in the surveys. Expert assessments across all six top-level Fields of Science indicate that a substantial portion of the additional datasets are considered useful, and some are regarded as novel for the specific topics chosen by the experts. These findings establish citationcontext mining as an effective and generalizable paradigm for dataset discovery, particularly in settings where datasets lack sufficient or reliable metadata. To support reproducibility and future extensions, we release our code, evaluation datasets, and results.<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup><sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>https://github.com/Fireblossom/citation-context-dataset-discovery

title: Functional Data Analysis based on the MT System
authors: K. W. Vong, H. Iwamoto, Y. Nagata
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: The Mahalanobis-Taguchi (MT) system encompasses a class of multivariate analysis techniques developed by Dr. Gen-ichi Taguchi, with the MT method being particularly notable for its use in anomaly detection. However, the method becomes inapplicable when the variance-covariance matrix is singular. Although various modifications have been proposed to overcome this limitation, the present study introduces a more efficient solution grounded in the principles of functional data analysis. The proposed approach is evaluated for its applicability and potential to improve detection accuracy. Results demonstrate that the proposed approach improves detection accuracy in high-dimensional settings and remains applicable when the number of variables exceeds the number of observations. Furthermore, it outperforms conventional methods when dimensionality increases or when only limited samples are available.

title: Real-Time Dynamic Job Shop Scheduling Method Based on Digital Twin and Deep Reinforcement Learning (TD3)
authors: Chen Yang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: In highly dynamic and uncertain job shop environments, real-time scheduling faces complex challenges such as sudden tasks, equipment failures, and processing time fluctuations. To address this, this paper proposes a dynamic job shop real-time scheduling method that integrates digital twins with deep reinforcement learning (TD3). Initially, a Digital Twin Synchronization Module (DTSM) is designed to achieve a realtime virtual mapping of the physical shop floor by merging sensor data and modeling time delays. Next, a Priority-Aware State Encoder (PASE) is constructed, using a graph neural network to model the dynamic relationships between workpieces and equipment, and integrating workpiece urgency, equipment failure probability, and processing delay information to form a highdimensional state representation. Finally, a Multi-Head Action Selection Network (MH-ASN) is introduced, decoupling dispatching and sequencing decisions to achieve more fine-grained and interpretable scheduling control. Experimental results show that the proposed method significantly outperforms traditional heuristic algorithms and existing reinforcement learning-based scheduling models across multiple dynamic job shop benchmark scenarios.

title: A Substation Digital Pressure Plate State Recognition Algorithm Based on Convolutional Neural Networks and AI Large Models
authors: Naichao Song
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: To address the problem of limited visual information on pressure plate surfaces, which leads to low recognition accuracy for digital pressure plate states in complex environments, a substation digital pressure plate state recognition algorithm based on convolutional neural networks and AI large models is proposed. Multimodal perception is achieved by deploying magnetic sensing components and layered data acquisition terminals. Hardware synchronization and software collaboration address spatiotemporal synchronization issues. A weighted fusion model is then used to fuse multimodal data from substation digital pressure plates. The YOLOv3 object detection model is used, and the Darknet53 backbone network is used to extract features from the fused data. Mish activation functions are used to improve performance, and a decoding formula is used to calculate bounding box coordinates to locate the substation digital pressure plate area. The located pressure plate area data and state labels are fed into the AI large model for training. Parameters are optimized using a loss function. Finally, the substation digital pressure plate state is identified based on multiple feature results and confidence thresholds. Experimental results show that this method successfully identifies pressure plates in different states. Under normal lighting conditions, this method achieved recall rates of $96.5 \%, 95.8 \%$, and 94.2% for pressure plates in active, passive, and maintenance states, respectively. In a confusion matrix comparison, 312 active states were correctly identified, exceeding the comparison method. In a recognition accuracy comparison, this method consistently maintained a stable accuracy above 95%, approximately $15-25$ percentage points higher than the comparison method on average, effectively improving the recognition accuracy of digital pressure plate states.

title: Factors Affecting Cross-Functional Collaboration in New Business Development in Japanese Enterprises
authors: C. Ozawa, T. Kawamura, H. Noguchi, T. Toma
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: To maintain sustainable competitive advantage, firms must continuously innovate by developing new business ventures. Cross-functional collaboration is a critical driver of success in this process. This study contributes to the advancement of corporate entrepreneurship literature by identifying key factors that facilitate cross-functional collaboration during the concept development stage. A web-based survey collected 411 valid responses from employees involved in new business development in Japanese companies. Factor analysis and multiple regression analysis revealed two significant determinants of cross-functional collaboration: i) individual curiosity and proactive engagement in new business development, and ii) managerial understanding and support for such initiatives. These findings suggest that enhancing individual motivation and securing management commitment are essential to promote effective collaboration across job functions. By addressing these elements, organisations can accelerate the creation of new business opportunities and strengthen their innovation capabilities.

title: Weighted Subspace Graph Learning for High-Dimensional Data_supp1-3656436.pdf
authors: Zhiwen Yu
abstract: Graph-based clustering has been extensively explored and applied due to its exceptional performance. However, most existing methods operate directly in the original high-dimensional space, where complex nonlinear structures and redundant noisy features often obscure the intrinsic data distribution. Consequently, constructing a reliable similarity graph in such a space is inherently challenging, as uncertainty and noise can significantly degrade clustering performance. To address this issue, this paper proposes a novel graph-based clustering method, Weighted Subspace Graph Learning (WSGL). Specifically, WSGL leverages kernel principal component analysis (Kernel PCA) to construct multiple kernel-based subspaces, effectively capturing nonlinear structures while reducing redundancy and noise. This strategy enhances subspace features from different perspectives, providing a more comprehensive understanding of the data distribution. Next, WSGL learns pairwise relationships across these subspaces, fully exploiting their complementary information to mitigate the limitations of relying on a single original space for capturing the global data structure. Furthermore, to ensure that the learned similarity graph preserves the same number of connected components as the ground-truth clusters, we impose a low-rank constraint on the graph structure. Additionally, considering the varying quality of different subspaces, WSGL introduces a dynamic weighting mechanism that adaptively assigns weights to subspaces based on their contribution to clustering performance, allowing high-quality subspaces to play a more dominant role in the final clustering results. Extensive experiments on multiple high-dimensional datasets demonstrate that WSGL surpasses state-of-the-art methods, validating its effectiveness and superiority in complex clustering tasks.

title: AI-Powered Network Intruder Alert System using Machine Learning
authors: Amalia Augustus, Chris Junior Shane Thomas, Attlee Munyaradzi Gamundani
abstract: The evolving field of cybersecurity faces increasing challenges from sophisticated and dynamic threats. This research presents the development of an AI-powered Network Intruder Alert System using machine learning techniques to enhance detection and mitigation of network intrusions. Leveraging a comprehensive dataset of network traffic logs, various machine learning models, including K-Nearest Neighbours, Logistic Regression, and Decision Tree Classifiers, were implemented to identify suspicious activities indicative of potential security breaches. The proposed system underscores the potential of machine learning to improve network security dynamically.

title: Improved efficiency of the fuel cell vehicle energy management system: a multi-phase optimization approach
authors: Abdesattar Mazouzi, Khaldi Belgacem Said, Charrak Naas, Abdelhamid Iratni, Ahmed Hafaifa, Moussa Boukhnifer
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: The work introduces an optimization strategy for a fuzzy-logic-driven energy management system (EMS) for a fuel-cell-powered hybrid vehicle (FCHEV), aiming to improve fuel efficiency by fine-tuning fuzzy-logic parameters across different phases using a genetic algorithm (GA). The method is confirmed using simulations in the MATLAB/SIMULINK environment. The optimization process was carried out in four phases: first, adjusting the types of membership functions (MFs); second, tuning the fuzzy variable ranges; third, focusing on optimizing MF parameters; and finally, tuning the rule weights. The results of the proposed method demonstrated an improvement in the fitness function, indicating that the fuzzy logic EMS is particularly sensitive to parameter variations, which directly impact system performance. The performance of the optimized EMS was evaluated using various metrics and compared to the original EMS. The findings demonstrate a 42.36% increase in fuel economy and a 5.41% decrease in the inefficient operation of the fuel cell system.

title: A Methodology for Scenario-Based Narrowing of Technical Solution Spaces Under Uncertainty with a Focus on Ecological Sustainability
authors: M. Mertens, A. Keuper, G. Schuh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Taking ecological sustainability into account when developing new products is not only demanded by society but has also recently been legally anchored by the Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive. To comply with the newly formulated laws and regulations, it is essential to take them into account during product development. Decisions made in the early stages of product development have the greatest influence on sustainability impacts of a product. At the same time, while trying to realize the product idea, knowledge about the effects on ecological sustainability of the decisions for or against technical solution alternatives is minimal. Wrong decisions cannot be changed at all or only at great cost. This paper presents a method to perform an initial narrowing of possible solution alternatives for a new product under high uncertainty. The aim is to focus on and develop only those solutions that are most promising based on individually selected sustainability goals. To this end, this article develops a method that combines scenario techniques and robust decision-making approaches to narrow down the solution space in a timely manner with minimal effort.

title: PrivFGL: Differentially Private Federated Graph Learning via Personalized Data Transformation
authors: Songyan Zhang, Hanyu Lu, Hongfa Ding
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: While differential privacy (DP) has been widely adopted to strengthen privacy guarantees in federated graph learning (FGL), its application often incurs a significant accuracy-privacy trade-off. To address this limitation, we propose PrivFGL, a framework that enhances the utility performance of differentially private FGL by mitigating noise-induced heterogeneity. Through empirical analysis, we demonstrate that the accuracy degradation in existing DP-FGL frameworks stems from amplified client heterogeneity caused by randomized perturbations during training. PrivFGL mitigates this issue via Personalized Data Transformation (PDT), which adaptively aligns the feature distributions of perturbed graph data across clien. In PrivFGL, each client utilizes a local PDT module during training to process its perturbed data. Extensive experiments on two widely-used datasets, in comparison with one heterogeneity solution method, verify the effectiveness of our method in addressing the heterogeneity problem.

title: OptiFLIDS: Optimized Federated Learning for Energy-Efficient Intrusion Detection in IoT
authors: Saida Elouardi, Mohammed Jouhari, Anas Motii
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: In critical IoT environments, such as smart homes and industrial systems, effective Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) are essential for ensuring security. However, developing robust IDS solutions remains a significant challenge. Traditional machine learning-based IDS models typically require large datasets, but data sharing is often limited due to privacy and security concerns. Federated Learning (FL) presents a promising alternative by enabling collaborative model training without sharing raw data. Despite its advantages, FL still faces key challenges, such as data heterogeneity (non-IID data) and high energy and computation costs, particularly for resource-constrained IoT devices. To address these issues, this paper proposes OptiFLIDS, a novel approach that applies pruning techniques during local training to reduce model complexity and energy consumption. It also incorporates a customized aggregation method to better handle pruned models that differ due to non-IID data distributions. Experiments conducted on three recent IoT IDS datasets, TON_IoT, X-IIoTID, and IDS-IoT2024, demonstrate that OptiFLIDS maintains strong detection performance while improving energy efficiency, making it well-suited for deployment in real-world IoT environments.

title: Research on Fast Impedance Matching Networks for RF Plasma Based on Back-to-Back SiC MOSFETs
authors: Shuo Zhang, Haiping Ren
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Radio Frequency (RF) plasma technology is established as the cornerstone of semiconductor manufacturing processes. However, matching networks with exceptionally high response speeds and precision are necessitated owing to the dynamic variations of the plasma load impedance. With the continuous downscaling of semiconductor process nodes, the matching speed requirements have escalated significantly; consequently, traditional mechanical Vacuum Variable Capacitors (VVCs), characterized by response times in the range of seconds, are rendered inadequate for tracking rapid impedance changes. These limitations are found to seriously compromise the stability and yield of advanced manufacturing processes. In this paper, an Electronic Variable Capacitor (EVC) based on back-to-back SiC MOSFETs is proposed to substitute traditional mechanical matching components. Bidirectional control of the 400 kHz RF signal is achieved by this topology through the alternating operation of body diodes and conducting channels. It is confirmed via ADS simulations that the proposed circuit responds to PWM signals within microseconds, thereby effectively eliminating the latency associated with mechanical matchers. Matching time and system costs are significantly reduced while reliability is improved; these enhancements are identified as critical for ensuring consistency in nanoscale semiconductor manufacturing.

title: Screening Crossref for integrity issues: Massive and longitudinal mining of publication metadata
authors: Jules Di Scala, Guillaume Cabanac, Ophélie Fraisier-Vannier, Ronan Tournier
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries (JCDL)
abstract: Scientific articles are usually associated with a Digital Object Identifier (DOI). Most publishers request DOIs from Crossref, the largest registration agency that has minted 173 million DOIs to date. The Crossref database stores the metadata of each scholarly work, including its title, authors, as well as references found in the bibliography. Since 2018, Crossref releases monthly dumps of its database amounting to 64 TB in JSON format. Recent integrity issues warrant a complete audit with longitudinal analysis of the Crossref archives. However, auditing is challenging due to the evolving nature of these massive metadata. We introduce an approach to store the complete archives that tracks the history of modifications efficiently. The longitudinal screening of the metadata is illustrated with two indicators designed to detect potential misconducts. We discovered and report two such anomalies involving suspect authors/publishers seemingly gaming citation metrics as well as a previously documented case of fraud involving a journal and its authors. The code is released for reproducibility and to encourage other researchers and Crossref to perform further analyses.

title: Prompt Once, Manage All: A Unified LLM Framework for Multi-Task Optical Link Management
authors: Khouloud Abdelli
abstract: We present a unified large language model (LLM) framework for multi-task optical link management, in which a single fine-tuned LLM jointly performs five optical link management tasks: quality-of-transmission (QoT) estimation, QoT forecasting, anomaly detection, anomaly classification, and launch-power optimization. Using structured natural-language prompts, the model ingests multimodal telemetry—including physical-layer measurements, state-of-polarization traces, historical QoT statistics, and configuration parameters—collected from a single looped-back connectivity service on a long-haul C+L-band experimental link. The LLM achieves a QoT prediction RMSE of ≈0.016 dB, near-perfect anomaly detection, and up to 96% anomaly-classification accuracy when guided by prompt-embedded semantic rules, while providing launch-power optimization with ≈0.2 dBm RMSE. By unifying multiple tasks within a single inference pipeline, the framework eliminates the need for task-specific ML models and reduces operational overhead. Although the evaluation focuses on single-channel, single-service link operation, the results highlight the potential of structured prompting and lightweight fine-tuning to support future extensions toward multi-channel and network-wide management.

title: Waveguide-assisted Single-mode Fiber Bragg Gratings in a Highly Multimode Coreless Fiber via Femtosecond Laser Inscription for Extreme Temperature Quasi-Distributed Thermal Sensing
authors: Farhan Mumtaz, Koustav Dey, Bohong Zhang, Jeffrey D. Smith, Ronald J. O'Malley, Jie Huang
abstract: This research reports a potential quasi-distributed thermal mapping optical sensing system for extreme temperatures, leveraging femtosecond (fs) laser inscribed single-mode fiber Bragg gratings (FBGs) and a waveguide within coreless, highly multimode optical fiber, resulting in a single-mode structure. Unlike doped single-mode fibers, coreless fibers composed of silica rods prevent issues associated with dopant migration and ensure data accuracy. The strategic placement of point-by-point FBGs in a cascaded formation on the fs-laser inscribed waveguide facilitates localized multipoint sensing. The long-term stability of the proposed waveguide-assisted FBG system was assessed over 24 hours at elevated temperatures (1000°C), showing no hysteresis during heating and cooling cycles. This approach promotes the use of single-mode waveguide-assisted cascaded FBG systems in extreme temperature environments. The point-by-point FBG writing technique via fs-laser enables rapid inscription compared to the conventional line-by-line method, providing fine control over the grating configuration and ensuring fast bulk production. The proposed device offers comprehensive temperature monitoring suitable for challenging multipoint sensing applications, such as industrial processes operating in extreme conditions.
