title: Two-Stage Electricity Market Optimization Considering Wind Power Uncertainty and Coordinated Flexibility Resources
authors: Shanke Mou, Hao Chen, Nan Yang, Yingbei Yao, Zhendong Wan, Jingxuan Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: With the growing integration of wind energy into modern power systems, its inherent uncertainty and intermittency present significant challenges to electricity market operations. This paper proposes a two-stage electricity market optimization model that coordinates multiple flexibility resources, including energy storage systems (ESS), demand response (DR), and fast-ramping thermal units, to address these challenges. The model introduces a day-ahead and real-time coordinated decision framework. In the day-ahead stage, unit commitment, ESS baseline operation, and DR baseline load are optimized. In the real-time stage, actual wind power deviations are addressed through dynamic adjustments of flexibility resources. A distributionally robust optimization (DRO) approach is employed, using fuzzy sets to model wind power forecast errors, balancing robustness and economic efficiency. The model features finegrained constraints on ESS operation, DR response characteristics, and unit ramping rates, and includes a coordinated clearing mechanism to leverage resource complementarity. Simulation results on a modified IEEE 30-bus system demonstrate the model’s effectiveness: total system cost is reduced by up to 18.6%, wind curtailment by 41.3%, and price volatility by 36.5%. The proposed model offers a robust and efficient decision-support tool for electricity markets with high renewable penetration.

title:
MLSBOX: Automated Sandbox for Fine-Grained Isolation of Multiple Third-Party Libraries
                    <sup>*</sup>
authors: Yuqi Qiu, Juan Wang, Chenjun Ma, Yunfeng Kang, Jie Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: In the development process, utilizing the existing functions and interfaces of third-party libraries can significantly reduce development time and resources. However, the introduction of third-party libraries also brings security risks. These libraries may contain defects or vulnerabilities and can even conceal malicious code. Introducing vulnerable third-party libraries can compromise the security of the entire software system. Although existing solutions can provide sandbox environments for libraries, they require extensive modifications to the source code to implement isolation. Furthermore, current sandboxes cannot support the simultaneous isolation of multiple libraries, including memory and privilege isolation. To address these issues, we propose MLSBOX, the first automated sandboxing framework designed to provide fine-grained isolation for multiple untrusted third-party libraries. This sandbox leverages Attribute Program Dependence Graph (APDG) analysis to identify data dependencies from different libraries. It automatically modifies the program at the compiler level to partition the program into multiple independent isolation domains, enforcing memory and privilege isolation for each domain to enhance overall program security. We have successfully implemented a prototype of MLSBOX on LLVM and conducted rigorous functional and performance evaluations on third-party libraries such as OpenSSL and Zlib. MLSBOX provides the most fine-grained memory and permission isolation currently available. In terms of runtime efficiency, MLSBOX incurs an average overhead of 2.50%. For isolating multi-threaded programs, such as a program with 8 threads, MLSBOX incurs a minimal runtime overhead of just 0.80%, significantly lower than that of the current state-of-the-art solution, Cali (365.70%).

title: Consider the mixed energy storage scheduling optimization strategy of compressed air and battery energy storage and its analysis
authors: Hao Chen, Shanke Mou, Nan Yang, Feike Li, Xuanwen Zhu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: With the acceleration of the energy transition, the proportion of renewable energy in the power system is constantly increasing. The coordinated operation of sources, grids, loads and storage is becoming increasingly crucial for ensuring the stability of the power system and improving energy utilization efficiency. This paper focuses on the optimization scheduling analysis of single battery storage and the mixed storage scheme combining compressed air and battery storage in the power system. The system is modeled and solved through mixed integer linear programming. A detailed analysis of the electricity cost data of the two storage schemes within $\mathbf{2 4}$ hours reveals their cost fluctuation patterns and differences. The study finds that the mixed storage has an advantage in average cost control, thanks to its technical complementarity and better scheduling strategies, which can better cope with complex and variable system operation conditions, reduce energy costs, and achieve better peak shaving and valley filling effects. This research provides important references for the scientific selection and efficient scheduling of energy storage schemes in the power system, and helps the energy system develop towards a green, economic and reliable direction.

title: Experimental Evaluation of the Effect of Layer Interfaces on the Performance of Magnetoelectric Wireless Power Transfer Receivers
authors: Orpita Saha, Binh D. Truong, Shad Roundy
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Micro and Miniature Power Systems, Self-Powered Sensors and Energy Autonomous Devices (PowerMEMS)
abstract: Magnetoelectric composites are promising as wireless power transfer receivers, but typically require a large DC bias magnetic field. Magnetization-graded structures can overcome this requirement. In this work, we experimentally investigate the effect of the number of magnetostrictive layer interfaces on power output, independent of the total amount of magnetostrictive material. We fabricated devices of Metglas, nickel, and PZT. We varied the number of Metglas/nickel interfaces while keeping the total amount of material the same. The results indicate that the total amount of magnetostrictive material strongly affects the power output, but the number of Metglas/nickel interfaces does not.

title: Apply Patent Network Analysis to Gene and Cell Therapy Technology Development
authors: K. K. Hu, K. L. Chen, Y. W. Liu, M. A. Chu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Gene and Cell Therapy (GCT) technology is booming in the modern medical field, and the number of patents is increasing year by year. However, in addition to patent analysis, mastering this type of forward-looking biotechnology with diverse feasibility requires precise clarification of important technologies and clinically useful technologies. This practical phenomenon presents the translation and connection across different value processes, and therefore the so-called "breakpoints" often appear. Various technology developers have to cooperate clinical sites in the value chain in order to have a chance of success. Therefore, this study uses patent network analysis calculations based on basic patent information in order to identify main technology paths for each GCT technologies. While various biotechnology-based therapies are flourishing, we use actual data verification to compare the development trends, important nodes and clinical data to demonstrate indications and industrializations of GCT technologies. At the end of the study, the analysis methods and GCT technology trend were discussed and suggested.

title: Investigation of Bio-inspired Hybrid Approaches to improve Localization in Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: Abdelkader Lichti, Seddik Rabhi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: determining the locations of data-sending nodes is crucial in various wireless sensor applications where data is collected and sent to base station for analysis and study. However, the value and importance of this data require knowing its source, or the sensor nodes that sent it. The localization of nodes in a wireless sensor network has attracted many researchers in the field to achieve better and more accurate positioning with minimal error. In this paper, we will present a review comparison between the different current research trends for localization in wireless sensor networks (WSNs) by reviewing a range of studies, techniques used, and artificial intelligence methods in optimization algorithms and dynamic swarm intelligence and behavior, which combines exploration and exploitation with the aim of achieving high localization accuracy. We will also discuss the strengths and weaknesses of each approach and the extent to which each outperforms its counterparts in terms of convergence speed, optimization accuracy, scalability, and avoidance of computational complexity. This work will serve as a guide for the research community in identifying the most suitable methods to find solutions for the expected challenges in wireless sensor networks. We will also conclude this paper with the new directions for future research in this field.

title: Ontology Synthesis Using Semi-Automatic Semantic AI Using Deep Learning and Reinforcement Learning
authors: Gerard Deepak, Anubrat Bora, M S Roopa, K R Venugopal
abstract: The need for automatic ontology modeling has become particularly significant in the era of Web 3.0, where ontologies serve as the structural metadata backbone. Despite their importance, certain domains such as environmental studies, though common—have been neglected and lack formal ontologies. To address this, the proposed model leverages auxiliary knowledge from Web 3.0, beginning with seed term pool generation from datasets and their classification using a Bi-LSTM model. Following this, the AdaBoost classifier is employed for dataset classification, while Pearson’s correlation coefficient aids in feature extraction through federation between two classifiers, enabling sedated learning. The integration of Google’s Knowledge Graph Search API further enhances the model by incorporating additional information, thereby strengthening its knowledge infrastructure. To ensure semantic accuracy, Morista’s Overlap Index is applied for semantics-oriented relevance computations, supporting reasoning through semantic similarity measures. Additionally, the Imperialist Competitive Algorithm is adopted as a metaheuristic optimization strategy. The use of YAGO along with Google’s Knowledge Graph API enriches the model with dense auxiliary knowledge, ultimately leading to high precision, and reliable estimation of F-measure with the lowest False Discovery Rate (FDR). In summary, the proposed framework named Ontology Synthesis using Semi-Automatic Semantic AI (OSSS) represents a state-of-the-art model for automatic ontology generation, specifically tailored for the domain of environmental journalism.

title: Artificial Intelligence in In Vitro Diagnostics (IVD): A Comprehensive Review of the New Frontier
authors: Hieu Le Ngoc
abstract: The healthcare industry is undergoing a dual transformation driven by digital innovation and sustainability. This paper provides a comprehensive review of the pivotal role of Artificial Intelligence in In Vitro Diagnostics (AI-in-IVD) as the primary enabler of this shift. Through a systematic review of academic literature, market reports, and regulatory documents, we analyze the technological maturity, disruptive potential, and market trajectory of AI across key medical domains. The results indicate that while all areas of medical AI are growing, the IVD sector demonstrates superior potential, with market forecasts projecting a Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR) of over 14.8% to 20.37% through 2034, driven by its alignment with both digital and sustainable transformations. Our synthesis identifies four key AI-driven frontiers in IVD: liquid biopsies, digital pathology, multi-omics integration, and point-of-care testing. We demonstrate how these innovations uniquely align with the dual transformation framework by advancing P4 (Predictive, Preventive, Personalized, Participatory) medicine while simultaneously promoting healthcare sustainability through resource optimization and decarbonization. The review concludes that the AI-in-IVD sector represents the most strategic frontier for innovation and investment, offering a roadmap for building resilient and equitable healthcare systems, with specific implications discussed for emerging economies with rapidly growing AI ecosystems, such as Vietnam.

title: FaultSpy: On the Insecurity of SPDM Protocols under Fault Injection
authors: Peiyao Sun, Qifan Wang, David Oswald, Mark Dermot Ryan, Vladimiro Sassone, Ahmad Atamli
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: The Security Protocol and Data Model (SPDM) establishes device-level trust in hardware platforms through authentication, attestation, and secure session establishment. While prior research has focused on formal analyses and deployment considerations, the impact of implementation-level vulnerabilities, particularly under active physical adversaries, remains largely underexplored. This work presents FaultSpy, the first systematic framework for evaluating SPDM against Fault Injection Attacks (FIAs) and their combination with other prominent attack vectors, such as Man-In-The-Middle (MITM) attacks. Leveraging the fault injection simulation tool, FaultFinder, with our custom SPDM-specific hooks, we uncover nine concrete vulnerabilities spanning both threat models. These include bypassing mutual authentication, suppressing signature generation and verification, downgrading negotiated capabilities, skipping mandatory protocol steps, manipulating key update behavior, transmitting messages intended to be encrypted in plaintext, and extracting session keys. We further validate the feasibility of these attacks through practical voltage glitching experiments on an RP2350 microcontroller. Our findings demonstrate that FIAs-whether in isolation or combined with other attacks-significantly expand the SPDM attack surface, highlighting the need for robust implementation-level countermeasures.

title: EvTexture++: Event-Driven Texture Enhancement for Video Super-Resolution
authors: Dachun Kai, Jiayao Lu, Yueyi Zhang, Xiaoyan Sun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Event-based vision has drawn increasing attention owing to its distinctive properties, including ultra-high temporal resolution and extreme dynamic range. Recent works have introduced it to video super-resolution (VSR) to enhance flow estimation and temporal alignment. In contrast, this paper shifts the focus of event signals from motion refinement to texture enhancement in VSR. We propose EvTexture++, the first event-driven framework dedicated to texture enhancement in VSR. It leverages high-frequency spatiotemporal details from events to improve texture recovery. EvTexture++ incorporates a customized texture enhancement branch, along with an iterative texture enhancement module that progressively exploits high-temporal-resolution event information for texture restoration. This enables gradual refinement of texture regions across iterations, yielding more accurate and detailed high-resolution outputs. Besides intra-frame texture recovery, large motions could degrade inter-frame temporal consistency, particularly in texture regions, leading to texture flickering. To mitigate this, we further exploit the continuous-time motion cues of events to enhance temporal consistency, introducing a temporal texture alignment module that estimates event-guided texture-aware flow for precise inter-frame texture alignment. Moreover, EvTexture++ is designed as a plug-and-play tool to flexibly boost the performance of existing VSR models. Experiments on five datasets demonstrate that EvTexture++ achieves state-of-the-art performance. When integrated into recent VSR models, it yields significant improvements, with gains of up to 1.55 dB in PSNR on the texture-rich Vid4 dataset.

title: AuthVR: Securing Authentication Against Shoulder Surfing and Keystroke Inference Attacks using Virtual Reality
authors: Md Yeasin Ali, Touhid Islam Udoy, Md. Ishmam Tasin, Masum Alam Nahid, Fairuz Rahaman Chowdhury, Farida Chowdhury, Md Sadek Ferdous
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Passwords serve as the primary authentication mechanism for knowledge-based systems, facilitating user access across a diverse spectrum of applications. Although password-based authentication is commonly employed in high-security environments such as security checkpoints and central control and command systems, it remains susceptible to fraudulent activities, e.g. shoulder-surfing and inference attacks (via direct observation, eavesdropping, or recording) particularly in public or monitored spaces equipped with CCTV cameras. In this paper, we present AuthVR, a Virtual Reality (VR) enabled authentication mechanism creating an additional layer of security in such high-security environments, significantly enhancing existing systems' security. Using Design Science Research Methodology, we assess potential threats and establish the system requirements. We present the architecture, its detailed protocol flow, validate its security through a formal analysis using ProVerif and provide a thorough analysis of the proposal's probable resistance against a number of attack vectors. Additionally, a user study is conducted to evaluate the usability and practical aspects of the system showing a positive impression towards the system.

title: A Game-Based Learning Framework to Enhance Student Engagement and Knowledge Gain in Operations Research Education
authors: Zhonghao Zhao, Carman K.M. Lee, Haonan Wang, Zhefan Hou
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Teaching operations research (OR) in higher education presents several challenges due to its inherently abstract and mathematical nature. Many students struggle to grasp the underlying theoretical concepts and understand the involved algorithms. To mitigate this issue, this paper presents a gamebased learning (GBL) framework designed to enhance student engagement and knowledge gain in OR education. The proposed GBL framework integrates three interactive game modes: teaching mode, where students learn through guided tutorials; exploration mode, which allows students to design and solve their own problems; and competition mode, enabling student groups to create and challenge each other with customized problems. Through these modes, the GBL framework aims to foster active participation, critical thinking, and collaborative learning. To evaluate the effectiveness of the developed OR game, a pilot study was conducted with a group of students. The results indicate that students exhibited greater motivation and a better grasp of optimization concepts compared to traditional teaching methods.

title: Verilog-A Modeling and Experimental Validation of Random Telegraph Signal Noise in Single-Photon Avalanche Diodes
authors: Yinglong Zhu, Jianhui Bu, M. Jamal Deen, Wei Jiang
abstract: This article presents a physics-based Verilog-A model for simulating random telegraph signal (RTS) noise in single-photon avalanche diodes (SPADs), particularly near breakdown voltage. The model captures both transient waveforms and statistical features of RTS noise, overcoming limitations of conventional circuit-level approaches. Implemented in Cadence Spectre, the model is validated against experimental data, showing excellent agreement in RTS amplitude and hold-time distributions. We analyze how RTS noise characteristics vary with bias voltage and temperature. Results indicate that the on-state probability increases with bias voltage, but decreases with temperature, reflecting the trap-assisted nature of RTS behavior. The model also reveals underlying probabilistic switching mechanisms and accurately captures frequency-domain characteristics of RTS noise, which are critical for evaluating its impact on SPAD performance. This work enables predictive, noise-aware SPAD and circuit co-design by offering a compact, simulator-compatible model and providing a valuable tool for advancing high-performance photon-counting systems.

title: Provenance graph-based advanced persistent threats detection via self-supervised contrastive learning
authors: XuTao Xiang, Yanqing Yang, Yurong Qian, Kai Zhao, Linlin Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Advanced persistent threats (APTs) have become a major network threat due to their persistence, complexity, and multi-stage nature. Existing APT detection methods based on provenance graphs have been proven to be effective. However, most studies based on provenance graphs are limited to single event detection, and rely on rule design and prior knowledge, making it difficult to effectively extract contextual information hidden in the graph. To address these issues, this paper innovatively proposes an APT detection model based on self-supervised contrastive learning, APT-SSC. First, the model uses an improved GraphSage(Graph Sample and Aggregate) encoder combined with a multi-head attention mechanism to learn the embedding representation of nodes; then, through context-based (local-global) contrastive learning, the robustness and context-awareness of node embeddings are effectively enhanced; finally, the optimized node embeddings are used as the input of the classification detection model to achieve node-level anomaly detection and tactics detection. Experiments are carried out on two public datasets, CICAPT-IIoT2024 (containing a variety of complex tactics) dataset and DAPRA TC-E3 dataset. The experimental results show that APT-SSC improves F1-Scores by 5% and 7% in anomaly detection and tactic detection experiments, respectively. APT-SSC has been proven to be significantly superior to existing methods in APT detection and can also effectively identify APT tactics.

title: A New End-to-End Encrypted Image Retrieval Scheme in Cloud Environment
authors: Yanfeng Chen, Jing Liang, Hongliang He, Peiya Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Encryption algorithms are usually applied to images in cloud environment to protect privacy, which will make image retrieval difficult. Existing encrypted image retrieval schemes mainly follow the two-step strategy, which firstly extract features from encrypted images and then use these features to conduct retrieval. However, the feature extraction procedure brings additional computational expense, and the extracted feature will result in privacy leakage. In this paper, we propose a new encrypted image retrieval scheme in end-to-end manner. End-to-end means we combine the feature extraction process and the retrieval process, which can reduce computational complexity. Specifically, images are encrypted by DC coefficients encryption, AC coefficients permutation and block permutation. After encryption, the encrypted images can be directly input into our retrieval model, which is based on Vision Transformer (Vit), without any process to conduct retrieval. What’s more, we propose a new type of data augmentation method named random block selection transformation (RST), which is compatible with the Vit backbone and can improve the model performance. Experiment result shows that our scheme can achieve superior retrieval accuracy than other state-to-the-art encrypted image retrieval schemes, while relatively high security can be retained.

title: A Novel Connector-and-Gripper Design for Precision Robotic Peg-in-Hole Operations in Automated Wire Harness Applications
authors: S. Lamprecht, A. Hartmann, D. Makwana, P. Bründl, J. Franke
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: The increasing complexity of modern automotive wire harnesses, combined with the demand for cost-efficient automation, necessitates the development of reliable robotic connector-insertion solutions. Conventional connector designs exhibit that small gripping surfaces lead to positioning inaccuracies and insertion failures, as slippage at forces below 20 N has been observed, which is insufficient to reliably activate their locking mechanisms. To address these limitations, this paper introduces a novel connector–gripper design, proposed as the first potential open standard, in combination with a force-controlled insertion strategy that enhances precision and robustness in automated wire harness assembly. The design was subjected to mechanical stress tests, which demonstrated that the novel design withstood axial forces up to 150 N without mechanical failure, thus significantly surpassing the performance of conventional connectors. Furthermore, an automated insertion trial using a blind search algorithm demonstrated 100% reliability within ±3 mm translational and ±4° angular tolerances. The findings of this study indicate that the proposed approach offers a scalable and standardized solution for the automated handling and mating of connectors.

title: LDP: Latent Diffusion-based Adversarial Purification towards Transformer-based Visual Encoders
authors: Mengfan Li, Xinxin Fan, Quanliang Jing, Shaoye Luo, Yunfeng Lu, Jingping Bi
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Adversarial purification has emerged as a critical defense mechanism against various adversarial attacks on deep neural networks, however, such category of diffusion-based purification in the pixel space confronts two challenges while applying into today’s large vision transformers: i) the distributional divergence between adversarial and clean examples in high-dimensional image manifold; and ii) the prohibitive computational cost while processing high-resolution images. To address the predicament, we in this paper focus on the transformer-based visual encoders commonly employed in large Vision-Language Models (VLMs), and propose a novel Latent Diffusion-based Purification (LDP) mechanism through leveraging the latent space to pave the gap between adversarial distribution and clean distribution. Resorting to projecting adversarial input into a low-dimensional latent representation, our proposed LDP not only suppresses the off-manifold perturbations to achieve accelerated denoising, but also preserves critical semantic features by aligning input with the priori high-quality visual representations. Multi-facet experiments over both proactive robustness enhancement and post-attack purification demonstrate that our LDP has a superior performance in terms of effectiveness and efficiency.

title: How Devices Shape Mental Effort in Digital Document Reading: An Eye-Tracking Study
authors: Kumushini Thennakoon, Yasasi Abeysinghe, Pasindu Thenahandi, Lawrence Obiuwevwi, Vikas Ashok, Sampath Jayarathna
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries (JCDL)
abstract: The shift from print to digital reading environments has introduced new challenges for understanding how device interfaces influence mental effort during reading. While prior work has often relied on controlled user studies, this study investigates device-dependent mental effort using the Reading in the Wild dataset collected with Project Aria. We analyze eye tracking data during reading tasks on four commonly used digital devices: laptops, tablets, mobile phones, and wall-mounted screens, using fixation duration as the key eye-tracking measure to understand mental effort. Our results indicate that device type significantly shapes mental effort: wall-mounted screens elicited the longest fixations, laptops showed intermediate values, and handheld devices exhibited the lowest and most comparable levels of effort. These findings highlight how ergonomic differences such as viewing distance and display size influence visual processing and mental efforts during digital reading. Our work advances the understanding of device-specific mental effort and offers insights for designing digital reading environments that emphasize usability.

title: SSRCorr: A Self-Supervised Robust Flow Representation Learning Framework for Flow Correlation Attacks on Tor
authors: Chen Chen, Mengyan Liu, Zhong Guan, Yaochen Ren, Yanbo Wu, Yangyang Guan, Zhen Li, Gaopeng Gou, Junzheng Shi
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Tor is one of the most widely adopted anonymity networks, yet its anonymity can be undermined by adversaries through flow correlation attacks. Current mainstream technologies focus on exploiting the sequence characteristics of packet lengths and timestamps to execute attacks. However, the padding mechanism of the Tor network and time delays caused by multi-hop relays obscure these single-modal features. Additionally, the diversity of network services and the randomness of user behavior result in sparse packet distributions, which impact model training and inference. In this paper, we propose SSRCorr, a novel self-supervised learning framework for flow correlation attacks, incorporating the Flow Feature Aggregation (FFA) module and Global-Local Fusion (GLoF) Encoder to address these challenges. Firstly, we construct a Byte-based Traffic Aggregation Matrix (BTAM) by integrating time and length sequences and applying two data augmentation methods tailored for Tor flow correlation, thereby reducing the impact of Tor network noise on attack effectiveness. Secondly, we employ GLoF to extract features from the output by FFA and fuse the global context information of the traffic, thus mitigating the impact of low-information traffic on model performance. Experiments show that SSRCorr achieves a TPR of 96%, surpassing other methods, and maintains robust performance under temporal drift and obfuscation, supporting future research on countering anonymity system defenses.

title: Can We Distinguish? A Deep Learning Approach to AI-Generated Content Detection
authors: Yikai Liang, Mengqing Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: The proliferation of advanced generative AI models creates an urgent need for robust AI-generated text detection systems, particularly in high-stakes domains such as news media and academic publishing. Existing approaches face significant limitations: traditional linguistic methods fail against sophisticated Transformer-generated text, large-scale deep learning models require prohibitive computational resources, and most systems neglect the complementary nature of semantic understanding and linguistic pattern recognition. To address these challenges, we propose EffLingSem (Efficient Linguistic-Semantic fusion), a parameter-efficient hierarchical framework that systematically integrates semantic embeddings with explicit linguistic features for AI-generated text detection. Our approach employs a dual-stream architecture combining Qwen3-Embedding-0.6B for semantic feature extraction with a 15-dimensional linguistic feature set encompassing lexical diversity, syntactic complexity, and stylistic patterns. The features are fused through a learnable hierarchical attention mechanism that adaptively balances modality contributions based on domain characteristics. Extensive experiments on DAGPap22 and our newly constructed NewsSciGen dataset demonstrate that EffLingSem consistently outperforms strong baselines, achieving F1 scores of 88.34% on scientific texts and 87.23% on news articles, representing substantial improvements of 2.89% and 3.56% respectively over the strongest baseline. Comprehensive ablation studies validate the necessity of each component, with removing linguistic or semantic branches causing 3.67-4.78% and 6.89-7.56% F1 drops respectively, confirming their complementary roles. The hierarchical attention mechanism provides an additional 2.56-3.11% improvement over a baseline using simple feature concatenation. The framework accomplishes these gains using only 1.2M trainable parameters—over 1,400× fewer than competing methods—while providing interpretable feature contributions that offer actionable insights into AI-generated content characteristics. Our work bridges the gap between detection performance and computational efficiency, offering a practical solution for real-world deployment in resource-constrained environments.

title: Application of Dynamic Focus Programming to Sequential Investment Decisions in Urban Real Estate
authors: Bilal Dia, Peijun Guo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Real estate development decisions often involve high uncertainty, requiring developers to navigate volatile markets and evolving risks. Traditional decision-making models, such as Expected Utility Theory and Net Present Value, assume rational behavior and stable preferences but often fail to reflect real-world complexity. This study applies Guo’s Dynamic Focus Programming (DFP), a decision-support framework designed to address sequential decision problems in uncertain environments. The DFP framework focuses on minimizing downside risk through the pessimistic evaluation function (ψ-), which enables developers to make decisions that prioritize risk mitigation and the avoidance of significant losses. This approach contrasts with traditional models by identifying robust decision paths that remain viable even under adverse market conditions. Using a vertically phased, mixed-use real estate project in Beirut, Lebanon, the study demonstrates how DFP can guide developers in selecting strategies that reduce financial exposure, particularly in the face of a market downturn. The results highlight that, under the pessimistic evaluation system, low-end residential units in high demand consistently outperform luxury configurations, showcasing the resilience of affordable housing in uncertain conditions. The findings suggest that DFP provides a more effective tool for real estate developers, offering a clear, risk-conscious decision-making framework that helps navigate market volatility and minimize financial losses.

title: A Watermarking Framework for Secure Distribution of Meteorological Images
authors: Yue Wu, Fenghua Li, Feng Lu, Zifu Li, Yixuan Zhang, Yanru He
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Meteorological images typically contain sensitive and critical information, demanding effective security mechanisms to prevent unauthorized copying and distribution. Digital watermarking, a widely adopted protection technique, imperceptibly embeds user identity information into images to enable subsequent traceability. However, existing methods fail to consider the impact of watermark embedding on critical meteorological features, as well as the limitations of high computational overhead and low embedding efficiency in multi-user distribution scenarios. To address these issues, we propose a watermarking framework tailored for the secure distribution of meteorological images. Specifically, we first design a content-adaptive region selection scheme that avoids embedding watermarks in critical meteorological regions such as cloud features. We then develop a two-stage decoupled embedding strategy to enhance distribution efficiency, where the preprocessing stage performs region selection and frequency transformation, while the distribution stage reuses these cached results to rapidly generate user-specific watermarked copies. Extensive experimental results demonstrate that our framework effectively avoids critical regions in meteorological images and maintains high visual quality (average PSNR of 38.10 dB and SSIM of 0.9815) while achieving better extraction accuracy under various attacks. Furthermore, the two-stage decoupled embedding strategy reduces server response latency by over 60.8% in concurrent distribution scenarios.

title: Efficient Single Image Dehazing Based on Gradient Line Prior
authors: Lei He, Zunhui Yi, Pei Li, Siyi Wang, Chaoyang Chen, Ming Lu
abstract: Images captured in hazy environments experience gradient reduction due to the scattering of light by atmospheric particles, yet few existing dehazing methods utilize the gradients of hazy images to restore the visibility of the scene. In this paper, we propose an efficient dehazing method based on gradient line prior. By associating image gradients in atmospheric scattering model, we obtain a stable and simple prior, termed the gradient line prior (GLP), that is, in the corresponding hazy images normalized by atmospheric light, there is a linear relationship between the reciprocal of the gradients distributed across different regions of the hazy image plane and the corresponding ratio of pixel intensity to the gradient. For accurate estimation of the transmission map, its refinement is realized through the analysis of the distribution characteristics of pixels in three channels. Experimental results demonstrate that, compared to different dehazing methods, our approach exhibits good detail enhancement and color restoration performance. The code is available at: https://github.com/heyuanlei/Gradient-Line-Prior.

title: Model Predictive Control Based on Discrete Space Vector Modulation for Single-Stage Dual-DC-Port Inverter
authors: Lijie Liu, Yuxing Wan, Yu Huang, Dehong Zhou
abstract: Model predictive control (MPC) provides an at tractive solution for the single-stage dual-dc-port inverter (SDI) due to its capabilities to deal with multiobjective control under unbalanced dc-port voltages. However, the existing MPC for SDI uses only one of the basic voltage vectors throughout the control period, which increases the dc-port power ripple and reduces current quality. To address this issue, the candidate voltage vectors are extended from 27 to 117 based on unevenly distributed basic voltage vectors, which reduces the dc-port power ripple and improves power quality due to extra control degree of freedom being provided. To reduce the computational burden caused by extended voltage vectors under unbalanced port voltages, the space vector diagram is divided into asymmetrical quadrangle sub-sectors, where the candidate voltage vectors required to be iterated are reduced by 82%. On this basis, an MPC based on discrete space vector modulation (SVM) is proposed for the SDI, enabling simultaneous grid current tracking and flexible power regulation. The comprehensive comparison experimental tests are conducted to verify the effectiveness and advantages of the proposed MPC based on discrete SVM.

title: Adaptive fuzzy active fault-tolerant control for fractional-order nonlinear systems with output constraint
authors: Ziyun Zhao, Zhiyao Ma, Jie Lan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: This paper addresses the active fault-tolerant control problem for fractional-order nonlinear systems with output constraint. Firstly, fuzzy logic systems are employed to approximate the unknown nonlinear functions. Secondly, a state observer is designed for the unmeasurable states, while a fault detection mechanism is established to detect the occurrence of faults, and a fault compensation term is constructed to counteract their effects. Then, an asymmetric tangent-type Barrier Lyapunov Function (ATBLF) is introduced to handle the output constraints. Concurrently, an auxiliary function is incorporated into the virtual control signals to compensate for the coupling terms arising from the BLF. Finally, by combining backstepping techniques with a fuzzy adaptive update mechanism, a novel control strategy is designed. The Dynamic Surface Control (DSC) technique is utilized to avoid the “explosion of complexity” problem. Based on the fractional-order Lyapunov stability theory, it is proven that all signals in the closed-loop system are semiglobally uniformly ultimately bounded, and the output of the system can be constrained within the given bounds.

title: In-orbit Spectral Calibration Prospects for the COSI Space Telescope
authors: Aravind B. Valluvan, Steven E. Boggs, Savitri Gallego, Jarred Roberts, Gabriel Brewster, Sophia Haight, Carolyn Kierans, Sean Pike, Albert Y. Shih, John A. Tomsick, Andreas Zoglauer
abstract: The Compton Spectrometer and Imager is an upcoming NASA space telescope in the MeV range. COSI’s primary science goals include precisely mapping positron annihilation and nuclear line emissions in the Milky Way galaxy through Compton imaging. This relies on our ability to maintain COSI’s spectral performance over its mission lifetime. Changes in the detectors’ gain characteristics over time will result in inaccurate measurement of astrophysical gamma-ray energies. Moreover, observations from past MeV telescopes and proton-beam experiments have shown that radiation damage in space causes photopeak shifts and spectral line broadening. These necessitate a plan for regular, in-orbit spectral calibration. In this study, we demonstrate a method to monitor and recalibrate the COSI detectors using background line emissions produced by the space radiation environment. We employ Monte Carlo simulations of particle background and show that strong background lines arise from nuclear excitation of COSI’s detectors (germanium) and cryostat (aluminum) materials. These span COSI’s entire bandwidth for single-site interactions and can be used to monitor the effects of radiation damage and gain shifts every 12 hours at the full instrument level and every 16 days at the individual detector level. Methods developed by Pike et al. [1, 2] to correct the effects of hole trapping and gain characteristics can then be applied to recover the original spectral performance. These results inform COSI’s telemetry requirements for calibration and housekeeping data, and rule out the need for an onboard radioactive calibration source, which would have increased the complexity of the spacecraft.

title: A Decision-Making Tool for a Criteria-Based Selection of Process Maturity Models in Industry
authors: J. Kiefer, J. Zöld, C. Zöllner, C. Moser
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Due to rising internal and external requirements, there is a growing need for process assessments in industry. Today, a flood of process maturity models is available for this purpose and most companies find it extremely difficult to keep track of everything and to make a suitable selection.This paper introduces a new method to support companies make the right selection of maturity models for process assessments. To do this selection process in a most efficient and effective way a new developed decision-making tool based on defined criteria is presented. Apart from methodical, information-technical and organizational issues, this paper illustrates the application of this decision-making tool using a real existing process from food industry. By means of this practical example, the procedure, potentials and current limits of this new decision-making tool is discussed and critically evaluated.

title: Quantum Policy Learning for Energy Storage Arbitrage
authors: Bin Huang, Tianqiao Zhao, Meng Yue, Xiaodong Zheng, Jianhui Wang
abstract: The emergence of quantum computing offers a transformative approach to energy arbitrage (EA) in energy storage systems (ESSs) by enabling efficient, data-driven solutions with enhanced learning capabilities. This study introduces a Quantum Policy Learning (QPL) algorithm designed to optimize online EA processes in energy markets. Unlike traditional reinforcement learning, which relies on neural networks for policy approximation, QPL utilizes a Variational Quantum Circuit (VQC) as the parameterized policy model. The VQC is tailored for the Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum era, featuring a low-depth and low-width design with alternating variational entanglement and embedding sub-layers. The loss function and gradient calculations are derived using action re-parameterization. Case studies indicate that QPL achieves faster convergence and competitive optimization performance compared to classical algorithms while using only 1.6% of the number of trainable parameters. To highlight the expressivity advantage, VQCs are further compared with classical neural networks through a harmonic-regression benchmark and the downstream ESS arbitrage task. Experiments on IBM quantum hardware confirm QPL’s resilience to gate errors and qubit decoherence, and additional analyses demonstrate its superior training stability and efficiency.

title: A Stacking Ensemble Framework Incorporating Weather Information for Enhanced Traffic Flow Prediction at Highway Entrances
authors: Xiang Yin, Qingsong Xu, Zhipeng Zhang, Lei Dai, Feng Xu, Hao Hu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Traffic flow prediction at highway entrances is essential for intelligent transportation systems, as it significantly enhances operational management and service quality on highways. Although previous studies have contributed valuable insights into traffic flow prediction, their reliability, particularly at highway entrances, still needs further improvement. Furthermore, few studies have considered weather conditions that affect traffic dynamics, thus limiting the reliability of their predictions. In this study, one year of traffic data is collected from a highway entrance to promote the practical implementation of intelligent transportation systems. This traffic data is integrated with corresponding weather information to enhance predictive reliability across various weather scenarios. Subsequently, a stacking-based ensemble model is developed to further improve the generalization performance of base predictive models. Extensive experimental results indicate that predictive models incorporating weather data yield more reliable traffic flow predictions. Furthermore, the developed ensemble model demonstrates superior predictive reliability compared to base predictive models.

title: Cable Charging Status Detection: A Deep Learning Method Based on Magnetic Field Intensity Time-Series Signals
authors: Xiong Cai, Shuzhi Dai, Wulin Miao, Qijiang Pei, Haiqi Li, Liqun Su
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: This paper presents a novel approach for detecting the charging status of cables using magnetic field intensity timeseries signals processed through a deep learning model. The core methodology involves collecting multi-channel magnetic field data from sensors positioned near the cable, where charged cables exhibit alternating magnetic fields due to current flow, while uncharged ones show primarily background noise. We employ a hybrid architecture combining 1D Convolutional Neural Networks (1D-CNN) for local feature extraction and Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) networks for capturing temporal dependencies, augmented with an attention mechanism to focus on critical signal segments. Simulated datasets, generated based on electromagnetic principles, consist of 10000 samples with sequence lengths of 1024 across three channels, ensuring manageable size and realistic noise inclusion. Experimental evaluations demonstrate superior performance, achieving an accuracy of 97.60%, precision of 95.41%, recall of 98.13%, F1score of 96.47%, and AUC of 98.63%. Ablation studies confirm the efficacy of each component, with the full model outperforming baselines like SVM (accuracy $\mathbf{9 2. 2 8 \%}$). Noise robustness tests show graceful degradation, maintaining over 86% accuracy at higher noise levels. The ROC curve highlights the model’s discriminative power, and the loss curve indicates efficient convergence within 20 epochs. This non-contact method offers real-time, reliable detection for power systems, enhancing safety and maintenance efficiency in scenarios like underground cables or high-voltage lines. Future extensions could integrate real-world data for broader applicability.

title: TID Effects in Si and SiC Power MOSFETs and their implications on the performances of a Buck DC/DC Converter
authors: Hadrien Couillaud, Noé Fourmont, Christophe Delbos, Giles Assaillit, David Poujols, Guillaume Hubert, Laurent Artola, Marc Gaillardin
abstract: This study investigates the effects of Total Ionizing Dose (TID) on the static response of two commercial 650 V power vertical MOSFETs, based on silicon (Si) and silicon carbide (SiC). This preliminary analysis of static degradations provides the foundation for assessing their impact on the performance of a 300 V DC/DC Buck converter. To this end, several static and dynamic bias conditions under TID were studied to reproduce the actual operating conditions of the components within the converter. These scenarios highlight an unexpected behavior: the threshold voltage (V<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">TH</sub>) shift as a function of TID is smaller for the SiC MOSFET under high gate bias than under low gate bias. An analysis of this phenomenon is proposed, relying on complementary experimental tests, cross-sectional observations and the literature. Finally, the impact of TID on the operation of the DC/DC Buck converter is assessed. The results show that TID alters the dynamic parameters of the MOSFETs and leads to instability in the converter’s output voltage (V<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">OUT</sub>). V<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">OUT</sub> degradations are caused by an increase in the switching and response times of the device, mainly related to the degradation of V<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">TH</sub> and the gate parasitic capacitances induced by TID effects.

title: Cross-Modal Collaborative Recovery: Breaking Multimodal Unlearnable Examples Protection
authors: Ruijia Li, Zijiao Zhang, Ximin Huang, Hongwei Hu, Xining Gao
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: With the rapid development of multimodal machine learning, data security has become a critical bottleneck constraining multimodal artificial intelligence advancement. Multimodal unlearnable examples, as an emerging data protection paradigm, prevent unauthorized model training by disrupting cross-modal semantic consistency through adversarial perturbations and trigger identifiers. However, existing multimodal protection mechanisms suffer from significant robustness deficiencies and security vulnerabilities. This paper conducts a systematic security evaluation of multimodal unlearnable examples and proposes a Cross-Modal Collaborative Recovery (CMCR) attack framework. CMCR integrates Joint Conditional Diffusion Purification for image denoising, Adaptive Text Purification for trigger removal, and Visual Cross-modal BART for cross-modal reconstruction. Experiments demonstrate that CMCR successfully restores image-text retrieval performance to levels approaching clean data across different model architectures, achieving an average recovery rate of 89.0%. Our results reveal that current multimodal unlearnable examples have security vulnerabilities and insufficient robustness against coordinated cross-modal attacks.
