title: Multi-objective Optimization of Core Parameters for Electric Detachable Grounding Device Based on NSGA-III
authors: Tianyu Zhang, Bo Zhang, Da Li, Zheng Liu, Dianwen Li, Guangpu Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: In the operation and maintenance of power systems, grounding wires are crucial protective devices for ensuring safety during power outages and maintenance. Traditional grounding wire installation requires maintenance personnel to manually operate an insulated lever, mechanically rotating it to secure the conductor end of the grounding wire to the equipment conductor. This method is not only labor-intensive and inefficient, but also poses significant risks when working at heights or in confined spaces. To address these issues, this paper proposes a grounding wire insulated operating lever design that enables electrically operated installation and removal without modifying existing insulated levers. A multi-objective optimization method based on the NSGA-III algorithm is employed to improve its overall performance. This design ensures connection reliability while reducing the labor intensity of maintenance personnel and saving on equipment modification and usage costs, providing an effective solution for improving the performance of substation grounding wire installation and removal tools.

title: Infrared Thermography-Based Photovoltaic Short-Circuit Fault Detection using Transfer Learning and Machine Learning Classifiers
authors: Ali Teta, Derradji Bakria, Ahmed Chennana, Belkacem Korich, Ahmed Hafaifa
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: The growing installation of photovoltaic (PV) systems highlights the necessity for dependable fault detection for maintaining operation safety, reducing energy losses, and lowering maintenance expenses. In this paper, a short-circuit fault detection method is presented using infrared thermography (IRT) images from the PVF-10 dataset. The method employs transfer learning from MobileNetV1 deep learning backbone for feature extraction, with machine-learning classifiers: Support Vector Machine (SVM), Random Forest (RF), and voting ensemble classifier for enhancing classification accuracy. Two sub-datasets were created to distinguish healthy modules from short-circuited modules, and the models were compared based on accuracy, precision, specificity, sensitivity, and F1 score. Results demonstrate that the hybrid deep learning–machine learning approach surpasses conventional classifiers with a maximum overall accuracy of 96.60%. Results confirm the superior performance of the proposed PV fault detection framework.

title: Design of a Monitoring System and Operating Parameter Optimization for a Controllable Commutated Converter
authors: Meng Sun, Fei Jiang, Jianliang Lu, Chao Leng, Chenghao Wang, Xiaolong Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: The controllable line-commutated converter (CLCC) adopts a hybrid topology combining thyristors and IGBTs. By actively diverting fault current and establishing a commutation voltage, it can fundamentally eliminate the problem of commutation failure. To enable comprehensive, intuitive, and real-time monitoring of the operating status of all components within the CLCC, and in conjunction with the requirements of an actual engineering project, this paper proposes a monitoring-system design based on a dual-network, dual-redundancy architecture, and investigates in detail the hardware and software implementation schemes of the communication management board, the digital fault-recorder cubicle, and the SCADA system. On this basis, a CLCC monitoring system is developed, and the critical firing-angle threshold for CLCC operation is optimized based on simulation results. The developed converter valve monitoring system and the optimized parameter have already been deployed in the Genan refurbishment project, fully satisfying the requirements for online condition monitoring of the converter and valve-control equipment as well as long-term operation.

title: General Diffusion Transformer for Arbitrary Medical Image Translation
authors: Jiahao Zheng, Xiaoping Wang, Yongcan Luo, Yun Wang, Yu Tang, Dapeng Wu
abstract: Medical image translation plays a crucial role in assisting clinical diagnosis by enabling cross-modal synthesis (e.g., Computed Tomography to Magnetic Resonance Imaging) and super-resolution, effectively addressing clinical challenges such as radiation exposure, prolonged scan times, and allergic reactions to contrast agents. However, existing approaches primarily focus on developing specialized models for specific tasks, limiting their adaptability across different applications. Developing a general model capable of handling arbitrary medical image translation tasks not only enhances cross-domain generalization but also aligns with the broader trend of artificial intelligence evolving from specialized to general-purpose solutions. Achieving such one-for-all model, however, presents three key challenges: (1) varying task complexity, (2) modality discrepancies, and (3) structural variations across anatomical regions within the same modality. To tackle the first challenge, we utilize an advanced diffusion-based training paradigm to endow the denoising model with extensive pattern coverage capabilities, thereby handling tasks of varying difficulty levels. Subsequently, a General Diffusion Transformer incorporating a Fuzzy Mixture-of-Experts (FMoE) module and an Entropy-guided Attention Soft Prompt (EASP) module is proposed. The FMoE module, equipped with nonlinear modeling capabilities, is designed to address modality discrepancies, while the EASP module is employed to enhance the model's perception of structural variations in images. Extensive qualitative and quantitative experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed model in the arbitrary medical image translation task.

title: Line current analysis as a technique to detect bearing faults in permanent magnet synchronous motors
authors: Mohammed Ferradj, Noureddine Benouzza
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: With the increasing use of permanent magnet synchronous motors (PMSMs) across robotics, automotive, aerospace, medical, and renewable energy sectors, fault diagnosis has become essential to avoid costly unplanned downtimes. Although PMSMs are known for their high efficiency and robustness, they remain vulnerable to both electrical and mechanical faults, with bearing failures being among the most common. Spectral analysis offers an effective approach for detecting these faults by identifying characteristic frequencies that depend on bearing geometry and rotational speed. Because PMSMs operate at a constant rotational frequency, identifying these fault-related signatures is simpler than in induction motors. This study applies spectral analysis to the diagnosis of bearing faults, with particular attention given to outer ring faults. The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method provides accurate and effective detection of bearing failures in PMSMs.

title: Intelligent Control of Semi-Active Friction Dampers for Seismic Control of Buildings: A Deep Reinforcement Learning Approach
authors: Mert Can Kurucu, Ercan Atam, Masoum M. Gharagoz, Mohamed Noureldin, Ibrahim Eksin, Müjde Güzelkaya
publish: IEEE Transactions on Emerging Topics in Computational Intelligence
abstract: Semi-active friction dampers (SAFDs), which can adaptively adjust the friction force, function as flexible semi-active control systems for the seismic protection of structures, including buildings exposed to strong ground accelerations. The effectiveness of SAFDs in dissipating seismic energy is highly dependent on the control strategy used to adjust the friction force of dampers. Due to the highly nonlinear and complex nature of buildings equipped with SAFDs, achieving optimal control is challenging and requires advanced adaptive control techniques. In this paper, we propose an intelligent control method based on deep reinforcement learning for the seismic control of buildings with SAFDs. We examine the potential of SAFDs to improve the seismic response of multi-story buildings and present a numerical case study to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed intelligent method. In this case study, the performance of the proposed intelligent control method is compared with two optimization methods and a reference controller: (i) friction dampers (FDs) using a constant friction force that is calibrated using a heuristic approach, (ii) FDs whose friction force is optimized through a Genetic Algorithm (GA), and (iii) SAFDs employing a rule-based approach for adaptive friction force adjustment. It was observed that the proposed DRL approach outperformed the alternatives, for example, achieving up to 63.7 % improvement over the rule-based controller. The core contribution of this study is the formulation of an MDP and reward-design framework that enables DRL to perform real-time friction control in SAFDs integrated into multi-story buildings.

title: Resilient supplier selection with supplier fortification in the presence of multiple manufacturers using mixed recovery profile
authors: Praveen Kumar, Lohithaksha M. Maiyar, D. G. Mogale
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: In the recent past, epidemic disruptions have been known to have affected several industry sectors, with the automotive industry being no exception in facing the adverse impact. The automotive industry remained at the receiving end of the COVID-19 turmoil while being a witness and victim to widespread manufacturing component shortages during the aftermath, resulting in larger lead times, plant shutdowns, and undelivered inventory orders. This study addresses the supplier selection and order allocation problem for post-disruption scenarios by developing a mixed integer-linear programming model for epidemic disruptions. The proposed model of this study minimizes the loss of resilience in the presence of supplier fortification for multiple manufacturers, considering a mixed nature of recovery profiles to deal with disruptions. Further, the results are validated on small and medium dataset instances inspired by the Indian automotive supply chain scenario.

title: Enhancing Federated Learning under Partial Participation via Proportional Variance Reduction
authors: Xiang Wang, Lei Tian, Chen Yang, Feilong Lin, Minglu Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Federated learning is a distributed learning framework with privacy protection; however, data heterogeneity poses significant challenges for federated training. Due to heterogeneous data, client models tend to overfit their local datasets during local training, leading to client drift. Variance reduction-based methods are currently the most popular solutions for addressing client drift; however, their performance deteriorates significantly under low client participation rates. We analyze the limitations of existing variance reduction techniques and attribute them to control variate drift and imbalanced global correction. To address these issues and further constrain client drift, we propose an easy-realization yet effective solution: Federated Proportional Variance Reduction (FedPVR). Specifically, we scale both client gradients and client control variates by a factor that is matched to the client participation rate. This can be viewed as replacing the outdated gradient information associated with each client in the global control variate with their most recent gradients, thereby deriving a closer overall update direction. This approach helps mitigate both client drift and the additional variance introduced by the staleness of control variates. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach under partial client participation. Specifically, under limited client involvement, our method achieves an average accuracy improvement of 2–3% compared to baseline methods and further accelerates the convergence rate.

title: Traceable and Revocable Key-Policy Attribute-Based Encryption scheme from Lattices
authors: Yanqi Ma, Yuan Liu, Yongbin Zhou, Yiwen Gao
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: ABE as a powerful tool for secure fine-grained access control, has been widely adopted in data-sharing scenarios such as cloud computing. However, most existing traceable and revocable ABE schemes are constructed using bilinear pairings and are thus vulnerable to quantum attacks. Although lattice-based ABE schemes provide post-quantum security, they often lack critical features such as traitor tracing and timely revocation, which may lead to key abuse problem. Some revocable lattice-based schemes are unable to identify the source of leaked keys, while existing traceable and revocable lattice-based schemes also fail to resist collusion attacks between revoked and un-revoked users. In addition, the exposure of attribute values in access policies poses serious privacy risks. To solve the above issues, this paper proposes a traceable and revocable KP-ABE scheme based on RLWE assumption. The proposed scheme embeds the user identity into the key through a white-box tracing mechanism, enabling the system to detect and revoke malicious users in case of key leakage. It also protects attribute privacy by hiding attribute values in the access policy and resists collusion attacks by embedding random parameters in the key. Theoretical analysis and experimental evaluation results show that the proposed scheme ensures security and privacy while maintaining high computational efficiency and is suitable for post-quantum secure data sharing environments.

title: Non-Restrictive Hardware-Based Trust in Embedded High-Level Operating Systems
authors: Simon Unger, Sven Gebauer, Stefan Katzenbeisser
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Hardware-based trust mechanisms are essential for securing embedded systems against physical and software attacks. Although restrictive approaches like verified boot enforce strict code integrity, they often limit device reusability and owner control. In contrast, non-restrictive methods, such as measured boot and remote attestation, assess system state without enforcing execution policies.We present a secure embedded high-level Operating System (OS) architecture that exclusively uses non-restrictive Trusted Platform Module (TPM)-based mechanisms to achieve secure storage, rollback protection, reliable updates, and remote attestation. Our design targets unattended devices like smart gateways or industrial Internet of Things (IoT) nodes, enabling maintainable and owner-controlled deployments.A key contribution is a scalable rollback protection mechanism based on TPM extend-indexes and Enhanced Authorization (EA), which avoids per-device policies and vendor lock-in. Combined with secure storage and remote attestation, our system protects application data against offline access, rollback, and replay attacks.We evaluated our prototype on real hardware, showing moderate performance overheads and strong security properties. We further identify limitations and outline future directions to improve policy management and reduce boot latency in TPM-based platforms.

title: Reverse generation of substation logic model method from optical cable data
authors: Xiaoyan Hu, Xiaojing Zhang, Xiaomin Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Digital substations are a key development focus in China’s power grid during the 15th Five-Year Plan period. As the core component of secondary digital design for substations, logical models face significant challenges in forward engineering due to their complexity and lengthy development cycles. To address this, this paper proposes a method for reverseengineering substation logical models using optical cable data. By scanning electrical secondary drawings (including terminal block diagrams, schematic diagrams, and file information), OCR technology extracts critical data such as cable numbers, circuit numbers, core function descriptions, and terminal cabinet connections. These data are then integrated with logical model specifications to automatically generate interface (interface), connection point (point), core, and cable elements in the Substation Physical Description (SPD). The developed front-end and back-end separated logical model generation system achieved $95.1 \%, 95.6 \%, 91.8 \%$, and $89.6 \%$ conversion rates for interface, point, core, and cable respectively, with an overall success rate exceeding 90%. Verification through actual engineering drawings demonstrates that this method effectively reduces design workload and supports substation digitalization. However, it still exhibits certain misjudgments in distinguishing between DI/DO and AI/AO types, requiring manual verification for refinement.

title: Hybrid Adaptive Wavelet Thresholding for Partial Discharge Signal Denoising
authors: Zisheng Zou
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Partial discharge is an important indicator of earlystage development and aging of high-voltage insulation defects, but field signals are often submerged in random and broadband noise, leading to pulse distortion and difficulty in feature identification. To enhance the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) while preserving the transient characteristics of PD pulses, this paper proposes a hybrid adaptive wavelet-threshold denoising method. Based on discrete wavelet multi-scale decomposition, the method first estimates noise at each scale using median absolute deviation combined with standard-deviation constraints, and introduces the proportion of detail-signal energy to construct an energy-guided adaptive threshold. A hybrid threshold function is then employed, which approximately preserves large-amplitude coefficients in a hard-threshold manner while applying piecewise shrinkage to small-amplitude coefficients, thereby achieving differentiated suppression of the PD pulse main lobe and highfrequency noise components. Finally, the denoised PD signal is obtained through wavelet reconstruction. Simulation results demonstrate that, compared with traditional hard and soft thresholding methods, the proposed approach provides superior overall performance in terms of SNR improvement, amplitude preservation, and waveform smoothness.

title: Joint Application of Wind Load LiDAR and X-ray Nondestructive Testing in Overhead Line Conductor Maintenance
authors: Hongjie Zhang, Chuanfei Jiang, Huibin Liu, Xin Shang, Peng Chen, Jianming Hao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: This study proposes an integrated maintenance strategy combining wind load LiDAR and X-ray nondestructive testing (NDT) to address challenges in managing wind-induced fatigue damage of overhead conductors. These challenges include the concealed nature of the damage, difficulties in locating high-risk points, low efficiency of live-line detection, and the safety risks associated with tower-climbing maintenance. The proposed methodology involves a three-step process: first, acquiring high-resolution 3D wind field data along the transmission corridor using coherent Doppler wind LiDAR to calculate conductor fatigue life; second, screening high-risk damage points via a weighted least squares inversion algorithm; and finally, conducting precise re-examination of these points with portable X-ray NDT equipment in a live-line environment. The efficacy and operational workflow of this combined approach are elaborated through an engineering case study of the 220 kV Lingtai Line in Eastern Inner Mongolia, demonstrating a standardized technical pathway for effective maintenance.

title: RASKEE: A TEE-Assisted Secure Range Spatial Keyword Query in a Multi-user Setting
authors: Zhen Lv, Yaorong Tan, Hongwei Huo, Yanguo Peng, Youliang Tian
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: The burgeoning interest in cloud computing and trusted execution environments (TEEs) has prompted a focus on enhancing the performance of diverse queries on encrypted geo-textual data within public cloud infrastructures. Secure spatial keyword range queries are pivotal for applications that rely on cloud assistance. However, current approaches to SRSK queries are inadequate for multi-user settings or demand excessive client-side resources to process queries.In this paper, we present RASKEE, a novel SRSK query model integrating conventional cryptographic techniques with TEEs. RASKEE is designed to support a multi-user environment, offloading most computational and storage demands from clients to the public cloud. Theoretically, RASKEE minimizes client-side storage and computational overheads and provably achieves IND-CKA2 security. Empirical evaluations on three real-world datasets demonstrate that RASKEE outperforms state-of-the-art solutions by up to 0.5 − 4 orders of magnitude in terms of response time for clients.

title: Unleashing the Potential of Differential Evolution through Individual-Level Strategy Diversity_supp1-3659799.pdf
authors: Ran Cheng
abstract: Since Differential Evolution (DE) is sensitive to strategy choice, most existing variants pursue performance through adaptive mechanisms or intricate designs. While these approaches focus on adjusting strategies over time, the structural benefits that static strategy diversity may bring remain largely unexplored. To bridge this gap, we study the impact of individual-level strategy diversity on DE’s search dynamics and performance, and introduce iStratDE (DE with individual-level strategies), a minimalist variant that assigns mutation and crossover strategies independently to each individual at initialization and keeps them fixed throughout the evolutionary process. By injecting diversity at the individual level without adaptation or feedback, iStratDE cultivates persistent behavioral heterogeneity that is especially effective with large populations. Moreover, its communication-free construction possesses intrinsic concurrency, thereby enabling efficient parallel execution and straightforward scaling for GPU computing. We further provide a convergence analysis of iStratDE under standard reachability assumptions, which establishes the almost-sure convergence of the best-so-far fitness. Extensive experiments on the CEC2022 benchmark suite and robotic control tasks demonstrate that iStratDE matches or surpasses established adaptive DE variants. These results highlight individual-level strategy assignment as a straightforward yet effective mechanism for enhancing DE’s performance. The source code of MetaDE is publicly accessible at: https://github.com/EMI-Group/istratde.

title: An Intelligent Multi-Fault Diagnosis Method for Lithium-ion Battery Based on Deep Learning Framework
authors: Shilong Wang, Lingfeng Wang, Peiben Wang, Haiming Xie, Fachao Jiang
abstract: The nonlinearity of lithium-ion batteries complicates the fault mechanisms, particularly making the diagnosis of minor faults challenging due to the lack of obvious fault characteristics. While early-stage faults may not immediately compromise battery performance, their unchecked propagation could eventually lead to critical operational failures. This study proposes an intelligent multi-fault diagnosis method for lithium-ion batteries, enabling effective identification of minor internal short circuit, overcharge, and overdischarge faults. By leveraging voltage and current data segments alongside the incremental capacity curve as inputs for the temporal convolutional network model, achieving initial fault recognition. For diagnosed defective cells, the voltage signal is processed utilizing variational mode decomposition optimized by the bat algorithm to enhance fault features, facilitating intelligent diagnosis of multiple faults. Through validation across diverse operational scenarios and varying battery health states, the proposed method achieves an impressive fault diagnosis accuracy rate of 99.62%, enabling effective identification and diagnosis of multiple faults, which is paramount in preventing the escalation of faults and averting potential safety hazards.

title: Knowledge-Embedded Deep Reinforcement Learning-Based Emergency Frequency Control Method for Power Systems
authors: Xiaoyu Zhou, Jiannan Li, Qiangsheng Xu, Junru Lin, Chao Ge
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: In the context of the rapid development of the new power system construction, the challenges to frequency security within the power system have become increasingly acute. When a system fault leads to frequency instability, it is of great significance to implement emergency control measures to restore frequency stability. Therefore, an artificial - intelligence - based frequency emergency control approach for power systems, which is founded on knowledge - embedded deep reinforcement learning, is proposed. Initially, the frequency emergency control problem is transformed into a Markov model. A simulation system is employed as the reinforcement learning environment, and a deep reinforcement learning agent is constructed based on the Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (DDPG) algorithm. Moreover, theoretical knowledge is utilized to guide the optimization of the action space, and both high - frequency generator tripping and low - frequency load shedding scenarios are comprehensively taken into account. Finally, control effectiveness tests are carried out on the IEEE 39 system. Experimental results indicate that the deep reinforcement learning agent can offer effective frequency emergency control strategies to safeguard system frequency security. Additionally, the knowledge - embedding method enhances the stability of model training, thereby significantly improving the agent’s strategy learning efficiency and decision - making quality.

title: Game-Theoretic Day-Ahead Pricing Strategy for Renewable Energy Clusters Considering Multi-Timescale Forecast Deviations
authors: Ying Li, Weilin Zhong, Jialong Han, Junru Chen, Quan Li, Muyang Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Under the background of rigid mid- to long-term planning and the uncertainty of day-ahead generation, renewable energy clusters (RECs) tend to suffer from enlarged forecast deviations and constrained profits in multi-timescale electricity markets. To address this challenge, this paper develops a dayahead game-theoretic pricing strategy for renewable energy clusters considering mid- to long-term and day-ahead forecast deviations. First, a mid- to long-term monthly centralized bidding model is established to capture the scheduling commitments. Then, to handle day-ahead forecast deviations, a cluster agent is introduced, and a day-ahead deviation model is constructed. Based on this, a collaborative control mechanism between the agent and the clusters is proposed to realize the day-ahead gamebased pricing strategy considering forecast deviations. Finally, the simulation results show that, while satisfying the current deviation assessment constraints, the proposed strategy can reduce the total deviation settlement cost and improve the overall profits of the participating clusters, thereby validating the economic efficiency and practical feasibility of the proposed model.

title: High-Impedance Fault Detection in Distribution Networks Based on Multi-Dimensional Feature Fusion of Zero-Sequence Current
authors: Zebo Jiang, Dong Liang, Xingchi Cui, Rui Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Addressing the challenges of weak signal characteristics and class imbalance caused by the scarcity of field fault samples in High Impedance Faults (HIFs) within medium voltage distribution networks, this paper proposes a fault identification method based on multi-dimensional feature fusion and Support Vector Machine (SVM). Firstly, by analyzing the time-frequency characteristics of zero-sequence current, Discrete Wavelet Transform (DWT) is utilized to obtain multi-level detail signals. Seven statistical features, including amplitude, mean, and energy entropy, are calculated to construct a multi-dimensional feature fusion matrix, thereby enhancing the representation capability of faint fault features. Secondly, the SVM algorithm is introduced to resolve the poor reliability of traditional datadriven algorithms under imbalanced sample conditions, leveraging its characteristic where the classification hyperplane is determined by support vectors. Finally, the effectiveness and robustness of the high-impedance fault identification model were validated in a $\mathbf{1 0 ~ k V}$ distribution network simulation model.

title: Cooperative Control Framework for Dual-Arm Robot Enhanced by Vision Language Model and Reinforcement Learning
authors: Guangrong Chen, Qizhe Yang, Jiehao Li, C. L. Philip Chen, Chenguang Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: This paper presents a cooperative control framework for dual-arm robots that integrates vision-language models (VLMs) with online reinforcement learning (RL) to enhance autonomy and adaptability in complex manipulation tasks. The proposed framework adopts a hierarchical architecture: at the top level, the VLM interprets natural language instructions and visual image to generate task plans; at the middle level, an online RL module refines manipulation policies and ensures adaptive decision-making under environmental uncertainty; and at the bottom level, compliant control based on trajectory planning and impedance regulation enables safe and robust execution. In the feedback, YOLOv5 is used to detect the object, GraspNet is used to obtain the optimal grasp pose, and CLIP (Contrastive Language-Image Pre-Training) is used to judge whether task is completed. Simulations and real-world experiments validate the effectiveness of the proposed method. The dual-arm robot successfully performed various cooperative tasks such as grasping, bottle-cap unscrewing, water pouring, and box carrying, achieving an increase in the task success rate from 43% to 100% with online adaptive learning and training. These results demonstrate that the proposed framework effectively bridges high-level reasoning with low-level control, providing a scalable solution for future applications in service robotics, industrial automation, and human-robot collaboration.

title: Building Provably Secure Pseudo-Strong PUFs via Weak PUFs and Pseudorandom Functions for Cryptographic Protocols
authors: Chenghao Chen, Xiaolin Zhang, Kailun Qin, Tengfei Wang, Yipeng Shi, Tianyi Huang, Chi Zhang, Dawu Gu
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Physical Unclonable Functions (PUFs) are widely used in hardware security due to their inherent unclonability and randomness. However, the temporal instability of strong PUFs remains a barrier to their adoption in latest PUF-based cryptographic protocols, as it incurs significant overhead from error correction. In this paper, we propose PS-PUF, a novel architecture that leverages weak PUFs and cryptographically secure pseudorandom functions (PRFs) to construct a pseudo-strong PUF with stable and reproducible outputs. Our design includes a PRF for secure mapping, and a buffer to optimize performance in batch-access scenarios. We formally analyze the threat surface of PS-PUF and provide cryptographic security proofs showing resistance against modeling attacks. Implemented on the Genesys 2 FPGA, PS-PUF achieves at least 2<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">.</inf>72× in batch scenarios with negligible hardware overhead and a maximum performance reduction of 10<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">.</inf>7%, enabled by reusing the PRF module in integrated environments.

title: Age of Correct Sensing in Sensing-and-Then-Transmit ISAC Networks
authors: Yiyang Ge, Ke Xiong, Wenjuan Yu, Qiang Ni, Wei Chen, Pingyi Fan, Khaled Ben Letaief
abstract: This paper investigates the sensing-and-then-transmit (SAT) integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) network, where a multi-functional base station (MBS) senses the target's state and then transmits the sensed results to the receiving node (RN). To measure the timeliness of the SAT process, we define a novel metric called Age of Correct Sensing (AoCS). To enhance the system's AoCS, we propose a pipelined SAT ISAC (P-SAT ISAC) paradigm, where the MBS simultaneously transmits individual beams to perform sensing and communication. We derive the mathematical expression of the probability of detection (PD), the probability of false alarm (PFA), and the probability of communication outage (PCO), based on which, the AoCS of the P-SAT ISAC is quantified. Furthermore, we formulate an expected AoCS minimization problem by optimizing the power splitting factor for sensing and communication to explore the achievable lower bound of AoCS. Then, the minimum expected AoCS is found by developing a linear search based algorithm. Simulation results validate the theoretical analysis on PD, PFA, and PCO, and also show the impact of system parameters on them, as well as the minimum achievable expected AoCS. Compared with the existing alternating SAT ISAC (A-SAT ISAC), our proposed P-SAT ISAC achieves an average reduction in expected AoCS of 38.97%, demonstrating the efficiency of the proposed pipelined sensing and communication paradigm in improving system timeliness.

title: IQ-EVNet: An Eigenvalue-Aware End-to-End Framework for SNR Estimation
authors: Tao Chen, Xiaolong Zhou, Shilian Zheng
abstract: Accurate estimation of the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) plays a vital role in improving the performance and reliability of modern communication systems. The eigenvalue vector (EV) derived from the covariance matrix (CM) of in phase and quadrature (IQ) signals provides a compact yet discriminative statistical representation of signal characteristics. Motivated by this property, we first propose an EV-based SNR estimation method that leverages eigenvalue representations as compact network inputs, effectively reducing feature dimensionality and improving estimation robustness and accuracy under low-SNR conditions. Building upon this foundation, we further propose an IQ-EVNet framework, which directly learns eigenvalue representations from IQ sequences and performs SNR estimation based on the learned features. This design enables end-to-end SNR estimation without explicit CM construction or eigenvalue computation. This design preserves the discriminative capacity of EV features while significantly improving inference efficiency. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed IQ EVNet achieves notably higher estimation accuracy than IQ based methods and approaches the performance of the EV-based method, offering an excellent trade-off between accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Better by Comparison: Retrieval-Augmented Contrastive Reasoning for Automatic Prompt Optimization
authors: Juhyeon Lee, Wonduk Seo, Hyunjin An, Seunghyun Lee, Yi Bu
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries (JCDL)
abstract: Automatic prompt optimization has recently emerged as a strategy for improving the quality of prompts used in Large Language Models (LLMs), with the goal of generating more accurate and useful responses. However, most prior work focuses on direct prompt refinement or model finetuning, overlooking the potential of leveraging LLMs’ inherent reasoning capability to learn from contrasting examples. In this paper, we present Contrastive Reasoning Prompt Optimization (CRPO), a novel framework that formulates prompt optimization as a retrieval-augmented reasoning process. Our approach retrieves top- k reference prompt-response pairs from the HelpSteer2 dataset, an open-source collection where each response is annotated for helpfulness, correctness, coherence, complexity, and verbosity, and constructs two complementary optimization paradigms: (1) tiered contrastive reasoning, where the LLM compares high-, medium-, and low-quality exemplars (both prompts and responses) to refine its own generation through reflective reasoning, and (2) multi-metric contrastive reasoning, where the LLM analyzes the best exemplars along each evaluation dimension and integrates their strengths into an optimized prompt. By explicitly contrasting high- and lowquality exemplars, CRPO enables the model to deduce why certain prompts succeed while others fail, thereby achieving more robust and interpretable optimization. Experimental results on the HelpSteer2 benchmark demonstrate that CRPO significantly outperforms baselines. Our findings highlight the promise of contrastive, retrieval-augmented reasoning for advancing automatic prompt optimization.<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup><sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>Code is Available at: https://github.com/GitLeo1/CRPO

title: Research on A High-Sensitivity Near-Real-Time Accurate Health Monitoring Method for Satellite Flywheels in Orbit Based on the “Speed-Current” Model
authors: Chaoqun Li, Lin Li, Shiyu Xia, Zhenqiang Hong
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Flywheel is a kind of high precision angular momentum exchange actuator widely used in all kinds of satellites. As a kind of rotating component, flywheel is the key factor that restricts the life of satellite in orbit. Aiming at the typical anomaly mode of slow increase of in-orbit current of flywheel bearings, a highly sensitive near-real-time accurate monitoring method for the slow increase trend of flywheel bearing current in orbit is proposed, and a flywheel bearing health model based on “speed-current” is established by distributed linear fitting of satellite flywheel speed and bearing current in orbit, and the health model of flywheel bearings is established by distributed linear fitting of satellite flywheel speed and in-orbit telemetry, and it is continuously iteratively updated with the accumulation of telemetry data to solve the problem of highly sensitive real-time assessment of the health state of flywheel bearings and accurate prediction of trends. Simulation shows that compared with the traditional interpretation monitoring method based on telemetry threshold, the abnormal trend of the flywheel can be found within 20 minutes, and the timeliness of anomaly detection is shortened from tens of days to tens of minutes in traditional engineering applications based on the upper and lower limit threshold monitoring methods. This method has been widely used in the long-term monitoring of the flywheel health status of a series of satellites such as TJS, which is conducive to adopting fault plans in advance for non-inductive disposal and ensuring the stability of satellite attitude, which has practical engineering significance.

title: A Strategy for Isolation Zone Partitioning in Distribution Networks Considering Graph-Based Physical Information Coupling
authors: Guangru Zhang, Haodong Ren, Jie Chen, Jiawu Zhang, Dilong Fan, Binyu Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Addressing the issue of information node incapacitation caused by physical node failures in distribution networks under extreme fault scenarios, this paper proposes an island partitioning method to enhance distribution network resilience. First, a physical-information coupling graph model is constructed for the distribution network, comprehensively considering the impact of physical node failures on information node incapacitation. This ensures the effectiveness of both the information and physical layers within isolated island regions from a network structural perspective. Subsequently, an island partitioning model is established based on the operational characteristics of distributed power sources, load criticality levels, controllability of loads, radial constraints of the distribution network, maximisation of enabled information nodes, and communication connectivity. to establish an island partitioning model that enhances distribution network resilience. The Whale Migration Algorithm (WMA) is employed to derive the final island partitioning results. Finally, the proposed method’s validity and feasibility are validated using a cyberphysical coupled system generated by PG&E69.

title: Multi-Objective Optimization of Dynamic Recyclable Waste Vehicle Scheduling with Limited Number of Vehicles
authors: Liu Liu, Yuxin Wang, Chang Liu, Meimei Zheng, Wei Weng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: This paper investigates the optimization problem of vehicle scheduling in a community recyclable waste collection system considering vehicle quantity constraints. A mixed-integer programming model is constructed to minimize makespan, recyclable waste loss, and transportation cost. A nested optimization algorithm is designed to solve the model. The outer layer uses a genetic algorithm to determine the collection thresholds for each collection point. The inner layer employs a heuristic algorithm to transform the outer layer's collection thresholds into collection plans and utilizes a savings algorithm to plan the vehicle routes. Based on real data from a community in Shanghai, a case study is conducted to verify the effectiveness of the model and algorithm.

title: Exploiting Bursting Dynamics for Enhanced Energy Harvesting and Vibration Control
authors: Michele Rosso, Raffaele Ardito
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Micro and Miniature Power Systems, Self-Powered Sensors and Energy Autonomous Devices (PowerMEMS)
abstract: In this work, we investigate bursting dynamics in piezoelectric energy harvesters as a strategy to enhance performance under low-frequency (<10 Hz) excitations. A mesoscale bistable harvester with permanent magnets is modeled and numerically simulated, showing that bursting regimes enable efficient frequency up-conversion, providing an alternative to approaches based on moving proof masses. Compared to classical inter-well oscillations, bursting yields a substantial increase in harvested power, with representative steady-state values of about 3.5 mW on a 50 kΩ load. These results highlight the potential of bursting dynamics not only for energy harvesting from sources such as human motion, but also for vibration control and programmable devices.

title: SPPF: A Speech-Semantic and Privacy-Preserving Framework with Prompt-Tuning Large Language Models
authors: Ben Niu, Tiantian Kong, Yuqiao Hou, Bohao Li, Guoli Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Speech services are widely used in people’s lives, but privacy-preserving techniques for semantic privacy information of speech still suffer from limited semantic understanding and generalization due to the difficulty in collecting privacy datasets. Therefore, we propose a novel framework for semantic privacy information extracting and preserving of speech. To take use of the generalization ability of large language models (LLMs), we present a novel prompt fine-tuning method which transforms the sequence labeling task into a dynamic template-based multi-turn interaction generation task. Besides, we use self-consistency check mechanism to mitigate the hallucination problem. After completing the recognition of privacy information, we perform anonymization operations. Validated on three open-source LLMs, our approach achieves over 96% coverage in recognizing privacy information on both Chinese and English datasets under lightweight, few-shot learning settings, yielding an average Macro-F1 improvement of 32.38%. This shows that our method has better generalization and transferability to LLMs, and provides an effective privacy recognition and preserving technology framework for speech data.

title: Microgrid Load Forecasting and Optimization Scheduling: A Method Based on Deep Learning with Multi-Source Data Fusion
authors: Peng Deng
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Microgrids represent a pivotal advancement in modern energy systems, integrating renewable energy sources, energy storage, and advanced control mechanisms to enhance reliability, efficiency, and sustainability. This paper proposes a novel approach for microgrid load forecasting and optimization scheduling based on deep learning with multi- source data fusion. By leveraging convolutional neural networks (CNN) combined with long short-term memory (LSTM) models, the framework processes diverse data inputs including renewable energy production, weather conditions, and historical load patterns to achieve high-accuracy predictions. A particle swarm optimization (PSO) algorithm is employed for scheduling, minimizing operational costs while ensuring grid stability. The methodology incorporates a modified CNN-LSTM architecture with dropout regularization to prevent overfitting, trained on a simulated dataset mimicking real-world microgrid scenarios. Experimental results demonstrate superior performance over traditional baselines like ARIMA, with mean absolute error (MAE) reduced by approximately 57% and root mean square error (RMSE) by 57%. Ablation studies confirm the efficacy of key components, while sensitivity analyses highlight parameter impacts. This work contributes to energy management by providing a scalable, robust solution for microgrids, addressing uncertainties from renewables and promoting efficient resource allocation. Future extensions may include real-time adaptive learning and integration with edge computing for enhanced deployment in practical settings.

title: Multimodal Emotion Classification in Artwork: A Comparative Study Across Modalities
authors: Clayton Durepos, Abigail Pitcairn, Behrooz Mansouri
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries (JCDL)
abstract: Digital collections benefit from metadata that captures the emotional impact of artworks, yet affective annotation remains challenging due to subjectivity and stylistic variation. This study compares unimodal and multimodal models for emotion classification in fine art, leveraging ArtEmis V2 and LLaVA-generated captions. Three models are studied: (1) an image-only ViT classifier; (2) a text-only BERT model using visual descriptions; and (3) a custom multimodal model that fuses embeddings from both. Experimental results indicate that multimodal input yields statistically significant improvements in emotion classification for fine art compared to unimodal approaches. title: Machine Learning-Based Detection of AI-Generated Text via Stylistic and Statistical Feature Modeling
authors: Karla Schäfer, Martin Steinebach
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Through the advances of large-language models (LLMs) AI- generated text can be created with ease. But, these tools can also pose a threat, e.g. through the creation of disinformation. In this work, we analysed texts generated by three LLMs: GPT-3.5, LLaMA3, and Qwen from the CUDRT dataset. We extracted 220 stylistic and statistical features of human and AI-generated text using the LFTK library. First, we analysed the features using the pearson correlation. Second, we trained five machine learning models and tested the classifiers on detecting completely AI-generated, polished, rewritten texts, and summaries created by AI. We calculated an F1-score of 90%+ for the text generated entirely by AI, depending on the LLM used. We found that AI-generated texts, independent of LLM, can be identified through a high kuperman age, i.e. high word complexity, whereby human-written texts are written with higher lexical variation and richness. We provide an explanation for the classification results and a comparison with RoBERTa (fine-tuned).

title: A Relay Protection Method for New Energy Grid Integration Based on Multi-Source Information Fusion with Dynamically Adjusted Weights
authors: Guohua Wu, Xu Fang, Yirong Ma, Haohui Zhu, Jun Wang, Luohao Lin, Yiqiao Chen, Wenjing Fang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: To solve poor relay protection adaptability from grid parameter fluctuations in new energy integration, this paper proposes a dynamic weighted multi-source information fusion method. A Kalman filter dynamically forecasts operating ranges of voltage, frequency, and THD, corrected with environmental parameters. Weights adjusted by historical violations and forecast deviations enable grid status scoring. Scores trigger four strategies—accelerated response, threshold adjustment, delayed response, and status maintenance—with real-time STM32 parameter control. Tests demonstrate effective handling of renewable fluctuations, improving protection accuracy and reliability while reducing malfunctions and extending lifespan.

title: MV-EA-IDS: An Optimized Dual View, Energy-Aware IDS for Battery Drain Attacks in IoT
authors: Rahma Berchi, Lemia Louail, Sarra Cherbal, Abdul Ghafar Jaafar, Noor Hafizah Hassan, Selma Amrani
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: Battery-drain attacks pose a stealthy yet critical threat to Internet of Things (IoT) networks, enabling adversaries to exhaust device power without triggering traffic-based alerts. Existing intrusion detection systems (IDS) seldom address such energy-aware threats or report false alarm rates under realistic conditions. This paper introduces the Multi-View Energy-Aware Intrusion Detection System (MV-EA-IDS), a dual-view framework combining network-level analysis with inferred Energy Proxy Features to detect both conventional and power-drain attacks. It integrates a supervised Random Forest for traffic classification and an unsupervised Isolation Forest trained on benign energy proxies to capture anomalous drain patterns. Adaptive percentile thresholds and a meta-heuristic k-of-n fusion rule further minimize false positives. On the public CIC-IoT2023 dataset, MV-EA-IDS achieves 99.87% accuracy and only 0.01% false positives, establishing the first reproducible benchmark for energy-aware IoT intrusion detection.

title: Fuzzy Logic Control for Trajectory Tracking of a Differential Drive Mobile Robot
authors: Lalia Miloudi, Nacer Hacene, Melina Issad, Lynda Ben Si Saud
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: The accurate trajectory tracking is a fundamental challenge in mobile robotics, with critical applications from warehouse automation to autonomous vehicles. This work focuses on differential drive robots, which, despite their mechanical simplicity, present complex, nonlinear control problems. To overcome these challenges, we propose a dedicated fuzzy logic controller (FLC). A Mamdani-type FLC is designed to process tracking and orientation errors, generating appropriate control signals. The controller was developed and tested using a comprehensive robot model in MATLAB/Simulink. Its performance was validated through two distinct trajectories: a circular path and a complex eight-spiral. Results demonstrate accurate path following with minimal error and stable motor commands, confirming the controller's robustness and effectiveness for autonomous navigation. This approach offers a practical, model-free solution for reliable mobile robot guidance.

title: Encroachment or not? The Effect of Reputation and Commission on Platform’s Selling Format
authors: Qiu Nan, Shi Jia-Qi, Liu Chang-Xian, Tian Hou-Ping
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Platforms often provide not only distribution channels for manufacturers and charge commissions, but also engage in direct sales—a phenomenon known as platform encroachment. This trend raises critical questions: why do platforms encroach? In what way do they encroach? What is the impact on the performance of supply chain? To investigate these issues, this paper considers two distinct encroachment strategies: one is strategy D (dual-channel), where the platform retains agent selling while introducing reselling; the other is strategy R (reselling only), where the platform abandons agent selling channel and only implements reselling. By comparing these strategies with a no-encroachment benchmark, our analyses yield several key insights. First, when commission rate is higher, platforms prefer the dual-channel strategy (strategy D). Conversely, under low commission rate, platforms tend to abandon agent selling and only implement reselling (strategy R). The last interesting conclusion is that, in scenarios characterized by high platform reputation and low commission rate, encroachment through Strategy R does not undermine the manufacturer’s profitability; instead, it creates a win-win situation for both players.

title: DoNotSurf - Low-Latency DNS IP Tunneling
authors: Alexandru Kiraly, Darius Vasile Bufnea
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: This paper presents research from the field of cybersecurity, addressing the problem of data transmission over DNS-based covert channels in restricted network environments. The study investigates the impact of request timing on the performance of such tunnels, with a focus on identifying the relationship between throughput, latency, and polling strategies. Existing tools such as dnstt, TUNS, and iodine, were evaluated and compared through benchmarks using synthetic data. The results indicate that performance can be significantly improved by employing a dynamically adjusting mechanism that adapts the timing between requests based on real-time server-side feedback. This approach achieves better jitter and latency metrics, particularly in bidirectional and high-throughput scenarios. While the current solution uses a static adjustment strategy, the findings indicate that this mechanism is well-suited for further integration with intelligent systems capable of traffic pattern recognition and adaptive control. These insights direct the future research towards the development of adaptive and intelligent DNS tunneling systems that can optimize performance in real-world network conditions.

title: Anisotropic Diffusion with Dynamic Z-score Thresholding for Efficient Low-Contrast Defect Detection in Textured Metal Surfaces
authors: Sarah Benziane
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: Detecting low-contrast surface defects on highly textured metal components continues to be a key and challenging focus area in automated industrial quality control. Traditional techniques such as classic Anisotropic Diffusion (AD) are hin- dered by the need for time-consuming manual optimization of the gradient threshold parameter (K), which can change due to item surface texture. This paper presents a new Adaptive Anisotropic Diffusion (AAD) algorithm which utilizes a dynamic Z-score computation, in conjunction with, and measurement of the local diffusion coefficient. Z-scores effectively measures the statistical significance of local gradient magnitudes, simplifying the performance of the algorithm and decoupling the algorithm from human performance. Using a dataset of 24 unique and challenging textured metal surfaces, there was a 70% reduction in parameter optimization trials with the proposed method, leading to an overall execution time improvement of as much as 71% when using static-parameters AD. While AAD showed an increase in time per individual diffusion iteration (23% increase) in comparison to static parameters due to the statistical overhead, the reduction in time in the critical parameter optimization trials proved AAD’s performance as a robust and reliable high data processing solution for Industrial quality control applications.

title: An Efficient Feature Extraction Model Based on Asymmetric Deep Convolutional Autoencoder for Abnormal Traffic Detection
authors: Guofeng Zhang, Yang Zhang, Bingbing Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: With the widespread use of Internet in daily life, the scale of network traffic has shown an explosive growth trend. However, malicious activities such as cyberattacks have a severe impact on cybersecurity. An effective countermeasure is to detect abnormal traffic from large-scale network traffic to maintain cybersecurity, but traditional abnormal traffic detection methods are unable to effectively handle current complex and diverse network traffic. The development of artificial intelligence has provided an effective solution, but its performance is influenced by the quality of extracted features. To accurately detect abnormal traffic, this paper proposes a feature extraction method called AD-CAE for network traffic based on a symmetric deep convolutional autoencoder. Firstly, raw network traffic is preprocessed by z-score normalization to transform into the format that can be easily handled by ADCAE model. Then, the multilayer convolution of ADCAE is used to hierarchically extract the features, and the step-size compression strategy of spatial dimension is used to preserve the spatial structure information as well as enlarge the sensory field. Finally, a convolutional block attention module (CBAM) is added at the end of encoder to highlight the key features by learning channel weights through global pooling and fully connected layers. Experimental results on two widely used network traffic datasets show that the features extracted by ADCAE achieve better performance on three detection models.

title: Visual Exploration of a Historical Vietnamese Corpus of Captioned Drawings: A Case Study
authors: Kailiang Fu, Tyler Gurth, David H. Laidlaw, Cindy Anh Nguyen
abstract: This paper presents a case study focusing on the exploratory visual analysis of a unique historical dataset consisting of approximately 4000 visual sketches and associated captions from an encyclopedic book published in 1909-1910. The book, which offers insight into Vietnamese crafts and social practices, poses the challenge of extracting cultural meaning and narrative structure from thousands of drawings and multilingual captions. Our research aims to explore and evaluate the effectiveness of multiple visualization techniques in uncovering meaningful relationships within the dataset while working closely with professional historians. The main contributions of this study include refining historical research questions through task and data abstraction, combining and validating visualization techniques for historical data interpretation, and involving a focus group of historians for further evaluation. These contributions offer generalizable insights for the development of domain-specific visualization tools and support interdisciplinary engagement in historical data visualization and critical digital humanities research.

title: WTCLIP: A Wavelet-Aware CLIP Framework for Boundary-Refined Weakly Supervised Semantic Segmentation
authors: Feng Xiao, Jianhua Zhang, Peihua Han, Shengyong Chen, Houxiang Zhang
abstract: Some advanced methods have leveraged the zero-shot recognition capability of the contrastive language–image pretraining (CLIP) model and adapted it to weakly supervised semantic segmentation (WSSS), achieving promising performance. However, they primarily use CLIP as an auxiliary feature extractor, leaving the fundamental limitations of class activation mapping unresolved, particularly in preserving fine-grained object boundaries and achieving precise pixelwise localization under sparse supervision. To address these challenges, this article proposes a novel end-to-end WSSS framework WTCLIP, which aims to fully exploit the potential of CLIP for weakly supervised segmentation tasks. Different from traditional methods that use CLIP only as a static feature extractor, we innovatively introduce a learnable wavelet transform decoder to enhance the information extraction capability and significantly improve the model's perception of object boundaries. We dynamically adjust the weight distribution ratio of the CLIP feature layer, capture multiscale edge information, and make full use of the time–frequency localization characteristics of the wavelet transform to significantly improve the quality of pseudolabels and achieve more accurate semantic segmentation. Experimental results show that our method significantly improves the performance of the WSSS task on two public benchmark datasets, notably by 4.0% over the state-of-the-art methods, especially in capturing weakly annotated object boundary details.

title: Vertically Stacked Doping-Less Dual-Metal Gate Nanosheet FET with TiO2 Dielectric for High Sensitivity Autoimmune Disease Biosensing
authors: Srinivasa Rao Karumuri, Peravali Rahul, V.B. Sreenivasulu, Girija Sravani Kondavitee
abstract: In this paper, we have presented and simulated a Vertically Stacked Doping-less Nanosheet FET biosensor for autoimmune disease detection with improved sensitivity and performance. The proposed device has a dual-metal gate configuration with different work functions for the source, drain, and gate. TiO₂ is used as the high-K gate dielectric to achieve improved electrostatic control and reduced leakage currents. The vertically stacked nanosheet structure improves channel controllability while reducing short channel effects resulting in improved subthreshold swing (SS) and ON current. The proposed device performance has been evaluated in Silvaco ATLAS TCAD in terms of performance parameters I<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">on</sub>, I<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">off</sub>, I<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">on</sub>/I<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">off</sub> ratio and sensitivity. The device achieved a better I<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">on</sub> (1.92 x 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-4</sup>), I<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">off</sub> (8.07 x 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-13</sup>) and I<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">on</sub>/I<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">off</sub> (2.38 x 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">8</sup>) conforming its suitability for biosensing applications. The device effectively detects neutral biomolecules with dielectric constants ranging from K = 1 to 12 as well as charged biomolecules introduced into the sensing cavity. The device has good sensing ability varied for different cavity filling levels (25%,50%,75%,100%) shows the better detection at 100% filling level. The effect of temperature is explored and demonstrates that a rise in temperature leads to lower drain current while slightly lowering sensitivity due to increased thermal carrier activity. This confirms reliable sensor performance under different conditions. The proposed design therefore provides a potential path to next generation high sensitivity biosensor systems for early identification of illnesses and biomedical diagnostics.

title: Communicate Less, Synthesize the Rest: Latency-aware Intent-based Generative Semantic Multicasting with Diffusion Models
authors: Xinkai Liu, Mahdi Boloursaz Mashhadi, Li Qiao, Yi Ma, Rahim Tafazolli, Mehdi Bennis
abstract: Generative diffusion models (GDMs) have recently shown great success in synthesizing multimedia signals with high perceptual quality enabling highly efficient semantic communications in future wireless networks. In this paper, we develop an intent-aware generative semantic multicasting framework utilizing pre-trained diffusion models. In the proposed framework, the transmitter decomposes the source signal to multiple semantic classes based on the multi-user intent, i.e. each user is assumed to be interested in details of only a subset of the semantic classes. To better utilize the wireless resources, the transmitter sends to each user only its intended classes, and multicasts a highly compressed semantic map to all users over shared wireless resources that allows them to locally synthesize the other classes, i.e. non-intended classes, utilizing pre-trained diffusion models. The signal retrieved at each user is thereby partially reconstructed and partially synthesized utilizing the received semantic map. We design a communication/computation-aware scheme for per-class adaptation of the communication parameters, such as the transmission power and compression rate to minimize the total latency of retrieving signals at multiple receivers, tailored to the prevailing channel conditions as well as the users' reconstruction/synthesis distortion/perception requirements. The simulation results demonstrate significantly reduced per-user latency compared with non-generative and intent-unaware multicasting benchmarks while maintaining high perceptual quality of the signals retrieved at the users. For a typical setup of multicasting street scene images to 10 users, our proposed framework achieves a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$15.4\%$</tex-math></inline-formula> reduction in per-user latency at a fixed power budget, or equivalently <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$50\%$</tex-math></inline-formula> reduction in the transmission power required to achieve a fixed per-user latency, compared with non-generative multicasting.

title: You May Not Be Your Username: Cross-Market Vendor Alias Attribution with Automatic Multi-Signal Evaluation
authors: Wesley H. Kwan, Lynn K. Takahashi, Nathan Pham, Apurva Sista, Ericsson Marin
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Vendor alias attribution is a critical but under-explored challenge in cyber-threat intelligence. Hackers frequently operate under multiple aliases across marketplaces to evade detection, manipulate reputation systems, or rebrand after scams—complicating efforts to track activity, analyze behavior, or disrupt operations. Progress is hindered by the absence of labeled ground truth across markets and the reliance of prior work on single-signal heuristics, manually constructed alias pairs, or limited-scale evaluation. In this paper, we propose a fully automated framework for cross-market alias matching using recent Tor marketplace data focused on criminal hacking. Our two-phase approach trains supervised models on labeled vendor data from one market and applies them to listings from unseen markets. To evaluate predictions, we introduce the Oracle, a multi-signal mechanism that triangulates evidence from usernames, image similarity, and textual signature patterns. This evaluation layer—ranging from single-signal to composite triplets—enables high-confidence alias confirmation and is assessed through a manual audit that estimates the Confirmed Positive Ratio (CPR) across tiers. As part of this audit, we present case studies that demonstrate how reliance on single signals—such as usernames—can lead to false matches. Our framework achieves 0.68 F1-score in alias prediction across 25 markets, yielding a performance gain of up to 61% over the most competitive baseline. By combining cross-market modeling with automated multi-signal validation, our approach strengthens cyber defense through trustworthy forensics for alias attribution.

title: Mitigating Leakage Amplification in DP-Enhanced Encrypted Search Across Multiple Users
authors: Yingying Qi, Jiabei Wang, Tiancheng Zhu, Yongbin Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Searchable symmetric encryption (SSE) enables keyword search over encrypted data but inevitably leaks patterns that adversaries can exploit to infer sensitive information. Differential privacy (DP) has been adopted to mitigate such leakages efficiently, yet existing DP-enhanced schemes are limited to single-user settings, lacking support for multi-user data sharing under diverse privacy needs. In such settings, distinct encryption keys and heterogeneous privacy levels raise two critical challenges: (i) leakage amplification, a prevalent yet under-explored threat where adversaries infer keywords from low-privacy data and link them to high-privacy data in cross-user retrieval; and (ii) inefficient privilege management, where cross-user search requires cumbersome key transmissions and frequent updates due to changing privileges. To bridge these challenges, we propose DPE-MUSE, a DP-Enhanced Multi-User Searchable Encryption scheme that achieves secure mutual retrieval while hiding access and size patterns. At its core is an adaptive keyword-level budget allocation strategy that derives budgets from data distributions and mitigates cross-user inference. A unified key management strategy further eliminates direct key sharing and streamlines privilege updates. Experiments on the Enron dataset show that DPE-MUSE achieves high recall (98.96%) under strict privacy requirements with relative low overhead, requiring only 58.951 ms for budget computation on a dataset of size 2<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">14</sup>.

title: An IPT-CPT Hybrid Wireless Power Transfer System for Uncrewed Aerial Vehicles
authors: Cancan Rong, Haoyang Wang, Yingzhou Guo, Junhao Wu, Huimin Gao, Weizhe Cai, Wei Han, Yanting Luo, Shuai Wu, Xichen Liu, Xiaowen Xu
abstract: In the field of uncrewed aerial vehicle (UAV) wireless charging, inductive power transfer (IPT) and capacitive power transfer (CPT) have become the two main technical approaches. However, existing single-topology systems still face significant challenges. This article proposes a hybrid IPT-CPT wireless power transfer (WPT) system to address key limitations of lightweight design and landing misalignment tolerance. First, a hybrid coupler is designed, with CPT serving as the main energy transfer channel. By reusing the compensation inductor as the coupler of IPT, the integration level of the system is improved. Then, a frequency-variable reconfiguration strategy with single-switch control is introduced to enable constant current (CC) and constant voltage (CV) output modes. Furthermore, a modified MOEA/D algorithm is employed to co-optimize electromagnetic parameters, balancing transmission efficiency and output power. Experimental results demonstrate that the system delivers 218.8 W with 86.38% efficiency in CC mode at 750 kHz and 216.6 W with 81.39% efficiency in CV mode at 778 kHz. The system exhibits strong misalignment tolerance, maintaining stable operation within $\boldsymbol{\pm}$25~mm (x-axis) and $\boldsymbol{\pm}$100 mm ($y$-axis) offset ranges.

title: Learning to Co-Design Routing and Processing in Computing Power Networks
authors: Ye Qin, Kexian Liu, Jianli Liu, Xiaolong Hu, Zejun Lan, Jianfeng Guan
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Orchestrating the intertwined computing and network resources at the foundational fabric level of Computing Power Networks (CPNs) remains a critical challenge. Current network architectures often lead to resource fragmentation and performance bottlenecks because routing decisions are decoupled from the dynamic, intrinsic processing loads of network nodes. This fundamental disconnect creates inefficiencies and security risks that undermine the entire CPN substrate. To address this, we introduce GAT-GRPO, a Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) framework designed for the fine-grained Joint Routing and in-Network Processing Placement (JR-PP) task. GAT-GRPO features a novel dual-path Graph Attention Network (GAT) that explicitly models the distinct heterogeneity of link states and nodal capacity. To master the complex combinatorial action space, we are the first to leverage Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO)—a stable, critic-free algorithm—for network resource orchestration. Extensive evaluations show GAT-GRPO boosts network revenue by 3.7%-5.3% over latest baselines. Mininet emulations further validate its superiority, with a 6.7% reduction in peak queue length and a 6% decrease in peak link utilization against the latest DRL agent. Our work delivers a practical, high-performance solution for foundational resource orchestration in CPNs, enabling a more intelligent and resilient networking substrate for higher-level services.

title: Switching Control of double-heater heating systems based on Predictive Model
authors: Shuai Chen, Feiyang Zheng, Lin Sun
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Heat exchangers are critical components in heat exchanger networks (HENs), directly influencing the overall heat exchange efficiency. In the event of a heat exchanger failure, maintenance personnel must shut down the faulty unit and activate a compensator heat exchanger (CHE). Manual switching operations often result in significant temperature jumps, compromising the safety of both personnel and equipment. To address this issue, this paper proposes a switching control strategy based on predictive model. The switching system consists of the faulty heat exchanger (FHE) and the CHE. Using the model predictive control (MPC) approach, the predictive model calculates the optimal control inputs for the CHE, reducing the temperature jump to just $1.4^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$-a substantial improvement over the $52^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ observed with manual adjustment. Furthermore, the multiple Lyapunov function (MLF) method is employed to analyze the stability of the switching control system, demonstrating that the entire system remains stable under the predictive-model-based control strategy.

title: Electrochemical Plated Zinc Metal for Yarn Zinc Ion Supercapacitor
authors: Sheng Yong, Jidong Liu, Stephen Beeby
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Micro and Miniature Power Systems, Self-Powered Sensors and Energy Autonomous Devices (PowerMEMS)
abstract: This paper presents the design, fabrication, and characterization of yarn-based zinc-ion hybrid supercapacitors (ZICs). The devices were constructed using activated carbon-coated stainless-steel (SS) yarn as the cathode, electrochemically plated zinc on SS yarn as the anode, and a zinc gel electrolyte. The flexible yarn supercapacitor operated within a voltage window of 0.1–1.8 V and achieved an area capacitance of 43.6 mF cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−2</sup> with an energy capacity of 10.2 μWh cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−2</sup> after wetting with deionised water. Furthermore, it retained 85% of its capacitance (or energy capacity) after 300 charge–discharge cycles.
