title: Design and Optimization Methods of Key Parameters for Enhancing HVDC-Based Renewable Energy Transmission Capacity
authors: Changzun Wu, Yi Hao, Kai Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: One major obstacle to integrating ultra-high penetration of renewable energy into line-commutated converterbased high-voltage direct current (LCC-HVDC) systems is that the power transmission capacity is severely limited by transient overvoltage at the sending end after commutation failures (CF). To overcome this, this research proposes a quantitative assessment indicator based on reactive power-voltage sensitivity analysis and binary table method to evaluate the transmission capability of regional renewable energy grids. Integrate this indicator into the improved overvoltage suppression strategy (IOSS) to enhance the transmission capacity of renewable energy. To validate the effectiveness of the proposed methodology, a HVDC-based renewable energy transmission system is established using the PSCAD/EMTDC simulation platform. The proposed method is applied to this system, confirming its efficacy in enhancing transmission capacity.

title: Module Power Balance Modulation Method for Cascaded Multilevel Inverters with full modulation ratio range
authors: YANG MA, ZHONG CHEN, JIAKAI GAN, LEXUAN HUANG, YAMING XU
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Industrial Electronics Society
abstract: The cascaded H-bridge (CHB) inverters has drawn much attention in renewable energy and industrial applications. Conventional modulation strategies for CHB inverters face challenges in simultaneously achieving optimal output voltage harmonic characteristics and active power balancing among cascaded units. To address this issue, this paper proposes a novel power-balancing modulation strategy based on carrier cycle adjustment for nine-level CHB inverters with full modulation ratio range. The proposed method extends conventional Phase Disposition (PD) modulation by synchronously rearranging the carriers above and below the time axis, thereby creating a new carrier period cycle that can improve the output of internal power units. Within this framework, duty cycle expressions for each cascaded unit are derived, and the corresponding fundamental voltage components are analytically obtained. The analysis demonstrates that the proposed strategy achieves effective power balancing across all cascaded units within a single fundamental cycle. Finally, both simulation and experimental results confirm the effectiveness and practicality of the method.

title: An Integrated AI Framework for Unsupervised Wildfire Risk Prediction and Automated Detection
authors: Kamel Touati, Lamia Cheklat
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: The growing global challenge of wildfires requires advanced systems for both timely prediction and rapid detection. This paper presents a novel dual-component AI-based system that uniquely integrates unsupervised fire risk prediction with real-time wildfire detection, addressing critical limitations in existing approaches. The first component introduces an innovative unsupervised machine learning ensemble that eliminates the dependency on labeled historical fire data a major bottleneck in current prediction systems. By analyzing meteorological data from regions in Bejaia, Algeria, our ensemble combining K-Means, Gaussian Mixture Model, and Isolation Forest successfully stratifies weather patterns into risk categories, identifying high-risk periods with robust accuracy. The second component pioneers a scalable auto-labeling pipeline that overcomes the prohibitive cost of manual annotation for large-scale image datasets. Using a pre-trained segmentation model, we automatically annotated over nine thousand images, then enriched this dataset with six additional Roboflow datasets to create a comprehensive training corpus. Our comparative analysis of state-of-the-art object detection models reveals that YOLOv12n achieves superior performance, demonstrating exceptional capability in distinguishing true fires from common false positives including fog and factory smoke. This work establishes the first comprehensive framework that synergistically combines unsupervised risk forecasting with wildfire detection, providing a practical, scalable solution for integrated fire management systems.

title: SE-GS: Sensor-Enhanced Gaussian Splatting
authors: Tianzi Zhang, Mingrui Li, Zhaoyang Xia, Lirong Zheng
abstract: The degradation issues of visual sensors, such as noise and motion blur, limit their applications. Traditional discrete-view approaches to addressing these problems often rely on prior neural networks and cannot leverage multi-view geometry for unsupervised solutions. Recently, 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) has demonstrated remarkable performance in the field of multi-view synthesis. Although some 3D Gaussian-based methods have proposed frameworks for single tasks, they lack effective capabilities for generalizable multi-task solutions. Therefore, we propose SE-GS, a joint optimization framework that combines a sensor enhancement network with 3D Gaussian parameters. Our innovations include: We introduce a self-supervised learning module that can achieve adaptive task optimization. We propose a perception enhancement module based on frequency-domain transformations to adaptively acquire pixel masks for degraded interference. We propose a coarse-to-fine feature optimization method based on geometry-optical flow to reduce the model size, thereby improving training speed and eliminating artifacts. We propose a joint optimization loss module that includes multi-view consistency loss and structural similarity loss to achieve rendering optimization.Our method can adapt to multi-task constraints and demonstrate good generalizability. It avoids the view separation caused by decoupled training and reconstruction, which significantly reduces reconstruction artifacts caused by sensor degradation. Extensive experiments conducted on multiple datasets demonstrate that our method achieves competitive performance in rendering and real-time metrics compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Factors Influencing Cybersecurity Risk and Autonomous Shipping Awareness
authors: D. Huso, Z. H. Munim, Y. Chai, T.E. Kim, Z. Bhuiyan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Cybersecurity has emerged as a critical concern as the maritime industry adopts advanced digital technologies and transitions toward autonomous operations. This study explores the factors influencing cybersecurity risk and autonomous shipping awareness among maritime professionals. Using data from a survey of 130 professionals, this study reveals that professionals with a degree of higher cybersecurity awareness are more likely to be aware of autonomous shipping, and vice versa. Further, international exposure is positively associated with this dual awareness. These findings highlight the importance of integrating cybersecurity and autonomous shipping education within maritime education and training. Industry stakeholders and policymakers should facilitate international training and exchange programs to enhance safety in the maritime transport sector.

title: Improving Accuracy with VGG16 based Normal/Drusen Retinal OCT Images Compared with ResNet152 Results
authors: Neal Stephen Reon C, V. Rajinikanth
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: Eye is a necessary sensory part and provides visual information to the brain for processing. Any illness in the eye can result in various complications, and neglecting eye disease may lead to several eye health problems, including vision loss. The medical assessment of eye disease will consider non- invasive imaging schemes to evaluate its health. This research considers the eye images recorded using Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT). This study focuses on creating a deep-learning (DL) technique for detecting normal/drusen class eye condition using DL-model along with SoftMax-classifier. This study includes several stages; image collection and resizing, deep-features mining using the selected DL-model, implementing SoftMax classification, and evaluating the system's performance. The VGG16 model offered superior results compared to ResNet152, and these findings are analyzed to validate the merit of DL-scheme.

title: Off-Site Battery Swapping Traveling Salesman Problem: a Logic-Based Benders Decomposition Reformulation and Exact Algorithm
authors: Rui Luo, Ziyu Wang, Xinhao Cui
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: The Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP) encounters significant variations in the context of electric vehicles (EVs), primarily due to their limited battery capacity. In practice, EVs need to detour to finish battery swapping or recharge. Previous works mainly use heuristic methods to solve this problem on a large scale. This paper introduces a novel and exact methodology: a logic-based Benders decomposition (LBBD) reformulation. We propose a branch and check framework that leverages dynamic programming to efficiently solve the benders subproblem. It performs best in over 85% of cases and has considerable potential for future expansion to accelerate solving and accommodate even more complex models.

title: SCADA-Based Analysis of Temperature Effects on Wind Turbine Performance in Hot Climates
authors: Kaouthar Othmani, Ahmed Hafaifa, Abdelhamid Iratni, Ayman AlQattan, Soliman Shalaby
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: High ambient temperatures can substantially affect wind turbine performance in hot climates by altering aerodynamic behavior and reducing efficiency. This study uses one year of high-frequency SCADA data to investigate the thermal sensitivity of a 2 MW wind turbine. By accounting for air density effects and deviations from expected performance, the analysis evaluates how temperature variations influence power generation. Even under favorable wind conditions, the results indicate measurable power losses during hotter periods, suggesting that thermal stress contributes to efficiency reduction and irregular turbine operation. These findings highlight the importance of considering thermal effects when evaluating turbine performance and developing operational strategies in extreme environments.

title: Towards Online Frequency Response Analysis of In-Service Power Transformers: A Single-Coil Three-Phase Parallel-Connected Sensing System
authors: Sen Yang, Yuhan Wang, Guangmao Li, Yangchun Cheng, Shirui Gao, Yuanshu Wei
abstract: Winding deformation is an important contributor to power transformer faults and forced outages. Effective and mature online detection methods are still lacking. The online frequency response analysis (FRA) method is a promising candidate for further development. A major obstacle in online FRA is the strong interference posed by the high-amplitude power-frequency load current (hundreds of amperes) to the extremely weak FRA test signal at the sub-milliampere level. This paper proposes a single-coil, three-phase parallel-connected sensing system, which employs three identical coil-type current sensors. Its capability to suppress power-frequency interference while measuring high-frequency signals has been theoretically analyzed and experimentally validated. An online measurement system based on it was applicated on an operating 110 kV power transformer. Field measurements verified that the proposed single-coil sensing system suppresses power-frequency interference by a factor of 100. Furthermore, the new frequency response functions derived from the online current signals exhibited resonance features closely aligned with the conventional offline FRA method, confirming the method's stability and suitability for diagnosing winding deformation in in-service power transformers.

title: Two-Stage Robust Co-Optimization of Capacity Planning and Day-Ahead Dispatch for a MultiMicrogrid System
authors: Ziyang Zhang, Hairong Zou
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: We address joint capacity planning and day-ahead dispatch for a multi-microgrid system under renewable and load uncertainty. A two-stage robust co-optimization is formulated as a mixed-integer linear program: the master minimizes annualized investment plus an upper bound on operating cost, and the subproblem selects adversarial wind/ $\mathbf{P V}$ and load from interval sets to maximize cost. The model enforces mutual exclusivity of grid buy/sell and battery charge/discharge, intertemporal SOC balance constraints with bounds and initialization, grid-exchange caps, and device limits. An iterative scenario-cut loop tightens the lower bound and closes the LB-UB gap. Implemented in MATLAB/YALMIP with Gurobi as the MILP solver, the framework is evaluated on a 24 -hour, fourmicrogrid dataset. Experiments report convergence diagnostics, zero violations of exclusivity/SOC constraints across adversarial scenarios, the resulting capacity mix and cost decomposition, and sensitivities to uncertainty widths and price perturbations. Results yield feasible, economical schedules with a small primaldual gap and a stable capacity plan, reducing the under sizing risk inherent in deterministic planning while remaining computationally tractable and reproducible.

title: Automated Parsing of Engineering Drawings for Structured Information Extraction Using a Fine-tuned Document Understanding Transformer
authors: Muhammad Tayyab Khan, Zane Yong, Lequn Chen, Jun Ming Tan, Wenhe Feng, Seung Ki Moon
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Accurate extraction of key information from 2D engineering drawings is crucial for high-precision manufacturing. Manual extraction is slow and labor-intensive, while traditional Optical Character Recognition (OCR) techniques often struggle with complex layouts and overlapping symbols, resulting in unstructured outputs. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a novel hybrid deep learning framework for structured information extraction by integrating an Oriented Bounding Box (OBB) detection model with a transformer-based document parsing model (Donut). An in-house annotated dataset is used to train YOLOv11 for detecting nine key categories: Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing (GD&T), General Tolerances, Measures, Materials, Notes, Radii, Surface Roughness, Threads, and Title Blocks. Detected OBBs are cropped into images and labeled to fine-tune Donut for structured JSON output. Fine-tuning strategies include a single model trained across all categories and category-specific models. Results show that the single model consistently outperforms category-specific ones across all evaluation metrics, achieving higher precision (94.77% for GD&T), recall (100% for most categories), and F1 score (97.3%), while reducing hallucinations (5.23%). The proposed framework improves accuracy, reduces manual effort, and supports scalable deployment in precision-driven industries.

title: FedEdge: Federated Self-Supervised Graph Learning with Personalized Fine-Tuning for Node Classification
authors: Zichao Deng, Han Yu
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Subgraph Federated Learning (FL) enables collaborative training of Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) across clients, each holding a local subgraph. However, it faces significant challenges due to label scarcity and community heterogeneity. We propose a two-stage framework that combines self-supervised pre-training with personalized fine-tuning to address these issues. As the first to extend graph self-supervised learning to the FL setting, our FedEdge method enables clients to collaboratively learn meaningful structural representations without labeled data. In the fine-tuning stage, personalized aggregation is guided by functional similarity, promoting collaboration among clients from similar communities. Extensive experiments on three real-world datasets show that FedEdge consistently outperforms five state-of-the-art methods, improving average test accuracy by up to 9.86% over the best FL baseline.

title: Layered Website Fingerprinting Defense Against Adversarial Training
authors: Yong Zeng, Jiaze Li, Hao Liu, Zhihong Liu, Jianfeng Ma
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: The Tor browser ensures secure internet access through multi-layer encryption and anonymity, yet remains vulnerable to Website Fingerprinting (WF) attacks. The emergence of adversarial training poses a critical challenge: attackers now leverage publicly available WF defenses to create augmented training data. This data augmentation strategy, as demonstrated in S&P’23, dramatically strengthens attack models’ robustness. Consequently, many existing defenses have become ineffective against these enhanced adversaries. We propose FRONT-R and its combination with TrafficSliver, called FRONT-RS, to counter this threat through two key innovations:(1) disrupting trace patterns by injecting randomized dummy packets at feature-rich front segments instead of fixed single-packet insertion, and (2) trace splitting through multi-path routing. In adversarial training environments, FRONT-R demonstrates superior performance over FRONT with 10% accuracy reduction in closed world and lower F1 in open world settings. When synergized with TrafficSliver, the layered approach achieves over 20% accuracy reduction compared to standalone methods while maintaining equivalent data overhead.

title: PoDIBC: Prevention of DrDoS Attacks Using Identity -Based Cryptography in Software-Defined Networking Environment
authors: Shain Saharan, Vishal Gupta
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: The rise of DDoS attacks, especially Distributed Reflection DoS (DrDoS), poses serious challenges due to source-IP spoofing. This paper introduces PoDIBC, a novel prevention scheme based on the BLMQ signature of Identity-Based Cryptography (IBC), which uses the source IP as a public key, eliminating the need for traditional certificate infrastructure. PoDIBC prevents spoofed attack packets from reaching the victim and is validated both mathematically and experimentally in a Software Defined Network (SDN) setting. Results show that PoDIBC adds 672 bits per packet—significantly less than TrueIP and X.509—and causes a one-time RTT increase of 2.25 seconds for the first packet, with an average 21 ms delay for subsequent packets. Additionally, PoDIBC is resilient to replay attacks, a known IBC vulnerability.

title: Technology for Database Compression and Encryption Based on User Privacy Protection
authors: Yu Qin, Yanli Zhang, Lisai Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: With the continuous advancement of information technology in the State Grid Corporation of China, big data technology has been widely applied in the data analysis and processing of field images and backend databases, significantly improving the work efficiency of operational personnel. However, during the transmission, storage, and analysis of image and electricity consumption data, the risk of leakage of users’ private information has become increasingly prominent. This paper proposes a joint compression and encryption technology for power databases based on an improved LZW compression algorithm and a physical unclonable function (PUF)-enhanced encryption mechanism. This technique ensures a high compression ratio while achieving secure protection of users’ electricity consumption privacy information. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method meets the expected benchmarks in both compression efficiency and security, making it suitable for privacy-sensitive data processing in power systems.

title: Optimization Design Method for Nets in Multi- Stage Filtration System of Nuclear Power Plant Using Cognitive Intelligence Techniques
authors: PeiYan Pan, ZhiFeng Zhang, YiXiong Feng, Zhengqin Zhu, Junjie Song, JianRong Tan
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Cooling water intake systems in nuclear power plants are increasingly susceptible to operational disruptions due to marine organism intrusions. Traditional optimization methods based on static numerical simulations and evolutionary algorithms lack adaptability to complex, dynamic operational conditions and uncertainties. This study introduces a cognitive intelligence-integrated optimization framework, combining discrete element method (DEM) and finite element method (FEM) simulations with deep reinforcement learning (DRL), fuzzy analytic hierarchy process, and expert knowledge to optimize filtration net parameters adaptively and robustly.

title: Sensor Fault Diagnosis and Switched Fault-Tolerant Control for Gas Turbines Using Wavelet Features and Random Forest Classifier
authors: Abdelhak Djellad, Mohamed Rouamel, Hani Malem, Hani Abderrahim Benleulmi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: This study addresses the problem of fault diagnosis and fault-tolerant control in gas turbine systems, with a focus on sensor faults in the combustion chamber. In the first phase, a data-driven fault diagnosis framework is proposed using sensor datasets combined with wavelet decomposition for feature extraction. The decomposed signals capture both time and frequency-domain characteristics, enhancing fault sensitivity. These features are then classified using a Random Forest (RF) classifier, which is benchmarked against Support Vector Regression (SVR) and other traditional machine learning methods. Experimental results demonstrate that the RF-based model achieves superior accuracy and robustness in identifying temperature sensor faults under varying operational conditions.In the second phase, a fault-tolerant control strategy is developed to ensure continued safe operation despite detected faults. The control system employs a switched control structure, where a classical state feedback controller is used under fault-free conditions, and a robust controller is activated in the presence of faults. The switching mechanism is governed by a Bernoulli distribution-based probabilistic model, which captures the intermittent nature of sensor faults. The robust controller is implemented as a cascade state-feedback controller, specifically designed for the combustion chamber dynamics. Simulation results confirm that the proposed approach effectively stabilizes the system and maintains performance despite sensor degradations, offering a reliable solution for modern gas turbine control under uncertainty.

title: Performance Monitoring and Fault Diagnosis of Piezoelectric Accelerometers Using Optimized Sensitivity Modeling
authors: Salima Khaoula Reguieg, Mouhcen El-Hadi Dahmoun
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: Piezoelectric accelerometers, based on the direct piezoelectric effect, are widely utilized for vibration monitoring in industrial environments and early fault diagnosis of rotating machinery. This paper proposes an enhanced mathematical model derived from Newton's law; this allows a new formulation of relative sensitivity to be expressed in terms of measurement error. The approach developed in this work will permit more accurate characterization and optimization of sensitivity behavior. The simulation results show that the proposed model reduces the measurement error below 0.3% and can further improve the measurement accuracy significantly via an optimized selection of damping ratio. The result of such improvements is much more reliable condition monitoring and predictive maintenance applications.

title: RT-DriftSelect: A Real-Time Dynamic Feature Selection Framework for Concept Drift Adaptation in SDN-IoT Environments
authors: Selma Amrani, Chirihane Gherbi, Khedidja Medani, Abdul Ghafar Jaafar, Noor Hafizah Hassan, Rahma Berchi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: The dynamic nature of Software-Defined Networking (SDN)-based Internet of Things (IoT) environments poses a major challenge for maintaining model accuracy under evolving data distributions, known as concept drift. This paper introduces RT-DriftSelect, a real-time adaptive framework designed to address this issue through dynamic feature selection and incremental learning. The proposed method continuously monitors feature statistics and computes drift magnitudes between consecutive data windows to identify relevant and evolving attributes. Features with significant drift are retained for model updates, while irrelevant ones are discarded, thereby enhancing computational efficiency. The retained features are incrementally trained using an AdaBoost–Hoeffding Tree ensemble, allowing continuous adaptation without retraining from scratch. Experiments conducted on the SDN-IoT dataset demonstrate that RT-DriftSelect achieves a high cumulative accuracy of 99.85%, while dynamically reducing the feature space by up to 93.8%, outperforming static baselines. The proposed system ensures both robustness and efficiency, making it suitable for real-time and resource-constrained IoT scenarios.

title: Sustainable Solution-Based Textile-Triboelectric Nanogenerators for Self-Powered Pressure Sensing
authors: Xinlong Sun, Stephen Beeby
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Micro and Miniature Power Systems, Self-Powered Sensors and Energy Autonomous Devices (PowerMEMS)
abstract: Textile-based triboelectric nanogenerators (t-TENGs) harvest human motion for self-powered wearable sensor and energy harvester. Solution-based process is highly compatible with textile/yarns platform for scalable t-TENGs fabrication. However, most inks rely on fluorinated species and hazardous solvents, raising environmental and health concerns. This research reports a green tribo-positive yarns derived from silk fibroin without hazardous components. Under identical conditions, silk-based TENGs achieve ~77.6% of the Voc of unsustainable PA-based devices. To compensate for weaker polarity, 2D and 3D woven architectures are employed to enhance interfacial contact. A proof-of-concept 2D plain-woven t-TENG shows stable pressure sensing (2–10 N) with force-dependent Voc and low drift. Furthermore, a fully sustainable 3D woven t-TENG interlacing silk and PDMS-coated yarns is proposed. This work combines sustainability with self-powered pressure sensing textile design for practical t-TENGs.

title: BayesFuzz: Bayesian-Based Greybox Fuzzing for Stateful Protocols
authors: Jianwen Xiang, Junwei Jiang, Songsong Liao, Xueming Zhang, Rui Hao
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Protocols serve as the foundation for communication between devices and systems in modern computing environments. However, their widespread use also exposes them to various security threats. A flaw in protocol implementation can be exploited to compromise system security, leading to severe disruptions or unauthorized access. Fuzzing has become a widely used technique for protocol vulnerability detection. However, the existing protocol fuzzing approaches often lack effective guidance strategies for exploring the complex protocol state space, which leads to limited coverage and suboptimal testing efficiency.In this paper, we propose BayesFuzz, a Bayesian-guided greybox fuzzing approach for stateful protocols. It maintains a probability table to record the probability of sending different messages and triggering different state transitions in the current state. This table is updated via Bayesian inference based on feedback from each fuzzing iteration. Accordingly, BayesFuzz is able to select the optimal message for the current state during test case generation, thereby improving fuzzing efficiency in complex stateful protocols. Experimental results confirm the effectiveness of BayesFuzz. Compared with state-of-the-art fuzzers BooFuzz and AFLNET, BayesFuzz increases branch coverage by averagely 23.18% and 45.3% within 24 hours. Furthermore, it successfully discovered an unknown vulnerability in the MQTT protocol implementation.

title: Design of an Ultra-Wideband Circularly Polarized Microstrip Patch Antenna for Sub-6 GHz 5G Mobile Applications
authors: Radia Tabet-Derraz, Abdellatif Berkat, Noureddine Boukli-Hacene
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: In this paper, a circularly polarized ultra-wideband (UWB) microstrip patch antenna for sub-6 GHz 5G mobile applications is presented. The antenna, with overall dimensions of 36.8 × 46.4 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, is implemented on a low-cost single-layer FR4 substrate. The design employs an arc-shaped slot etched on the circular patch, combined with a partial ground plane, to enhance both impedance and axial ratio (AR) bandwidth performance. The proposed antenna achieves a wide −10 dB impedance bandwidth of 86.88% (2.22–5.63 GHz) and a 3 dB AR bandwidth of 22.73% (3.9–4.9 GHz), with a peak gain of 4.2 dBi. The prototype demonstrates reliable performance and can be easily fabricated for integration into 5G devices.

title: Research on Dual-loop Optimization Method for Steam Generator Control System Performance Based on Random Forest Algorithm
authors: Yuxuan. Xie, Xiaoyu. Li, Xiangsong Kong, Yimin Zeng, Weiming Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Traditional control optimization methods typically enhance system performance and economic efficiency by tuning controller parameters. However, these approaches exhibit significant limitations in parameter adjustment: they heavily rely on expert knowledge, are prone to human errors, and incur substantial economic costs. To address these challenges, this study proposes an asynchronous dual-level optimization framework for control system performance enhancement. In this architecture, the inner layer employs conventional control optimization techniques to tune system parameters, while the outer layer integrates machine learning to analyze optimization trajectories and estimate process states in real-time. Specifically, a random forest algorithm dynamically adjusts optimization parameters to achieve concurrent improvements in both economic performance and operational efficiency. Simulation results demonstrate that automated parameter tuning significantly improves the optimization efficiency of steam generators while simultaneously enhancing economic performance.

title: From Offline to Periodic Adaptation for Pose-Based Shoplifting Detection in Real-world Retail Security
authors: Shanle Yao, Narges Rashvand, Armin Danesh Pazho, Hamed Tabkhi
abstract: Shoplifting is a growing operational and economic challenge for retailers, with incidents rising and losses increasing despite extensive video surveillance. Continuous human monitoring is infeasible, motivating automated, privacy-preserving, and resource-aware detection solutions. In this paper, we cast shoplifting detection as a pose-based, unsupervised video anomaly detection problem and introduce a periodic adaptation framework designed for on-site Internet of Things (IoT) deployment. Our approach enables edge devices in smart retail environments to adapt from streaming, unlabeled data, supporting scalable and low-latency anomaly detection across distributed camera networks. To support reproducibility, we introduce RetailS1, a new large-scale real-world shoplifting dataset collected from a retail store under multi-day, multi-camera conditions, capturing unbiased shoplifting behavior in realistic IoT settings. For deployable operation, thresholds are selected using both F1 and HPRS scores, the harmonic mean of precision, recall, and specificity, during data filtering and training. In periodic adaptation experiments, our framework consistently outperformed offline baselines on AUC-ROC and AUC-PR in 91.6% of evaluations, with each training update completing in under 30 minutes on edge-grade hardware, demonstrating the feasibility and reliability of our solution for IoT-enabled smart retail deployment.

title: Evaluation of a Methodology for a Change-Specific and Company-Individual Manufacturing Change Management – Industrial Application, Requirement Fulfilment, and Cost-Benefit Analysis
authors: Jan-Philipp Rammo, Jennifer Graf, Clément Roumegoux Rouvelle, Michael Atzenbeck, Bjoern Klages, Christina Reuter, Michael F. Zaeh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Manufacturing companies are increasingly challenged by the frequency and diversity of required changes to their production systems. To address this, a change-specific and company-individual methodology for Manufacturing Change Management (MCM) was developed. This paper presents a multi-perspective evaluation of the methodology through an industrial case study, a simulation game, and expert interviews. The results indicate that the methodology enhances process efficiency, streamlines documentation and method selection, and improves transparency in change handling. The cost-benefit analysis demonstrates a rapid amortization. The broad fulfilment of key requirements confirms the practical value of the approach, while also revealing opportunities for further improvement.

title: Distributionally Robust Optimization of Park-level Integrated Energy System Considering Demand Response and Uncertainties
authors: Xiaolin Zhang, Liang Song
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: With the increasing penetration of renewable energy, park-level integrated energy systems (PIES) have garnered significant attention. However, their practical operation is constrained by uncertainties and variations in user loads. This paper addresses uncertainties in wind power output and the indirect carbon emission intensity of the grid within PIES, while incorporating user-side demand response. A bi-level optimization model is constructed: the upper level is a two-stage distributionally robust optimization model for PIES, and the lower level is a user demand response model. The model is transformed into a solvable single-level mixed-integer linear programming problem using the column-and-constraint generation (C&CG) algorithm and Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) conditions. Case study results demonstrate that the proposed method enhances economic efficiency while ensuring system robustness, effectively balancing renewable energy integration, carbon emission, and economic operation.

title: Research on AC Ice-melting Reactive Power Compensation Control Method Considering the Impedance Variation of Overhead Ground Wire
authors: Haoyi Liu, Shuangyan Shu, Zheng Wang, Lu Cai, Changfa Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: The flexible adjustment of AC ice-melting current is of great significance for saving power consumption and improving the safety of power systems. This paper proposes a reactive power compensation control method that considering the impedance variation of overhead ground wires during the ice-melting process, addressing the need for matching the AC ice-melting current with the line icing conditions. The method utilizes feedback control of reactive power compensation capacitor switching based on the impedance variation of the ground wire during ice-melting, to achieve the desired matching and adjustment of the AC ice-melting current. A theoretical model is first established to describe the impact of ground wire temperature and sag variation on impedance, then dynamic impedance-based reactive power compensation capacity and matching methods are derived considering the ground wire temperature rise constraints. A simulation model of aluminum-clad steel strand and composite optical cable ground wire, combined with actual capacitor switching of the compensation device, is used to calculate the reactive power compensation capacity and control strategy during the ice-melting process, validating the effectiveness of theoretical model. The designed method achieves high control accuracy, providing a more flexible and adjustable current feedback control solution for overhead ground wire AC ice-melting.

title: Systems Thinking To Advance Skills Forecasting
authors: S. Telukdarie, M. Munsamy, A. Telukdarie, S. P. Philbin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: The accurate forecasting of skills is a key differentiator of growth, as technological advancements are increasingly impacting skills and the nature of skills forecasting. This requires a more sophisticated and holistic approach, i.e., a systems thinking approach. This method aims to account for this impact and addresses the complexity of contemporary skills forecasting. A multi-layer approach commences with a bibliometric analysis, illustrating the technological evolution of skills according to a sector-specific search and a multi-country analysis. The results illustrate an increase in publications corresponding to technological advancements in each sector. The impact of specific technological advancements, such as artificial intelligence, has a significant impact on skills research. This analysis compares skills associated with healthcare jobs advertised on job sites in South Africa and the USA. A network illustration tool offers a novel approach to job requirements per country. Analysis using the job descriptions allows further insights into the requirements of jobs in the healthcare field. The level of technological integration of South Africa is less well developed than in the USA. The novelty of this study lies in the systems thinking approach to skills forecasting by combining two sources of data and multiple layers of analysis.

title: iSME: Image Steganography with MECS Based on GAN
authors: Yamin Li, Chen Zeng, Liu Duan, Xuansong Li, Can Li, Haofeng Ju
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Image steganography faces inherent trade-offs among embedding capacity, undetectability, and visual fidelity. To address this, we propose iSME, a novel GAN framework for image steganography with a Median-Enhanced Channel-Spatial (MECS) attention mechanism. The MECS module integrates channel attention and multi-scale spatial attention, enhancing feature representation while reducing embedding-induced distortion. The framework includes a generator (for embedding), an extractor (for recovery), and a discriminator based on XuNet, trained with the Wasserstein GAN objective for stability. Experiments on COCO and DIV2K datasets show that iSME outperforms SOTA methods (such as HiDDeN, SteganoGAN, CHAT-GAN) across 1–5 bits per pixel (BPP). Notably, at 5 BPP, it achieves PSNR of 41.93 (COCO) and 45.52 (DIV2K), with high SSIM and extraction accuracy (>91%), and stego images are nearly imperceptible. Ablation studies validate the critical role of MECS. This work provides a promising approach for high-capacity, secure, and high-fidelity image steganography.

title: A Stability- and Orientation-Constrained Algorithm for the Three-Dimensional Container Loading Problem
authors: Miharu Namiki, Takashi Hasuike
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: With the rapid expansion of globalization and e-commerce, international logistics demand has experienced strong medium- to long-term expansion, placing urgent pressure on both land and maritime transport to improve efficiency in the face of rising labor costs, stricter environmental regulations, and congested urban roadways. Container - based shipping remains a cornerstone of global trade, where maximizing stowage density directly reduces cost and carbon emissions. This study addresses a three - dimensional container loading problem by extending the Sub-Volume Based Simulated Annealing Algorithm (SVBSA) method to allow full XYZ - axis rotation of rectangular parallelepiped. We introduce a metaheuristic that considers six possible directional degrees of freedom in addition to the stability of the load. Finally, benchmark experiments show that loading efficiency can be improved by strategically introducing 3D rotation by limiting the timing at which it is allowed, rather than always allowing it, and by introducing it in a strategic manner.

title: Research on optimal regulation strategy of virtual power plant for regional voltage regulation
authors: Kaicheng Liu, Haoran Yang, Xiang Hu, Jiayi Zhu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: In response to the issues of voltage flicker and exceeding limits in distribution network nodes caused by the large-scale integration of distributed energy, this paper introduces virtual power plants as the key subject of regional voltage regulation to cope with the reactive power control challenges brought by fluctuations in new energy. This article evaluates the reactive power output potential of wind turbines, photovoltaic units, energy storage, and flexible loads in a virtual power plant, and establishes an optimized operation model with economic objectives based on constraints such as power balance and voltage threshold. Validate the effectiveness of the strategy in an IEEE 34 node distribution network through numerical analysis. The results show that this strategy can reduce the load peak valley difference by $11.2 \%$, significantly improve voltage deviation, and reduce the total operating cost of the virtual power plant by $6.2 \%$, improving the system’s operational economy and safety, providing a solution for voltage regulation under high proportion new energy integration.

title: Coordinated Operation of Power Distribution Network Considering Optimal Capacity Regulation of Distributed Energy Storage and Electric Vehicle Charging Stations
authors: Zhen Pan, Ke Li, Lijuan Huang, Hui Qin, Shizhong Zhang, Zhen Wu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: The increasing growth of distributed energy storage station (EES) and electric vehicle charging station (EVCS) has brought significant challenges on the secure and economic operation of power distribution network (PDN). This work proposes a coordinated operation method of PDN that enables the capacity regulation of ESS and EVCS. First, the coordinated operation model is proposed where the charging/discharging capacity of ESS and EVCS and dispatch of power generation units are simultaneously scheduled with traffic assignment and electric vehicles’ optimal routing and charging taken into consideration. Second, a branch price and cut-based solution algorithm is proposed, which efficiently decomposes the proposed model and tackles the computational intractability. Finally, numerical simulations verify the effectiveness of the proposed model and solution method and underscore the necessity of the capacity regulation in ensuring the grid operation security and economy.

title: Enablers for Digital Twin Adoption: People-Process-Technology Perspective
authors: N. Somsuk, T. Laosirihongthong, P. Samaranayake, M.W. McLean
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: This study prioritizes the enablers of digital-twin (DT) adoption in Thailand’s automotive supply chain by applying the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) from People–Process–Technology (PPT) perspective. Nine senior experts provided pairwise judgements that satisfied the AHP consistency threshold. The aggregated weights indicate that Technology is the dominant pillar, followed by People and Process. At a sub-factor level, knowledge & skills, cybersecurity, and technical performance of digital twin (DT) components emerge as top priorities. A five-scenario sensitivity analysis posited a 20% variation in the Technology weight, while redistributing the residual to People and Process. All technology-centric sub-factors remained within the top five, and no process-centric sub-factor rose above fifth place, indicating that the priority structure is robust to moderate weight changes. The results provide an evidence-based roadmap for staged DT roll-out, highlight the need for strong cybersecurity and workforce up-skilling, and furnish researchers with a validated PPT hierarchy for future comparative studies.

title: From Sample Generation to Efficacy Transfer: Optimization of Privacy-Preserving LLMs for Content Moderation
authors: Mingyong Yin, Tong Liu, Hejun Wang, Yulong Wang, Run Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: The performance improvement of large language models (LLMs) in domain-specific content moderation faces the dilemma of a trade-off between scale and cost. Current research urgently needs to break through the performance bottlenecks of lightweight models to achieve efficient deployment. This paper analyzes the performance of LLMs of different scales in content moderation tasks and investigates the fine-tuning methods for small LLMs under the conditions of scarce training data and high privacy requirements. This paper proposes a rule-constrained method for regulating Chinese text content. By drawing on the multi-stage training process of the DeepSeek-R1 model and the concept of Agent technology, it adopts a multi-role collaboration framework to generate domain-specific sample data based on rules, and establishes an end-to-end construction process for fine-tuning datasets oriented to the Chinese content moderation domain. Fine-tuning small LLMs using the generated sample data effectively transfers the capabilities of large LLMs to small LLMs. Sufficient experiments verify the effectiveness of the proposed method: it increases the accuracy of the DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-7B model by 48.1% while reducing its miss rate by 33.56%; it improves the accuracy of the Qwen2.5-7B-Instruct model by 29.07% and decreases its miss rate by 32.87%.

title: Smarter Extraction of Scholarly Metadata using Knowledge Graphs and Language Models
authors: Muhammad Asif Suryani, Brigitte Mathiak, Florian Reitz, Florian Jäckel, Ansgar Scherp
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries (JCDL)
abstract: Scholarly metadata is an essential element in the scholarly ecosystem, empowering discovery, interoperability, and provenance and its efficacy relies on metadata quality and coverage. However, with the substantial increase in the number and diversity of research artifacts over time, it has become a cumbersome task to harvest metadata features for scholarly publications, datasets, source code, and machine learning models. These artifacts generate heterogeneous metadata features, which are distributed across various repositories. In addition, large language models (LLMs) have emerged as powerful tools and are now being extensively adopted to facilitate a wide range of tasks across domains, ranging from information extraction to knowledge graphs. Nevertheless, numerous open questions persist regarding their adoption in diversified research disciplines, especially concerning their accuracy, robustness, biases, and societal impact when applied in the context of research metadata, scholarly information extraction, and open science. This workshop aims to cover these exciting aspects centered around metadata features from research artifacts, with a focus on large language models and knowledge graphs.

title: Distribution Network Topology Identification and Robust Grid Reinforcement Considering Topological Uncertainty
authors: Hengle Cao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: To address the issue of distortion in traditional network reconfiguration due to deviations between distribution network archival topology and the actual network structure, this paper proposes an integrated method for topology identification and robust network reconfiguration considering topology uncertainty. A topology identification model with archival and measurement errors is constructed, along with multi-scenario power flow evaluation. The method optimizes the configuration of tie lines and switches based on a two-stage robust programming and Benders decomposition approach. IEEE 33node test case results show that, when errors exist in the archive, this method can reduce the worst-case network loss by approximately $\mathbf{1 0 \% - 1 5 \%}$, decrease the number of over-voltage nodes by about $\mathbf{4 0 \% - 6 0 \%}$, and demonstrates superior robustness and stability compared to traditional methods under different archival errors and measurement noise.

title: A Systematic Literature Review of Last-Mile Delivery: Analyzing Current Situations and Identifying Research Gaps for Future Perspectives
authors: Piyanee Akkawuttiwanich, Sai Pim Khay Noom, Phuwit Sanganate, Waralee Rattanakijsuntorn
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Last-mile delivery (LMD) has become a critical challenge in logistics, driven by the rapid rise of e-commerce and growing consumer expectations for speed, flexibility, and sustainability. Despite significant advances in optimization models, simulation techniques, and machine learning applications, existing reviews remain fragmented and offer limited comparison of methodological strengths. This study addresses this gap through a systematic literature review of LMD research published between 2019 and 2025, following the PRISMA framework. Out of 162 screened publications, 33 were analyzed using bibliometric mapping in R and methodological clustering in Python. The analysis identifies four methodological streams: optimization and mathematical modeling, simulation and heuristics, multi-criteria and learning models, and literature-based analytical studies. Beyond classification, the study highlights critical gaps, including the limited integration of behavioral factors, financial trade-offs, and policy implications. By mapping methodological trends and proposing targeted research directions, this work provides a foundation for advancing more resilient, adaptive, and sustainable last-mile delivery systems.

title: Developing AHP-based Frameworks for Evaluating Agricultural Waste as Corrosion Inhibitors for Mild Steel in Process Industries
authors: K. O. Garuba, O. E. Olorunniwo, O. O. Ige, O. A. Olanrewaju
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: This study conducts a comparative methodological analysis to optimise corrosion inhibitor selection from agricultural waste. The framework integrates Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) with Fuzzy AHP (FAHP) through a reciprocal-based fusion algorithm, enhancing alternative prioritisation while preserving methodological integrity. A multidisciplinary panel with 115 years of expertise selected nine agricultural waste products. The assessment used validated criteria across technical, economic, environmental, and application-specific domains. The study presents three methodologies enhancing decision-making processes. A reciprocal-based fusion algorithm maintaining decision consistency while managing uncertainty, and a Methodology Dependency Analysis quantifying ranking sensitivity across MCDM approaches. Finally, a dual-phase sensitivity framework combining MDA with Monte Carlo simulations. Results indicate significant prioritization shifts, with efficiency dominating AHP (weight = 0.33) while FAHP yields equitable distribution, elevating environmental considerations (weight = 0.12). Ranking divergences revealed inverse correlation (r = -0.76), where orange peel extract led in AHP (0.243) and FAHP favoured cassava peel extract (0.18). The Integrated AHP-FAHP approach achieved the highest stability (71.5%), which is optimal for corrosion inhibition decision-making and advancing sustainable agricultural waste valorization.

title: Waste Collection Routing Problem with Electric Vehicle
authors: S. Sakti, A. M. S. Asih
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: This study investigates the waste collection routing problem by comparing the operational performance of electric vehicles (EVs) and conventional vehicles (CVs) in municipal solid waste collection. The proposed mathematical model incorporates vehicle capacity limits, maximum working time, and allowing multiple visits to disposal sites. This research considers fully charged EVs at the start of the day, which eliminates the need to model recharging strategies. The model is tested on customized datasets derived from benchmark instances and solved using exact method. The results show that EVs can achieve an average energy cost reduction of 31% compared to CVs, while also avoiding up to 55 grams of tailpipe emissions per day. This study provides initial insights into the benefits of EVs for waste collection and lays the groundwork for future research incorporating broader cost and operational considerations.

title: Effects of Scent on the Perceived Emotional Expression of Dance
authors: Arinobu Niijima, Yuki Kubo, Yukio Koike
abstract: Dance is an art form that conveys a wide range of emotions through the fusion of visual movement and music. Yet emotional expression in dance is inherently ambiguous: the emotions intended by the dancer do not always match those perceived by the audience. Although this ambiguity can hinder accurate transmission, it also offers creative opportunities for interpretive flexibility and diversity. This study explores whether such ambiguity can be harnessed by introducing olfactory stimuli alongside conventional audiovisual cues to modulate the audience’s emotional perception. We conducted a user study with a wearable aroma display that emits scents synchronized with the dance music. Twenty-five participants watched seven dance videos and rated the degree to which each conveyed Joy, Anger, Sadness, and Pleasure on a 7-point Likert scale under five conditions: one no-scent control condition and four scented conditions (Orange, Peppermint, Lavender, and Banana). The results showed that scent significantly alters the emotions perceived in the dances, and that the direction and magnitude of this effect depend on the specific dance–scent pairing. Notably, even for the same dance, different scents elicited different emotional impressions; conversely, the emotional impact of a given scent varied across dances. These findings establish scent as a novel modality for shaping the emotional perception of dance.

title: Comparative Analysis of Deep Learning Models for Background Subtraction on LASIESTA
authors: Ihssane Houhou, Chaima Hebbache, Yamina Rahmoune, Yassine Ruichek
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive evaluation of deep learning models for moving object detection via background subtraction, focusing on the LASIESTA dataset. We compare state-of-the-art convolutional neural networks, including Multiscale Fully Convolutional Network (MFCN) and Foreground Segmentation Network (FgSegNet) variants (M, S, V2), assessing their performance in segmenting moving foreground objects under challenging conditions such as camera jitter, illumination changes, and dynamic backgrounds. Our framework includes dataset pre-processing, binary mask generation, and model evaluation using the F1-Score, MCC, and PWC metrics. Results show that FgSegNet S achieves superior accuracy and robustness across indoor and outdoor scenes, while MFCN struggles with high-variability scenarios. This study provides valuable insights into the strengths and limitations of these models.

title: Association Mining between Electric Vehicle Charging Behavior and Electricity Price
authors: Na Li, Chao Ma, Jianwen Zhang, Mengyao Tian, Wenxuan Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Under the current circumstance with strong advocacy for energy conservation, emission reduction, and sustainable development, the scientific utilization of electricity in the areas with abundant wind and solar power potential, holds significant practical value. This paper focuses on charging behaviors of electric vehicle, as critical electricity consumption form, and then proposes an association mining model of charging behavior and electricity price policies. By integrating the economic development and user characteristics of different regions, it achieves the association mining method between charging behavior for electric vehicles and electricity price policies supported by survey questionnaire, which provides practical experience of time-of-use price policies, and vehicle charging demand management.
