title: Using ISO 25023 Model to Evaluate the Usability of The Halal Food Tracer Information System
authors: A. Susanty, A. A. Ramadhani, N. B. Puspitasari, Z.F. Rosyada, S. Jati
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: The rapid growth of the Muslim population has significantly increased the demand for halal products for food security and services across various sectors. However, challenges such as cross-contamination and halal certification fraud continue to undermine the integrity of the halal food supply chain. In response, Halal Food Tracer, a web-based information system, was developed to facilitate the exchange of information about halal products and ensure halal compliance across the supply chain. This study evaluates the system's usability in supporting its adoption by Muslim communities. Data was collected through user testing and questionnaires based on the ISO/IEC 25023 model and processed using multiple linear regression techniques. The analysis revealed a user satisfaction score of 3.61 out of 5.00. The study found that User Interface Aesthetics, Accessibility, and User Error Protection were the most influential factors on user satisfaction, with regression coefficients of 0.316, 0.293, and 0.150, respectively.

title: Machine Learning Diagnosis-Based of HVDC Faults
authors: Medoukali Hemza, Bouras Taha, Djamal Blidi, Boubakeur Zegnini
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: This study explores the application of machine learning (ML) techniques for fault diagnosis in high-voltage direct current (HVDC) systems, with a focus on generalization to previously unseen fault conditions. A line-commutated converter (LCC) HVDC system was modeled in MATLAB/Simulink to simulate a variety of fault scenarios, from which statistical features were extracted. Seven ML models—logistic regression, support vector machine (SVM), k-nearest neighbors (KNN), decision tree, random forest, gradient boosting, and multi-layer perceptron (MLP)—were assessed. Two evaluation protocols were applied: a conventional random data split and a more rigorous generalization test involving unseen fault resistances. Results show that random forest, gradient boosting, and MLP achieved the most robust performance, with random forest delivering the highest accuracy under generalization. The findings underscore the necessity of incorporating generalization testing to ensure reliable and, real-world-applicable HVDC fault diagnosis.

title: Enhancing Large-Scale Consumer Prediction Models Using Generative AI Dataset Expansion and Probabilistic Output Mechanisms
authors: Susumu Namikawa, Yoko Kohata, Amarsanaa Agchbayar, Baasandorj Tserensambuu, Satoru Yamamoto
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: This study presents advancements in large-scale consumer prediction models by leveraging generative AI techniques. Building upon previous research that utilized a subset of 11,000 respondents from a 150,000-participant dataset, we now incorporate the entire dataset to enhance model generalization. Additionally, we introduce a probabilistic output mechanism, enabling the model to generate probability distributions over multiple-choice responses rather than deterministic outputs. These enhancements have led to a significant improvement in prediction accuracy, with the correlation coefficient increasing from 0.68 to 0.80 and the root mean square error (RMSE) decreasing from 0.18 to 0.06. These findings underscore the potential of integrating comprehensive datasets and probabilistic outputs in generative AI models for more reliable consumer behavior predictions.

title: A secure and provable deletion method over outsourced data for fog-based smart grid
authors: Changsong Yang, Yueling Liu, Yong Ding, Hai Liang, Shuo Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Thanks to the advent and rapid development of fog computing, the smart grid has made great progress. In fog-based smart grid, the fog node can maintain and handle the data for the smart meter which is resource-constraint, thus improving the performance. However, the security of the data (especially for malicious data reservation) is the primary concern of the smart meter. To resist the malicious outsourced data reservation in fog-based smart grid, we propose a provable deletion method in this article. In our method, we first improve the Merkle hash tree and design a novel tree named Merkle position index hash tree (MPIHT). For maintaining the same number of data blocks, MPIHT can reduce the height of the tree since it is able to store plenty of data blocks in every leaf. At the same time, the number of data blocks in every leaf would be changeably, thus supporting data deletion operation. Subsequently, we use MPIHT to propose a secure and provable deletion method for outsourced data. Our method can guarantee data integrity and achieve provable data deletion, requiring neither a trusted third party nor any complex calculations or protocols. Moreover, we demonstrate the security analysis to formally prove that our method can meet the expected requirements. Finally, we also implement our method to assess the performance. The assessment results disclose the efficiency advantages of our method over some existing methods.

title: Automated detection of Lung disease using deep learning techniques: a comparative study
authors: Rajendran Sivakumar
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: Pneumonia, a distinct pulmonary disease, persists as a significant global health concern, substantially affecting morbidity and mortality rates. Timely and precise identification is crucial for effective intervention and enhanced patient outcomes. Throughout the past few years, deep learning (DL) has become known for a transformative approach in medical image analysis, delivering superior performance relative to traditional machine learning (ML) methods by independently recognising complex, distinguishing features from imaging data. This research presents a comparative analysis of various sophisticated DL architectures, including ResNet, Xception, Inception, and MobileNet, for the automated diagnosis and classification of lung illnesses using medical imaging modalities like as chest X-rays. A big open-access dataset is utilised by applying enhancement and preliminary processing techniques together to boost generalisability and robustness. Essential performance indicators like as F1-score, sensitivity, and accuracy are used to assess the models. The findings highlight the merits and limitations of each architecture and provide insights into their suitability for real clinical applications. This comparative investigation improves computer-aided diagnostic systems and supports progress in creating robust, interpretable, and clinically relevant AI techniques for pneumonia detection.

title: Development of a Wireless Image Monitoring System Powered by Energy Harvester
authors: Masahiko Ito, Norihiko Itoh, Shimpei Ono
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Micro and Miniature Power Systems, Self-Powered Sensors and Energy Autonomous Devices (PowerMEMS)
abstract: We prototyped a wireless image monitoring system capable of operating even with weak power sources generated by energy harvesters (EH). Power obtained from EH is temporarily stored in an energy storage device and supplies the necessary power for image capture and wireless transmission. The wireless image monitoring system operates regularly once per day and can perform additional operations upon receiving a request signal from the base unit. By optimizing the wake-up frequency for checking signals from the base unit, standby power consumption was maintained at an ultra-low 65 μW. Operational testing of the prototype system were conducted at a hydroelectric power plant, and it was found to be able to supply sufficient power for more than one month when using any of the EHs as a power source: thermoelectric, magnetic field, or window-side solar cell. This demonstrated the system's operational viability in real field conditions.

title: Incentive-Compatible Pricing for Truthful Data Sharing
authors: Mingjian Tang, Weiqi Wang, Shui Yu
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: With the rapid development of Artificial Intelligence, fake data are being generated and circulated on an unprecedented scale. While such data may be entertaining in some contexts, data collectors are generally reluctant to accept them due to concerns about service quality and security risks. A central challenge, therefore, is how to incentivise contributors to provide authentic data. Existing research has mainly focused on regulating the use of fake data, with limited attention to designing mechanisms that motivate contributors to share real data. In this paper, we propose a pricing strategy with an embedded incentive mechanism that ensures contributors obtain higher financial benefits from sharing real data rather than fake data. We formulate the problem as a Stackelberg game, where the data collector acts as the leader and contributors are the followers. To enhance reliability, we integrate a peer-review method to help verify data authenticity, which in turn informs the incentive-compatible pricing design. We establish the existence and uniqueness of the equilibrium solution, and further conduct numerical simulations to demonstrate the equilibrium-seeking process and the influence of key parameters.

title: Validation of a Governance Framework Supporting Security Controls across Emerging Systems
authors: Maysa Sinan, Mojtaba Shahin, Iqbal Gondal
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Effective integration of security controls is essential to safeguard organizational assets and ensure security compliance and operational resilience. In particular, organizations having DevOps often face critical challenges in the practical implementation and governance of these controls, which can significantly compromise their ability to maintain a robust security posture. In response to these challenges, a governance framework was developed to systematically address critical gaps; and guide security practitioners in integrating security controls throughout the Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC). Verifying this framework is critical to ensure its applicability and alignment with security requirements in dynamic IT environments. To achieve this, empirical validation and structured sessions were conducted with subject matter experts (SMEs) and experienced security practitioners. The sessions used real-world use cases and evaluation techniques to elicit feedback on the reliability, adaptability, and general effectiveness of the framework. This study outlines the results of the validation process and identifies potential enhancements to consider before the framework is deployed. The findings indicated that the framework is well-structured and aligned with industry best practices and security standards, such as NIST SP <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup> and ISO 27001 <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. In addition, all participants affirmed the comprehensiveness, traceability, and readiness of the framework for automation. It can be used effectively as a practical guide for managing security controls in both traditional and agile development environments. Ultimately, the insights gained from the feedback guided a series of refinements to improve the usability of the framework and ensure better alignment with the operational contexts of the real world.

title: Semantic-Graph-Indistinguishability: A Novel Approach to Location Privacy Protection Under Road Networks
authors: Sai Wang, Huijuan Lian, Lei Shi, Gaolei Li, Yan Cao
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: The core challenge in location privacy protection for location-based services (LBS) remains balancing location privacy and data utility. Differential privacy, backed by mathematical proofs, offers an effective framework for location protection. However, existing extended differential privacy methods for this purpose have some limitations. On one hand, most such methods focus on Euclidean spaces, making them ill-suited for road network-based LBS. They fail to align with road network contexts, potentially disrupting path planning, and often introduce excessive noise that inflates distance loss and degrades service quality. On the other hand, location semantics, a critical component of data utility, are frequently overlooked. Their degradation directly undermines utility. To address these issues, this paper introduces Semantic-Graph-Indistinguishability (SEM-G-IND) within the differential privacy paradigm, aiming to enhance location protection under road network and semantic constraints. First, a POI-based location semantic hash is designed to quantify location semantics. Then, integrating semantic distance and shortest path distance, a novel graph-based metric, Semantic-Graph-Distance (SGD), is proposed to measure inter-location distances. Finally, based on SGD, we propose a semantic penalty-based differential privacy (SPDP) location protection mechanism under road networks that satisfies ϵ-SEM-G-IND. We validated on real-world datasets that the SPDP mechanism effectively reduces the semantic loss of locations while ensuring minimal path distance loss, and it is feasible in terms of time overhead.

title: Diffusion Learning-guided Evolution for Large-scale Dynamic Multi-Objective Optimization
authors: Chenyang Li, Gary G. Yen, Zhenan He
abstract: Large-scale, dynamic multi-objective optimization problems (LSDMOPs) extend traditional DMOPs into high-dimensional decision spaces, reflecting the growing complexity of real-world dynamic systems. However, the effectiveness of existing dynamic multi-objective evolutionary algorithms is severely limited for LSDMOPs, due to inadequate training data, predictions in unknown environments, and large-scale dynamic search spaces. To address these challenges, we propose a diffusion learning-based evolutionary framework, inspired by the intrinsic analogy between iterative evolution of optimization search and stepwise denoising of diffusion model. Firstly, a new training paradigm is designed to treat evolutionary trajectories of population across environments as a learnable supervised source, thereby constructing rich training data to learn the changing patterns of optimal regions in dynamic fitness landscapes. Secondly, we introduce a trajectory alignment loss which encourages the stepwise denoising process to conform to the true population evolutionary behaviors in terms of spatial exploration, convergence trends, and boundary adaptation. Thirdly, a conditional diffusion model-based evolutionary strategy is proposed, which can gradually control denoising direction and intensity using predefined conditions, thereby generating optimization paths from noise toward Pareto-optimal solutions in a new environment. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework outperforms state-of-the-art designs on a typical dynamic multi-objective test suite and real-world large-scale dynamic scenarios.

title: Research on Trajectory Planning and Motion of a Hybrid-Structure Flexible Manipulator Using an Improved PSO Algorithm
authors: Jialin Sun, Haidong Hu, Zifeng Shen, Yu Jiang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: To solve the problem of residual vibration in hybrid-structured flexible manipulators during motion start-stop phases and to improve trajectory tracking accuracy under external disturbances, this paper proposes a control scheme combining improved particle swarm optimization (PSO)-based vibration suppression trajectory planning with a nonlinear disturbance observer (NDO)-based controller. Firstly, an improved PSO algorithm incorporating dynamic inertia weight, adaptive learning factors, and differential evolution mutation operations is designed. Combined with a non-uniform time interpolation strategy, it performs trajectory planning aimed at minimizing end-point vibration. To counteract external disturbances, a composite controller integrating a nonlinear disturbance observer (NDO) and sliding mode control (SMC) is developed to achieve real-time disturbance estimation and compensation. MATLAB simulation results demonstrate that: compared with standard PSO and other algorithms, the trajectory planned by the improved PSO algorithm significantly suppresses residual end-point vibration, accelerates convergence speed, and effectively restrains modal vibrations; the designed NDO-SMC controller enables both rotary and telescopic joints to track desired trajectories rapidly and without overshoot, while the NDO accurately estimated disturbances with minimal error. This study provides an effective integrated solution for highprecision, low-vibration control of hybrid-structure flexible manipulators.

title: Drivers of Digital Technology Adoption in MSME: A DEMATEL and ISM Approach
authors: A. Susanty, S.M.J Sihombingi, N.B.Puspitasari
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: The study examines the drivers of digital technology adoption among Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) in Semarang, the capital of Central Java Province, Indonesia, to reduce the digital divide. Based on a systematic literature review and validation process, this study identifies 14 primary drivers that influence digital adoption among MSMEs. Then, employing an integrated analytical framework that combines the Decision-Making Trial and Evaluation Laboratory (DEMATEL) and Interpretive Structural Modelling (ISM) methodologies, this study can identify the structural relationship between 14 drivers. The most pivotal driver is the level of trust in the security and effectiveness of digital technology, as well as the expected long-term strategic benefits. Other essential drivers include technical readiness for digitalization, the digital competencies of human resources, and the willingness of all parties in MSMEs to actively engage in the digitalization process. This comprehensive analysis highlights the interrelationships between these drivers and provides insights into proposed strategy recommendations that promote digital adoption in the MSMEs sector.

title: Rule-Based Clustering and Decision Tree Approach for SCADA-Driven Early Fault Detection in Wind Turbines
authors: Kaouthar Othmani, Ayman AlQattan, Ahmed Hafaifa, Abdelhamid Iratni, Nassr allah Guezouli, Nadji Hadroug
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: Reliable wind turbine operation requires timely fault detection before minor anomalies evolve into costly failures. Conventional threshold-based alarms typically react only after a fault occurs, limiting opportunities for preventive maintenance. This paper proposes a rule-based fault detection framework driven by SCADA data, combining reference modeling, wind-speed clustering, and decision-tree logic to enhance interpretability and diagnostic precision. The method establishes reference profiles for power, rotational speed, temperature, and pitch angle across different aerodynamic operating zones, derived from manufacturer specifications. Deviations from these references are converted into severity indices that highlight abnormal behavior. Applied to a Siemens Gamesa G97 2 MW turbine, the framework detected consistent deviations in key parameters shortly before the built-in alarms were triggered. Future work will focus on integrating data-driven approaches to further improve predictive accuracy and adaptability.

title: Efficient and Secure Spatial Keyword Similarity Query with User Preference
authors: Shen Du, Xinrui Ge, Chengliang Tian
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Most existing privacy-preserving spatial keyword query schemes rely on exact keyword matching, which cannot effectively capture the keyword relevance between user queries and spatial objects. Moreover, they often neglect the individual preferences of users for different keywords. To overcome these limitations, we propose SSKQ-UP, a novel and efficient privacy-preserving spatial keyword query scheme that supports personalized ranking. The index structure of SSKQ-UP is an R-tree based on Geohash code, called HR-tree. The internal nodes of HR-tree store Geohash codes to achieve rapid spatial pruning. The leaf nodes store the Geohash code of the spatial objects and the Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF) vectors, facilitating filtering based on the spatial range and keywords. Users can submit queries with weight vectors to reflect their keyword preferences. The cloud computes cosine similarity between the query weight vector and the TF-IDF vectors of candidate objects to identify the top-k most relevant results. To ensure privacy, both index and query vectors are encrypted using an Enhanced Asymmetric Scalar Product Encryption (EASPE) algorithm. Security analysis confirms that the proposed scheme is IND-CPA secure. Extensive experiments validate the practicality and efficiency of our scheme, demonstrating superior performance compared to existing methods.

title: Robust Optimization of an Electric Vehicle Powertrain Mounting System Based on an Adaptive Subinterval Method
authors: Jie Wu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: For the uncertainty parameters of electric vehicle powertrain mounting system (PMS) due to manufacturing, installation errors and material aging, a robust optimization is investigated on the inherent characteristics of the PMS. The interval number is used to describe the uncertain parameters. The inherent characteristics are expanded by single-point Taylor series for each interval parameter, and a high-precision approximation of the inherent characteristics is given, which can significantly reduce the truncation error and does not need to calculate the derivative. Based on the convergence criterion for calculating the variation interval of the inherent characteristics, the interval parameters with large uncertainty are adaptively divided into several sub intervals, and the inherent characteristics at the characteristic intersection of the sub intervals are calculated and the high-precision variation interval is obtained. Then, a robust optimization model of the PMS inherent characteristics is established and solved. The method is verified by the variation range calculation and robust optimization of the inherent characteristics of an electric vehicle PMS.

title: Recipient-Agnostic Hash Locks for Cross-Chain Auctions with Bitcoin Bidding
authors: Fuyang Deng, Qianhong Wu, Bo Qin
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Cross-chain auction is a promising paradigm for enabling on-chain price discovery across blockchain systems. While existing bridge solutions can functionally support cross-chain auctions, their deployment across heterogeneous blockchains remains challenging. In addition, conventional hash time-lock contracts (HTLCs) inherently predetermine the receiver, making them incompatible with the flexible recipient assignment required in auction settings. In this paper, we propose recipient-agnostic hash locks (RAHL), a new primitive that extends the HTLC framework to support dynamic recipient selection. By leveraging adaptor signatures and the UTXO model, we construct mutually exclusive pre-payments that allow multiple potential receivers to participate, while ensuring that only one is ultimately finalized. Furthermore, we embed adaptor signatures with polynomial commitments such that the secret revealed during settlement encodes recipient information, thereby enabling recipient-agnostic functionality. We formally model RAHL under a rational cross-chain communication (CCC) setting, and prove that it satisfies effectiveness and atomicity, while providing resilience against front-running and temporary censorship attacks. Experimental results demonstrate that RAHL primitive supports auctions between Bitcoin and Ethereum, reducing cross-chain settlement overhead by 33% compared to representative light-client approaches.

title: Intelligent Temperature Prediction of Shale Oil Stations Based on VMD-CNN-LSTM
authors: Honghong Li, Lihui Zheng, Xiangchun Wang, Peng Zhang, Binbin Qi, Xueqian Zuo, Shuaishuai Nie
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: The present study proposes a novel intelligent temperature prediction method to address low temperature control accuracy and high energy consumption caused by the complex production process and strong coupling and nonlinearity of the thermal systems in shale oil stations. Firstly, the Variational Mode Decomposition (VMD) algorithm was used to decompose the original temperature series into multiple modal components. Subsequently, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) were employed to extract spatial features of each component, which were input into Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks to capture temporal dependencies. Finally, the predicted results of each component were aggregated and reconstructed to obtain the final temperature prediction. The prediction accuracy was evaluated using Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Root Mean Square Error (RMSE), and the coefficient of determination ($\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$). The results show that the VMD-CNN-LSTM combined model offers high prediction accuracy, strong robustness, and excellent noise resistance. Compared to the CNN-LSTM model, the MAE and RMSE were decreased by $48 \%$ and $45 \%$, respectively, and the $\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$ value was closer to 1.0. This method demonstrates significant practical value for temperature control and safe operation in shale oil stations, providing theoretical support for their optimization.

title: Effects of customization and body movement of AI-driven virtual doctors on user experience in varied healthcare consultation scenarios
authors: Wenjie Zhang, Da Tao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: The application of AI-driven virtual doctors in healthcare faces challenges of user distrust and poor experience. This study aimed to examine how customization and body movement of AI-driven virtual doctors affect user experience in healthcare consultation scenarios. A three-factor within-subjects experimental design was employed, where 32 young participants were asked to interact with different virtual doctors, varying by customization, body movement, and disease scenarios. The results showed that customization reduced the total visit count and cognitive load, increased the attention; body movement increased the total visit duration and total visit count, improved experience scores, and enhanced anthropomorphic performance; high-risk scenarios increased average pupil diameter. There was an interaction effect with body movement and disease scenario; anti-customization in high-risk scenarios triggered an alert reaction; disease scenarios significantly affects doctor-patient trust and cognitive experience; users demand more professionalism from the virtual doctor in high-risk scenarios. The findings provide practical implications for designing user-friendly AI-driven virtual doctor consultations.

title: Tell-Tale Watermarks for Explanatory Reasoning in Synthetic Media Forensics
authors: Ching-Chun Chang, Isao Echizen
abstract: The rise of synthetic media has blurred the boundary between reality and fabrication under the evolving power of artificial intelligence, fueling an infodemic that erodes public trust in cyberspace. For digital imagery, a multitude of editing applications further complicates the forensic analysis, including semantic edits that alter content, photometric adjustments that recalibrate colour characteristics, and geometric projections that reshape viewpoints. Collectively, these transformations manipulate and control perceptual interpretation of digital imagery. This susceptibility calls for forensic enquiry into reconstructing the chain of events, thereby revealing deeper evidential insight into the presence or absence of criminal intent. This study seeks to address an inverse problem of tracing the underlying generation chain that gives rise to the observed synthetic media. A tell-tale watermarking system is developed for explanatory reasoning over the nature and extent of transformations across the lifecycle of synthetic media. Tell-tale watermarks are tailored to different classes of transformations, responding in a manner that is neither strictly robust nor fragile but instead interpretable. These watermarks function as reference clues that evolve under the same transformation dynamics as the carrier media, leaving interpretable traces when subjected to transformations. Explanatory reasoning is then performed to infer the most plausible account across the combinatorial parameter space of composite transformations. Experimental evaluations demonstrate the validity of tell-tale watermarking with respect to fidelity, synchronicity and traceability.

title: Toxic Ink on Immutable Paper: Content Moderation for Ethereum Input Data Messages (IDMs)
authors: Xihan Xiong, Zhipeng Wang, Qin Wang, William Knottenbelt
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Decentralized communication is becoming an important use case within Web3. On Ethereum, users can repurpose the transaction input data field to embed natural-language messages, commonly known as Input Data Messages (IDMs). However, as IDMs gain wider adoption, there has been a growing volume of toxic content on-chain. This trend is concerning, as Ethereum provides no protocol-level support for content moderation.We propose two moderation frameworks for Ethereum IDMs: (i) BUILDERMOD, where builders perform semantic checks during block construction; and (ii) USERMOD, where users proactively obtain moderation proofs from external classifiers and embed them in transactions. Our evaluation reveals that BUILDERMOD incurs high block-time overhead, which limits its practicality. In contrast, USERMOD enables lower-latency validation and scales more effectively, making it a more practical approach in moderation-aware Ethereum environments.Our study lays the groundwork for protocol-level content governance in decentralized systems, and we hope it contributes to the development of a decentralized communication environment that is safe, trustworthy, and socially responsible.

title: ST-SSNet: Spatio-temporal feature fusion-based DOA estimation network for underwater array signals
authors: Jiayang Song, Qiuna Niu, Lingwei Xu, Haoyu Tian, Yulei Yang, Shuzhuo Chen, Jingjing Wang
abstract: For Underwater Internet of Things (UIoT) applications, the accurate and efficient estimation of the direction of arrival (DOA) is fundamental to technologies such as node localization and autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) node cooperative communication. However, the low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) and limited energy in underwater environments pose severe challenges to DOA estimation. Furthermore, existing methods typically require a large number of snapshots. To address these issues, this paper proposes the use of an adaptive wavelet denoising model to enhance the quality of underwater acoustic signals. Subsequently, a dual-branch space-time state space network (ST-SSNet) is proposed. This network consists of a time feature extraction branch (TFEB) and a space feature extraction branch (SFEB). The time branch incorporates gating units and time mixing functions into the state space model (SSM) within the Mamba framework to extract temporal features. The spatial branch uses one-dimensional convolutions in different directions and the convolutional block attention module (CBAM) to extract spatial features. Extensive simulation and sea trial experiments demonstrate that ST-SSNet outperforms other deep learning methods in various scenarios, while having lower computational complexity than other methods. Compared to ResNet18, the accuracy improves by 2.14%, and RMSE is reduced by 43.4%.

title: Study on the Curing Kinetics and Multiphysics Simulation of New Highly Degradable Epoxy Resin for Dry-type Transformer
authors: Jiaxin Liu, Li Zhang, Yiwei Wang, Junpeng Ji
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Under the “dual carbon” strategy, the environmental friendliness of power equipment is gradually receiving attention. The insulation of dry-type transformers is cast using materials such as epoxy resin; however, traditional epoxy resins suffer from poor degradation and difficulty in recycling. This paper synthesizes highly degradable epoxy resins based on ester exchange reactions, studies their curing kinetics through non-isothermal DSC, and establishes a dual-parameter autocatalytic model. A three-dimensional thermal-mechanical coupled model is constructed using COMSOL Multiphysics simulation software to analyze and compare the temperature, degree of cure, and residual stress during the curing process of high-degradation epoxy resins and traditional epoxy resins in dry-type transformers.

title: Variability in Fetal Movement Patterns Captured by Different Wearable Sensors
authors: Abhishek K. Ghosh, Mikdam-Al-Maad Ronoue, Ravi Vaidyanathan, Niamh C. Nowlan
abstract: Fetal movement (FM) patterns serve as crucial biomarkers of fetal health. However, the reliance on intermittent, in-clinic ultrasound assessments has restricted our ability to track the longitudinal progression of FM patterns. Although wearable FM monitors could address this gap, the interpretation and standardization of wearable sensor-detected FM patterns have been severely complicated by the lack of commercial solutions and inconsistencies in sensor types, algorithmic settings, and validation protocols across different studies. This study presents a comparative analysis of in-home monitored longitudinal FM patterns concurrently captured by the three most prevalent wearable sensing modalities: accelerometer, acoustic sensor, and piezoelectric sensor. Additionally, we propose a novel algorithm to automatically separate fetal hiccups, which can confound the interpretation of FM patterns. Five pregnant women participated in this study, providing 31 hours of longitudinal in-home FM recordings between 25–38 weeks of gestation. The results demonstrated significant differences (p < 0.05) in FM patterns across sensor types for most biophysical properties, except for the incident rate (FMs/hour), suggesting that the incidence rate may serve as a relatively robust metric across sensor types. The proposed hiccup detection algorithm demonstrated strong agreement with maternally detected fetal hiccups (F1 score ranging from 0.5–0.8 across sensor types) and the resulting hiccup rates (0.1–0.19 bouts/hour across sensor types) aligned well with the established literature (0.17–0.2 bouts/hour), validating the algorithm. These findings underscore the feasibility of our wearable system for longitudinal, in-home FM monitoring and lay the groundwork for standardizing FM assessment.

title: Robust Synthetic Air Data Estimation via Kalman-Aided Deep Learning Approach for Analytical Redundancy
authors: Hyuntae Bang, Angelo Lerro, Wonkeun Youn, Hyojung Ahn
abstract: Reliable air data is essential for safe and stable flight operations. However, physical air data sensors are susceptible to failure due to environmental disturbances, especially in ultralight manned aircraft where hardware redundancy is often impractical due to strict size, weight, and power constraints. Although model-based synthetic air data systems (SADS) have been proposed to reduce sensor reliance, they require precise aerodynamic coefficients and are sensitive to modeling errors. To address these limitations, this study proposes a lightweight, data-driven SADS framework based on a hybrid deep learning model that combines temporal and trend-based features. An unscented Kalman filter (UKF) is applied as a post-processing step to enhance robustness against noise and anomalous inputs. The system is trained and validated on real-world flight data and demonstrates improved accuracy and stability over conventional deep learning baselines. These results suggest that the proposed method offers a robust and complementary alternative to model-based SADS, particularly in resource-constrained flight environments.

title: Scalable Distance-aware Fuzzy Private Set Intersection
authors: Zhenyu Xiong, Kai Chen, Xingwei Ren, Yongqiang Li, Mingsheng Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Fuzzy Private Set Intersection (FPSI) is a cryptographic protocol that extends traditional PSI to enable privacy-preserving similarity matching, allowing the receiver to learn elements from the sender’s set with "δ − close" of the receiver’s elements, computing {y<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">j</inf> | dist(x<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">i</inf>, y<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">j</inf>) ≤ δ, x<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">i</inf> ∈ X, y<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">j</inf> ∈ Y } where δ is predefined threshold. However, the current state-of-the-art integer-based approach by Chakraborti et al. (USENIX’23) suffers from excessive computation overhead, large communication costs, and limited scalability, hindering practical deployment.We construct two semi-honest $\Pi _{{\text{FPSI}}}^{{\text{int}}}$ for different scenarios. Along with compact Prefix Trie preprocessing, for the balanced settings, we propose $\Pi _{{\text{FPSI}}}^{{\text{OKVS}}}$ leveraging OKVS and subVOLE. For unbalanced scenarios, we introduce $\Pi _{{\text{FPSI}}}^{{\text{HE}}}$ protocol combining optimization techniques including Paterson-Stockmeyer algorithms and multiple algorithmic improvements.We implement our protocols in C++ using 32-bit IPv4 and 128-bit IPv6 addresses across balanced and unbalanced scenarios under single-threaded LAN environment. our balanced $\Pi _{{\text{FPSI}}}^{{\text{OKVS}}}$ protocol achieves 24.7-58.4× computational speedup across all scales and 9.9× communication reduction compared to Chakraborti et al. (USENIX'23) for datasets up to 1 million addresses. For unbalanced scenarios, our $\Pi _{{\text{FPSI}}}^{{\text{HE}}}$ protocol demonstrates superior scalability, enabling mobile devices with only 4K datasets against 16 million server elements in 56.74 seconds with 22.8 MB communication, achieving 2.8-38.5× speedup over the (USENIX'23).

title: A Reinforcement-Learning Logic Synthesis Framework and Its Integration into the EDA Flow
authors: Yicheng Duan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Classical logic synthesis is driven by hand-crafted flows and local heuristics. As circuits scale and constraints tighten, static recipes struggle to balance area, power, and delay while keeping iteration time acceptable. This paper proposes a reinforcement-learning (RL) logic synthesis framework that treats key synthesis steps as decision nodes in a Markov decision process. A deep Q-network (DQN) agent observes netlist/state features and selects transformations such as balance, rewrite, refactor, resub, and $d c 2$. A composite reward turns area, power, delay, and runtime into a single signal. Integrated into a standard Yosys → ABC flow, the agent learns flow policies that adapt to circuit structure. On ISCAS’89, the framework reduces average area by 15.6%, power by 12.8%, delay by 9.2%, and synthesis iteration time by 30.7% over strong baselines. Results show that learning-based flow control can deliver stable multi-objective gains with modest engineering effort.

title: Electrodermal Activity and Sweat Rate Sensing Technologies for Occupational Health Monitoring: A Systematic Review
authors: Sarah Tonello, Nicola Berti, Mattia Guidolin, Emilio Sardini, Nicola Francesco Lopomo
abstract: The human centered paradigm of the Industry 5.0 framework has boosted the demand of wearable sensing technologies able to monitor operators’ health, safety, and well-being. Among the most suitable physiological signals, Electrodermal Activity (EDA) and Sweat Rate (SR) stand up as suitable candidates for detecting conditions of stress, fatigue, and workload in occupational contexts. Despite sensing approaches for both EDA and SR have been widely investigated from both research and application perspectives, a limited comprehensive classification and analysis in terms of design, characterization protocols and performances can be highlighted. This systematic review aims to fill this gap analyzing the last decade of literature concerning the use of EDA and SR as tools to monitor operators. The analysis performed spans across applications, sensing technologies, testing protocols, signal processing, as well as multimodal integration. Each of these classes is deeply analyzed in order to compare information regarding both commercial devices and custom-built solutions, with particular attention to novel approaches exploiting flexible electronics, advanced materials, and microfluidics. Results obtained showed promising adoption in sectors such as construction, agriculture, manufacturing, and office work, with persistent challenges in terms of heterogeneous testing protocols, lack of standardized metrics for reliability and usability, motion artifacts, comfort, battery life, and user compliance. One of the major trends is represented by integration of EDA/SR with other biosignals—such as HRV, EEG, and skin temperature—enabling more robust and accurate detection of stress and emotional states through multimodal approaches. The discussion and conclusion of this review outlines current advances and identifies future directions to guide the development of user-centric, multimodal monitoring systems for occupational health.

title: Optimal Job Scheduling in Real-Time Cyber-Physical Systems: A Soft-Computing Approach
authors: Daniele Masti, Francesco Smarra, Francesco Basciani, Paolo Serri, Patrizio Pelliccione
abstract: Real-time cyber-physical systems in aerospace and other safety-critical domains require deterministic task execution under strict certification constraints. Although static time-triggered scheduling fulfills these requirements, its manual configuration remains error-prone and limits scalability. This article proposes an automated framework that generates optimized schedules for fixed-priority, fully preemptive systems based on the Thales Alenia Space—Italia real-time platform. A simulator that replicates the scheduling semantics of the target platform is implemented, enabling precise analysis and validation of a given schedule plan. The scheduling problem is formulated as a bilevel optimization solved via soft-computing techniques, while a complementary mixed-integer linear programming formulation provides performance bounds. The approach is validated on an industrial satellite case study, demonstrating a significant reduction in preemptions and improved timing consistency compared to manually engineered schedules.

title: Optimization of Maintenance Scheduling for Wind Farms Using Genetic Algorithm
authors: Amar Souissi, Tahar Benmessaoud, Djaidir Benrabeh, Bachir Naas, Abderrahmane Amari
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: Wind energy has become a cornerstone of renewable power generation, yet its long-term sustainability strongly depends on efficient maintenance strategies. Conventional periodic maintenance often results in excessive interventions or unexpected failures, both of which reduce system availability and increase costs. This paper proposes an optimization framework for wind farm maintenance scheduling based on a Genetic Algorithm (GA). The model minimizes the overall maintenance cost by jointly considering repair operations and downtime losses under reliability constraints. A simulation study of a 10-turbine wind farm over a 12-month horizon shows that the GA-based approach reduces total cost by nearly 30% compared with fixed-interval strategies. These results underline the potential of heuristic optimization in improving both the economic and operational performance of wind energy systems.

title: Optimizing DRAM Chip Treatment Selection by Enhanced Robust Reinforcement Learning with Decision Regime in Progressive Decision-Making Data.
authors: H.Y. Yi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: The test process of DRAM is sequential and structured in stages. Engineers make decisions at each stage to select chip control conditions that ultimately produce a superior final outcome, Y. However, relying solely on engineers’ experience at each decision-making stage to achieve the best final performance is challenging to assess comprehensively based on data. This study extracts a decision-making regime that can guarantee the highest performance from the initial decision stage by leveraging backward Q-learning when multiple decision-making stages are involved. By incorporating IPTW, regret, and blip fitting methods, the enhanced reinforcement learning algorithm addresses challenges such as high dimensionality and model fitting difficulties in panel non-randomized sequential data. In various simulation environments, the estimates demonstrated robustness and the potential to extend to different regression models and feature variables using intuitive concepts. Ultimately, the algorithm successfully selects control conditions that enhance the predictability of the final Y value with shorter fitting times, achieving higher improvements than previously possible.

title: Locating Emergency Flood Shelters Using P-median Method
authors: Wichitsawat Suksawat Na Ayudhya
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Strategically located as gateway to northeast and part of the East-West Economic Corridor, Nakorn Ratchasima is a major industrial and transportation hub in Thailand. However, during monsoons season, this province experiences with flooding, impacting both residents and industries. This work aims to help the decision maker to determine the location of emergency flooding shelters beforehand. We apply the scenario-based P-median model. The 5-year historical data of population and travel distance data in each district were used. Additionally, we investigated three test scenarios to find a contingency plan to handle flooding when some emergency flooding shelters are not available and the redundancy of emergency flooding shelter is required.

title: MSG-ImDiffusion: Multi-Scale Spatio-Temporal Diffusion Modeling for Anomaly Detection in Microservice Systems
authors: Ruoyao Zhang, Yuchun Guo, Yishuai Chen, Zhong Cao
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: With the rapid advancement of cloud computing technologies, microservice architectures have emerged as the de facto standard for modern software systems. However, their highly dynamic and complex nature poses significant challenges for anomaly detection. Although recent diffusion-based models have demonstrated promising capabilities in modeling multi-variate time series, they often overlook the inherent multi-scale spatiotemporal correlations present in microservice systems. This oversight limits their capacity to fully capture system-wide behaviors, thereby constraining detection performance. To address this issue, we propose a novel framework for anomaly detection based on imputed diffusion models, termed Multi-Scale Graph Imputed Diffusion Model. Building upon the imputation–reconstruction paradigm of standard ImDiffusion, our approach introduces a multi-scale spatiotemporal correlation module that is seamlessly integrated into the denoising network. This module employs parallel multi-scale graph convolutions and temporal convolutions to explicitly capture inter-service spatial dependencies from the microservice dependency graph and multi-granular temporal dynamics from service metric time series. By conditioning the diffusion process on richer spatiotemporal contexts, MSG-ImDiffusion enhances the model’s sensitivity to anomalies that deviate from expected temporal and spatial patterns. Extensive experiments conducted on the open-source HipsterShop microservice benchmark demonstrate that our proposed model significantly outperforms existing baselines, including ImDiffusion, in terms of both detection accuracy and F1-score. These results validate the effectiveness of incorporating multi-scale spatiotemporal information into diffusion-based anomaly detection frameworks for microservice systems.

title: Untangling the Links: Supply Chain Bottlenecks and Export Challenges in Indonesia’s Pulp and Paper Industry
authors: M. P. E. Tarigan, T. M. Simatupang, L. Okdinawati
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: This paper explores critical supply chain bottlenecks hindering the export competitiveness of Indonesia’s pulp and paper industry, with a focus on Riau province in the post-pandemic era. While the COVID-19 crisis exposed global supply chain vulnerabilities, a significant research gap exists, as no prior studies have systematically applied Interpretative Structural Modelling (ISM) to analyze export bottlenecks within this specific sector in Indonesia. To fill this gap, this study introduces a novel application of ISM, a methodology to identify, analyze, and hierarchically structure these obstacles. The model’s structural input was derived from a two-round Delphi process involving 12 purposively selected experts, chosen for their extensive experience in logistics, production, and trade policy. Initial findings, enhanced by a MICMAC analysis, identify rising raw material costs, strict environmental regulations, inefficient domestic logistics, and evolving international trade policies as key bottlenecks with high driving power. ISM framework provides a structured understanding of their systemic impact. The result offer actionable insights for industry players and guide policymakers in prioritizing targeted strategies to enhance the resilience and global competitiveness of Indonesia’s pulp and paper sector.

title: Positioning Analysis in the Construction Market based on the Structural Equations Model (SEM)
authors: Andrea Mora-Mora, Gabriela Araujo-Ochoa, Javier Cabrera-Mejía
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Market positioning is of utmost importance for a construction company as it is essential for its success and sustainability, helping to win projects, attract clients, retain talent, improve profitability, and build a solid image in a highly competitive industry. This document seeks to develop a model to evaluate construction companies' market positioning in Cuenca. A survey was carried out among experts using structural equations with the help of the Smart PLS software to achieve the goal. The majority of the experts surveyed, 73.3%, have postgraduate studies, which suggests that the research is based on the opinion of individuals with a high level of education and experience in the construction field. Through the analysis of structural equations, it has been identified that the positioning of construction companies is grouped into three fundamental categories: Perception, Motivation, and Attitude. These groups represent the essential pillars to measure and understand how these groups interact and relate to developing successful strategies in the construction industry.

title: Improving the Robustness of Generalized Extreme Value Distribution Estimation Using γ-Divergence
authors: A. Iwasaki, H. Iwamoto, Y. Nagata
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: This study aims to develop a robust method for estimating the upper quantiles of the generalized extreme value (GEV) distribution. Extreme value statistics are used to model infrequent extreme events that may cause major disasters. The primary objective is often to estimate the return level, and the analysis is performed using extreme value data such as block maximum data. Exceptionally large values among these extremes can be regarded as outliers. These outliers can significantly influence the estimated distribution, leading to substantial deviations in return level estimations. In Japan, the observation period for precipitation data is approximately 150 years, and the estimation results should not vary significantly depending on whether an outlier falls within the observed period. We focus on estimation based on γ-divergence—a robust estimation technique—and investigate its applicability and effectiveness in the estimation of the GEV distribution.

title: Identification Method for Vulnerable Nodes in Power Distribution Systems Based on Operational Status and Network Centrality
authors: Yafeng Wang, Jingda Gu, Zihan Zhang, Xiaotong Li, Yiting Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Identifying the vulnerable components of a distribution system under disaster conditions is a crucial aspect of power system security protection and disaster emergency response technology. The method for identifying these vulnerable components, based on scenario clustering and network centrality, includes: constructing a set of extreme disaster scenarios to simulate the failure process of distribution equipment under heavy rainfall conditions; establishing a distribution system network model that incorporates distributed generation, energy storage, and loads, and calculating the state vulnerability index of each node under heavy rainfall scenarios by developing a maximum power supply capacity model; combining node degree centrality and betweenness centrality to compute the structural vulnerability index of each node; and integrating the state and structural vulnerability indices to form a comprehensive node vulnerability score. This approach enables a comprehensive and probabilistic assessment of the vulnerable components in a distribution system under extreme disasters, making it suitable for pre-deployment of emergency resources, optimization of grid structure, and development of islanding operation strategies.

title: Optimization Method for Wind Power Frequency Regulation Parameters Based on Coordinated Frequency Response Control
authors: Xiaohui Zhao, Laifu Ming, Tenglong Lu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Wind turbine units can participate in primary frequency regulation through the frequency control system. Their frequency response is related to the wind power output and the frequency regulation parameters. This paper proposes an optimization method for wind power frequency regulation parameters based on frequency response collaborative regulation. Under the optimal power flow framework, the frequency dynamic response and stability constraints of both synchronous generators and wind turbine units are integrated. By optimizing the frequency regulation parameters and unit output, the framework minimizes both the operating cost and the frequency regulation reserve cost. The differential algebraic equation is used to describe the relationship between wind power and frequency, and the dynamic power flow is introduced to describe the changes in node power and voltage after disturbances. The 3machine, 9-node simulation of the Western Systems Coordinating Council (WSCC) demonstrates that this method can effectively coordinate the response of frequency regulation resources. It maximizes the potential of wind power for frequency regulation, suppresses frequency drops, reduces the burden on synchronous machines, and lowers the risk of frequency instability.

title: Research on Load Transfer of Distribution Networks Based on Improved Reinforcement Learning
authors: Zhunan Jiang, Chenxu Zhao, Peng Ye, Shixuan Lu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Aiming at the new operational risks in the non-outage scenario of urban power grid N-1 faults, existing research has insufficient coverage and algorithms have limitations. This paper proposes a load transfer strategy integrating phased risk indicators and improved Reinforcement Learning. Adopting a progressive multi-agent framework, the strategy is verified based on the improved IEEE 30-bus system. The model converges after 300 training episodes: the number of risky substations approaches 0, the risky load is significantly reduced, and the safe operation level and economic benefits of the power grid are effectively improved.

title: PSO-LSTM Based SOH Estimation Method for Liion Batteries
authors: Jinqiao Du, Jie Tian, Bo Rao, Zhaojie Liang, Tengteng Li, Xiner Luo, Jiuchun Jiang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: The internal chemistry of Lithium-ion batteries is complex and the State of Health (SOH) of Lithium-ion batteries cannot be measured directly. Meanwhile, the energy storage efficiency of Lithium-ion batteries is high, but Lithium-ion batteries have problems such as range and safety, so the estimation of SOH of Lithium-ion batteries becomes an extremely important task. To enhance SOH estimation accuracy, this paper constructs a battery SOH estimation model based on an LSTM neural network optimized by PSO, utilizing health features extracted from the NASA dataset as training inputs. Test results demonstrate that the estimation error of this method remains within $3.5 \%$, significantly improving SOH prediction accuracy.

title: Ghost Vehicle: A Game-Theoretical Attack Strategy Targeting CAV Platoons
authors: Lanai Huang, Winston Ellis, Sana Belguith
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: With the rapid development of V2X and autonomous driving technologies, the security and stability of platoons based on Connected Autonomous Vehicles (CAVs) have become a critical research focus. However, these systems remain vulnerable when facing sophisticated attacks. In this study, we propose a Game Theory-based attack framework that introduces a Ghost Vehicle capable of executing three distinct attack modes, Leader Attack, Mid-Platoon Attack, and Follower Attack. Experimental results demonstrate that our attack effectively destabilizes the platoon during Leader Attack and Mid-Platoon Attack, while seamlessly integrating as a normal member during the Follower Attack. Unlike prior sensor-spoofing attacks that rely on hardware-intensive methods, the behavior of the Ghost Vehicle is dynamically controlled using Mode Predictive Control (MPC) and Finite State Machine (FSM), ensuring high efficiency with a maximum computation time of 40 seconds, which represents an average across multiple runs. Our attack modes are validated in a highway scenario, demonstrating the high effectiveness with low computational cost.

title: Improvement Targets Setting via Convex Combinations of Efficient DMUs in DEA-R
authors: Xu Wang, Hiroki Iwamoto, Takashi Hasuike
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: The DEA-R model integrates data envelopment analysis (DEA) with ratio (R) analysis, making it a suitable method for efficiency evaluation when ratio data is involved. However, a notable limitation within the DEA-R framework is the lack of established methods for setting improvement targets, which is a common feature in conventional DEA. Thus, this study aims to propose a novel method for setting improvement targets within the DEA-R framework. Grounded in the target-setting principles of conventional DEA, the proposed method determines improvement targets in DEA-R through convex combinations of efficient decision-making units. Consequently, this enables the provision of specific input and output improvement targets within DEA-R, similar to those in conventional DEA. Furthermore, the method offers a significant computational advantage, requiring only the solution of a system of linear equations.

title: A Trust-Based Data Quality Assessment Mechanism in Crowdsensing Services
authors: Hai Liu, YaDong Peng
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: In crowdsensing services, traditional trust evaluation methods struggle to assess user reliability when historical user records are lacking. Moreover, trust evaluation only infers reliability indirectly and fails to prevent collusive deception by malicious users. To address these issues, this paper proposes a trust-based data quality assessment mechanism. This mechanism models trust evaluation as a social exchange process between the platform and users, encompassing historical contributions, privacy utility, and data similarity-mitigating the cold-start problem to a certain extent. It employs local differential privacy to protect user data privacy while quantifying data similarity, balancing privacy protection levels with trust evaluation accuracy. Additionally, the mechanism integrates the Mann-Whitney U statistical method to test data consistency among users and applies locality-sensitive hashing to enhance testing efficiency. This filters out false user data and improves the accuracy of sensing task outcomes. Finally, theoretical analysis and experimental validation demonstrate that the proposed scheme is feasible and effective in executing sensing tasks, with the ability to effectively filter false data collusively uploaded by malicious users.

title: Optimizing Spectrum Sharing in Low-Altitude Intelligent Networks: A Model-Based Reinforcement Learning Approach
authors: Tianle Li, Qingyu Liu, Peixi Peng
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: The Low-Altitude Intelligent Network (LAIN) leverages cutting-edge Artificial Intelligence (AI) technologies to enable fast and reliable communications for Uncrewed Aerial Vehicles (UAVs), supporting the rapid growth of various low-altitude economy applications. However, as UAV deployments increase, the scarcity of spectrum resources has emerged as a critical bottleneck that severely limits the quality of service in LAIN. While Reinforcement Learning (RL) has shown promise in optimizing spectrum sharing and improving spectral efficiency of UAVs, existing RL-based methods suffer from high training costs and require extensive interactions with the environment to converge to near-optimal solutions. To address these challenges, we propose a novel model-based RL framework for dynamic spectrum sharing of UAVs in LAIN. Our approach employs a world model to learn compact state representations and reconstruct environment dynamics, significantly enhancing the sample efficiency in complex scenarios. Extensive simulations demonstrate that our approach drastically reduces the number of environmental interactions required for UAVs to achieve near-optimal spectrum allocations, lowering training costs while maintaining high performance.

title: Evaluation of Automotive Maintenance Practice Firms in Selected Area in Lagos State
authors: Akinlo Olorunju Mogbojuri, Oludolapo Akanni Olanrewaju
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Automotive maintenance practice is the overhaul of industrial equipment or machinery to reduce production loss, and downtime. The Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP) is a technique used to evaluate automobile maintenance performance analysis in connection to utility maximization and social relevance. A structured questionnaire was created and with the use of Spice Logic, the weights, priorities, and priorities for the sub-criteria were calculated. The research indicated that reliability, engine type, tool type, and pricing are the paramount criteria for small-scale automotive maintenance enterprises, as they possess the greatest overall relative priority compared to other factors. It is proposed that the service business employ an AHP methodology or other evaluation methodologies to constantly evaluate and enhance efficiency and effectiveness. The evaluation of automotive maintenance practice allows the company to regularly track and compare its accomplishments in terms of operating strategies with rival outstanding companies.

title: PingCNN: A Low-Latent and Low-Cost Network for Mine Detection in Side Scan Sonar Signal
authors: Lakshmi Annamalai, Cris Benjamin, Faheema AGJ
abstract: Underwater mine detection using side scan sonar is of paramount importance to the safety of ships and submarines. Traditional 2-D mine detection algorithms are computationally intensive and induce substantial latency. Real-time operation of mine detection algorithms is essential, especially for underwater vehicles with limited computational capacity. To address this, we propose ping based convolutional neural network (PingCNN), a novel approach leveraging raw 1-D sonar pings, yet not explored in literature. We hypothesize that the characteristics of reflected pings are distinctive to the objects being scanned, thus employing a time series deep learning approach to advance underwater mine detection. PingCNN articulates mine detection as a detection-by-classification problem in a 1-D signal domain. In addition, we propose a novel likelihood-based sensitivity enhancer module, built with statistical and signal processing techniques, to mitigate false negatives. We have thoroughly validated the proposed approach using a custom data set recorded under different scenarios. Validation on a custom data set shows PingCNN performs comparably with 2-D methods, with minimal latency and computational requirements. In summary, PingCNN offers a low-latency, computationally efficient solution suitable for resource-constrained underwater vehicles.

title: Zero Trust-Based Dynamic and Continuous Access Control for Mobile Devices
authors: Xiaoya Cao, Zhenya Chen, Ming Yang, Xin Wang, Xiaoming Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Communication among mobile devices in the Inter-net of Things (IoT) typically relies on fixed security boundaries and centralized trust models, resulting in weak trust mechanisms, unauthorized access, and limited adaptability to dynamic environments. To address this, this paper proposes a zero-trust-based secure communication access control method that follows the principles of zero trust and least privilege, establishing a dynamic trusted framework encompassing identity authentication, real-time trust evaluation, multi-layer access control, continuous behavior analysis, and trajectory visualization. A dynamic trust evaluation model combining static attributes and historical interaction data is designed to ensure that only users who pass trust assessments are granted access. An interaction trust computation method incorporating direct trust, indirect trust, and a time-decay factor is introduced, along with a sliding window algorithm for dynamic threshold updates, enhancing responsiveness to changes in device behavior. A machine-learning-based continuous behavior monitoring mechanism is implemented to perform real-time modeling and detection of performance, traffic, and access patterns, improving anomaly identification and rapid response. The prototype system was validated through multi-device collaborative interaction simulations, demonstrating significant advantages in traffic anomaly detection and communication security over existing approaches.

title: Towards Stateless Post-Quantum Remote Attestation for IoT Using TPM and DICE
authors: Michael Eckel, Janik Gorbracht, Georgios Gkoktsis, Tobias Kaupat
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Remote attestation is a cornerstone of Trusted Computing, ensuring the integrity and trustworthiness of devices in diverse environments, ranging from resource-constrained IoT nodes to cloud-based virtual machines (VMs). The two predominant attestation technologies, the Trusted Platform Module (TPM) and the Device Identifier Composition Engine (DICE), provide strong security guarantees but often rely on stateful challenge-response models. These models introduce scalability challenges, particularly in large-scale Internet of Things (IoT) and smart metering deployments.This paper presents a powerful stateless post-quantum remote attestation approach for IoT devices, leveraging authenticated and encrypted (AEAD) challenges within TPM and DICE-based attestation. The stateless approach effectively limits replay attacks to a short validity window, even in environments where IoT devices lack real-time clocks, and enables robust integrity and trust verification across dynamic network topologies, by avoiding the downsides of other freshness concepts for remote attestation.Furthermore, this paper presents a performance evaluation of suitable post-quantum cryptography (PQC) algorithms across five heterogeneous hardware platforms, ranging from high-end laptops to constrained IoT devices, to present a recommendation to the reader, thereby illustrating the continued utility of remote attestation on IoT devices in the future.Our findings suggest that stateless post-quantum remote attestation can enhance security and scalability in IoT environments, by reducing overhead from storage of nonces making it a compelling alternative to traditional challenge-response models.
