title: Two-Phase Gaussian Processes Framework for Accelerated Degradation with Change-Point
authors: Siyi Chen, Yuan Li, Min Xie, Qingpei Hu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Degradation modeling plays a critical role in reliability analysis and prognostics for engineered systems operating under varying environmental conditions. Many real-world degradation processes exhibit a two-phase behavior characterized by an initial slow deterioration followed by accelerated decline, where the change point often depends on the applied stress. To address this phenomenon, We propose a stress-aware Gaussian process regression (GPR) framework for modeling two-phase degradation processes commonly observed in accelerated degradation testing (ADT). The model incorporates a piecewise mean function with a stress-dependent change point to capture early-stage decline and post-knee accelerated degradation. A composite covariance structure is adopted to jointly model temporal dynamics and stress-level correlations. To assess the model’s performance, we generate simulated degradation data that mimic lithium-ion battery aging under various temperature stresses. The results demonstrate the model’s extrapolated ability to accurately predict degradation behavior at unseen stress levels. These results highlight the potential of stress-aware GPR models in reliability applications requiring cross-stress prediction and early failure detection.

title: DCP-Guided One-Shot Remote Sensing Image Dehazing via Self-Supervised Redegradation Model
authors: Jianchong Wei, Yan Cao, Dongying Chen, Pingping Chen, Shahid Mumtaz, Hadeel Alsolai, Chengbin Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Haze often degrades remote sensing (RS) imagery, reducing contrast and obscuring structural details, which undermines the accuracy of downstream vision tasks. While recent one-shot dehazing methods offer improved generalization by training on a single image, they suffer from prohibitively slow convergence due to unstable optimization from random initialization. To address this, we propose a dark channel prior (DCP)-guided one-shot dehazing framework that integrates a non-trainable DCP module with a redegradation haze imaging model for self-supervised optimization. The key idea is to use the DCP module to provide stable initial estimates of the atmospheric light and transmission map, while two UNet-based subnetworks refine the dehazed image and transmission map under redegradation-based physical consistency constraints. An adaptive warm-up strategy is further introduced to prioritize DCP-regularized learning in the early stage and then gradually transition to full joint optimization as the network predictions stabilize. Extensive experiments on synthetic and real-world RS datasets show that, although our method does not achieve the highest Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR) compared with fully supervised Convolutional Neural Network (CNN)-based models trained on large paired datasets, it attains competitive Structural Similarity Index Measure (SSIM) and clearly better perceptual quality among one-shot and prior-based baselines, while significantly reducing training iterations compared with existing one-shot methods.Moreover, evaluations on a road extraction task demonstrate that the dehazed outputs notably enhance segmentation accuracy and robustness, confirming the practical value of the proposed framework for high-level RS vision applications where paired training data and long per-image optimization are impractical.

title: Hamster: Private Transformer Inference via Fully Homomorphic Encryption
authors: Huizhuo Wang, Zhiyong Zhang, Lei Ju
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Large transformer-based models have achieved remarkable performance in natural language processing and related fields, yet they pose significant privacy risks when handling sensitive data. Fully homomorphic encryption (FHE) offers a natural solution for private transformer inference: the client encrypts the input data, the server performs inference directly on ciphertexts, and the results remain encrypted until decrypted by the key holder. However, FHE struggles to efficiently support non-linear activation functions, and encrypted inference often incurs substantial performance overhead and degrades model accuracy. To address these challenges, we propose Hamster, an FHE-based private transformer inference system that protects both client and server privacy. Our contributions are twofold. First, Hamster introduces a comprehensive set of more efficient approximations for the costly nonlinear functions in transformer models, significantly reducing the performance overhead of homomorphic evaluation. Second, unlike some existing works that only support a limited set of nonlinear components, Hamster implements a complete end-to-end evaluation pipeline for private transformer inference. Extensive experiments demonstrate Hamster achieves an average inference time of approximately 12 minutes per token, with minimal loss in model accuracy. This performance outperforms BumbleBee (NDSS 2025) by 2.2× and NEXUS (NDSS 2025) by 1.2×, highlighting the effectiveness and practicality of our system.

title: FPGA-based Parallel Compressible Flow Solver Accelerator
authors: Songpei Li, Yubo Li, Feng Liu, Liang Zhao
abstract: Field-Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs), with their highly parallel computing capabilities and flexible hardware programmability, have emerged as a promising hardware platform for accelerating Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) simulations. To address the requirements of numerical solution for compressible flows, this study designs a compressible flow solver accelerator optimized for data-level parallelism and pipelining. The solver integrates custom modules for complex function evaluation to meet the hardware implementation requirements of complex function computations in CFD simulations. Numerical calculations are performed on the one-dimensional convection-diffusion problem and the Sod shock tube problem. The results demonstrate that the designed FPGA acceleration scheme yields accurate and reliable computational results, achieving an order-of-magnitude improvement in computational performance compared with the CPU platform.

title: Imperceptible Protection against Style Imitation from Diffusion Models
authors: Namhyuk Ahn, Wonhyuk Ahn, KiYoon Yoo, Daesik Kim, Seung-Hun Nam
abstract: Recent progress in diffusion models has profoundly enhanced the fidelity of image generation, but it has raised concerns about copyright infringements. While prior methods have introduced adversarial perturbations to prevent style imitation, most are accompanied by the degradation of artworks' visual quality. Recognizing the importance of maintaining this, we intro duce a visually improved protection method while preserving its protection capability. To this end, we devise a perceptual map to highlight areas sensitive to human eyes, guided by instance-aware refinement, which refines the protection intensity accordingly. We also introduce a difficulty-aware protection by predicting how difficult the artwork is to protect and dynamically adjusting the intensity based on this. Lastly, we integrate a perceptual constraints bank to further improve the imperceptibility. Results show that our method substantially elevates the quality of the protected image without compromising on protection efficacy.

title: Bibliometric Study on Knowledge Hiding and Innovation
authors: W. A. Amelia, N. Indarti, S. Sitalaksmi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: This study presents a bibliometric analysis of research examining the relationship between knowledge hiding and innovation. Drawing on 70 peer-reviewed articles published between 2014 and 2025, this review maps publication trends, theoretical lenses, research methods, contexts, and industrial sectors that have shaped the academic discourse. The findings reveal a significant increase in publications after 2021, with notable geographic concentration in Asia—particularly in China and Pakistan—accounting for over 50% of the studies. Despite the growing interest, the field is marked by fragmented theoretical approaches and a reliance on quantitative survey methods, with minimal use of qualitative or longitudinal designs. Moreover, research remains clustered in specific sectors such as information and communication technology and education. This review contributes to the literature by identifying critical gaps and proposing future research directions that emphasize theory integration, methodological diversification, and broader contextual exploration.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Order-picking Optimization with Dynamic Order Arrivals in Express Centers
authors: D. Y. Mo, Y.P. Tsang, Y. Wang, K.T. Chung, C.K.M. Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Quick commerce relies on ultra-fast and low-cost order fulfilment, yet its primary bottleneck is order picking at express logistics centers, where fragmented and time-critical requests must be consolidated and dispatched within hours. To address this challenge, this study proposes a deep reinforcement learning (DRL) approach that learns optimal postponement policies for express logistics center operations with dynamic order arrivals. Through simulation experiments, the proposed DRL approach is shown to achieve a cost saving of 14.6% compared to other heuristics under standard capacity conditions, and the cost-saving potential is inversely proportional to the available capacity. These results provide practical guidelines for optimizing the order-picking process using DRL technology.

title: Mechanical Transfer of 2D Graphene from Sapphire to Silicon Substrates
authors: George R. Teifel, Angel Mata, Sakineh Chabi
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Micro and Miniature Power Systems, Self-Powered Sensors and Energy Autonomous Devices (PowerMEMS)
abstract: We present a polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA)-assisted mechanical method for transferring two-dimensional (2D) graphene flakes from sapphire to silicon substrates. Unlike chemical etching approaches, this technique avoids contamination and preserves flake integrity. The process involves spin-coating PMMA, water-mediated delamination of the PMMA/graphene film, and alignment onto silicon. After acetone removal of PMMA and IPA rinses, optical microscopy confirms successful transfer at 10× and 100× magnification. The method is reproducible, clean, and scalable, enabling integration of graphene into microelectromechanical systems (MEMS), quantum sensors, and photonic devices, and is adaptable to other 2D materials such as silicon carbide.

title: GPEA: Grad-CAM-Guided Perceptibility-Reduced Ensemble Attack in Object Detection
authors: Zhengheng Li, Hui Xia, Rui Zhang, Mengyuan Song, Aoqi Ruan, Shaoqiang Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Black-box adversarial attacks bypass internal target model information, broadening their applicability and making them a critical area in deep learning security. However, most existing methods prioritize attack success over perturbation imperceptibility, resulting in visually detectable perturbations. Addressing this, we propose the Grad-CAM-guided Perceptibility-Reduced Ensemble Attack (GPEA), integrating ensemble learning and Gradient-weighted Class Activation Mapping (Grad-CAM) to improve both attack success and perturbation imperceptibility. GPEA comprises two modules: Dynamic Weight Ensemble (DWE) and Grad-CAM-Based Perturbation Restriction (GPR). DWE introduces a novel weight initialization and adjustment scheme, optimizing surrogate model contributions to enhance black-box attack success. GPR applies Grad-CAM to restrict perturbations to critical image areas, markedly reducing perceptibility. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of GPEA in balancing attack success and imperceptibility across various datasets and models. On VOC dataset, GPEA improves the black-box attack success rate by up to 8.4% over state-of-the-art methods; across five target models, it achieves average improvements of 18.5%, 16%, 36.4%, 33.9%, and 26.8% in SSIM, PSNR, LPIPS, ℓ<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</inf>, and ℓ<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> metrics, respectively.

title: Bio-Inspired Swarm Intelligence Approaches to Wireless Sensor Network Optimization: Innovations and Applications
authors: Taha Bachir Ammour, Mohammed Kaddi, Mohammed Omari
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) are a fundamental component of modern Internet of Things (IoT) systems, enabling large-scale data collection and real-time monitoring across domains such as smart cities, healthcare, and environmental monitoring. Whilst having wide applicability, WSNs are plagued by critical constraints on energy resources, network lifetime, and scalability. Traditional deterministic and accurate optimization methods are generally unable to handle these concerns due to the NP-hard nature of related problems such as clustering, routing, and node deployment. Metaheuristic algorithms are now a good alternative, offering near-optimal solutions at reasonable computational cost. Among these, bio-inspired metaheuristics such as Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), Ant Colony Optimization (ACO), and Genetic Algorithms (GA) have garnered significant attention because they are capable of mimicking natural processes and responding to dynamic systems. This work aims to provide a comprehensive overview of metaheuristic approaches for WSN optimization and provides their applications in clustering, routing, energy management, localization, and coverage. It also emphasizes the comparative analysis of the strengths and weaknesses of such algorithms and their performance.

title: An Integrated Dynamic Group Maintenance Strategy for Multi-Component Systems with Adaptive Bayesian Updates
authors: Yi Chen, Yuhan Ma, Yu Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: This paper proposes an integrated dynamic group maintenance strategy for multi-component systems, incorporating both preventive and opportunistic maintenance. The strategy dynamically updates maintenance schedules and decisions based on real-time inspection data, utilizing Bayesian parameter updating to enhance failure risk predictions. A Proportional Hazards Model (PHM) is employed to model component degradation and failure risks, and a Monte Carlo simulation is used for reliability analysis. The proposed strategy was compared with a traditional periodic maintenance approach, and the results demonstrate that the dynamic strategy significantly reduces maintenance costs. The findings suggest that integrating adaptive maintenance strategies based on component-specific conditions can improve system reliability while minimizing long-term maintenance expenses.

title: ANFIS-PSO model optimization for predicting the output parameters of a two-shaft gas turbine
authors: Abdelouahab Chebbah, Ahmed Hafaifa, Mourad Bachene, Abdellah Kouzou, Nadji Hadroug
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: Gas turbines exhibit strong nonlinear behavior, and reliable prediction of their main operating variables is crucial for supervision, diagnostics, and control. This work develops an Adaptive Neuro-Fuzzy Inference System (ANFIS) whose parameters are tuned by Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) to estimate four key outputs: compressor outlet pressure (P2), high-pressure turbine rotational speed (TNH), low-pressure turbine rotational speed (TNL), and exhaust gas temperature (T7). The fuzzy rule base is constructed from data using the Fuzzy C-Means (FCM) clustering algorithm and the resulting model is assessed on real operating measurements. The analysis of performance indices (MSE, RMSE, MAE, R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) shows that PSO-based optimization of ANFIS improves prediction quality compared with a standard ANFIS: for P2, MSE decreases from 0.0725 to 0.0648; for TNH, from 0.0035 to 0.0034; for TNL, from 0.5303 to 0.4908; and for T7, from 3.46×10⁻<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">9</sup> to 1.10×10⁻<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">10</sup>. The coefficient of determination R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> also increases for P2 (0.9311 to 0.9385), TNH (0.7493 to 0.7594), and TNL (0.8461 to 0.8576). In addition, lower RMSE values and reduced standard deviations over five-fold cross-validation for all outputs indicate that the proposed hybrid ANFIS–PSO scheme provides a robust and accurate representation of gas turbine dynamics.

title: A GMR-Based Smart Respiration Belt for Non-Invasive Real-Time Monitoring
authors: Aryan Sharma, Sayam Chakraborty, Thomaskutty Mathew, Siva Sankar Rusum, Satuluri Tejaswini, Abhay Renjith T J, Anoop C
abstract: Respiration rate (RR) is a vital physiological parameter, yet conventional measurement methods are often invasive, inaccurate, or unsuitable for continuous monitoring. This paper presents a wearable respiration monitoring belt for continuous and non-invasive measurement of breathing activity. The system employs a giant magnetoresistance (GMR) sensor with a paired neodymium magnet to detect chest movements, with the optimal spacing determined through finite element simulations. An instrumentation amplifier, equipped with a DC servo-loop, and a low-pass filter enable robust signal acquisition, while a microcontroller computes the respiration rate in real time. Validation on 12 healthy volunteers showed a maximum error of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\pm 2$</tex-math></inline-formula> breaths per minute compared with a BIOPAC reference, confirming accuracy and stability. Owing to its compact size, low power consumption, and skin-contact-free operation, the proposed system shows strong potential for applications in remote healthcare, sleep apnea detection, and automotive safety.

title: Image Based Air Quality Level Assessment Using MobileNet And ResNet152V2
authors: Prathik Kumaar.B, A.Deepak A. Deepak
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: Air is a fundamental resource for sustaining life, and maintaining its quality is vital for ensuring the well-being of people and the protection of the natural environment. Rising levels of pollution caused by rapid industrialization, vehicular emissions, and urban development have made air quality assessment a critical scientific and policy concern. In this work, we examine how deep learning techniques can be applied for accurate air quality level classification using image data caputured in various cities . Specifically, We conduct a performance comparison between two leading convolutional neural networks, MobileNetV2 and ResNet152V2. While both achieved notable improvements over traditional methods, MobileNetV2 proved to be the most effective, offering the highest classification accuracy along with better computational efficiency. Its lightweight architecture makes it well-suited for deployment in environments with limited resources and real-time processing requirements. The findings highlight the efficiency of deep learning in advancing air quality monitoring and suggest future improvements through hybrid models such as Inception-ResNet to enhance predictive capability and generalization across diverse environments.

title: Time-Optimal Trajectory of a Dubins Vehicle with a Controllable Laser
authors: Shivam Bajaj, Bhargav Jha, Shaunak D. Bopardikar, Alexander Von Moll, David W. Casbeer
abstract: We formulate a planar motion planning problem for a Dubins-Laser system that consists of a Dubins vehicle with an attached controllable laser. The vehicle moves with unit speed and the laser, having a finite range, can rotate in a clockwise or anti-clockwise direction with a bounded angular rate. From an arbitrary initial position and orientation, the aim is to steer the system so that a given static target is within the range of the laser and the laser is oriented at it in minimum time. We characterize multiple properties of the optimal trajectory and establish that the optimal trajectory for the Dubins-laser system is one out of a total of 16 candidates. Finally, we provide numerical insights that illustrate the properties characterized in this work.

title: From Text to STIX: Reducing Hallucinations through Fine-Tuned LLMs
authors: Ruoyao Xiao, Yu Luo, Weifeng Xu, Dianxiang Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: The Structured Threat Information Expression (STIX) standard has become essential for representing and sharing cyber threat intelligence (CTI). However, automatically generating valid and semantically consistent STIX objects remains challenging. Large language models (LLMs) often succeed at extracting low-level indicators but struggle with higher-level abstractions, leading to missing fields, invalid properties, and structurally inconsistent outputs. To address these issues, we propose a methodology that integrates instruction fine-tuning with a novel evaluation framework. Specifically, we fine-tune LLMs using curated text–STIX pairs and domain-specific instructions to internalize schema alignment and reduce hallucinations. We further introduce the Object and Properties Similarity Evaluation (OPSE), which measures both structural validity and semantic fidelity of generated STIX objects against expert ground truth. Experimental results show that our fine-tuned model substantially improves object coverage, property completeness, and structural accuracy compared with baseline prompting and existing STIX generation tools.

title: SCodeGen: A Real-Time Trustworthy Constrained Decoding Framework for Secure Code Generation with LLMs
authors: Muzi Qu, Jie Liu, Liangyi Kang, Shuyi Ling, Shuai Wang, Dan Ye, Tao Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Large language models (LLMs) are increasingly integrated into software development workflows to accelerate code generation, but often produce insecure and uncontrollable code due to vulnerable training data and unconstrained decoding strategies. This poses severe risks in security-critical systems, where post-generation vulnerability detection and manual remediation incur significant overhead. While constrained decoding offers a practical mitigation strategy, existing methods suffer from degraded trustworthiness, constraint conflicts, and high latency—especially when enforcing multiple concurrent security constraints.We propose SCodeGen, a real-time constrained decoding framework designed to enforce fine-grained security controls during LLM code generation. To improve trustworthiness and controllability, SCodeGen introduces (1) a matching-length-aware logit modulation strategy that enhances trustworthiness and controllability without semantic disruption, and (2) a two-stage low-latency decoding architecture, which compiles constraint phrases into a runtime-enforceable constraint automaton (RCA) with precomputed logit bias vectors for efficient online decoding. Extensive evaluations on CodeGuard+ show that SCodeGen significantly improves secure pass rates under both single and multi-constraint settings, while maintaining latency comparable to unconstrained decoding. This work demonstrates a practical and scalable solution toward trustworthy LLM-assisted software development under security constraints.

title: A Hybrid Deep-Machine Learning Approach to Diagnose Partial Shading and Short-Circuit Faults in Solar Photovoltaic Systems using Infrared Thermography Images
authors: Derradji Bakria, Ahmed Chennana, Ahmed Chaouki Megherbi, Noureddine Bessous, Ali Teta, Mohammed El Amine Mihoubi, El Ouanas Belabbaci, Belkacem Korich, Ridha Djamel Mohammedi, Ahmed Hafaifa
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: Photovoltaic (PV) systems represent a key solution to global energy security, yet the need for reliable fault diagnosis is an essential operational challenge, preventing significant degradation in energy harvesting efficiency and system performance. This research presents a novel hybrid diagnostic system based on transfer learning-based deep feature extraction and ensemble machine learning classification for partial shading (PS) and short-circuit (S-C) detection in PV arrays. Features are extracted from infrared thermography (IRT) images with three state-of-the-art pre-trained CNN architectures (ResNet50, MobileNetV2, and VGG16); then, the feature vector dimensionality is decreased by principal component analysis (PCA) technique and classified by XGBoost and SVM classifiers. Extensive experimental evaluation on a database of 2,249 thermal images reveals that the MobileNetV2-SVM combination performs the best with 97.56% classification accuracy, surpassing other model combinations. The proposed method enables real-time, non-invasive, and very reliable fault detection that can aid predictive maintenance actions that minimize downtime, decrease operational costs, and enhance energy yield in commercial and utility-scale PV power plants.

title: Solution Approaches and Comparative Analysis for Multi-Product Vehicle Routing Problems with Capacity Constraints under Demand Uncertainty
authors: Yumu Yasui, Takashi Hasuike
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: The objective of this study is to define a vehicle routing problem in which the demand at each location follows a normal distribution under the driver shortage conditions and to propose several formulations. To assume a driver shortage, the number of trucks is fixed to one, and the objective is to minimize the transportation cost, satisfy the demand, and increase the revenue in addition to minimizing the transportation cost. Then, the existing solution methods for each formulation and for a situation where multiple trucks can be used are run on multiple data sets with different characteristics, and a comparative analysis of the results is performed.

title: TSDAs: Enhanced Statistics-Based Query Recovery in Dynamic Searchable Symmetric Encryption via Probabilistic Modeling
authors: Yikang Fan, Xiaojie Zhu, Chi Chen, Yong Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Dynamic Searchable Symmetric Encryption (DSSE) schemes typically permit certain predefined leakages at runtime to ensure efficiency, such as the response/update volume and the response file volume. Query Recovery Attacks (QRAs) exploit such leakages, combined with auxiliary knowledge, to recover the user’s query contents. Powerful QRAs typically rely on the ground-truth knowledge of the dataset or queries. While QRA based on the weaker statistical knowledge, termed statistics-based QRA, is also possible, it yields lower accuracy and consequently is not considered a significant threat. In this work, we revisit statistics-based QRAs within the DSSE context and introduce a unified probabilistic optimization attack model. Building on this model, toward volumetric leakages, we develop Two-Stage Decode Attacks (TSDAs), which formulate the QRA as a Conditional Random Field (CRF) decoding problem and solve it through a two-stage optimization process. TSDAs not only generalize the state-of-the-art counterpart (i.e., LVIA, Xu et al., CCS 2023), but also significantly outperform it, even under more realistic and constrained leakage assumptions. Against traditional DSSE schemes lacking protection on response volume leakages, our attack achieves nearly 100% query recovery accuracy on the Lucene dataset under the same evaluation settings as Xu et al. In contrast, LVIA achieves only 77% accuracy. Even when applied to ShieldDB (Vo et al., TKDE 2023), which incorporates response volume obfuscation, our method maintains an accuracy at 50%, whereas LVIA drops sharply to just 0.2%. Our findings suggest that statistics-based QRAs pose a serious threat to DSSE schemes.

title: ETCFF: An Encrypted Traffic Classification Method Based on Fusion Features
authors: ZhiPeng Fu, FanPing Zeng
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: With growing awareness of user privacy and the widespread adoption of encryption tools such as SSL/TLS, VPN, and Tor, traditional traffic classification methods based on port analysis and deep packet inspection (DPI) have become increasingly ineffective. While conventional machine learning approaches can classify traffic using flow statistical features, they remain limited by their dependence on manual feature engineering and poor generalization capability. Deep learning techniques overcome these constraints by automatically extracting features and enabling early traffic classification. However, existing deep learning solutions still exhibit notable shortcomings: most rely exclusively on either flow-level or packet-level features, neglecting the complementary information present in the other dimension; furthermore, packet-level methods often mix header and payload data, risking violation of user privacy. To address these issues, this paper proposes a novel encrypted traffic classification method that effectively integrates both flow-level and packet-level features without relying on payload content. By introducing new techniques for feature extraction and fusion at both levels, our approach captures complex nonlinear relationships among features. Extensive evaluation on four public datasets demonstrates that the proposed method achieves high accuracy and significantly outperforms single-modal models.

title: Design of Intelligent Generation System for Power Grid Fault Reports Based on Multi-source Heterogeneous Data Fusion
authors: Meizi Hou, Baichi Ou, Xuanzhen Chen, Xianzheng Chen, Lijun Mo, Jiaxuan Tang, Ming Gao, Ziyi Li, Yuanfa Cen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Aiming at the problems in power grid fault report generation under the “dual carbon” background, such as insufficient fusion of multi-source heterogeneous data, frequent model hallucinations, and heavy reliance on manual work, this paper proposes an intelligent generation system for power grid fault reports based on multimodal fusion and domain knowledge enhancement. The system achieves a key feature extraction error of $\lt 1 \mathrm{~ms}$ for fault record graphs by constructing a unified representation model for multi-source data and an “OCR+CNN” dual-channel image parsing algorithm; suppresses model hallucinations and ensures the logical consistency of reports by relying on a domain knowledge-enhanced RAG-LLM collaborative framework; and completes the full-process automation from fault data collection and information retrieval to report generation by combining a multi-level retrieval strategy and standardized templates. Experimental verification shows that the system can improve the fault report generation efficiency to the minute-level, outperforming traditional manual methods in data fusion accuracy, image recognition accuracy, and language logic. It successfully realizes the transformation of fault reports from “manual experience” to “intelligent generation”, providing highly reliable intelligent support for power grid dispatching and operation inspection.

title: Enhancing Medication Recommendation with LLM Text Representation
authors: Shih-Wen Ke, Yu-Tzu Lee, Ling-Chien Hung
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Most existing medication recommendation models rely heavily on structured data such as diagnosis and procedure codes, often overlooking the wealth of clinical information embedded in unstructured text. To better exploit this data, we propose enhancing medication recommendation using text representations derived from Large Language Models (LLMs). These representations capture semantic and contextual information from clinical notes and doctors’ narratives, enabling deeper integration of free-text and coded EMR data. We incorporate LLM-derived embeddings into several baseline models and evaluate performance on two datasets: the public MIMIC-III and a real-world inpatient dataset from Ditmanson Medical Foundation Chia-Yi Christian Hospital in Taiwan. Experimental results show consistent performance gains across models when LLM-based text representations are used, with some models achieving results comparable to or better than using medical codes alone. Our findings demonstrate that LLM-enhanced representations offer a scalable and model-agnostic approach for leveraging unstructured data in clinical decision support.

title: A Robust Federated Learning Framework Integrating Principal Component Analysis and Dual Detection Mechanisms
authors: Lina Ge, JianWei Zhai, Qinchun Su
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Federated learning (FL) enables collaborative training of global models with local data, preserving privacy. However, its parameter update process exposes it to Byzantine attacks by malicious clients, degrading model performance. We propose FedPMR: first, PCA reduces dimensionality of client-uploaded parameters to lower clustering costs; second, a dual detection module identifies anomalies via global deviation and local structural similarity; finally, a robust aggregation module integrates detection results with historical scores to determine client weights. Experiments show FedPMR effectively suppresses malicious clients, maintains accuracy, reduces overhead, and exhibits strong robustness and adaptability.

title: Collaborative Autonomous Truck and Electric Tricycle delivery for Inventory Routing Problems
authors: S. H. Lu, R. Raj, C. C. Chang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: As profit margins are extremely narrow and the retail industry is more competitive than ever, it is therefore crucial that business operations be carried out as cheaply as possible. One such strategy for the logistics sector is the integration of autonomous vehicles into the delivery cycle, as their per-mile transportation costs are far lower than those of trucks, which are the conventional delivery mode. In the traditional contexts of the vehicle-routing problem (VRP), collaborative delivery has been the subject of much research over the years. In this research, we propose an investigation into the integration of autonomous truck (AT) and electric tricycle (ET) delivery into an inventory routing problem (IRP), a more complex and realistic operations model. We first give a formulation of the inventory routing problem with autonomous truck and electric tricycle (IRP-ATET) using mixed integer-linear programming, and then we suggest an exact solution method. We addressed the robust IRP using the heuristic bees algorithm (BA) to address this issue. Lastly, a numerical instance is given to show that the approach is feasible.

title: Application of Waveform Date Preprocessing Method in Transformer Fault
authors: Jian Wang, Xiao Sun, Dingqian Yang, Ziliang Zheng, Haoran Zhou
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: The fault recording data serves as the core data source for the intelligent diagnosis of transformer faults. Its quality directly determines the accuracy of the diagnosis results. However, in actual engineering scenarios, the recording data is prone to be interfered by random noise, high-order harmonic components, and DC bias, which masks the characteristic signals containing winding fault information. As a result, the fault features are extracted with distortion and the calculation of key parameters becomes inaccurate. To address this issue, this paper proposes a set of targeted preprocessing procedures for transformer fault recording data. These procedures consist of three key steps: the parsing of COMTRADE format files to standardize the restoration of the recording data, multi-scale denoising based on wavelet transform can precisely separate the signal from random noise, and Butterworth band-pass filtering can effectively suppress the influence of DC components and high-order harmonics. To verify the effectiveness of this preprocessing procedure, transformer fault recording simulation data with 5% Gaussian white noise and 10% third harmonic components were constructed for testing. The results show that the edge spurs of the Lissajous characteristic graph have been effectively eliminated, restored to a regular elliptical shape, and the calculation accuracy of the characteristic parameters (long axis, short axis, inclination angle, etc.) has significantly improved. The data quality has been effectively enhanced. This preprocessing method provides high-quality data input for the subsequent extraction of winding fault features and intelligent diagnosis algorithms based on the Lissajous graph method, significantly reducing the risk of diagnostic errors and having strong practical engineering value.

title: Adaptive Neuron Honeypot: Trapping Malicious Backdoors in Federated Learning
authors: Xingyu Lu, Yang Cao
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Federated learning allows multiple clients to locally train on private datasets, followed by the central server aggregating these parameters to form a global model. This process maintains the privacy of client data while enabling the global model to learn from diverse data distributions, thus enhancing its generalization capability. However, it cannot be ensured that all clients participating in the federated aggregation process are fully trustworthy. Some clients might maliciously alter the parameters they upload to the central server, embedding backdoors into the global model. This causes the model to behave in ways dictated by attackers for specific inputs. Existing backdoor defense mechanisms primarily operate on the central server side, attempting to eliminate malicious clients by analyzing parameter characteristics or behaviors, or by pruning or distilling the aggregated model. In this paper, we first reveal the impact of backdoor attacks on neural networks at the neuron level and analyze the parameter changes during backdoor training from the attacker’s perspective. Building on this analysis, we propose a neural network honeypot mechanism. This approach initially uses parameter perturbation and masking for adversarial training to identify fundamental malicious neurons. These neurons are then processed to lure attackers into traps, thereby enhancing the accuracy of malicious neuron identification. We conducted extensive experiments under different adversarial settings and assumptions, demonstrating that our backdoor defense approach consistently surpasses current state-of-the-art baseline methods.

title: Measuring Firm-Level Innovation Resilience in R&D Networks
authors: Yuheng Huang, Naiding Yang, Junfan Zhai, Chenxi Dong
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: In the current global R&D environment characterized by frequent internal and external disruptions, enhancing the innovation resilience of R&D networks has become imperative. This study introduces a method for measuring organizational innovation resilience within networked contexts by integrating social network analysis with the Slack-Based Measure (SBM). Utilizing patent data, the research assesses the resilience of organizations in the global aerospace R&D network prior to the COVID-19 pandemic. Findings indicate that organizations exhibiting high innovation resilience are predominantly located in the United States, Europe, and China, with companies > research institutes > universities. This study holds significant implications for advancing the completion of complex product R&D on a global scale.

title: Identity-Based Asymmetric Group Message Franking
authors: Hang Liu, Yang Ming, Aotian Cai, Chenhao Wang, Yi Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: In recent years, with the increasing prevalence of online group chat applications, malicious information has been more easily disseminated on the internet. Asymmetric group message franking (AGMF) allows users to report received malicious messages to moderators, achieving content moderation in large-scale online end-to-end messaging systems. However, the state-of-the-art construction is built upon traditional public key cryptosystems, resulting in the complex certificate management problem. This paper systematically explores identity-based AGMF (IB-AGMF) to resolve this issue. Specifically, we first introduce a novel primitive called hash proof system-based anonymous identity-based key encapsulation mechanism supporting sigma protocol (HPS-AIB-KEM<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Σ</sup>) and present a practical construction based on DBDH assumption. After formalizing the concept and security notions of IB-AGMF, we propose the generic construction of IB-AGMF based on HPS-AIB-KEM<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Σ</sup> and non-interactive zero knowledge proof system. Finally, we conduct comprehensive performance evaluations and comparisons to demonstrate the feasibility of IB-AGMF in group communication scenarios.

title: Delphi-based Mapping of the Impact of Preventive Measures on Error-influencing Factors within Manual Assembly Lines
authors: B. Klages, L. Heller, C. Reuter, M. F. Zaeh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: In a globalized world with increasing demands for low costs, high quality, and short lead times, the pressure on employees continues to rise. Combined with a shortage of skilled workers and demographic changes in many industrialized countries, this creates a heightened risk of human errors. To achieve long-term error reduction, mitigating the factors contributing to such errors is essential. This requires the careful selection of preventive measures. Selecting the most suitable measures, in turn, benefits from understanding their impact on error-influencing factors. To support practitioners in this process, a Delphi study was conducted with twelve experts from the manufacturing industry. This article presents the results and includes a 19 × 19 Domain Mapping Matrix that links 19 preventive measure sub-categories to 19 error-influencing factor sub-categories.

title: Adaptive Game-Based Strategy for Spacecraft Counter-Reconnaissance
authors: Yijun Zhong, Yan Wei, Chanying Li, Li Yuan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: This paper studies the problem of payload protection for a target spacecraft in counter-reconnaissance. The target spacecraft aims to avoid having its critical payloads captured within the imaging areas of reconnaissance spacecraft, while minimizing fuel consumption and service disruption, as well as preventing hazards such as collisions and direct solar illumination of sensors. In this complex confrontation between reconnaissance and counter-reconnaissance, the outcome is highly sensitive to both parties' strategies. Therefore we propose an adaptive non- zero-sum game-based strategy by leveraging information asymmetry, opponent strategy inference and imaging conditions. To further achieve online decision-making, we perform a situation-based real-time optimization of the value functions during strategy computation, significantly reducing the computational load without compromising global game performance. Simulation results validate that this strategy provides effective payload protection at a low cost, even when confronted with high-threat adversarial situations, and exhibits a certain level of robustness and adaptability to scenario uncertainties.

title: Robust Cooperative Guidance of Leader-Follower AAVs Against Maneuvering Target With False-Data Injection
authors: Jun Liu, Shulong Zhao, Xiangke Wang, Yongbin Zheng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: To address the cooperative guidance problem for autonomous aerial vehicle (AAV) formation with false-data injection and only the leader equipped with a seeker, a hybrid algorithm is developed to estimate the line-of-sight (LOS) angles between AAVs and the target by integrating Tiny Long Short-Term Memory (TLSTM) and Kalman Filter (KF). A cooperative guidance method with the leader-first follower (LFF) configuration is proposed to achieve simultaneous attacks on a maneuvering target within a prescribed time by regulating the contraction rate of the formation. First, the Expectation-Maximization (EM) algorithm is employed to optimize the parameters of the KF, while the TLSTM model is integrated for updating the observation for the optimized KF. The KF extracts local features of the angular data to smooth the angle predictions from the TLSTM. Subsequently, a prescribed-time guidance law is developed for the leader in the LOS direction. To ensure rapid convergence of follower AAVs, a prescribed performance control method is adopted to adjust the contraction rate of the formation. Finally, rigorous theoretical demonstration and numerical simulations validate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: Toward Self-Healing, Stretchable, and Wearable Microbial Fuel Cells for Sweat-based Energy Harvesting
authors: Ruohan Zhang, Yang Gao, Seokheun Choi
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Micro and Miniature Power Systems, Self-Powered Sensors and Energy Autonomous Devices (PowerMEMS)
abstract: Wearable microbial fuel cells (MFCs) offer sustainable power by utilizing microbial metabolism with human sweat. While skin bacteria or safe strains are viable for bio-integration, MFCs have struggled to achieve self-healability, stretchability, and conformability required for wearable electronics, due to their rigid three-layer structure (anode, membrane, and cathode). Here, we introduce the first wearable, stretchable, and self-healing MFC powered solely by sweat. Each functional layer is built from soft, self-healable materials, enabling robust performance under deformation and recovery after damage. This innovation advances bioelectronic power systems for healthcare, sensing, and next-generation human–machine interfaces.

title: Multi-Coil-Based Wireless Stimulation and Sensing for Zero-Dc-Power Passive Spherical Soil Moisture Sensor and System Design
authors: Sheng Ding, Qiwu Zhang, Shad Roundy, Kam K. Leang, Cody Zesiger, Darrin J. Young
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Micro and Miniature Power Systems, Self-Powered Sensors and Energy Autonomous Devices (PowerMEMS)
abstract: A multi-coil-based wireless stimulation and detection system was designed and demonstrated to enable an underground zero-DC-power passive spherical soil moisture sensor over an extended telemetry distance. A 6cm-diameter spherical soil moisture sensor incorporates three orthogonal coil windings to reduce its orientation sensitivity and ensure sufficient inductive coupling to an above-ground system. The above-ground system employs a two-coil configuration (one for stimulation and one for detection). Each coil exhibits 20cm-radius with one turn. The two-coil configuration is highly critical for suppressing interference coupled from the stimulation coil to the detection coil by electronically controlling the loss in each coil loop under each corresponding operation. The two-phase Q-switching architecture enables a substantially increased telemetry distance. The prototype system demonstrates precision sensor’s resonant frequency detection achieving a measurement accuracy with an error less than 0.2% across an extended telemetry distance of 35cm.
