title: Assessing the Effectiveness of Singling-Out Attacks on Synthetic Data: Is the Current GDPR Guidance Adequate?
authors: Fatima Jahan Sarmin, Atiquer Rahman Sarkar, Noman Mohammed
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Privacy remains one of the central challenges to data sharing under contemporary data protection regulations. To mitigate privacy risks, real datasets are either sanitized using anonymization techniques such as generalization or suppression, or replaced with artificially generated synthetic data. The European General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) defines a singling-out attack as the ability to isolate specific records and identify an individual based on the content of a released dataset. Data controllers must ensure that published data does not allow singling out. However, this concept was originally designed for anonymized datasets, where a singled-out record corresponds to a real individual. In contrast, synthetic datasets contain artificially generated records, which may or may not represent or coincide with real individuals. This distinction raises questions about the applicability and effectiveness of singling-out attacks on synthetic data. To assess the effectiveness of singling-out attacks, we evaluated the attack on synthetic data generated by three well-known generative models (CTGAN, PATEGAN, and TabDDPM) across four real-world datasets. Our study reveals inherent limitations of conventional singling-out attacks when applied to synthetic data. As the GDPR’s privacy risk framework was originally developed with anonymized data in mind rather than synthetic data, there is a critical need for further research to establish robust evaluation frameworks and metrics specifically designed to assess the privacy risks associated with synthetic data.

title: CTIGEN: Generating Cyber Threat Intelligence Oriented Summaries Through Summarization Fine-Tuning with Domain-specific NER
authors: Xuhao Wan, Xiang Lin, Jianhua Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Cyber Threat Intelligence (CTI) serves as necessary information to support intentional cyberattack detections, but the extraction of CTI primarily relies on manual efforts, which is extremely inefficient. This paper presents an approach, named CTIGEN, to enhancing text summarization by leveraging cybersecurity-domain-specific Named Entity Recognition to ensure that the generated summaries possess the characteristics of CTI. This refinement makes the summaries suitable for direct use as CTI or simplifies the task for security professionals to analyze relevant information. CTIGEN involves defining and extracting CTI-specific named entities, using them to fine-tune the summarization process, and creating a dataset named text-to-CTI to evaluate CTIGEN. Experimental results showed a 4.35% improvement on CNN/DailyMail dataset and a 11.96% improvement on text-to-CTI dataset, and the CTI entity coverage rate improved by 19.39% compared to the traditional pre-trained language models, confirming the model’s capability to produce concise, accurate, and CTI-oriented summaries, thereby contributing to improved efficiency in CTI generation.

title: Application of GAI to Empirical Studies: It’s High Time to Discuss Challenges and Pitfalls
authors: Miyoung Chong, Junhua Ding, Chirag Shah, Haihua Chen
publish: 2025 ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries (JCDL)
abstract: ChatGPT became the fastest technological adoption in history within two months of its launch, reaching 100 million users each month. Scholars have been investigating the possible uses of ChatGPT and related tools for peer review and manuscript preparation in academic publishing. The use and effects of GAI tools in academic publishing have been examined in hundreds of thousands of scientific and medical articles. Despite its fastgrowing adaptability, GAI raises multiple concerns. Challenges may include authorship eligibility, hallucination, confidentiality, analysis validation, and precision and recall enhancement. Yet, there are far from sufficient discussions about how information science scholars have been epistemologically, methodologically, technically, and ethically challenged while employing GAI in their research studies. As the obstacles of GAI use in research become clear, there is an urgent need to discuss how to navigate best use practices for Library and Information Science scholars to adopt GAI in research studies. Focusing on potential barriers and pitfalls of GAI use in research studies, this panel will discuss impediments and address solutions in applying GAI to scientific research by sharing specific cases drawing from the panelists’ empirical studies.

title: Intrusion Detection via Federated Learning: Tackling Non-IID Data and Poisoning Attacks
authors: Quan Li, Yuhong Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Intrusion detection based on Federated Learning has been proven to be an effective method to address security risks in the Internet of Things (IoT). However, it faces challenges in dealing with non-independent and identically distributed (non-IID) data and poisoning attacks in IoT. To address these challenges, we propose an IDS approach named Clustering and Defending Against Poisoning Attacks (CDPA). Through clustering, CDPA not only alleviates the challenges of non-IID data, but also reframes the defense against poisoning attacks as one under nearly IID conditions. CDPA uses a novel federated clustering method to ensure that malicious clients are grouped without leaking additional information, and it adaptively selects the number of clusters. Moreover, CDPA proposes a novel federated aggregation algorithm specifically designed to address the previously overlooked challenge of high malicious client ratios within clusters - a vulnerability particularly exacerbated in cluster-based training scenarios. Extensive experiments demonstrate that CDPA can effectively handle non-IID data and defend against poisoning attacks, achieving a performance gain of approximately 20% over the baseline.

title: Hypnos: A Hardware-Software Co-Design Framework for Memory-Efficient Homomorphic Processing
authors: Haoxuan Wang, Yinghao Yang, Shangjie Pan, Hang Lu, Xiaowei Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems
abstract: Fully Homomorphic Encryption (FHE) introduces a novel paradigm in privacy-preserving computation, but operating on encrypted data imposes significant challenges, elevating data transmission, memory access demands, and programming complexity. Consequently, developing an efficient and usable system becomes vital. Conventional FHE accelerators often prioritize computational performance, typically assuming abundant encrypted data resides in accelerator memory. However, this perspective frequently overlooks the inefficiencies of the PCIe bus and main memory, alongside the complexities of optimizing for dedicated hardware in real-world deployments. This paper proposes Hypnos, a hardware/software co-design framework for memory-efficient homomorphic processing. The Hypnos framework pairs a novel processing unit architecture with a dedicated Hypnos Compiler. In architecture, the heterogeneous processing unit based on homomorphic encryption paging memory management system to reduce memory fragmentation and optimize the PCIe traffic. In software, the Hypnos compiler which is able to automatically translate high-level FHE schemes into optimized hardware commands. It schedules the data placement in cooperation with our memory management system to effectively harness the performance of hardware. This co-design of hardware and compiler not only reduces memory access and execution time but also lowers the complexity of deploying FHE applications. Finally, We implement Hypnos on the QianKun FPGA Card and highlight the following results: (1) outperforms SOTA ASIC and FPGA solutions in data-intensive applications by up to 2.75× and 4.72×; (2) the communication overhead is reduced by 4.85× compared to traditional architectures; (3) up to 30.1× and 20.7× energy efficiency improvement compared to ASIC-based ARK and FPGA-based Poseidon for ResNet-20 respectively.

title: Multi-Material Ink-Jet Printed Microsystems
authors: Haiyang Yun, Mehdi Yaghoubi Arzefouni, Amir Shelef, Jacky Borenstein, Benyamin Davaji
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Micro and Miniature Power Systems, Self-Powered Sensors and Energy Autonomous Devices (PowerMEMS)
abstract: We proposed a novel approach utilizing a multi-material ink-jet additive manufacturing electronics (AME) system to fabricate controllable resistors with tunable sheet resistance and thermal coefficient of resistance properties. We developed a method for achieving tunable electrical properties by mixing conductive and dielectric inks through co-printing and mixing on a substrate. By customizing the AME process parameters and curing sequences, we successfully fabricated high-resistance traces with variations in the plane width of the Conductive Ink (CI) and margins of the uncured Dielectric Ink (DI). These adjustments resulted in sheet resistance ranging from 0.372 to 1.044 Ω/□ at the room temperature, compared to only 0.013–0.033 Ω/□ with the standard printing workflow. This enabled the demonstration of tunability in the temperature coefficient of resistance (TCR), spanning a range of 429-1301 ppm/°C for printed temperature sensors.

title: State-of-Charge Estimation of Lithium-Ion Batteries Using a Fuzzy C-Regression Model (FCRM) Approach
authors: Nahed Ghanay, Moussa Boukhnifer, Abdelmoudjib Benterki, Achraf Jabeur Telmoudi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Applied Automation and Industrial Diagnostics (ICAAID)
abstract: Accurate estimation of the State of Charge (SOC) is essential for effective battery management and performance optimization in electric vehicles and energy storage systems. This paper proposes an SOC estimation approach based on the Fuzzy C-Regression Model (FCRM), which integrates fuzzy clustering with local linear regression to effectively capture the nonlinear dynamics of battery behavior. The proposed method is evaluated using the Long-Term Degradation dataset, which contains diverse charge and discharge profiles recorded under varying current rates. Three distinct current profiles are analyzed to investigate the impact of current variation on estimation accuracy. After parameter optimization, the results demonstrate that the FCRM algorithm achieves high estimation accuracy, with R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> values approaching 0.999 and extremely low RMSE across all profiles, confirming its robustness and reliability under noiseless operating conditions.

title: Challenges for the German Manufacturing Industry – a Survey Among Manufacturing Companies
authors: J. Stang, B. Klages, Y. Guo, J. Dommermuth, C. Reuter
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Manufacturing companies in Germany and worldwide face various challenges. While multiple studies have explored these issues, few have differentiated or classified the challenges based on the company size. This distinction is crucial, as manufacturing companies of different sizes encounter distinct challenges and possess varying capacities to address them. This paper presents the results of a scientific study involving 54 practitioners from the German manufacturing industry. A total of 17 challenges were identified and categorized into six overarching groups, based on a systematic literature review. These challenges were then evaluated through an online survey to assess their relevance across different company sizes. The findings reveal significant differences in the challenges perceived as most relevant, depending on the company size. The results underscore the need for company-size-specific approaches to effectively support manufacturing companies in addressing their respective challenges.

title: Wireless Acoustic Communication Power Reduction Through Active Sensor Operation Optimization
authors: Kimhabin Yoon, Steven Tran, Seungbeom Noh, Hanseup Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Micro and Miniature Power Systems, Self-Powered Sensors and Energy Autonomous Devices (PowerMEMS)
abstract: This work presents a real-time wireless acoustic communication system that leverages environmental sensor optimization to reduce power consumption while ensuring reliable data transfer. Temperature, pH, and photodiode sensors are integrated into the communication system’s control loop, while a 3D-printed PETG package with a bubble-based CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> sensor enables external sensor inputs to dynamically adjust transmission power, frequency, and rate for real-time waveform optimization. Tests in both a controlled pool and a freshwater lake confirmed 100% transmission reliability with a notable sensor system power savings, 2.279 mW in the pool (31.5% reduction) and 2.803 mW in the lake (15.8% reduction) compared to 3.328 mW without sensor optimization. These reductions extend the system operational lifetimes to 123 days in stable environments and 106 days in natural conditions (up from 93 days at 24 transmission per week), demonstrating sensor operation optimization as a practical, energy-efficient solution for underwater networks.

title: A Novel Category of Tunable MEMS Energy Harvesters with Nonlinearity Compensation
authors: Alejandro Godinez Perez Medina, Sofian Bah, Jerome Juillard, Etienne Herth, Alexis Brenes
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Micro and Miniature Power Systems, Self-Powered Sensors and Energy Autonomous Devices (PowerMEMS)
abstract: In this paper, a novel electrostatic energy harvester with a resonant frequency tunable from 660Hz to 700Hz exhibiting near-linear behavior is presented. This behavior results from hybrid nonlinear interactions between two types of electrodes. Gap-closing and non-engaged gap- overlap electrodes are combined, along with standard linear gap-overlap electrodes, demonstrating a sensitivity of 1Hz/V between 60V and 70V and the absence of hysteresis in the frequency response. A power density of 40nW/mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> is achieved at 0.9g acceleration and 70V bias.

title: Passkeys in Practice: An Empirical Evaluation of FIDO2/WebAuthn Compliance and Interoperability
authors: Ahmed Mahfouz, Rawad Abdulghafor, Alaa A. K. Ismaeel
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Passwordless authentication is rapidly reshaping digital identity management, with passkeys emerging as a key technology prepared to replace traditional passwords. Built on the FIDO2 and WebAuthn standards, passkeys promise secure, phishing-resistant, and user-friendly authentication. Despite increasing industry adoption, their real-world interoperability across browsers and devices remains untested.This paper presents one of the first empirical studies evaluating passkey implementations in Chrome, Safari, Edge, and Firefox across four passkey types: iCloud Keychain, browser profile credentials, phone or tablet–based QR code workflows, and USB security keys. We propose a structured evaluation framework and introduce metrics to assess cross-browser credential reuse, cross-device synchronization, and roaming authenticator interoperability. Our results expose cross-browser inconsistencies driven by non-uniform credential management, consent handling, and error reporting. The study contributes a structured evaluation framework, reproducible criteria, and interoperability metrics that benchmark passkey readiness across major browsers.

title: Effects of Flow Rate and Split Ratio on Separation Performance of Bezier-Curved-Cone Hydrocyclone Series System
authors: Yafei Zhang, Yinghao Yang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: To overcome the performance limitations of singlestage hydrocyclones, this study constructs a two-stage Bezier-Curved-Cone Hydrocyclone (BCCH) system in a bottomunderflow series configuration. Experiments were conducted to investigate the effects of inlet flow rate $\left(0.5-1.25 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{h}\right)$ and overflow split ratio $(9.75 \%-23.5 \%)$ on the separation efficiency and pressure drop. The results show that the separation efficiency increases significantly with both flow rate and split ratio, with more pronounced improvements under high-flow conditions. The pressure drop rises linearly with increasing flow rate, but can be partially mitigated by operating at higher split ratios. Compared with a single BCCH, the series system enhances separation performance through a multi-stage separation mechanism, achieving comparable or superior separation efficiency at relatively lower split ratios while providing greater operational flexibility. This study offers experimental evidence for optimizing operating parameters and supporting the engineering application of curved hydrocyclone series systems.

title: Feature-Foundation Model Evolution: Toward Large-Model-Empowered Low-Latency Semantic Communication
authors: Haobo Zhang, Boya Di, Hongliang Zhang, Dusit Niyato, Zhu Han, Lingyang Song
abstract: To meet stringent requirements of high throughput in the 6G era, semantic communication (SC), a revolutionary framework that transmits semantic information rather than the original data, is expected to be a promising solution. However, existing SC frameworks struggle to accommodate data with new semantic features effectively and ensure minimal data processing latency. This is because achieving strong adaptability necessitates large-scale foundation models, such as large language models with robust semantic understanding, whereas low latency demands small models with simple structures. To address this issue, we propose a feature-foundation model evolution framework toward large model-empowered low-latency SC. In this framework, small-scale feature models and large-scale foundation models are deployed at edge nodes and cloud servers, respectively. The feature models perform real-time semantic encoding and decoding, and they evolve with the aid of foundation models when data with new semantic features occur, thus assuring low latency and high generalization ability simultaneously. We detail the architecture of the proposed collaborative framework and the related evolution protocol. Moreover, a case study on image transmission is presented to verify the effectiveness of the proposed framework. Furthermore, we summarize and discuss several future research directions based on the collaborative framework.

title: Optimized Platelet Supply Chain Coordination: A Reinforcement Learning Framework
authors: Sh. Valizadeh, B. Abbasi, Z. Hosseinifard, S. Nguyen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Platelets are vital blood components essential for clot formation and bleeding regulation. Their short shelf life of 5-7 days, coupled with unpredictable demand, presents significant challenges for inventory management. This study introduces a Reinforcement Learning (RL)-based framework leveraging the Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) algorithm to optimize platelet inventory management, integrating ABO-Rh substitution and lateral transshipment across a two-hospital network. The PPO-Complete model outperforms traditional base-stock policies by reducing shortages, expiration rates, and enhancing system cost-effectiveness.

title: Safety Hazard Identification and Captioning in Metallurgical Equipment Maintenance Using BLIP2 Vision-Language Model
authors: Yongshuang Li, Feng Xu, Zhipeng Zhang, Xinyu Mei
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Metallurgical equipment maintenance faces challenges of incomplete hazard coverage, inconsistent standards, and weak predictive ability due to complex working conditions. Yet, existing computer vision technologies, limited by data scarcity and complex environments, fail to meet the precise safety monitoring needs in metallurgical maintenance scenarios. To address these challenges, this study first establishes the Metallurgical Equipment Maintenance Safety Image-Text Dataset, filling the data gap in this field. Subsequently, this study proposes the MEMSHIC-BLIP2 model, a Bootstrapping Language-Image Pretraining-based model for safety hazard identification and captioning, which incorporates a multilevel instruction-guided template with Q-Former domain adaptation. MEMSHIC-BLIP2 can significantly improve hazard identification accuracy and descriptive standardization while demonstrating transferability to high-risk industries such as chemical and energy sectors.

title: Modular simulation implementation of radar sidelobe cancellation system
authors: Kun Zhang, Min Duan, Bin Deng, Yichi Zhang, Shilin Deng
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: This article presents a modular design for a radar sidelobe cancellation system. First, a standard radar signal is generated, and interference and noise are added to this signal. At the same time, another channel is constructed to generate interference and noise. Adaptive weights are achieved through minimum root mean square, and the generated simulated radar signal is cancelled. Then, parameters such as signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio and peak sidelobe level are evaluated. Finally, the effectiveness and practicality of the sidelobe cancellation algorithm are verified through simulation.

title: Comparative Overview of Solar Engineering Education in Zimbabwe: Short-term and Blended Training
authors: Ratidzo Pasipamire, Hagreaves Kumba, Joseph Akpan, Oludolapo Olanrewaju
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Zimbabwe's adoption of renewable energy technologies has led to a surge in demand for skilled personnel in the renewable energy sector. This work is a policy-oriented discussion with resource implications on two training schemes that contribute to addressing the skills gap in solar energy education. Short-term related training programs in solar engineering, such as those offered by universities, polytechnics, and vocational training centers, offer immediate technical skills but lack depth. Blended training, which emphasizes practical experience and project-based learning, has successfully produced skilled artisans with holistic knowledge in traditional engineering disciplines. However, this blended training system is yet to be adapted for training solar engineering professionals in polytechnics and vocational training centers. This has exposed critical gaps in training frameworks and the adaptability required to prepare workers for the renewable energy transition. Addressing these gaps through flexible learning paths, strong academic-industry partnerships, modern curricula, and coordinated resource mobilization could improve training outcomes and contribute to a more skilled and sustainable workforce.

title: Establishing Secure Intra-Solid Communication Networks via Acoustic Transceivers
authors: Chaoyi Sun, Henglin Pu, Junyi Zhou, Chao Cai
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Thick metal barriers pose a fundamental challenge to internal wireless monitoring due to their electromagnetic shielding properties, rendering traditional radio frequency (RF) communications ineffective. Acoustic communication offers a promising alternative that is also inherently secure against remote eavesdropping. However, the solid medium itself, when acting as a communication channel, exhibits complex characteristics of high loss and severe dispersion, which severely constrains reliability. This paper aims to solve this core problem by designing and implementing a novel intra-solid acoustic communication system. The core of our approach lies in proposing and validating a robust physical layer communication paradigm for the reliable propagation of acoustic signals in such an extreme channel environment. This paradigm, by encoding and spreading signal energy across a wide frequency band, is designed to fundamentally combat the severe attenuation and frequency-selective fading introduced by the channel. We build a complete system prototype and validate the effectiveness of this paradigm through a series of experiments in a real-world solid metal environment. The experimental results demonstrate that our system can successfully establish reliable communication links through thick metal barriers, providing a validated and feasible solution for the deployment of wireless sensor networks in extremely shielded environments.

title: A convolutional regression-based approach for short-circuit fault diagnosis in turbine generator excitation windings
authors: Yingjiang Ding, Tong Jiang, Mulin Liu, Yongjin Xu, Jing Gui
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Excitation winding short-circuit faults rank among the most prevalent failures in turbine generators. While their initial symptoms are often subtle, prolonged progression can induce severe secondary damages such as rotor grounding, exacerbating equipment deterioration. To address the challenges of high-cost physical fault replication and scarce experimental data, we developed a finite-element model based on operational power plant units. This model enables simulation of winding shortcircuit faults and facilitates fault characterization through radial search-coil monitoring. To overcome the limited sensitivity of search-coil signals during symmetrical short-circuits, we propose a CNN-based regression method that predicts healthy operational baselines. Comparative analysis between predicted and measured waveforms enables precise fault detection and localization. The algorithm’s diagnostic accuracy has been rigorously validated through comprehensive simulation studies. Furthermore, magnetic asymmetry analysis derived from the predicted curves provides critical indicators for early-stage and symmetrical fault identification, offering vital support for operational safety maintenance.

title: Advanced Federated Learning for Integrated Terrestrial and Non-Terrestrial IoT Networks With Security by Design
authors: Yue Xiao, Yu Ye, Sotiris A. Tegos, Panagiotis D. Diamantoulakis, Xianfu Lei, Guoqiang Xiao, Zheng Ma, George K. Karagiannidis, Pingzhi Fan
abstract: The evolution of technologies and standardization in next-generation systems is essential for building a ubiquitous communication infrastructure, enabling the integration of air-space-ground-maritime (ASGM)-based architecture that unify non-terrestrial networks (NTNs) and terrestrial networks (TNs) across diverse layers. However, this integration introduces heterogeneity due to varying network frameworks, the increasing number of internet-of-things entities, and the expected surge in data volumes, which pose challenges in ensuring network security and maintaining resilience in hybrid dynamic network environments. To address these challenges, this paper first provides a comprehensive review and analysis of the heterogeneities and obstacles within the integrated ASGM system, and then presents a robust wireless federated learning framework designed to enable privacy-preserving service and secure aggregation to achieve resilient networks. This framework incorporates security-enhanced algorithmic strategies while considering spatial and temporal variations with device selection mechanisms to meet diverse network requirements, resulting in reliable collaborative learning across multiple network components for further improvement in privacy, security, and resilience in seamless NTN-TN integration.

title: Dynamic Evolution of Technological R&D Strategies of Enterprises in Complex Product R&D Networks
authors: Yu Wang, Naiding Yang, Yuheng Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: As the latecomers of complex products are getting closer to the frontier of technological innovation, balancing the relationship between transnational collaborative R&D and domestic independent R&D has become a practical problem. This study constructs an evolutionary game model including technology provider from developed countries and complex product manufacturer from developing countries, and studies the dynamic evolution process of technology transnational collaborative R&D strategy and domestic independent R&D strategy. The results show that The evolutionary game system of dynamic technology R&D strategy adjustment in complex product systems industries exhibits complex path dependence, both technology providers and product manufacturers choose domestic independent R&D and both parties choose transnational collaborative R&D are two evolutionary stable Strategies.

title: Joint Model of Synchronous Machines and Transformers Based on Mate Equivalents
authors: Jiajun Luo, Yinsheng Su, Ziwei Zhao, Qian Ma, Yifu Liaozou, Haicheng Yao, Shujun Yao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: This paper proposes a joint equivalent modeling method for synchronous machines and transformers to improve simulation efficiency in modern power systems. By combining the DQ0-axis machine model with the transformer BCTRAN model using the Mate equivalence technique, the two components are integrated into a single generation unit with reduced system order and parallel solvability. Validated on RTDS with the IEEE 3-machine 9-bus system, the model maintains good accuracy-steady-state errors within $\mathbf{5 \%}$-while significantly enhancing computational efficiency, offering a practical solution for realtime simulation of multi-machine systems.

title: Pre-Equalized Multi-User OTFS
authors: Junseok Kim, Chung-Sup Kim, Kwonhue Choi
abstract: OTFS faces inter-symbol interference (ISI) due to delay and/or Doppler spreads, which requires compensation with an equalizer. In addition, in multiple access scenarios where users traverse distinct channels, OTFS also encounters multi-user interference (MUI). Hence, MUI is more challenging to mitigate than intra-user ISI and becomes more severe in high-mobility scenarios, where OTFS is typically deployed. This paper proposes a novel method called pre-equalized multi-user OTFS (PreEQ-MU-OTFS), which applies pre-equalization at the transmitter, using linear precoders for each user to fundamentally mitigate MUI. Specifically, the precoder is derived by initializing with the modified Wiener filter and employing a single step of iterative minimization. Additionally, the receiver in this method requires only per-user scaling, instead of full equalization. By leveraging the property of OTFS whereby fast-varying channels exhibit nearly time-invariant characteristics in the delay-Doppler (DD) domain, PreEQ-MU-OTFS performs effectively in high-mobility channels. The proposed method demonstrates superior bit error rate (BER) performance compared to conventional post-equalization receivers such as minimum mean square error (MMSE), MMSE-successive interference cancellation (MMSE-SIC), message passing (MP), and maximum-ratio combining (MRC) receivers. This method is validated in realistic channel scenarios with moving reflectors and practical channel aging levels.

title: CABLEGNOSIS Project: Ageing Studies on Insulating Materials and Superconducting Wires for Cable Applications
authors: Tiziana Spina, Riccardo Tebano, Christian-Eric Bruzek, Luca Soldati, Alberto Barutti, Umberto Melaccio, Georg Gamper, Pietro Corsaro, Gabriele Bino, Mohsen Abdolahi, Mohammad Yazdani-Asrami, Wenjuan Song, Stephane Hole
abstract: To ensure power cables' lifetime and to prove their reliability, standardized type and PQ tests are carried out, e.g., withstand voltage test. Usually, polymeric materials (typically polyethylene) are used as dielectric materials. Standard testing procedures integrate extrapolations using the analytical ageing laws mostly related to thermal and voltage ageing to investigate the impact of thermal stress and excessive temperature on lifetime of the cable insulation. Superconducting (SC) cables are cooled and maintained at a cryogenic temperature, below 77 K. In such conditions, one can expect different ageing mechanisms to be dominant rather than thermal ageing, and consequently ageing laws might be different that will impact standard type tests. To perceive the ageing law and guide the future process of manufacturing, and developing techniques for prognostic health management of SC cables as well as to predict when maintenance might be needed, ASG superconductors, University of Glasgow (UofG) and École supérieure de physique et de chimie industrielles de la ville de Paris (ESPCI) are involved in work packages related to the ageing mechanisms affecting both insulation materials and SC wires within the framework of CABLEGNOSIS project. This article presents insights on the ageing mechanisms at cryogenic temperature, an innovative prediction methodology based artificial intelligence and strategies to accelerate the ageing and acquire accurate physical information up to breakdown.

title: Robust Co-Planning of Dynamic Wireless Charging Lanes and Remote-Controlled Switches Under Exogenous and Endogenous Uncertainties
authors: Xin Cui, Jin Zhao, Chi-Kwan Lee, Yunhe Hou
abstract: Dynamic wireless charging (DWC) offers a promising solution to alleviate range anxiety of electric vehicle (EV) users. To address the limited flexibility of traditional DWC systems that rely on fixed power connections, this paper proposes a two-stage robust optimization (RO) framework for the co-planning of dynamic wireless charging lanes (DWCLs) and remote-controlled switches (RCSs). The framework explicitly models the interdependencies among DWCLs, RCSs, and power buses in an electrified transportation network. Two types of uncertainty are considered: (i) decision-dependent uncertainty, which reflects the induced effects of DWCL deployment on travelers’ stochastic path choices, and (ii) decision-independent uncertainty, arising from fluctuations in traffic demand and renewable energy generation. Decision-dependent uncertainty and decision-independent uncertainty are modeled using a random utility framework and bounded uncertainty sets, respectively. To ensure both operational feasibility and economic efficiency under uncertainty, a coordinated traffic–power flow model is integrated into the planning process. The resulting problem is reformulated as a two-stage RO model with mixed-integer recourse via linearization and convex relaxation. To solve it efficiently, an inexact nested column-and-constraint generation algorithm with sequential bound tightening is developed. Case studies demonstrate that the proposed approach effectively reduces system costs and enhances computational efficiency. Moreover, neglecting either decision-dependent uncertainty or decision-independent uncertainty can lead to significant network congestion.

title: Contrasting Crypto and Exfiltration Ransomware with Shamir’s Secret Sharing Data Flooding
authors: Daniele D’Ugo, Saverio Giallorenzo, Simone Melloni
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Ransomware poses a significant threat to both Individuals and organizations, with crypto-ransomware and exfiltration attacks causing widespread damage, financial loss, and operational disruption. Ranflood is a ransomware attack mitigation tool that confuses and overwhelms attackers by flooding the system with decoy files, thereby slowing down the attack and providing a critical window for intervention. In this paper, we extend the coverage provided by Ranflood with a new, advanced flooding strategy based on Shamir’s Secret Sharing (SSS) to counteract both crypto-and exfiltration ransomware. Our SSS-based strategy confounds ransomware by generating many shards from each user’s file, which we tune for high resilience when contrasting crypto-ransomware (so that the user can regain access to lost data from a few shards) and secrecy against exfiltration (so that the attacker needs many shards to recover the victim’s data). We explore the theoretical and practical challenges of applying SSS in this context, present the design and implementation details of our flooder, and empirically evaluate and profile its performance.

title: FDLLM: A Dedicated Detector for Black-Box LLMs Fingerprinting
authors: Zhiyuan Fu, Junfan Chen, Lan Zhang, Ting Yang, Jun Niu, Hongyu Sun, Ruidong Li, Peng Liu, Jice Wang, Fannv He, Yuqing Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: The proliferation of black-box Large Language Models (LLMs) makes source attribution essential for accountability and security. Yet, progress is limited by the lack of a large multilingual benchmark and by fragile or computationally intensive methods. We introduce FD-Dataset, a bilingual benchmark of 90,000 samples from 20 major LLMs, and FDLLM, a LoRA-adapted detector that extracts persistent decoding fingerprints from a foundation model. LoRA induces intra-model clustering and inter-model separation in representation space, explaining its effectiveness for fingerprinting. On FD-Dataset, FDLLM surpasses the strongest baseline by 22.1% Macro F1, generalizes to newly released models with 95% accuracy, and remains robust to polishing, translation, and synonym substitution, reducing average attack success rate from 49.2% (LM-D) to 23.9%.

title: Hybrid Optimization Design for Semi-Grant-Free Transmission in Space–Air–Ground Integrated Networks with Cooperative NOMA
authors: Luyao Wang, Na Li, Xiaofeng Tao
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 11th International Conference on Communication and Information Processing
abstract: None

title: Negative Impact of Manual Manufacturing on Small to Medium Manufacturing Enterprises: A Systematic Literature Review
authors: B. T. Selowa, K. Mushavhanamadi, O. Makinde
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management (IEEM)
abstract: Manual/traditional manufacturing methods have been highly deployed by manufacturing organisations. Small to Medium Manufacturing Enterprises (SMMEs), in particular, have been dependent on manual manufacturing due to the nature of their size and financial constraints. Manual manufacturing methods deployments have favoured SMMEs owing to their low-cost tasks and ease of changing the processes and systems. However, its deployment has been challenged by factors such as slow processing, longer production lead-time, production planning and execution errors, limited flexibility and scalability, miss-shipping of products ordered by the customers, product shipment delay, inefficient order fulfilment, inefficient inventory control which result into holding of stockout, difficulty to adapt to new market conditions and demands, operational inefficiency and high labour cost. Hence, this study discusses in detail the negative impacts of the usage of manual manufacturing methods on SMMEs, with a focal point on manual production and supply chain processes, and their impacts on the throughput and operational efficiency of SMMEs. Part of the conclusions generated from the study emphasized the need to shift away from traditional/manual manufacturing methods to cost-effective smart manufacturing methods.

title: Probabilistic Thermal Design for Electric Vehicles Operating at High Altitude: Guard-Bands and Validation Using Multi-City Reanalysis
authors: Julio Guerra, Ignacio Benavides, Jhonny Barzola, Victor Montenegro, Cristina Castejón
abstract: Thermal performance of air-cooled electric-vehicle (EV) packs and inverters deteriorates at altitude, yet design guidance remains calibrated to sea-level conditions. This study quantifies the altitude penalty on convective cooling and translates it into practical, probability-based design rules. Hourly meteorology (temperature, pressure, wind) from ERA5/ERA5-Land was extracted for Andean and Pacific/Caribbean cities and coupled to a property-aware 0D/1D thermal model using modern flat-plate Nusselt correlations. A physics-informed scaling for the convective coefficient yields a compact altitude penalty law, ϕ, and a sea-level equivalence mapping Ueq that preserves h. The framework is validated multi-city and embedded in uncertainty (Sobol’) and extreme-value analyses, with dependence-preserving copula sampling. Results show systematically higher thermal severity in the Andes: city-level P95(ΔT) and exceedance of ΔT > 20 K increase, and median guard-band factors for required heat-exchange area A\*are 20.8 % higher than at the coast. The Ueq mapping reproduces altitude–sea-level equivalence with ~1–3 % mean relative error, enabling sea-level bench testing of altitude operation. Practical design charts report A\*by city and vehicle archetype (hatch–bus), with linear slopes of +0.04 to +0.14 A\*per km. EVT return levels confirm that altitude amplifies not only percentiles but also rare thermal peaks. A fan-sizing layer links Aflow, RPM, and power to maintain ΔT targets across sites. The study delivers reproducible Python tools, validated mappings, and city-resolved guard-bands that convert altitude physics into deployable requirements for EV thermal management and inverter cooling.

title: Research Progress and Future Trends in Magnetic Induction Communication
authors: Kangjian Peng, Runqi Han, Yanqing Wei, Yinan Hu, Maoyin Chen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Magnetic Induction Communication (MIC) is an emerging wireless transmission solution designed to address communication challenges in complex media such as underground and underwater environments. By utilizing magnetic field as information carriers, this technology exhibits advantages including low attenuation and strong penetration capability. Its key technical aspects encompass the optimized design of highefficiency transmitters and high-sensitivity receivers, antiinterference signal modulation, and channel model construction. The application domains cover scenarios like underwater communication and emergency communication in coal mine downhole. Furthermore, it elaborates on the advantages of magnetic induction communication technology over downhole electromagnetic measurement while drilling (EM-MWD) technology, such as less susceptibility to formation resistivity and higher communication rate. Finally, integrating current research and application hotspots, the main existing issues in magnetic induction through-the-earth communication are expounded, along with the proposed future challenges and development trends.

title: Adjacent Channel Interference Analysis from U-NII-4 and U-NII-5 Devices into 5G NR V2X Devices
authors: Mustafa Harun Yılmaz
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission in the U.S. assigned 30 MHz from the 5895-5925 MHz band for vehicular communication. Adjacent bands, i.e., from 5850-5895 MHz and 5925-6425 MHz, were designated for unlicensed devices. In this study, the effect of adjacent channel interference (ACI) from unlicensed devices into 5G new radio (NR) vehicle-to-everything (V2X) devices was investigated at the link and system level simulations. After conducting link level analysis, a downtown congested traffic scenario with 330 vehicles was considered at the system level. An unlicensed device was assumed to operate using either IEEE 802.11ac or 802.11ax standard. At the link level, only the ACI from a U-NII-4 device degrades the performance of 5G NR V2X devices. At the system level, the ACI from U-NII-4 device with 90% duty cycle degrades the performance by 2.5 dB while for all other cases, a single unlicensed device does not affect the 5G NR V2X performance because it is obscured by the interference from the other 5G NR V2X devices using the same subchannels.

title: Dynamic Scheduling for Data-Parallel Path Tracing of Large-Scale Instanced Scenes
authors: Xiang Xu, Huiyu Li, Linwei Fan, Lu Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Data-parallel ray tracing is a crucial technique for rendering large-scale scenes that exceed the memory capacity of a single compute node. It partitions scene data across multiple nodes and accesses remote data through inter-node communication. However, the resulting communication overhead remains a significant bottleneck for practical performance. Existing approaches mitigate this bottleneck by enhancing data locality through dynamic scheduling during rendering, typically employing spatial partitioning to enable access prediction. Although effective in some scenarios, these methods incur significant redundancy in base geometry when applied to large-scale instanced scenes. In this paper, we introduce the first object-space-based dynamic scheduling algorithm, which uses object groups as the scheduling units to eliminate redundant storage of base data in instanced scenes. Additionally, we propose two data access frequency prediction methods to guide asynchronous data prefetching, enhancing rendering efficiency. Compared to the state-of-the-art method, our approach achieves an average rendering speedup of 77.6%, with a maximum improvement of up to 146.1%, while incurring only a 5% increase in scene memory consumption.

title: High Step-Up Switched-Capacitor ANPC Inverter for Weight-Optimized High-Frequency AC Power Systems in More-Electric Aircraft
authors: Vishal Anand, M Jagabar Sathik, Varsha Singh
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: This paper presents a hybrid 13-level active neutral point clamped switched-capacitor multilevel inverter (13L-ANPC-SCMLI) topology with inherent voltage-boosting capability, tailored for high-frequency AC (HFAC) power distribution in more-electric aircraft. The proposed topology offers 100% dc-link voltage utilization, supports midpoint clamping for possible three-phase extension, and achieves up to 33% lower maximum semiconductor voltage stress and 66% lower passive component voltage stress relative to the output voltage. Detailed comparisons with recent 13-level switched-capacitor inverter topologies highlight its advantages in voltage gain, device stress, and suitability for aerospace HFAC systems. Analytical design procedures for the switched-capacitor network and soft-charging inductors are provided. A 500 W prototype is implemented and evaluated for fundamental frequencies from 400 Hz to 1 kHz under dynamic loading, modulation index variation, and input voltage step changes. The prototype demonstrates peak efficiency of 97.08% in both simulation and experiment, along with stable operation across the tested conditions. These results confirm the proposed converter's potential for lightweight, high-efficiency, and high-frequency AC power conversion in aircraft electrification.

title: Multi-Perceptual Framework for Anomaly Detection
authors: Chaobo Li, Hongjun Li, Guoan Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Emerging Topics in Computational Intelligence
abstract: Anomaly detection is an imperative but challenging task in intelligent surveillance due to the scarcity and irregularity. Most existing unsupervised methods mainly detect anomalies through frame prediction, but their discriminative distance is limited. Meanwhile, some issues such as lack of semantic correlation and less attention to inter-frame relations are also existed, which are important to anomaly detection. To solve these issues, a multi-perceptual framework (MPFork) using textual and visual information is proposed, which combines the ideas of fusion prediction, semantic perception, and temporal discrimination. Specifically, features fusion prediction module is devised to concentrate on representing the normality and repressing anomalies by fusing heterogeneous features. Meanwhile, an image-text semantic perception module is proposed for semantic consistency by correlating the visual with textual features, where the local and global inferences are adopted to perceive local anomalies, simultaneously measuring the belongingness of each object in global frame. Moreover, a temporal attention discrimination module is developed to capture the inter-frame relations and identify pseudo-abnormal sequences from normal ones in temporal direction. Extensive experiments show the proposed MPFork outshines most of state-of-the-art methods, which indicates the efficacy of our MPFork for anomaly detection.

title: An Improved High-Frequency FinFET Model Capturing the Cryogenic Tunneling Effect
authors: Shihan Xiang, Yunqiu Wu, Jun Liu, Huihua Liu, Chenxi Zhao, Yiming Yu, Giovanni Gugliandolo, Nicola Donato, Giovanni Crupi, Yuehang Xu, Kai Kang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: An enhanced fin field-effect transistor (FinFET) model is proposed to characterize the quantum tunneling currents across ultrathin gate dielectrics under cryogenic conditions. Critically, the quantum tunneling effect persists even in the absence of an external bias voltage. To capture this effect, the model incorporates the work function difference between the materials into the conventional tunneling formula. Furthermore, a temperature-dependent correction term is integrated to extend the model’s applicability across the cryogenic-to-room temperature range. Experimental validation confirms that the proposed model accurately characterizes the cryogenic physical phenomena of FinFET devices, providing a theoretical foundation for further research on cryogenic integrated circuits. The validity of the model was ascertained by comparison with <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$S$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-parameter measurements up to 66.2 GHz.

title: A Systematic Approach to Predict the Impact of Cybersecurity Vulnerabilities Using LLMs
authors: Anders Mølmen Høst, Pierre Lison, Leon Moonen
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: Vulnerability databases, such as the National Vulnerability Database (NVD), offer detailed descriptions of Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVEs), but often lack information on their real-world impact, such as the tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) that adversaries may use to exploit the vulnerability. However, manually linking CVEs to their corresponding TTPs is a challenging and time-consuming task, and the high volume of new vulnerabilities published annually makes automated support desirable.This paper introduces Triage, a two-pronged automated approach that uses Large Language Models (LLMs) to map CVEs to relevant techniques from the Att&ck knowledge base. We first prompt an LLM with instructions based on MITRE’s CVE Mapping Methodology to predict an initial list of techniques. This list is then combined with the results from a second LLM-based module that uses in-context learning to map a CVE to relevant techniques. This hybrid approach strategically combines rule-based reasoning with data-driven inference. Our evaluation reveals that in-context learning outperforms the individual mapping methods, and the hybrid approach improves recall of exploitation techniques. We also find that GPT-4o-mini performs better than Llama3.3-70B on this task. Overall, our results show that LLMs can be used to automatically predict the impact of cybersecurity vulnerabilities and Triage makes the process of mapping CVEs to Att&ck more efficient.

title: Reliability and Deployment Technology of Power 5G Communication Network
authors: Yu Gu, Mengqing Zhao, Zhiyuan Yu, Tianyi Zhang, Xu Gong
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: To address 5 G reliability challenges in power IoT, this study proposes wireless terminal redundancy and virtual network redundancy technologies. A cross-layer hybrid judgment algorithm optimizes terminal control timing by integrating business-layer metrics and wireless channel observations. Field tests on a $\mathbf{1 0 ~ k V}$ distribution line achieved $\mathbf{1 0 0 \%}$ remote control success with $\mathbf{1 3 0 - 3 0 0} \mathbf{~ m s}$ end-to-end delay. Simulations demonstrated the proposed MRT algorithm’s superior performance, achieving $96.23 \%$ business request precision postfailure and minimal latency increase. The method balances reliability and real-time requirements, ensuring service continuity during primary path failures.

title: Multi-Objective Optimal Sizing of Wind-PV-ESS for Traction Power Supply Systems Based on MOEA/DSADE
authors: Fei Chen, Lele Fang, Lu Geng, Bohan Qiu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: To address the challenges of capacity planning and power coordination in traction power supply systems with high-penetration renewable energy integration, this paper develops a capacity optimization model for a wind-photovoltaic-energy storage system (WPV-ESS) integrated with hybrid energy storage and a railway power conditioner (RPC). The model aims to minimize the total lifecycle cost and maximize renewable energy utilization, while incorporating constraints such as device capacity, energy storage state dynamics, grid interaction, and power balance. Subsequently, a self-adaptive differential evolution (DE) operator is proposed, leading to the development of the MOEA/D-SADE algorithm for solving the optimization problem. Case study results demonstrate that the proposed method significantly outperforms conventional design approaches in enhancing renewable energy absorption and reducing the total lifecycle cost, thereby validating the effectiveness of both the model and the algorithm.

title: An Evolutionary Algorithm with Advanced Initial Solutions for Association Rules Hiding
authors: Jiaran Qiu, Peng Cheng, Jun Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: In the digital age, while data sharing brings numerous benefits, shared data may expose privacy through data mining. Privacy-preserving data mining has become an urgent issue to address. In response, many methods for hiding association rules have emerged. In this paper, we propose an association rule hiding method based on an evolutionary algorithm, EAAIS4ARH, to eliminate or mask sensitive association rules that may reveal personal privacy or trade secrets. In EAAIS4ARH, we design an advanced initial solution generation mechanism that can significantly improve the quality of the initial solution and lay a solid foundation for the subsequent optimization process. This mechanism can also be used in other heuristic algorithm-based association rule hiding methods to improve solution quality. We introduce a unique evolutionary framework that categorizes each generation of solutions into three classes based on their performance: optimal, ordinary, and inferior. This mechanism not only promotes solution optimization, but also effectively avoids the problem of premature convergence to the local optimal solution. EAAIS4ARH also exhibits a high degree of flexibility, generating solutions that cover the spectrum from robust solutions with a zero hiding failure rate to compromise strategies that moderately sacrifice the hiding rate in exchange for a more efficient data utility, satisfying the needs of different users.Experimental results under different types of databases show that EAAIS4ARH excels in both side-effect control and data utility.

title: Analysis of EM void growth failure time in multiple via structure
authors: Xiaojing Fan, Ge Gao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: With the continuous advancement of process nodes, electromigration has become one of the most critical issues affecting the reliability of integrated circuit interconnects. This paper applies a physics-based hydrostatic stress analysis model to perform finite element simulations on common interconnect structures and models the stress distribution. The electromigration analysis model is applied to specific digital integrated circuit layouts for evaluation, and an electromigration correction algorithm and script based on redundant via technology are developed. Ultimately, a electromigration repair method compatible with standard design flows is designed.

title: Hybrid Fault Attack on Grain-128AEAD: Signature or Machine Learning Localization with Bandit-Guided Recovery
authors: Ya Lin, Iftekhar Salam
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: This paper presents a novel differential fault attack (DFA) on the Grain-128AEAD stream cipher that integrates fault signature analysis with machine learning and reinforcement learning. The proposed attack operates under a realistic adversarial model in which the attacker can target a register but cannot control the precise fault location. We first develop a signature-based technique and two machine learning models, namely Random Forest and Gradient Boosted Trees, for fault location identification, which achieve over 99.9% accuracy. We then introduce a Multi-Armed Bandit (MAB) framework to identify optimal fault targets that maximize information gain for state recovery. Experimental results show that our MAB-driven strategy recovers the 256-bit internal state of the cipher with an average of 96 and 134 faults under the precise and random fault models, respectively.

title: A Comparative Analysis of State Estimators for Sensorless Control of DC Motors
authors: Shengkun Ji, Mi Lv
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Control Science (IC2ECS)
abstract: Aiming at the problem of state estimation in sensorless control of DC motor, this paper carries out a comparative study based on Luenberger Observer and Kalman Filter. By establishing the state space model of DC motor, the corresponding Luenberger Observer and Kalman Filter are designed. The simulation results show that both of them can accurately estimate the motor speed in the ideal noise-free environment. However, under the noise interference, the RMSE of estimation error between the estimated value and the true value of the motor speed by the Luenberger Observer is about $0.8258 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}$, and the RMSE of estimation error of the Kalman Filter is about $0.1973 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}$. The RMSE value of the error is reduced by 4.2 times. The output of Kalman Filter is smoother and more stable, and the dynamic tracking accuracy is higher. However, the Luenberger Observer is simpler in structure, less in calculation and simpler in parameter design. This study provides theoretical basis and practical guidance for observer selection in different application scenarios.

title: A Privacy-Preserving and Highly Fault-Tolerant Cross-Chain Atomic Swap Scheme
authors: Wenjun Zhu, Jianan Hong, Yingjie Xue, Jiayue Zhou, Shiyao Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 24th International Conference on Trust, Security and Privacy in Computing and Communications (TrustCom)
abstract: As the blockchain ecosystem continues to diversify, the lack of interoperability among heterogeneous blockchain systems has become a critical bottleneck, leading to fragmented data silos and limited collaboration. Although numerous cross-chain protocols—such as atomic swaps, sidechains, and relay-based mechanisms—have been introduced to address this issue, they often face significant challenges related to privacy, security, and decentralization. In this paper, we propose a novel cross-chain protocol that enhances traditional hash-locking mechanisms by integrating zero-knowledge proofs and chameleon hash functions. Our approach ensures strong path confidentiality, such that reconstructing the payment path is computationally infeasible under the discrete logarithm assumption, even in partially compromised networks. Additionally, we introduce a multi-path atomic swap framework that supports concurrent routing and preserves transactional autonomy, enabling users to flexibly select preferred payment paths. We evaluate the performance through theoretical analysis and simulation. Comparative results demonstrate that our solution achieves secure atomicity with minimal trust assumptions and improved latency compared to existing methods.
